I owned the 2018 model which was really nice but didn't have a lot of power and mileage was around 27 average. This one is super powerful, I'm getting 50  a gallon because my garage has free plug-in. if it had twice the battery only range, I would keep it forever

Just bought my SQ7 a month ago and I am super impressed.  The twin turbo V8 makes you smile with all the power it provides.  It took me a while to get used to all the tech and I am still learning.  Overall I am please with the two center screens and the driver screen is very nice.  I got the Prestige trim and enjoy the additional features that come with it.  Fit and finish is very good and this is the second Audi I have owned and love how the interior looks and is designed.  I was looking for a regular Q7 and this one was available at a good price so I decided to bust my budget and purchase it.  I am not disappointed.  I'm averaging 21 MPG on the highway and don't think that is bad going 80 mph.  The only thing I could warn someone about, is the insurance cost for this vehicle are much higher that a regular SUV.  I think the joy I get from driving it is well worth it!

I have owned the 2023 Q7 Premium Plus for over a year.  The car is smooth and nice to drive.  However, quite a few improvements are needed to create value in ownership.  Storage space in the car is woefully lacking.  The only decent storage are the front door pockets.  Otherwise, everything needs to go in the back behind the 3rd row seating.  The center console has enough space for a phone (wireless charger) and one snicker bar.  I can’t quite understand what the Audi engineers were thinking when they decided to put the wireless charger in this tight space.  The phone gets scalding hot on longer drives lasting more than 30 minutes with the lid closed.  You have to remember to open the lid often to dissipate the heat and bear the discomfort of not being able to rest your arm until you get tired and slam the lid shut.  The other gripe is cup holders.  Again, Audi - what the heck?  There are two cup holders in the front that bear any semblance of a cup holder and that’s it for a 7-seater car.  There are two little holes in the middle seat that could potentially fit a super narrow bottle but absolutely not the regular sized water bottle or even a coffee cup.  Rear doors have ash trays with a soft close/open lid on the door handles.  Again, no idea what the idiots were thinking.  Coukd they not have eliminated this wasted feature and instead maximized storage?  Ok, for the third row… that’s just torture if you are relegated to those seats.  It has a power open/close feature for the 3rd row which is awfully nice of Audi to provide (obviously with an incredibly high mark-up) but very impractical.  I would rather just have a manual 3rd row just like the 2nd row but instead will graciously accept more room and comfortable seats in the back.  

The MMI and the over-engineered electronics are a nuisance.  About once or twice every week it malfunctions and takes a long time to load after starting the car.  My iPhone 14 Pro rarely connects to the MMI via Bluetooth after I start the car.  I have to fiddle with the MMI controls and my phone to connect.  Alexa that’s built in the MMI rarely works.  Amazon music doesn’t work either most times.  Spotify that should work either via Siri or Alexa doesn’t, due to these connection issues.  Apple customer service was super helpful and very methodical with trouble shooting and follow-ups and even brought Audi customer service on conference call.  It was finally diagnosed as an Audi issue (Audi agreed) but unfortunately without a fix over the phone.  I was asked to take the car to the dealer for repair and the dealer after having the car for a day couldn’t do anything to resolve this issue. Audi called me after about 3 weeks or so to tell me they are working on an update for this issue.  A year later, the issue still persists.

The ride… it’s quite comfortable and smooth both on local roads and the highway but as I have noted above, the electronics are a pain.  The one dangerous feature that Audi has to immediately fix is the lane keeping assist and the jarring lane correction the system makes while driving.  I am surprised that there haven’t been accidents due to this feature.  The feature performs ok on a straight road and you are actively engaged with the steering control, however it can be very scary when the road divides or at a ramp and you are actively trying to keep the car in lane.  It suddenly jerks to the side and can easily cause the driver to lose control of the car and cause a life-threatening accident.  Audi - please take responsibility for this and fix this issue now on the cars you’ve sold with this dangerous lane keeping assist feature.

Overall, these issues aside, the car is ok to drive and looks nice overall both inside and outside.  This is my first German car; I hope it’s reliable and I can say after a few years it wasn’t a bad decision to purchase this after all.  Time will tell…
Solid and still competitive vehicle. Its maintenance is constant. No challenges so far. I have never taken it to the mechanics for any repair.

Bought my 2019 55, PP,  from CPO program. Have driven many luxury cars and suvs and my conclusion is that this is the smoothest engine and transmission combination on the market. Effortless to drive, both on highway and in town. Has a modest exterior size but is cavernous on the interior. Super quiet with a composed spring suspension. Fuel economy and performance is great because of the reduced weight aluminum construction. It is really impressive. Reminds me of an 1990s MB S class. Have had zero mechanical issues. Audi care has been great.
Excellent car.  No maintenance issues over 3 years.  Tires do wear quickly but normal on this level sports vehicle.

An island of luxury, performance and quality. Our Q7 is fully specced and it was worth the extra investment. Driving this SUV is a pleasure as while it has great performance it is so quiet and luxurious that one actually can enjoy the music from the great sound system. This far reliability has been exceptional so really nothing but positive feedback.

It is very unfair of texas to double charge sales tax on a leased vehicle. You pay tax on the full value at the start of the lease which is then built into the payments. If you buy out the vehicle for the residual, you pay sales tax again for the amount of the payoff--very unfair. Why not follow florida where they charge sales tax on the down payment and each payment.
This car definitely satiates my need for speed. Sounds amazing, turns like a beauty. The trunk space is awesome with third row down.

e question “What’s the Blue Book Value?” has been part of buying and selling a car for over 90 years. And simply put, no one has more experience with vehicle values and pricing than Kelley Blue Book. We’ve been the go-to source for both consumers and the automotive industry since 1926. We leverage massive amounts of data, including actual transactions - then adjust for local market conditions and seasonal trends. Our values reflect both wholesale and retail transactions to provide

This is my 3rd Audi and sadly my experience this time has been terrible.  I've had an A4, Q5 (3.0t) and now the Q8 Premium Plus Sport.  I had my Q5 for 10 years and traded it in when I hit 150k miles.   I bought the 2020 Q8 sight unseen from a dealership in Mobile and had them drive it to me due to lack of availability in my area. I had researched the vehicle for months before the purchase.  When it arrived, it was beautiful and matched the photos.  It wasn't long that I realized how slow the acceleration was from a stop. I am driving in "Dynamic" mode.  I have had random issues with the Audi Pre-sense slamming on brakes in intersections and  randomly while driving at various times.  The alternator went out at 40k miles which left me broke down on the side of the road.  Notably, the entire vehicle including steering wheel and transmission stopped working and I lost the ability to steer the car. I could have killed someone without the ability to stop.  I didn't have use of my car for more than a month and now, just 3 months later, I am at 47k miles and the engine light just came on.  I have had to go to the dealership to top off oil between oil changes at least 3 different times during my ownership.  I will be trading this car in sooner than later.  I wish I didn't have to write this review based upon the amount that I paid for the car.  Ridiculous.

I was so excited to find a 2019 Q8 Certified Pre-Owned at our local Audi dealer. Very quickly I was unhappy with how the car drives. It has a significant lag in the responsiveness when pressing the accelerator from a stop light or stop sign. I asked the dealer to check it out and they couldn't find anything. Fast forward a few months and the alternator has gone out (car less than 3 years old). I've been without my car for 65 days now because the part is backordered. I've asked for Audi Salt Lake City to buy back the car and they have given me a low ball offer. Getting in touch with Audi of America to ask them to make me an offer is a 3-4 hour wait to speak to a person (and once you ask they have 20 business days to reply). Don't bother with this car or this brand! I'm regretting it Big Time.
This car has been Great - We have lots of good expereince with it. It is good in the snow and is very reliable

Bought this car for my wife and over the two years we owned it it was nothing but trouble.  We had it in the shop for numerous issues to include the MMI, locking malfunction, and brakes just to name a few.  We were loyal Audi customers for the past 12 years but after owning this we have since moved on and will not own another Audi.

The car looks great and has great power and sound. Lots of useful tech. It is big and heavy so it's not meant for twisty bits of road. With 4 wheel steering it's more maneuverable than one might suspect. Thirsty, but not terrible considering the size, weight and power.

Another "look at me" mobile. 

Unnecessarily expensive trash can people buy for attention and approved from random people on the road they'll never meet. 

Garbage entitled trashcans.

I have had 19 Audis since 1973... this is by and far the best car I have ever owned. Plenty of power when needed, awesome safety features.  Super comfortable, plenty of room, great drivers car.  Can't say enough
This car has been amazing with no issues whatsoever, I would definitely tell you to buy...and skip the 7k extended warranty I've never used.
very cool car! 1/5
good

The more I drive the RS3, the more I like it.  It took a little while to find a good seating position and figure out how the car wants to be driven — but now I look for any possible excuse to go for a ride.  I had an RS4 for many years, which was great, then suffered through a 340i (boring and heavy) and an S4 (an okay but not great car), but the RS3 is a keeper.  It’s not quite as eventful as the RS4, but it’s great fun, surprisingly comfortable and, like the RS4, feels special, especially when pushed a bit.  I have the adaptive suspension with the Dynamic package - I’d say it’s the ideal set up for real world driving.  The handling is neutral and predictable, the brakes are progressive and strong with good feel, steering feel is good for a modern car, and the engine is just epic. If you turn off the stability control, it’s even better — this car can be rotated in spite of its tenacious grip. I’ve read complaints that it’s pricey but I disagree — the RS3 is a bargain.   If you’re an enthusiast who needs 4 doors and all-weather capability, I can’t think of a better car under $70K.
Very solid car, no major issues at all. Best of all worlds in one. Tons of space, looks great, very fast, luxury. All season ready. Can't go wrong.
Have to drive and own for experience breathtaking drive and steering position fell in love with the car very different from my f80 m3
Fantastic car.

Great all around car with super high performance edge when you want it. Can be parked at the store but still turns heads for those who know cars. Awesome in the snow (better than my F150, actually). Rear seats do in a pinch, perfectly fine for kids though. Strongly recommend the dynamic package, too.

This car is great in many ways.  Engine responsiveness, power and handling are excellent.  Interior fit, finish, look and front seating comfort are all top-notch.  The exterior is handsome and the car overall exudes quality.
This car is a balance between a super car and a practical everyday vehicle.  It comfortably seats four, not two, and with the rear seats folded cargo space is in line with a small SUV.  If you want a super car brute the BWM M4 or Mercedes AMD C63 are top choices.  But if you want a balanced car the RS5 Sportback is an excellent choice.

the speed is amazing and gorgeous car but when it goes to tech and safety features it horrible jeeps offers so much more for 60000 less and nowhere near mercedes level  but if all you cars for speded is car will be operfect

From a true car guy, this is without question the best car I have ever owned. What does it do right, EVERYTHING!  Not only is it beautiful, it has endless room, it's fast as hell and it's a great driving experience. With a few performance enhancements and a couple cosmetic tweaks can really make it your own.  And promise its will run with most anything. Yes it is expensive, but it is actually worth it.

Beautiful car with every imaginable feature.  Fast and fun to drive.  Great in any weather.  Excellent room for 4 adults and with expansive rear storage and folding rear seats, can accommodate all kinds of gear.

This RS7 performance was my second RS7 in two years. Go figure. It is glorious how it delivers the power. It just cruises the highway effortlessly (until you put your foot down). If you really want to get out of a jam quickly and safely, this vehicle does it so well! It is a head turner. I had the white with black-optic-carbon fiber, Bang & Olufsen entertainment system. Ceramic brakes tremendously good. (one downside: be careful after a carwash in the winter time with these brakes.) This car does not disappoint. The practicality is just unbelievable: I was able to transport two-adult size bicycles AND luggage! When dial-in the Engine/Transmission into Dynamic Mode, the pops and crackles from the exhaust is just perfect. It is not loud and outlandish--it's just perfect! The carbon fiber inlays and suede inserts are nicely put together. This car is not designed for inner city driving. It needs open road-highway preferably--to unleash its full potential. I wanted to rate it 4 stars for that fact, but it really doesn't disappoint beyond that. HERE'S THE BIG TAKEAWAY: It holds its value better than its rivals. They are rare and more desirable cars due to the hatchback design. If you are on the fence about this vehicle, get off and buy.

This car is amazing! From the 560 Horsepower to the sound of the exhaust and looks you get when driving it's a dream! Great handling, great performance and world class fit and finish on a car they make very few of and you won't see everywhere. I sometimes feel bad having a car this nice as I don't know what I will be able to do to top it next time around. First world problems I guess....

Love this car. It is fast, quick, planted, handles well under all conditions, great driver interface, Great daily driver, gets great mileage for the power and performance, comfortable in comfort mode, very sporty in dynamic mode, 0-60 MPH in 4.3 seconds with launch control, 0-60 MPH in 4.6 seconds without launch control, Attractive but under the radar,  Sleeper car.
Love this car. Extremely quick and planted. Great interior and ergonomics. very attractive. Built very solid. I have had numerous nice cars, but I like this one the best.

If you are looking for a small, quick (4 seconds 0 to 60 mph) and understated family sedan with all of the luxury trimmings, the S3 is it.  This car can hold its own against vehicles with much more powerful engines, while being as nimble as a small compact hatch.  The S3 works well in city driving situations as well as on the long road. The suspension is sporty and is something to get used to, but once acquainted with it it the driving experience will far exceed your expectations.

The car is great drives smooth I love it for when we go out for a fun night. But for any type of commuting it is not my favorite car at all! It’s way too cramped in the back I don’t even like being a passenger in my own car I prefer to drive over anything! Also the trunk space is ridiculously small I always end up using my extra space in the back seat for any extra room I can get for groceries or shopping . I’ve had a for a year and I am working hard so I can trade in as soon as I possibly can.

The 2018 S3 is a great car! I love the styling, quality and the speed & handling of the car. It's a handsome car and it sure does get a lot of compliments. In addition, Nano gray is such a unique color and I am really happy with it. The interior is simple and no overly busy, yet the digital cockpit feels ahead of its time. The B&O audio upgrade is a must for any audiophile! Finally, the ride can be a bit harsh when coupled with big wheels and the sport suspension, but it's a small price to pay for a quick little fun car.

I have owned 41 cars, trucks in 62 years. Most were foreign, only a few American except for the trucks which were all Fords. After owning a superb Porsche Cayman S, I’m now on my third Audi. The S3, purchased new, is a prestige with the Black Optic package. In my four years of ownership, it hasn’t missed a beat. Sure the back sear is a little tight for adults but work in a short trip. My golf clubs and cart fit in the trunk (driver in back seat) without folding the seats down. I’m an aggressive driver so I only average about 23mpg in my driving. But I never get left at a stop light just using moderate throttle. Once maybe twice a week, it will see 100-110 mph traffic permitting. It has only been to the dealer for scheduled service. Minuses? No Apple CarPlay. My wife doesn’t care for the non power sport seats. Maybe not for everyone, but in my experience, it’s just about the best sports sedan one can get. It isn’t the fastest but it has enough usable street (not necessarily track) performance for anyone.

While looking for an Allroad wagon, I ended up with an S3.  Oof, what a great choice.  While it does not have the cavernous cargo space of my old Allroad, the S3 is so zippy!  Quick out the gate, and that near delicious feel when the boost kicks in!  The growl coming out of the engine is quite enjoyable.  Not too loud, but just enough to let you know there is power under the hood.  The Quattro was a bit off, I did do a little slip and slide, however, I am readily able to attribute that to a combination of squirrely handling, snow conditions and slightly less than optimal tires.  Under normal road conditions, the car performs exactly as I want it to.  Turns on a dime, accelerates like a beast.  The interior space is black, so, well, it is very clear on teaching you the value of keeping it clean.  The plastic on the pillars is a bit cheap, and one small swipe of nearly anything causes a scuff that cannot be easily removed.  Overall, I love my S3.

This car handles like a dream. Glued to the road with almost no traction issues. From a dig its very very quick. Interior quality is very nice and exterior is easy on the eyes. The infotainment system is relatively easy to use. The optional sport seats are really comfortable and the adjustable (to an extent) magnetic ride is great for when you want to just cruise along the highway or carve up some twisty roads. Gas mileage is decent for how quick it is, Im averaging about 23mpg 70%/30% Highway/city. Had a lot slower car with a V-6 that I averaged only 19mpg mixed driving so yeah....

Athletic handling, room for enthusiast mods packaged in a business like, docile exterior. Like wearing business attire to respectfully conform, but really to clothe a beast. Driving at even 2/3 of capability is wild. Launch control with traction off in sport mode is a blast. With aftermarket tune and bolt ons, drops a sec from 4s to 3s. Have seen stage 3s that give sub 10 1/4s.

Definitely a sleeper, and they go fast on the market. One thing coming from Mercedes is that there are certain details like the gas door, moon roof or paneling that seem less high end. But I am willing to trade that luxury for greater performance. The comparable C43 has more luxury and the BMW 340i edges closer to the M-series with a stiffer ride. The Audi S9 is a good middle ground, enough niceties but not excessive sportiness to the point of sacrificing comfort.

Some have stated oversteer when pushing the car, but the default mode is really enough to gleefully get where you need to go. Things start getting slightly scarier if you want to test the grip limits, but the back kicks out fine in the quattro 40-60 rear bias. Quattro AWD is still one of the best vs xDrive or 4MATIC or even Genesis (which is similar to xDrive).

The exhaust noise is not excessive or overbearing, again leaning toward refinement. In cabin noise is decent, not ultra quiet like Mercedes, and aftermarket exhausts, going catless or burble tunes can really put you in obnoxious territory. This is after all, a sleeper, crouching silently and hidden away.

Twin-Scroll provides both low and high end torque. Default mode has a slight turbo lag from dead stop. A throttle controller or piggyback may reduce these. Enthusiasts suggest upgraded intercooler, there are non-warranty breaking piggybacks like the JB4 to up the response and ECU flash options. Stage 2/3 sees hybrid turbo/downpipe which bumps bhp 100  from 350s. Some use aftermarket springs like KW. The TCU is also modified to unlock a sort of race mode. The default refinement gives way to harder shifts and higher revs while maintaining stability, some wheel spin issues with the extra power.

This thing will consume oil over some time, less so than a BMW, but still needs to be monitored. There are some strange gauge settings - the boost indicator goes from Min to Max, so aftermarket gauges might come in handy. City driving averages low 20s, highway 30s. Mods would lower this further. The newer models include updated MMI, and mild hybrid.

Safety wise, there is emergency monitoring / braking which might startle drivers. The brakes are solid, but attempting to come to a smooth slow stop is touchy. The brake tends to grip hard at the  last moment, giving a slightly abrupt stop. Consumables like the brake pads, tires will wear more quickly due to sportiness, and maybe some internals like spark plug replacement at earlier than expected mileage.

Suspension is great, bumps do not feel jarring from overly rigid suspension and the tires stay planted through turns, with little sway from being lower to the ground. The weight is almost 4000 pounds with a full tank, but does not feel so. Third gear is where things start getting wilder. First and Second take some time to warm up, but can be controlled manually with S-tronic shifts. The shifts are really quick, transmission has not discernable issues - Something that lower end Mercedes had issues with in power delivery.

Overall, is a solid purchase, reliability seems okay, though Audi maintenance and repairs will be at a premium which are covered by maintenance packages. If you want a sports sedan, emphasis on sports and a well built interior, minus some high end luxury. This is good sporty/business attire to respectfully contain this sleeper, put on waze, a radar detector and you might escape attention when that sports jacket finally comes off.

Bought this car new and it has certainly met my expectations! Its a 4-door AWD vehicle that doesn't disappoint! Wonderful acceleration and control, along with a nicely appointed interior. This car is the whole package!
Love this car. Best car I have ever owned. Great blend of luxury and sport. A total blast to drive.

Amazing car.  No problems so far.  Five stars all around except...

Value: 4 stars because of its high cost of acquisition and the very expensive services ($700/20k and $1200/40k-spark plugs replaced for performance factor).  Every other service is around $250-$300.

Performance: should have been 5 stars but I rate 4 stars because of lag in throttle at low rpm especially in non sport mode, and lack of manual transmission.  It wakes up though if you depress throttle considerably in any mode.  Then, hold on to your kidneys because g forces may send them to the rear seat!

Comfort: 4 stars for lack of leg room and headroom for small people but great with small kids.  Who buys an S4 for rear leg room anyways?

Lazy Americans don't buy manuals anymore because they are too busy holding latte on one hand and cheeseburger on the other to shift manual.

I purchased a pre owned 2018 Audi s5. At the time, it had 71,800 miles on it. I’ve not even owned the car for a year, put right at 1000 miles on it, and the engine died at 72, 823 miles, 823 miles out of extended warranty. Audi refuses to back the vehicle or help with repairs, it was fully serviced at 70k miles with no issues. Worst purchase ever, quoted 29k to repair.

I cannot express how happy this car makes me. Every day I drive it it’s a blast. It’s fast, quiet, comfortable, and when the top is down, I can’t get the grin off my face.
You have to set a speed alarm because you will not notice how fast you are going. The car is so smooth and unlike every other convertible I’ve driven, it’s not noisy and uncomfortable as you drive highway speed.

The particular color combination I have makes every single time I drive it with the top down a show stopper. People always compliment. What a good looking car it is.

The interior is luxurious and comfortable to drive AND ride in the back.

The glove box has a CD changer for some reason so there is no room for storage at all. However, the trunk has a motorized spacer that moves up when the top is up, allowing you a normal-sized trunk, and it drops down to allow the top to store- so many convertible have a tiny trunk and no option for more.

Love this car!
Can not go wrong with the car... it's quick, reliable and you also have the option to change the drive mode from dynamic to comfort
I have owned a 2011 Q5, 2013 A6, and a 2016 A6. This is by far my favorite Audi that I have ever purchased.

So many cars in one. Multiple settings provide different driving experiences. Dynamic Steering compliments the sport suspension and new quatro power distribution to produce  amazing handling when pushed.  The S5 is also a pleasant and comfortable cruiser on long drives.  The seats have numerous adjustments for comfort and personal fit, including 3 different massage settings. Adjustable side bolsters provide an extra level of driver stability when maneuring curves at higher speeds. Launch control produces quick acceleration. The B & O sound system is good but would not  give it as high a rating as the the other feature of this wonderfully engineered and designed German beauty. Have not regretted the purchase or the extra features. In Addison to the carbon dash inlays , my S5 has carbon on the side mirrors and rear spoiler. Nice touch and have yet to see another with this package.

Impressive performance handling is tight, takes corners well in dynamic mode, very comfortable for long trips in comfort mode. My S5 has lots of trunk space for a coupe. Lots of head room in the rear. Good gas mileage almost 450 miles per tank approx 28 combined mpg city/highway. Love this car!
Great
Car handles any road terrain or weather very swift and smooth.
Best performance best ride best fuel economy everything is hundred percent love it I’ll buy Audis all my life

I truly am in love with this car. Engine is porsche derived and sounds great, however, it is lacking on the top end. With an e85 tune it launches to 60 from a dig in about 3.5 seconds but you'll notice the powerband begins to decline slightly in the top end.  I did the 1/8 mile in 6.9 seconds so that is something to write home about.


Interior quality is good not great, I did notice a bit of plastic noice on the steering wheel and the piano black can get scratched pretty easily. The seats are extremely comfortable and the bang and olufsen system is wonderful, the tweeters do give out if you like listening to loud music. 


Suspension is wonderful, audi has been doing air suspensions for a while now, but hit a sudden bump and it will shudder the car thanks to the 21 inch wheels.
In 2019 Audi killed the S6 making it V6.. so the facelifted 16 17

Audi fan since I was a kid and still .. S6 will fascinate you ! Superb power and performance.. parts and labor on this one expensive.. even some Audi shops will try to avoid working on them .. quite complicated engineering.. remove oil screens before 40k miles to avoid turbo failure.. Audi catalytic converters are cheap and so close to engine.. heat will damage them prematurely so .. plan to gut em .. driving this surely comes with big $$ to spend on maintenance but it’s so well worth it for me .. drive it in dynamic mode and you’ll know what I mean.

This is my second Audi S product.  I like the styling of the exterior and interior quite a lot.  The performance is above par with it's twin turbo v-8, dual clutch transmission, and air suspension.  There's a slight turbo lag in full automatic, that can be alleviated with switch transmission to manual mode and setting car set up to dynamic.  The S6 feels best at home on the highway, the Autobahn would be fantastic environment for it.  

Interior is top notch for the price, although a bit dated to some who like the latest look and equipment.  I would recommend for those who do lots of miles.
Great daily driver. A sleeper with incredible performance. The last S6 trim model with a V8. No issues so far. Great in the snow. Growls with a nice exhaust like it should.

My Audi by far is the nicest car I've owned. The heated seats are definitely a lecture it would not want to live without. Liquid leather interior catches everybody's attention I haven't met a single person that doesn't like this car. The 420 horsepower of the car came with I got used to that real quick and started to buy performance parts and the thing is a rocket. On my way home I had to go over a couple of mountain passes and threw some canyons and I just left my cruise at 85 mph in Indian bother touching the brakes The air ride soaks up everything and at 85 mph I still got 30 miles per gallon. After this car is paid off I'll probably keep this for a very long time More than likely I won't even sell it.

I bought my S6 in Feb 2020 from an Audi dealership, the car went down in October 2020. It is now March 2021 and it is still in the shop. The car cannot be repaired because Audi has discontinued parts for the car. Now I am stuck with a car that cannot be driven or repaired. Audi corporate has offered no solution, their response is simply “there is nothing we can do because the parts are discontinued.” With that being said, I will never buy another Audi and would recommend choosing a luxury car manufacturer that can competently complete work on cars that their company manufactures.

I've owned this car for about 3 months. Yes it is one of the best all around car available to enthusiasts. The best part is only other car enthusiasts will know that you are in something special. Here is what you don't know and I hope you never have to find out. These cars are nothing like a regular Audi. It is way more complicated to fix as well. I had to replace a $60 oil valve that was located beneath the twins. It cost me $3200 for a tear down to change. These cars are highly temperamental! When they are working it is amazing,  when their not, you will consider rolling it off a cliff! If you love cars and have disposable income, go for it! If you're trying to look cool, go buy something else. I warned you!

I love the subtlety of the car: no flashy and pretty lights inside and out. No bling! But what truly won me over was interior design and exhaust note. The v8 is just intoxicating and the interior is ultra modern.  The only downside to this vehicle is that it's not meant to be  driven in the inner city; this car is built to devour highways. And it does so easily. I traded in my Acura TL  (which was underwhelming with respect to power) for the S6. The s6 is worth every penny. The car is roomy and offers a quiet ride. The quilted red diamond stitched seats are nice. They give the car a race-car look without compromising it's sleeper status. Overall, it's a great engineering work. Many have complained about weight, but the power generated by this car makes that a non issue. Anyone on the fence about this car, I say go for it.

I have a love/hate relationship with this car. It is "put me in jail" fast with an exhaust note that makes all the right sounds. The infotainment interface is easy to use as are the car settings. The front seats are not especially comfortable but they are good enough. The back seat is not great, for long trips it is pretty poor. I do like the fact the back seat folds down making for huge trunk space. The trunk swallows furniture, luggage, bicycles with ease. It is a feature I love about this car. I gave four stars due to a battery failure early on and ongoing coolant leaks. With options this car was nearly $100,000 new. They depreciate like rocks and if you buy one used I think you are smarter than I am.

The S7 has proven to be a highly reliable and comfortable daily driver, yet capable of astonishing performance when called upon.  It is not a sports car of course, though its handling is excellent for a vehicle of its size and power.  However, it is an excellent balance between an all day people mover/shopping transporter and a pin you to your seat high powered sport sedan.

great performance and smooth ride
Very dependable
great mileage
highly recommend to family and friends
This a performance machine. The car looks and runs like new. It handles the road and curves well. When I trade, I plan to buy another Audi S7.

Originally I owned the 2017 S7 which had the V8 engine and upgrading to the new 2022 s7 with 2 cylinders less did concern me but overall I'm very happy with the car. The sound notes are great and although I notice a drop in power from my previous model its still a solid vehicle. 

The technology upgrades alone are pure quality and the 4 door salon still acts very much like a sleeper. I will most likely trade this in after 2 years for the RS7 since I do miss the V8 engine. Dont get me wrong the v6 twin turbo is great and there's literally no turbo lag thanks to the hybrid electrical system that they tied into the engine but its tough going down from the V8 to the V6.

Everything else on the car is fantastic the body styling is unmatched, the cargo space is never lacking and the handling and overall quality materials is all top tier, just be sure to have a micro fiber cloth handy to eliminate the inescapable number of fingerprints lol

I have owned my Audi 2015 for almost 6 years and still feel like a kid driving it!  You cannot help but smile when passing, driving winding roads or going for a leisurely drive.  For such a long and heavy car, the handling is amazing.  And the aesthetics ... It's a beautiful masterpiece of a car that is not highly replicated.  Even dirty, my car gets looks, compliments and questions from strangers on how I like my car.  As with all my Audi's, I never worry about it being in the shop (except for normal maintenance).  It's dependable and can drive in any situation all while looking sharp.  

The car is expensive, but well worth it.  First time I have ever wanted to just keep my car vs getting a new model (granted, I do have my eye on the Q8!) and will probably keep for another couple of years.  I am that pleased with my Audi S7!!

Bought my S7 almost 2 yrs ago off-lease, installed new tires & brakes + had the oil separator replaced.  It's an expensive car to own but well worth it if you can stretch your budget.  Speed builds quickly, passing slower drivers is a hoot.  Love the way it sounds when I mash the gas pedal!  Bose surround sound audio is fantastic and even plays DVDs (only while parked, of course).   Ride quality suffers a bit due to the 20" wheels but they add to the car's sporty feel.  Handling is great for such a big, heavy car.  Diamond stitch leather seats and carbon fiber trim are the icing on the cake.

I’ve owed the car for 2 years.  I live in NorthEast Ohio.  We get all kinds of weather; hot summers, a wet fall and harsh winters.  The Audi S7 never disappoints.  The sport’s differential is a must.  The dual clutch transmission coupled with the rearend makes you smile as the car seems to LITERALLY anticipate the turns.  You will always be in a great position if you want to lay down power to the Quattro AWD system.  The car is glued to the ground.  I use summer performance and winter dedicated tries.  21” for summer and 20” for winter. I love the inferred camera and B&O speakers.  The car is packed with tech.  Oh, and then there’s just the raw power whenever you want!   Car was ~$106,000 with all the options.  I think all boxes were checked off :)

The 2016 S7 should have been designed with acoustic rear windows!  No Apple car play in 2016. The powered windows are a little slow.  Too many steps to get into launch mode.  Also the break dust is horrific but they sure are impressive breaks!

Despite the negatives, the car will make you smile GUARANTEED! You also get better valet spots (no surprise) and lots of compliments and looks.

Would move to a 2020 S7 but those are coming with the V6.  The V8 is the only way!

I currently own this 2020 Audi S8 and a 2018 BMW 740. The S8 is more quiet, does a better job smoothing out imperfections in the road, has a more modern interior, handles better and is remarkably fast. By comparison the BMW seems a bit antiquated. The S8 is may favorite car I have ever owned, it is fantastic.

Now for the down sides. This car is nine months old and has 13,000 miles on it.  It has been back to the dealer for issues five times. Once the car turned off and went completely dark while driving on a Los Angeles freeway. It was pure luck that I was able to coast off the freeway with limited steering and brakes without getting in an accident. The car burns one quart of oil every one thousand miles and the dealer claims this is completely normal and acceptable. To get all of the technology features there is a required $500 per year subscription fee that was not mentioned at the time of purchase. I found this out when the free trial period ended. On a $150,000 car maybe Audi should not nickel and dime their customers and include this in the price.  

Even with these negatives I still absolutely love driving this car. Definitely will not buy another one after this.

Purchased a 2013 w/65k 4 months ago with a 45k 3 yr warranty.  This car is like most reviews state " a wolf in sheep's clothing".  This thing gets mean when you ask it to and can blend in with the symphony snobs.  I love it so far, just experienced my 1st problem that's been noted, leaking windshield.  Will put silicone on it and continue to drive it until the brand new 22" wheels fall off

This is a truly amazing luxo barge that turns wild at the touch of the pedal. I bought my 2015 in 2021 with 95k miles on, so I bit the bullet and also purchased a 5-yr extended warranty at around $7k knowing that I'd recover my money whenever I had a first breakdown. Almost two years later, I've added about 15k miles to it and have had two warranty repairs done which would have been about $10k, so my investment paid off. I had the sunroof replaced (the mechanism was making a nasty noise), a rear window mechanism, and engine mounts that were passing on a vibration to the chassis at low revs.

Pros: all the luxury items you'd expect in a Bentley like super comfy diamond-stitched seats with massage (I thought it's a gimmick, but actually use it quite a bit in Miami traffic) and ventilation; everything in the drivetrain is configurable to your taste; gorgeous and I mean drop dead beautiful looks with the 21" wheels (most people don't know 'what' this car is, but they know it is special); crazy power with 3.8 sec to 60 mph (I believe I might have done a 3.6 once but am not sure) enough to humiliate any punk out there trying to race you in their 5.0 Mustangs and even M4s; suspension is taught and responsive; all black alcantara and carbon interior is lit. The car is so well balanced that my kids learned to drive in it... it can be tame and easy to drive, but can just go wild when you want it and everything stiffens up when you give it some gas.

Cons: It spoiled me and I don't know how I can upgrade from this! A few other small nuisances: turning circle with the 21" is like a Suburban, making your parking and u-turns always needing an extra back and forth; also the 35 profile tires are a bit noisy, but it comes with the territory; audio tech seems dated even for 2015 with a non-touch screen and stupid MMI system and I frankly expected a louder sound system with the optional B&O option which is just OK in my opinion; expensive to fix, but that's what happens to any $144k MSRP super car; trunk is not as big as you'd expect in this size car; lane keeping self-steering is over intrusive and will make you carsick -- just drive yourself, you deserve it.

All in all, I took a gamble on a high-mileage supercar and I couldn't be happier. I cannot imagine where I'll go from here.

Extreme comfort with extreme power.  I love a big sedan and the S8 covers that while delivering an excellent driving experience.   In comfort mode she is an excellent highway cruiser which is great for my daily driving. Put her in dynamic mode and she handles corners like she's on rails and puts you into the back of the seat when you ask her to.  I have 2 small kids and both car seats fit great and there is just about as much legroom for them as in my wife's SUV.  25+ mpg for 520hp is great as well. After being away from Audi for a few years, I'm happy to be back!

The twin turbo V8 has torque for any situation - and with the subdued styling is definitely a wolf in sheep's clothing. Steering feel is nice especially in this day of "no-feel" electric steering systems. The suspension is taut but comfortable. Nice features throughout. Audi outdid themselves with the S8!

I've owned my fair share of high performance, luxury cars from Porsche, BMW and Mercedes.  The Audi S8 is without a doubt, the fastest and most comfortable / luxurious of them all.  From the messaging seats to the incredible pull of all-wheel drive powered by a twin turbo 500+ hp engine, it just doesn't get any better.  Drive one and you'll agree.
Also had Audi race team put in a chip that gives it another 75hp. Car is dual tone Gray.

A real pleasure to drive from a sporting experience to everyday driving.
Non routine maintenance is a bit inconvenient due to the small amount of cars
in circulation in the United States; so parts may need to be sent in from Germany.

This is one of the best cars that I have ever driven. It is extremely fast..prob faster than most anything on the road. It is also, family agile . very luxurious and handles beautifuly though not at the level of a sports car .
I am a little disappointed with space because It is a little tight in the back seat. Five adults still fit but leg room is lacking say compared to an A8L or and s550. There is a little bit of road noise as well I guess due to the tires and insulation.
Aside from that, This car is a beast.

Just after warranty finished had a check fuel light turn on, turns out there was a crack there as was as in the coolant and needed over 15k worth of repairs. I’m done with Audi. Sad because their customer service has been exceptional.

Fast, agile, and comfortable luxury SUV. It’s large enough to pick up your Christmas tree or mulch (please lay down tarp) yet nimble and quick enough to maneuver through traffic during your morning commute. The power will make you smile.
I love it honestly everything about it makes sense, is comfortable but once you switch it to sport it's just a different kind of beast
A comfortable, fun car to drive. Love the 10.1 inch screen. Easy to figure out. One of the nicest looking SUVs on the road.
My 2022 SQ5 Prem+ is just right in the power, seating, and interior. The cabin is very quiet and refined in its fit and finish. This Audi is fun to drive in any condition.

I bought my SQ5 2 months ago, love how it handles/drives, engine noise is great. I went with the black optic package with the 21” rims and I love how it looks. The car is quick for how large it is, and handles very well. Steering is light and responsive. 

I’ve really concerned with long term reliability. The air conditioning already broke and required 2 weeks at the shop to fix. The entire system needed replaced. Soon after, the lane keep assist camera stopped working. Found out that the camera was installed wrong and was never calibrated correctly. I’m worried about what might go wrong with the rest of the car. 

Small details could be improved on the interior/safety system to move the quality to 5 stars. Too much hard plastic, center screen feels cheap and should have been touch screen (which is now available in 2021 models I believe). The safety features are weird. The blind spot will ONLY shine a small light when someone is in your blind spot + you turn your blinker on (or are backing up). It should beep at you so you don’t have to look for the small light. The car beeps for so many other unneeded situations (ie when there isn’t a speed limit sign for the camera to recognize for more than roughly 2 minutes of driving), blind spot should be one as well.  

Also, be aware that there are not a lot of tire options for this rim size (255 / 21” rim). I live in Ohio and prefer an all season over a summer tire (you never know when it will snow), $350-360 per tire is the only option there with 2 different tire option. 

Overall (when the car was out of the shop..) the car is great and I love driving it. Hopefully the car will stay in-tact going forward and the reliability score will get better.

The car drives great but the software that runs everything from radio to climate is awful. It is confusing and hard to operate - my wife who has an engineering degree had to have two long appointments just to learn how to work - and still was confused. Have had people at the dealership and a repair place tell me there are always problems with the technology. I also have a Ram truck same year and it is 100 times better in that regard. They should be able to get that right.

I traded in a 2017 Q-5 to lease the 2021 Plug-in and get the California HOV sticker. It was very disappointing that the Hybrid batteries occupy the space under the rear cargo area (where a spare tire would fit) because the area provided space to keep a slew of items such as owner's manual, gloves, spare prescription glasses, tire air compressor, etc.  This is particularly important space since the console between the front two seats is tiny and difficult to access.  The batteries also forced Audi to reduce the size of the gas tank from 18.5 gal. to 14.3.  That costs about 110 miles of ICE range in exchange for only about 20 miles BEV range. You are on fumes at about 375 miles, which is a big deal if your two homes are 390 miles apart.  Because I did not install a 240v charger for a mere 20 miles, I use the standard 3 prong wall socket for charging.  The car will only gain about 1.5 miles per hour of charging.  The dashboard gage will display 31 miles range on electric, but that is an illusion.  You will get 20 miles, plus or minus and will need all night and then some to get a full charge from a totally dead hybrid battery if you just use a standard plug.  
I've been quite negative about these aspects of the Audi, but in fact when my lease ends in 2024 I intend to lease a 2024 Q-5e.  Journalists have reported that the vehicle will receive a new, slick trim and come with 40 BEV mile range, which is critically important for my personal driving habits.

Superb ride and handling. Average mileage 30 mpg on premium. Ventilated sport seats keep me comfortable Year round.

Fantastic service Audi Silver Spring.

Owning it for 2 years.  Some small issues with driving safety system - when pulling back sometimes  it breaks without any reason. I think parking markings could be misidentified by cameras as some distraction.  Handling is great. You “feel” the car on every corner.  Averaging 26 mpg , of mixed driving.  Also I wish the trunk space would be larger.

I have a mint 2008 Audi A4 1.0 Sline and love it 
I just bought my wife 2022 Audi Q5 Quattro Sportback "Ultra Blue" and this thing drives like a BEAST and is so fast, smooth and comfortable... Everything about this car is absolutely amazing 
I don't know if I got a great one but there is not one thing wrong from the cool Ultra Blue 
"BIG BLUE" will silver spoilers and the 20 inch fantastic rims not including a killer interior this is buy far the best Audi you can buy and kills the looks over the BMW & Mercedes in ever area -
Period !!! Plus I was smart and spent an additional 5K so everything - I mean everything on this car is guaranteed until 2028 !!!! 😊👍 - BOOM !!!!
This vehicle has great amenities. Very comfortable ride. I would have liked the screen to be a touch screen. The trunck is just big enough for my family of four.
Love just about everything with this SUV.  Throw it in Sport mode and wow you don't realize you are driving an SUV.  Reliability has been better than I expected and dealership is first class.

I owned the 2018 model which was really nice but didn't have a lot of power and mileage was around 27 average. This one is super powerful, I'm getting 50  a gallon because my garage has free plug-in. if it had twice the battery only range, I would keep it forever

Just after warranty finished had a check fuel light turn on, turns out there was a crack there as was as in the coolant and needed over 15k worth of repairs. I’m done with Audi. Sad because their customer service has been exceptional.

A comfortable, fun car to drive. Love the 10.1 inch screen. Easy to figure out. One of the nicest looking SUVs on the road.
My 2022 SQ5 Prem+ is just right in the power, seating, and interior. The cabin is very quiet and refined in its fit and finish. This Audi is fun to drive in any condition.

Just bought my SQ7 a month ago and I am super impressed.  The twin turbo V8 makes you smile with all the power it provides.  It took me a while to get used to all the tech and I am still learning.  Overall I am please with the two center screens and the driver screen is very nice.  I got the Prestige trim and enjoy the additional features that come with it.  Fit and finish is very good and this is the second Audi I have owned and love how the interior looks and is designed.  I was looking for a regular Q7 and this one was available at a good price so I decided to bust my budget and purchase it.  I am not disappointed.  I'm averaging 21 MPG on the highway and don't think that is bad going 80 mph.  The only thing I could warn someone about, is the insurance cost for this vehicle are much higher that a regular SUV.  I think the joy I get from driving it is well worth it!

I have owned the 2023 Q7 Premium Plus for over a year.  The car is smooth and nice to drive.  However, quite a few improvements are needed to create value in ownership.  Storage space in the car is woefully lacking.  The only decent storage are the front door pockets.  Otherwise, everything needs to go in the back behind the 3rd row seating.  The center console has enough space for a phone (wireless charger) and one snicker bar.  I can’t quite understand what the Audi engineers were thinking when they decided to put the wireless charger in this tight space.  The phone gets scalding hot on longer drives lasting more than 30 minutes with the lid closed.  You have to remember to open the lid often to dissipate the heat and bear the discomfort of not being able to rest your arm until you get tired and slam the lid shut.  The other gripe is cup holders.  Again, Audi - what the heck?  There are two cup holders in the front that bear any semblance of a cup holder and that’s it for a 7-seater car.  There are two little holes in the middle seat that could potentially fit a super narrow bottle but absolutely not the regular sized water bottle or even a coffee cup.  Rear doors have ash trays with a soft close/open lid on the door handles.  Again, no idea what the idiots were thinking.  Coukd they not have eliminated this wasted feature and instead maximized storage?  Ok, for the third row… that’s just torture if you are relegated to those seats.  It has a power open/close feature for the 3rd row which is awfully nice of Audi to provide (obviously with an incredibly high mark-up) but very impractical.  I would rather just have a manual 3rd row just like the 2nd row but instead will graciously accept more room and comfortable seats in the back.  

The MMI and the over-engineered electronics are a nuisance.  About once or twice every week it malfunctions and takes a long time to load after starting the car.  My iPhone 14 Pro rarely connects to the MMI via Bluetooth after I start the car.  I have to fiddle with the MMI controls and my phone to connect.  Alexa that’s built in the MMI rarely works.  Amazon music doesn’t work either most times.  Spotify that should work either via Siri or Alexa doesn’t, due to these connection issues.  Apple customer service was super helpful and very methodical with trouble shooting and follow-ups and even brought Audi customer service on conference call.  It was finally diagnosed as an Audi issue (Audi agreed) but unfortunately without a fix over the phone.  I was asked to take the car to the dealer for repair and the dealer after having the car for a day couldn’t do anything to resolve this issue. Audi called me after about 3 weeks or so to tell me they are working on an update for this issue.  A year later, the issue still persists.

The ride… it’s quite comfortable and smooth both on local roads and the highway but as I have noted above, the electronics are a pain.  The one dangerous feature that Audi has to immediately fix is the lane keeping assist and the jarring lane correction the system makes while driving.  I am surprised that there haven’t been accidents due to this feature.  The feature performs ok on a straight road and you are actively engaged with the steering control, however it can be very scary when the road divides or at a ramp and you are actively trying to keep the car in lane.  It suddenly jerks to the side and can easily cause the driver to lose control of the car and cause a life-threatening accident.  Audi - please take responsibility for this and fix this issue now on the cars you’ve sold with this dangerous lane keeping assist feature.

Overall, these issues aside, the car is ok to drive and looks nice overall both inside and outside.  This is my first German car; I hope it’s reliable and I can say after a few years it wasn’t a bad decision to purchase this after all.  Time will tell…
Solid and still competitive vehicle. Its maintenance is constant. No challenges so far. I have never taken it to the mechanics for any repair.

Bought my 2019 55, PP,  from CPO program. Have driven many luxury cars and suvs and my conclusion is that this is the smoothest engine and transmission combination on the market. Effortless to drive, both on highway and in town. Has a modest exterior size but is cavernous on the interior. Super quiet with a composed spring suspension. Fuel economy and performance is great because of the reduced weight aluminum construction. It is really impressive. Reminds me of an 1990s MB S class. Have had zero mechanical issues. Audi care has been great.
Excellent car.  No maintenance issues over 3 years.  Tires do wear quickly but normal on this level sports vehicle.

An island of luxury, performance and quality. Our Q7 is fully specced and it was worth the extra investment. Driving this SUV is a pleasure as while it has great performance it is so quiet and luxurious that one actually can enjoy the music from the great sound system. This far reliability has been exceptional so really nothing but positive feedback.

It is very unfair of texas to double charge sales tax on a leased vehicle. You pay tax on the full value at the start of the lease which is then built into the payments. If you buy out the vehicle for the residual, you pay sales tax again for the amount of the payoff--very unfair. Why not follow florida where they charge sales tax on the down payment and each payment.
This car definitely satiates my need for speed. Sounds amazing, turns like a beauty. The trunk space is awesome with third row down.

e question “What’s the Blue Book Value?” has been part of buying and selling a car for over 90 years. And simply put, no one has more experience with vehicle values and pricing than Kelley Blue Book. We’ve been the go-to source for both consumers and the automotive industry since 1926. We leverage massive amounts of data, including actual transactions - then adjust for local market conditions and seasonal trends. Our values reflect both wholesale and retail transactions to provide

This is my 3rd Audi and sadly my experience this time has been terrible.  I've had an A4, Q5 (3.0t) and now the Q8 Premium Plus Sport.  I had my Q5 for 10 years and traded it in when I hit 150k miles.   I bought the 2020 Q8 sight unseen from a dealership in Mobile and had them drive it to me due to lack of availability in my area. I had researched the vehicle for months before the purchase.  When it arrived, it was beautiful and matched the photos.  It wasn't long that I realized how slow the acceleration was from a stop. I am driving in "Dynamic" mode.  I have had random issues with the Audi Pre-sense slamming on brakes in intersections and  randomly while driving at various times.  The alternator went out at 40k miles which left me broke down on the side of the road.  Notably, the entire vehicle including steering wheel and transmission stopped working and I lost the ability to steer the car. I could have killed someone without the ability to stop.  I didn't have use of my car for more than a month and now, just 3 months later, I am at 47k miles and the engine light just came on.  I have had to go to the dealership to top off oil between oil changes at least 3 different times during my ownership.  I will be trading this car in sooner than later.  I wish I didn't have to write this review based upon the amount that I paid for the car.  Ridiculous.

I was so excited to find a 2019 Q8 Certified Pre-Owned at our local Audi dealer. Very quickly I was unhappy with how the car drives. It has a significant lag in the responsiveness when pressing the accelerator from a stop light or stop sign. I asked the dealer to check it out and they couldn't find anything. Fast forward a few months and the alternator has gone out (car less than 3 years old). I've been without my car for 65 days now because the part is backordered. I've asked for Audi Salt Lake City to buy back the car and they have given me a low ball offer. Getting in touch with Audi of America to ask them to make me an offer is a 3-4 hour wait to speak to a person (and once you ask they have 20 business days to reply). Don't bother with this car or this brand! I'm regretting it Big Time.
This car has been Great - We have lots of good expereince with it. It is good in the snow and is very reliable

Bought this car for my wife and over the two years we owned it it was nothing but trouble.  We had it in the shop for numerous issues to include the MMI, locking malfunction, and brakes just to name a few.  We were loyal Audi customers for the past 12 years but after owning this we have since moved on and will not own another Audi.

The car looks great and has great power and sound. Lots of useful tech. It is big and heavy so it's not meant for twisty bits of road. With 4 wheel steering it's more maneuverable than one might suspect. Thirsty, but not terrible considering the size, weight and power.

Another "look at me" mobile. 

Unnecessarily expensive trash can people buy for attention and approved from random people on the road they'll never meet. 

Garbage entitled trashcans.

I have had 19 Audis since 1973... this is by and far the best car I have ever owned. Plenty of power when needed, awesome safety features.  Super comfortable, plenty of room, great drivers car.  Can't say enough
The TT roadster is a great driving and performing convertible.  I have had three now and loved each one.  It’s affordably priced for a quality automobile.

Great styling and performance. A fun car to drive. After owning a TT for 4 years the tts has more power and the magnetic ride control is impressive. Add the additional exhaust sound and its quite an improvement.
Followed by C8 Corvette 8.5sec 89mph in 220yds strip Oct23,2021 total stock except cold air & 100+ racing gasoline

Difficult to find a complaint… in the past 4 years less than 1000 sold in the US per year.  Thus, rare.  2022 last year petro TT will be made.   Great price…. Thousands less than comparative models.   Definitely an eye catcher. Yes, stiff ride… recommend 18 or 19 wheels.  Quick, responsive…. Great handling.  If one enjoys driving a car instead of an autonomous ride…You will not be disappointed.   If you want to be driven (smile)…. stay away.

I was looking at Lexus RCF and Audi TTS and am extremely happy to have chosen the Audi TTS. The performance is great but yet when I drive sensibly, I can get over 30MPGs, 32 as a matter of fact. The look at styling is great as well, IMHO of course. I have taken the car onto a track and it out performs most of the cars there, in the intermediate class. The brakes are odd though in that the use performance brakes in the front that are hard to get outside the OEM.

This is actually my third Audi ( priors-1998 A4 2.8 V6 Quattro -5spd, and a 2001 TT Coupe 1.8T Quattro 5spd) . I special ordered this car and received it June 2018. Tango red w/ Competition Pkg. 16,500 miles ....When new hatch needed to be tightened but that aside she is trouble free. I am so glad I bought the normal TT as the TTS /TTRS seem overkill .  I rarely "floor it" ...A 0-60 of 5.3seconds  seems quite fast for the street and anything more seems wasted money to impress someone else. I looked at 18 cars when I considered the TT. The BMW 2 series coupe and a Porsche Cayman were close runners but the TT was chosen and offered some practicality , the renown Quattro AWD, $10k less than the Cayman and still gets 29 to 32mpg. Quality is outstanding and just as good if not better interior than the 2 and Cayman. The back seat is useless except in an emergency but at least it has the option . The trunk space is huge and is consolidated  (unlike the split trunks of the Cayman .  I will keep this car at least the full 4yrs of the warranty period maybe even 5) as yes, there will be another which will eventually catch my eye..... but thinking this is quite special and in no hurry just to chase another XYZ.  I heard that 21 is the last year .Only 3500 are sold world wide and it became too expensive to build. ( half in Germany and half built in Hungary) . If interested you won't regret it . Highly recommended and it is rare and unique.
2018 Audi best of 3 TT`s. This TTS is quick, fairly comfortable for trips with room for two full set of golf clubs and luggage for two adults. Loves to be pushed. Plenty of leg room and headroom.

This review is for the RS version. I once owned a 2012 RS that I liked very much. When the RS was reintroduced in 2018, I started looking right away, and eventually found one in NC that I had delivered to my home.
Had I driven the car first, I never would have purchased it. In spite of the fact that it was more powerful, it lacked the excellent acceleration that my 2012 had. The worst things about it, however, were the awful ride and excessive tire noise, due to the 20-255/30 tires, a profile inappropriate for regular driving. My previous RS had 19” wheels, which were much better.
I put up with it until the day that I drove a Porsche Cayman, which I bought on the spot: it was superior in every way to the Audi.

When I decided I wanted a convertible my husband wanted me to get a Camaro or Corvette. We live in a small town that does not have a Volvo, Mercedes, or BMW dealership. One of my main criteria was it had to be something I could have serviced locally. I test drove a Camaro. A corvette was not a consideration. I have personally never cared for them. I test drove a fiat. Then we went and drove the Cascada and my decision was made. I love it as much today as I did the day I drove it off of the lot. I wanted a car that drove and rode good with the top up or with the top down, and that is exactly what I got. LOVE, LOVE, MY CASCADA!

pleasant ride be smooth with the gas pedal and you will be rewarded for up to 40 mpg no kidding sits higher than the imports , flashy style, great colors made in Poland, great safety features, very comfortable plenty of pep when needed.quality built, better price than imports, cheaper price for parts, very nice ride,The convertible top comes in colors and is quality holds up very good. Simply the best convertible out there for the money as well as looks. Its a BUY BUY BUY

Ive owned 7 convertable in my life time & this is near the top It is good looking car! lots off wows from people The price is right when you at the huge differance other convertables  It has plenty off power with 1.6 Turbo the top works perfectly so far do good Its a fun to drive I wish GM kept making them but I got mine
I love the way my Cascada handles.  I had a T-bird with the added hard top, I bought the Cascada because the top is so simple to put up and down. Good gas mileage.

I purchased this car 1 mo. ago with 21,570 miles. I'm a senior citizen who doesn't like to act my age. This fills the bill very well. I get a lot of complements on its looks with the top up or down.  

I recommend it to any fun seeker.

I like the fact that this car isn’t like everything else on the road.  The car has a little over 11k miles on it.  It’s babied and kept in the garage, like any self respecting convertible owner would do.  Just kidding!! Sort of, maybe, kinda. After 4 years I still have people coming up to me asking what kind of car it is and usually saying how much they like it.  I have a red sport touring.  It has the dark effects package which blacks out the grill and other things.  They left the belt line chrome and I hated it since day one and had it painted glossy black and like it so much better.  I won’t get into styling of the car because those things are personal, you like it or you don’t, I personally think it’s a beautiful car.  Not perfect, it has some odd proportions about it, but for me it works.  As a lot of other reviews have stated don’t pay attention to professional reviews on this one.   So much is overstated.  It’s power and acceleration are fine, especially when merging or passing.  Drives great and has the least cowl shake of the 4 drop tops I’ve owned.  That stiffness does have a price though the car can be unforgiving of bad roads.  Just let a few psi out of those big ole tires and it’s much better.  Feels very “European” when driving and very similar to a BMW I had some years ago.  Though not exactly up to that standard but pretty close.  Love the fact it has buttons for a lot of its functions instead of fiddling with a touchscreen.  I’m by no means shy of technology but prefer to keep my eyes on the road and feel for a button.  Favorite options are;  The cornering lights, been awhile since I had a vehicle with them and forgot how useful they are.  Heated steering wheel, which I thought would be a useless gimmick, is freaking awesome I love it.  Doesn’t have blind spot monitoring which to me is no biggie, I installed a blind spot mirror which I prefer anyway.  No push button start.  Who cares?  I still have to remember to bring a fob with me anyway so might as well turn a key while I’m at it.  Oh the humanity!  My poor wrists!  Headlights in general are great, brightest I’ve personally ever owned. I’d say for the near 40k asking price you definitely got what you paid for, mid level luxury.   Overall a great fun car, if your interested in getting a used one don’t hesitate,  Judging by what most people who actually own the car say, including me, you’ll be very happy!  Shame they discontinued it instead of remodeling and updating with a bit more power, but GM sold off the division that made this car so guess there was no point.  No more 4 seater ragtops left under 60 grand anymore except for Camaros and mustangs.  And since I’m not in my 20’s anymore I’ll pass.  Maybe I can convince the better half we absolutely need to spend over 70 grand on our next car and get an Audi or 6 series drop top.  I’m sure that will go over well.

Just picked up a 2017 Cascada with only 2000 miles on it.  I must say, I'm very impressed with the sporty handling and overall drivability of it.   The Cascada is like 75% sports car, 25% Buick.   It handles like a sports car, but offers a softer, less punishing ride than corvettes, vipers, etc.   The front seats are snug and firm, but again, softer than your typical sports car.  Its like they wanted to build a true sports car, but then they woke up and realized they were Buick, so they only went three quarters of the way.  And that's probably a good thing, as many of us prefer a bit more livability in and comfort in their vehicles.  

The soft top is unbelievably quiet.  I'd say this car is as quiet as a typical hardtop, perhaps even more so.  And dropping the top is a breeze - just hit a button and the top completely disappears into the body of the car, with a hardtop cover flipping up and hiding it.     Both the trunk and backseat are suprisingly large, a rarity in convertibles.   And God forbid you're ever in an accident, the Cascada's rollbars pop up when it senses the car is going to flip.  An amazing feature for a car in this price range.

On the negative side, the rear window is very tiny, so visibility out the back is poor.  To make matters worse, Buick didn't provide Blind Spot Detection in the Cascade, which is a bizarre and terrible decision.

But other than that, this is really a fantastic car.   A shame they only made them for 4 years...!

My wife and I have been looking for a midsize midrange convertible for years and after seeing a Cascada in a parking lot knew this was the car we wanted.  It has all the bells and whistles you’d find in a BMW, Mercedes or Audi at a fraction of the cost to purchase and maintain.  Although they’ve been discontinued as of 2019 now is the perfect time to find a newer used car with low miles for half the sticker price.  The only drawbacks are the MPG isn’t optimal and you can’t link your iPhone to the display screen, but the pros (beautiful car, tons of standard features, handles great, decent back seat / trunk space) far outweigh those two potential cons.

I have a Chevy Volt for city driving… used 4 gals of gas last year… 98% all elec driving.

My Enclave is a road car. The 121” wheelbase makes a difference on the road. It’s a roomy comfortable 4300lb vehicle that gets up to 28mpg and has 310hp!  And I think it’s the best looking mid sized SUV.

The best looking interior that is clean looking and functional not just a jumble of buttons like I’ve seen in much more expensive vehicles.
    The only other SUV that I feel has a better ride is the Suburban or Tahoe. Of course the Caddy versions too.
   I keep my vehicles 10yrs or more … another reason the Buick is superior… galvanized 18ga steel body and stainless steel exhaust and alloy wheels are just a few advantages.
    I feel the Enclave is the best for the money.

I have been the owner of two Cadillac CTS's and one Buick Enclave with the 3.6 engine.  I have found them to be problem free workhorses.  I was surprised you didn't mention that the engine runs on regular 87 octane gasoline.  Many of your readers might consider this a plus as most 300HP engines are turbos that require premium gasoline.  In our area that's forty cents more per gallon.

We bought the Enclave Avenir after decades of being minivan fans. We have 50k miles in 21 months on it, and it has been a pleasure to drive. Plenty of cargo room for road trips, and it's a smooth, quiet ride. No issues at all. MPG on the highway is often 29-30 for the trip. I appreciate fitting bags and groceries in the back with all three rows up. We have even done short road trips with our adult kids in the third seat with no complaints.

Took the Enclave in for transmission service because of slipping at 80000 miles.  They said a fluid change should help.  After the fluid change it doesn't move at all.  Service manager said they did nothing wrong and these cars are known for bad transmissions and burning oil.  I'm over a quart low at each gas fill up.  Oil changes were always done on time.   I can't wait to get it fixed ( $5000 ) and traded in on anything but a GM auto.

I’ve been buying vehicles for 50 yrs…21 vehicles 
My current 2020 Buick Enclave is the best road car I’ve owned. 
  The 121” wheelbase and 310HP engine makes road trips much easier …
   I’ve gotten between 25-28 mpg in the 18k miles driven so far… pretty good considering I got 23mpg on the 4cyl RAV4 I drove.
   Rides smoother and more quiet than our BMW company car …
   Needless to say we are very pleased with our Buick Enclave!
Room for seven good cargo decent hauling with all the style of a  Buick. The v6 310 HP makes others like Toyota

Great ad Buick!!  My parents have owned this make for 10 years and absolutely love this vehicle!  My folks have always been a Buick guy!!  My dad just passed away and my mom is happy driving this dependable vehicle alone at 86 years old.   Great job Buick!
This vehicle has been a comfort and pleasure to own and drive for long and short distances whether it be for shopping or on vacationing.

This vehicle has been the worst vehicle ever. Cost are way to much for continuous repairs. Engine, transmission all junk. Had the hardest time trying to trade this in. Nobody offered anything much. That tells you something!! Bad experience owning this.

Just DONT buy this. Im 56 and I even hate it. Its NOT EVEN GOOD enough for a grandma car!

Our Buick Encore GX is a wonder vehicle. It has good gas mileage and is incredibly comfortable to drive. I recommend this vehicle to anyone wanting a reliable SUV.

I decided to lease my encore GX select I had a previous Buick and decided to stick with what I knew the best. I love the 29 to 32 mileage per gallon you get with the 1.2L FWD but it is very under powered. The 1.3 option is a much better option if you want a little more pep in your step. Now the turbo in the 1.2 does make up for certain situations but the CVT transmission is a little unnecessary.. just put a real transmission with a turbo and it would make things much better. Interior designs are very bold and beautiful I love driving my vehicle and having the comfort of the nice touch screen and also the digital and original speedometer to look at while driving.
The 2021 encore gx select awd is a great vehicle for the money. Has great safety features and a luxury feel. The 1.3 turbo motor has enough get up for daily driving but not the most impressive.

Not expecting to even look at a Buick (I was looking at Chevies as a previous Equinox owner) I was quite impressed with the vehicle's handling, peppiness, and overall looks.
