Five years ago I saw a 2014 fusion se, I just had a good feeling. It had 74000 miles. I'm very happy to have that se, I put so far 13000 on it. Never had any trouble. It is truly a good reliable car. The professional reviews have reported. When looking for a car or truck always go on the net, read what the people who know the pros and cons of the vehicle you are interested have to report.
Fantastic vehicle. Still drives as well as it did when I got it new 8 years ago. No major issues and hope Ford will make this an EV with the same type of styling and dimensions.

I bought my 2016 fusion hybrid new and still have it after 8 yrs. I read the combined mileage is 38. Not true in my experience. After 8 yrs it still gets more like 45 MPG. If you do mostly city driving I get around 50MPG in city. I get around  40 on HWY if going 70 mph or less. If you drive like a maniac speeding into stop lights and taking off fast you will get a lot less mileage as with any type car. Its common sense. The advertised 38 is driving reckless. I can get near 60 mpg in city many times. Its been a great car. It's no Cadillac and doesn't have a Cadillac price. It's a good sized car and Ford should've kept building it! Hybrids are the way to go with no range anxiety

Bought it new, It was one of the last produced. I searched a 4 state area to find it. I'm in Detroit but had to go to West Michigan to find this one. the next closest were in Minneapolis and Avon Lake Ohio. Better colors, but were supposedly sold. the silver is OK, it's acceptable but not thrilling. 
It's a fusion. Nice looking car, roomy, decent handling, very quiet, especially in e mode, great stereo. Lots of bells and whistles, which all work reasonably well. The lane keeping system could do with a bit more authority IMO, but adaptive cruise and collision avoidance both work great.
Mileage: 
Highway mileage is between 35-40, depending on how heavy your foot is, and altitude. Took a long road trip to the mountain west, over 5000 miles, and that's what we got.
Around home it routinely gets 70+ mpg with our retiree driving pattern. No daily commute, just groceries, doctor, out to dinner visiting friends. Electric only mileage varies. In the summer, low speed under 35mpg avg, we get about 22-24 miles per charge. January cold snap this year we got 12-15. As long as it's not in the single digits, and it's been left plugged in overnight, the electric mileage is minimally affected. Bottom line, I'd buy one again in a minute.

I have a 2017,  I have never had to bring this car to the Shop, EVER.  It goes thru front tires very quickly because of the weight and there is no trunk.  So we put the Luggage on the roof when we take trips.  It get about 18 miles on charge now being 7 years old but the MPG show 87 since we don't usually go to far.  On road trips we get about 41 MPG with four people in the car and a roof rack.
Don't buy, has recall now for five months, no solutions, engine light on, full charge gets twenty or so miles, wasted 41,000.00, vehicle is GARBAGE!!!

Great car, we haven't had not 1 issue with it.
Nice looking, Roomy interior, all the bells and whistles. Not sure why ford would discontinue it.
with 26 miles on charge plus great gas mileage we rarely put gas in it.
I love my Fusion energi and never had any problems yet. It feels like a luxury car and handles great.

I have owned this car for 5 years and have traveled many miles with it and have average of 52 mpg.
Now at 160,000 miles I have only changed the small battery and tires. I change oil with full synthetic every 5000 miles. I have never had a flat tire or used any kind of wrenches on this vehicle. The brake pads are still good.  Vehicle rides smooth is easy on my Bridgestone tires and more comfortable than my previous cars a toyota prius and a kia optima and sedonia. Also more comfortable than my daughters Mercedes small suv.
Only down size on vacation trips I would prefer a suv for hauling .
Overall this car is a fuel sipping solid midsized sedan with style and comfort of a luxury car. I am well pleased.

42 miles of EV range, great MPG from the 4-banger engine, sleek black leather interior and leather trim in the doors, mud lights to generously greet you every time you want to say hi, ambient lighting to, how should I say, set the mood? Overall, a very fun, reliable, and efficient vehicle.

Cons? Slowest car I've ever driven. Slower than a Prius. Slower than my grandma's 2001 Prius.

Pro? Looks much better and EV isn't as slow as solely gas-driving

After driving a year and 10,000 miles I am extremely satisfied with my Maverick hybrid XL. Averaging between 40-45 mpg per tankful. Very comfortable and roomy inside. Exterior styling looks no nonsense with simple lines and a utility look that I think is appropriate for the type of vehicle it is. The appeal to me is it's everything it needs to be and nothing that it's not. No surprise the Maverick has sold so well. Going on the third year of production and still no real competition for a truck with it's fuel economy, practicality, and low entry price.

I traded my 2017 Ford F250 King Ranch for this and wasn’t told so many things about this truck by the salesman. One huge downfall is when you put a Tonneau cover on it will leak from all points badly regardless as there’s no separation between the bed and the cab is what they tell me, there was a whole debacle on this for over three months before I was refunded? I find it hard to fight the wind when driving on the highway. It seems cheaply made (body), the salesman also let me believe the interior was leather when it’s not? Didn’t know there was no GPS, no CD player? Also upset that when I got a hold of the original window sticker they marked the truck up $10,000 with only 5,000 miles on it? I really wish salesman were better at their job and more honest!

I was looking for a small,  fuel efficient truck in fall 2022.  After extensive researched I settled on the Maverick Hybrid.  I  looked all over the country before finally finding ONE relatively nearby.  It was a basic model but the dealer tacked on $7k right off since it was so sought after.  It was still less expensive than other pickups.   It is smaller than any other new pickups but still larger than I hoped.  I had driven manual transmission my whole life.  My last was the Nissan Frontier I had for 18 years 250k miles and loved it.  It had relatively few issues but the clutch and transmission went out for the second time so I decided to move on.

Good:  
Love the backup camera.  Great milage and reliability. Crash warning that comes up if approaching a stopped vehicle too fast.  It automatically goes into park when you turn off engine. Great in stop & go traffic-that recharges the battery and makes it much more bearable than  with a manual.  The sides of the bed are high so things aren't so visible from the street and don't readily blow out.  

Not so much:  
-The turn radius: I used to be able to do tight u-turns and whip into small parallel parking spaces, now not possible.  BUT I haven't tried other pickups to see if this is an issue for others.
-Auto gear shift is a small, flat, round contraption that could easily have you inadvertently going in R or D if you are not attentive.  
-Ceramic paint:  Very tiny flecks of the came off in my first long road trip.  Never happened with other vehicles I've had.
-Small back window which cannot be opened.

Suggestion:  Should come standard  with top of windshield tinted.  I had that done after purchase. . .not as good as the fade in stuff.   I got the after purchase option of small doors on the side of the bed for tools and bungy cords.  Also got "rhino liner" and a small tool box installed.  All of these make it better for my needs.

If you can find one buy it. Fuel saving machine that you can actually use. Plenty of space even if your taller. Only fuss with it is the radio can be finicky sometimes. Easy fix would be to throw in a $100 dollar radio and not deal with it.

I’ve had my Lariat for 6 months now and I am happy with it. Although the entry models are very well priced for a brand new vehicle, I chose the Lariat without any upgrade packages as the XL & XLT do not have the current “luxuries” that most would consider standard in a new vehicle. (Push start, dash screen, “leather” seats) 
The Maverick is the perfect vehicle to suit work and everyday life without breaking the bank. 

Pros: well priced, well designed interior with ample storage, good on gas, comfortable seats, strong engine, great handling and overall feel without the overbearing ride and size of a truck. 
 
Cons: engine auto stop/start cannot be permanently disengaged, sync/bluetooth system can be glitchy on occasion, wind noise at highway speed is noticeable, adding extras to your build can get very pricey.

2.0 Eco boost motor is sound and reliable. Has good pick up and power. Gas mileage a little better than expected. Interior has a little worse than expected road noise. Biggest down side is the radio shack reject radio. My radio has locked up several times, only way to reset is disconnect battery. There was no upgrade option available for the radio when I ordered mine.  Upgrade the radio, and it would be a 5.

Had for 2 days.  Lariat lux package, AWD, copilot 360

Pros: feels secure on road, feels planted to road,  MPG 30+, easy park copilot 360 works good.  

Cons:  road noise seems to be from sliding rear window, even on this top of line version has manual review mirror, no window defroster, rides rough on bumpy roads.  Ford cheaped out little too much.  Could use little larger side view mirrors.

It took me a year, but this past summer my Ford Maverick finally came in.  I got the XLT trim with only 2 options,  the Blind Spot and the 2.0 Eco Boost engine for more power.  So far, it has been a great truck.  If I watch my rpm.s,  in the econ mode I get 30 mpg around town and on the hwy.   The only issue so far is a clicking type rattle in my dash that only happens on certain slow bumps in my neighborhood, once I am on the highway it goes away.  Strange.  Anyway,  if you miss the Ford Rangers from the 90s,  this truck reminds me of a 1996 Ranger I used to have back then.  It is a very solid truck,  loads of room in the cabin,  great bed to work with, and since it is front wheel drive I am looking fwd to seeing how it does in the snow this winter.  If you order one,  get the Lariat, for a few thousand more it is worth it.    Hope this review helps !      PS,  I was thinking of ordering a 2023 Ford Bronco 2 door,  but when I sat in one at a local car show,  I realized my Maverick was much more roomier and comfortable than the full size Bronco.  I will stick with my Maverick !

The GT driving experience with the top down is awesome. The automatic transmission is very responsive especially in the sport mode, love the performance exhaust, while using the paddle shifters.
Great exterior design and interior is a huge up grade one previous models. 
The built-in digital Owners Manual is easy to use.  
The center display is user friendly I love all the options available.  I'd rather have knobs for the environmental systems.

i am absolutely in love with my car. I got the ecoboost version and it’s a speedy little car. The ONLY thing I would actively trade it for is the GT, but the ecoboost is still incredibly quick. I love the big screen with all the features, changing the colors and the gauge display has been my favorite.

I just love my Mustang and everything about it. There is no other car I want; this car is just perfect. It's beautiful (ruby red) and so very fun to drive. I have had three previous Mustangs, but this Mustang flies! My other Mustangs never seemed to be fast, and actually, could be a bit sluggish. This one is fast and handles great. This car is a V6, and it is the last year they made them - with the V6 that is. It is definitely a must have. I cannot say enough good things about this car. I really love it, and to me it is the best car in the world! Go go go my little pony!
Great mustang if you just want something quick and not fast. It is really a nice dar fompared to other v6 and 4 cylinder muscle cars.

A car jewel 
Good looking
Safer on the road
Economic for a sport car
Classic American
Lovely
Lasting forever if you want.

Love my car I bought brand new off the lot.
Love the styling and interior  design.performance’s of the car is sensational
  The big that I like is the engine & transmission 10r80 & has been reliable
Great vehicle and reliable manual transmission also great sound when it comes to problems all I had was the window motor going bad that’s pretty much it

Expect a lot of issues. Purchased one of these with 56,000 miles on it in august of 2022. At 65,900 miles the engine failed completely, requiring 7 months off waiting and 11,000 dollars in repairs for a car worth according to KBB and most others to be about 13-15,000 dollars. Ford doesn’t warranty anything past 60,000 miles (which is what they expect their cars to last I guess). Interior isn’t as good as cars in this price range either. No electrical issues so far but the car was in a shop for half a year so I haven’t had any time to find any. Stay away from modern Ford products.

I bought my 2018 car from a major brand dealer 6 months ago for $25,000. KBB says trade in value is approximately $18,000. I was just informed that the “buy it now” offer from KBB and local dealers is just over $13,000. 
I have upgraded my cars wheels and tires (original size) and get compliments all the time. Other than that it is stock. 
What an insulting offer Cindy they will put it on their lot for $25,000 or better. 
Thanks but no freaking way!!!
This is a very luxurious sports car! Make sure to keep it in good shape and keep it clean! Did you know that you have a choice to have a spoiler on the back or not?

I traded in a RAV4 prime for a 2022 Mustang Mach e GT and have been entirely satisfied with the quality, performance, and practicality of this vehicle. Friends who would have never considered an electric car are now in the market because of how nice a total package this is. 

Most nit picks are related to software bugs or lack of features but they are slowly coming. 

Highly recommend.

I've driven to Vegas from San Diego twice and not a single problem.  The extended range (California version) was a great call.  I never worry about running out of charge.  There are so many charging stations but I usually charge at home.  This is a great car for daily driving.  Also, being able to get on the HOV lane is a great plus.  No mechanical issues and oil change to worry about.

Incredible car. Solid design, very reliable. We just love it. This car easily bests a Tesla Y. Everything about it is so cool from the exterior to the interior. We've had this car for over 8 months and literally every time we are in a parking lot complete strangers walk up and want to say what an incredible looking car it is and they are amazed it is an electric Mustang. Drivers slow down or pull up beside us to take a closer look. There are not that many on the road. I hate to say this but Tesla is sort of becoming the Toyota Prius of electric vehicles. What I mean by that is that I see lots of them on the road. That's very good, very reliable, they are leading the way and kudos to Elon Musk, however Ford really hit a home run with this car.

Love everything about it. Extremely low cost to drive,  ride and handling are great,  good comfort, excellent quality. Great features.  Every day someone comes up to me and says how much they like it.
Great Car. Dependable. Gives exactly what it says it gives as far as mileage. Actually more if you drive like a decent human being. LOL

We went on road trip and we were alerted with a power malfunction/reduced power message. We immediately requested road side assistance and had it towed directly to the dealership.

The vehicle has been in and out of the shop several times. It seems none of the dealer’s in house techs knows what is going on.
We were trying to utilize the lemon law. Although, the dealership is insisting we should contact Ford and Ford is saying the dealer should assist us. Overall, terrible experience. Great looking car with terrible management from top to bottom. If you value your time look elsewhere.
This is by far the best car I have ever owned. Stylish, comfortable, classy.  It exceeds my expectations. So glad I waited for this and did not settle for a Tesla.

This is our First Full Battery Electric vehicle.  Have had Hybrids in the past, three Priuses, and were skeptical buying an all electric.  The MachE is completely eliminated that fear.  No gas to refill and amazing range, 337 miles is our best before charging again.
The interior, materials, layout and immense 15" touchscreen are all finely assembled and glitch free.   The ride height and spacious interior along the quiet really set this vehicle apart.  Handling and poise are a dream.  We're leased because we were concerned about a Ford Electric vehicle, but will definitely buy it at the end of the term.

I bought my Ranger Lariat new in 2021.  Currently have 16,845 miles on it.  So far it has met most of my expectations.  Pros good gas mileage, lots of power for a 4 cylinder, mine has all the options available in 2021.  Love the adaptive cruse, would never have a vehicle without it.  Cons I am over 6 feet tall and am a bit cramped on the driver's side also the ride tends to be very stiff.  Otherwise, I am happy with the truck,

I live the 4000 foot level and have found my 2022 Ford ranger invaluable. My husband was diagnosed with stage four cancer and I was able to take them over Highway 88 six times and four-wheel-drive without having to need chains. Plus after he passed my house was hit with 3 1/2 feet of snow and I was able to get into town without any issues. what I also like about my Ranger is unlike, when I had my Ford escape I’m not challenged on the highway and people don’t cut me off.  I travel a lot and I like to be sitting high in traffic.
Looking to purchase xxxx.    Xxxx.      Xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx      Xxxxxxx.

Nice ride, affordable, great gas mileage so far 23.5mpg since i bought the truck. Bought used with 20k now have 57K. Up graded from 16" to 18" no change in ride or fuel mileage. very comfortable vehicle to drive. Have had no problems with towing at all. Over all great vehicle.

I bought my 2019 XLT supercab in 2021 with 9,000 miles on it.  I added a touneau cover and had "Bullet" truck bed liner added. I have had no trouble with the car.  I have only had to replace the headlight bulbs. I have 60,000 miles on it and the tires are still OK (I get them rotated).  I have driven to Florida from Delaware round trip, and I regularly drive three-hour round trips. The sound system is nice and I love having my GPS map on the dashboard screen as I drive (connected to my phone when plugged in the USB port) and it's a huge help being able to see and hear when someone has texted me and being able to speak my text messages through Siri to reply.  The gas mileage has been good (as good or better than my 2015 Subaru Forester was). It's true the transmission can be a little jerky at slow speeds, but I think the truck is just happier going fast. It never bothered me - just a quirk. The power and pickup when I need to pass a slow vehicle on a two-lane road is excellent. It does well at high speeds on highways. I love the cruise control on long trips!  The shocks can be a bit bumpy on uneven roads, but that's what I would expect from a pick-up truck. I have had to drive over curbs, on the grass of my yard, and over potholes on dirt roads and it handled great! I have also had to use the four-wheel drive on wet, or snowy/icy roads, and it was a big help. I love being able to shove my two kayaks in the back, strap them in, and go. I just leave the truck bed open. For short trips to a trail, I can also lay two bikes down in the back, one on top of the other, and shut the truck bed. I have had passengers in the back seat that didn't complain about space.

Purchased with 20k used in late 2021. driven to Florida no problem great gas mileage comfortable ride. Upgraded to 18" wheels . tonneau cover, tow package and other small thins done for the truck. upgraded it the way i wanted it to be. no problems at all so far. runs great,drives good and is a fun vehicle to drive. i would recommend this truck to anyone.

If you are interested the market for an all around truck, this is it. Beautiful design, almost 300 horsepower coming from a 4 cylinder turbo engine along with 7,500 pounds of towing capacity. Ford did this one right.

2019 is the first model year reintroduced to the US market. Test drove all comparable mid-sized trucks and the Ranger was hands down the most impressive. Powerful even though it’s just a turbo 4cyl engine, quick, great torque, comfortable seats, decent factory ride but much improved with aftermarket Fox shocks. I’m in 3rd year of ownership and have had no issues with it. I still love driving this thing every day.

I really love my car, I bought it used and the problems I've had have been far and in between.  Now the most expensive repair was a problem I had with the coolant area and that was 800.00. Everything else was very cheap.   I did have a problem that every now and then the car wouldn't start and make a weird clanking noise but after replacing a gadget that was only $76 near the fuel tank never happened again!!  I really love my car its been the most dependable car I've every owned!!

I purchased my 2016 Taurus with 100K miles on it from a reputable dealer. I have had no issues and am in love with the body style and the way it drives and rides. The options are amazing and the seats are the most comfortable I have ever had....They blow Acura and Lexus out of the water for sure. Amazing car that is so much fun to drive. I hate that they do not make these cars anymore.
Other than the known internal water pump issue, this car is excellent. Performs well, and got to 150k+ miles without too much trouble

tires and brakes only during its lifetime of service and garage kept
very dependable and comfortable on longer trios

My 2013 Taurus had 12,000 miles when purchased and now has 270,000 miles. My A/C needs its first service. The water pump went out at 200,000 miles and the steering rack at 240,000 miles. This car has been my mobile office for 7 years is very comfortable and has never given me a back ache. People always ask me, "what about the blind spots?" I am 6'1" and don't notice any blind spots. Flush the Transmission every 50,000 miles, change the oil when needed and the Taurus will serve you well.

My car was literally 1 month old (built in June 2016) when purchased in July that year.  The paint still shines so perfectly and the Ruby Red is just gorgeous.  The Taurus has been absolutely FLAWLESS and has never had a single problem whatsoever.  Plenty of power, and really love the fact that I can get in it and STILL smell the "new car" smell even after 82,000 miles.  Aside from oil changes, new tires and a new battery, it hasn't needed a single thing to be fixed.  Very comfortable, rides smooth as silk, great acceleration and braking power, and wonderful MPGs on the highway.  Even at 83,000 miles, it's worth over $14,000 when I only owe $8,000 left on it.  Very sweet car!

So I am amazingly surprised on how well I really like this car. I was never a Ford fan but after owning this car it has really changed my mind. I have the 2010 Ford Taurus Limited Edition which is completely loaded with all options available at the time such as keyless entry, push button start, Ford Sync

I absolutely love my 2019 Transit Connect XLT because it's great on gas mileage and it's so versatile! It's a Mini Van so I can haul big items for our home with no problem! If I put the seats it will seat a total of 6 people (including the driver) also it has Bluetooth Technology which is amazing! It has a backup camera, sensors that will let you know if you're too close to a moving vehicle (which will not alert you but applies the brakes to slow you down) so that you can avoid an accident! The backup sensors help keep your bumper from getting messed up, as well

The 2016 Ford Transit Connect has ruined my view of Ford as an auto manufacturer. I have always had good luck with Ford and thus drove them almost exclusively. That is until I started driving the 2016 Ford Transit Connect with the 2.5L engine.

I dont know where to start so I will just list all the issues I have with this thing. There are a lot. 

Good-
-Comfortable in the front seats
-Average MPG for fuel

Bad-
-Turns like a tank
-Towing capacity sucks. We actually ruined a set of tires towing with this at the rated capacity.
-Washer fluid capacity is .8 gallons. Washer fluid only comes in 1 gallon containers. I include this only to show the amount of thought that was put into this vehicle.
-I have to order wipers (special clips) and air filters (super small) online because no one in my city carries them.
-You need to remove the entire air intake just to access the battery. Replacing the battery has gone beyond simple replacement and into removing multiple parts, lines, and other obstructions in order to do simple repairs.
-Rear seats are not adjustable or removable. They fold flat but are very thick and take up a lot of your cargo room.

I bought my van in 2016.  I was concerned that it would not accelerate with two or three canoes on a roof rack in the mountains.  I have had no problems.  I converted my passenger transit connect xlt into a camper and it has done very well.  
I wish the gas mileage was a bit better, but it is one of the best gasoline engine vans out on the market for gas mileage.  In addition, I love the two manual side doors, and the manual back hatch.  The hatch has served as a rain shelter when I have cooked, hung out in a chair, changed my clothes after a day on a white water river. I have a wrap around screen that I attach around the hatch and the two manual side doors.  These have worked wonderfully on hot nights in North Carolina.  
The seats are a bit stiff, but with a little foam seat aid from a big box store does the trick . I have driven my van across North America five times, and spend up to 90 nights a year camping in my van.  This has been the best camper van.  I am hoping that I get many more years off of my van.

I absolutely love my 2019 Ford Transit Connect XLT so much! It's reliable, great on gas mileage and I love how versatile it is! It's big enough for hauling big items like from Lowe's or Home Depot and that's very important when you own a home! It's better than a pickup truck because everything fits inside so if the weather is raining or snowing I don't have to worry about anything that I'm hauling won't get ruined by the weather!! If I wanted to I can put an air mattress inside of it and take it on a camping trip! How cool is that?
traded in a 2017 Kia Soul for this vehicle as it was on lot with only 26k miles and not a thing wrong with it.

This vehicle has amazing functionality and I average better than advertised fuel economy both in city driving and on highway. The seats are very comfortable and everything is in the proper location. The Transit Connect drives like a car but stores so many work tools with tremendous amounts of cargo space. This is a very well thought out vehicle. I test drove both the Ram Promaster City and Nissan NV200 before driving the Transit Connect. It easily drove the best and was the most comfy.

Like this van overall with a few exceptions. First this vehicle needs at least the 2.5 as an option to non commercial users. The 2.0L is woefully underpowered for a vehicle of this weight. Load this to max GVWR or tow a 2000 trailer? Good luck with that! Now the vehicle has developed a very annoying and noticeable rattle around the instrument cluster. Gas mileage is nice but I’d sacrifice a little MPG for more power
clean,warranty still up too one more year or 12,000 miles, very,very well taken care of. the 2nd of two oners.no dent, a few door dings from shopping.the back seats have never been set in.
Won’t last past 109k miles. 11k for rebuild side panels had to be replaced for rusting out. Front fog cover fell off and paint flaking on bumper. Bought it brand new.

With all that being said this vehicle will not drive the miles it says. Filled tank it says 479 miles, was able to drive only 275 on one tank!!!! I am on my third transmission, luckily all under warranty.  But as the vehicle warranty expires I don't know if Subaru will replace the fourth transmission or will it cost me $9500.  If it does the car will be worthless.

The safety factor is  #1 for me and my family. The Semetrical AWD included on all their vehicles is a plus. When it comes to AWD Subaru has Mastered it compared  to it's competitors. They are #1 in that catagory.  Having that Boxster engine keeps the vehicle well grounded. All Subaru's include some of the most advanced safety features. As for model options & packages  Subaru gives you more bang for your buck best price in the market.  This is my 3rd Subaru. To me it's not about how hot (which I love mine) the car looks it's about comfort, safety features, options, pricing and value.

This is the 5th Subaru that I've owned over the years, and I'll never go back to anything else! Safe, comfortable, convenient, durable, and works amazingly well for both my family and my business needs.

I would never again get an Ascent.  My car only had 25,000 mles on it. It sit in the drivewat 80% of the time. The first set of tires was defective, so Subaru USA sent a new set to the Dealer. Well, ever since (2021) the tires have had issues.  *Leaks, pressure issues, now this past week, each tire goes flat every other day.  My kids and I bet $ on which tire will it be when we walk out of the house!  There are no nails. Just Little bubbles here and there, this is crazy. The Electrical System always tells me the wrong thing, 
it doesn't reser properly, not does the dealer worry about it.  Starlink send strange messages. And the Navigations systems works when it feels its in the mood.  Plus it doesn't always connect to my phone.  The dealer has no idea why!   How much fun is that????????  Not Fun at All

Recalls not repaired to satisfaction. 
1. Transmission; they would inspect it and if a drive belt showed signs of wear they would replace the transmission. If it wasn't worn very bad they would install a new program for how it shifts. Ours got the new program. Now it shifts too early, bogs down at low speeds and even bucks around 30 mph at times.
2. A ground bolt under the dash will corrode so this recall requires everytime it comes for service they gotta look at this bolt for the rest of the cars life. 
Everything seems to rattle and they kept it for a week, even stripping the interior trying to find it until they gave up and had us pick it up. It drives us crazy, something (multiple different ones) rattles all the time.
Struts kept going bad. We live in fort lauderdale it has never even seen a gravel road or a pothole yet its been in twice for strut failure in 26k miles.
Makes this weird noise when you turn a right corner and accell at 30% +. 
Subaru misleads about the MPG. Look up what other people say, but we never got over 20 mpg. 
Radio turns itself on. Safety features like collision warning, lane departure and eyesight will randomly have a problem, alert you that it's not working and then start working again a min later. 
We got this new before covid and our lease is about up. We got a good deal and should be able to profit by a few hundred by trading it in or selling out the lease, yet Subaru offers us the least amount for it. They don't even want their own car. 
The only positive thing I feel needs put here is that it never left us stranded or fully broke down. 
I'm not saying every ascent is bad but we aren't going to risk it by getting another one. Good riddance subaru.
2020 subaru ascent premium.

Some controls hard to see on left side below steering wheel. Foam in seats is too hard for long trips. Engine has good acceleration. Only navigation is  either Apple or  Android which is particularly inconvenient to use. Ride is not as smooth as other cars that size.

It's hard to come up with any negatives towards this vehicle. The most glaring one would be that it could use just a little more horsepower, but that can be pretty easily fixed. This car is an incredible entry-level sports car and is incredibly fun to drive. Having taken it on multiple long road trips, I can say that it is comfortable and fun as hell.

Ignore the one star dummy thats mad cause the car is not electric. Great handling and fast. The pit falls you will run into are the infotainment center (easy fix once car is out of warranty) and sits very low.

The only thing that really compares to this car in my opinion is the Mazda Miata, however this gives you more power for less money as well as better practicality. The car is enormously fun and allows you to drive spiritedly without breaking laws I really feel it has the perfect amount of power for a sporty daily.

This car may not be the fastest through the quarter mile, 0 to 60, or around a race track. But, it is faster than a lot of other cars and quick enough to make you grin from ear to ear without the OMG I can't think this fast moment. 

Now that we have that out of the way here is a little about the 2024 BRZ that apparently  is coming. We all know about the current 2023.

So the one star reviews are obviously used grass in a cow pasture. And why allow such obvious trash anyway? You edited this post to death because it mentioned........ But post reviews from someone who does not even own, nor has driven the car? And another from someone who has little or no knowledge of the future, but claims to be clairvoyant? Yep more of that stuff you have to watch out for. 
Enough soapbox already,
So a little context from the writer:
I have owned more than 14 sports cars. Some of them at decidedly the top end of the scale including a Porsche 944 and 911 a gaggle of Corvettes, several BMWs including a 2022 M3, and a couple of 5.0 Mustang GTs. 
And have driven many more than I can remember.

So against this backdrop I offer my humble opinion of the 2022 BRZ. It is FUN packed to the brim, rear end waggling, corner squeezing, speed limit busting FUN. Now I did stick a cat back exhaust and disabled the piped in sound so the real engine sound tells me what it's doing (very handy when referencing the tach would cause loss of situational awareness). It is more fun overall than any of the other war wagons I have owned or driven. 

Sure, some others are faster, or louder (love big v8s) or can reach a little farther into the lateral grip bucket. But none of them did it all with as much grace and sheer joy. The BRZ just begs you to toss it around with abandon. Plant your right foot and forget there is a brake pedal for a while. Playful, communicative, proactive, good looking, and willing. We all need some of that!

Not for everyone, but if driving is a passion or a sport then this belongs in your garage. Along with the bags of money you have saved.
This is my daily. Im a driver. Its awesome. 10000 miles and still finding things I like about it. These other couple of goons couldnt find their way out of a wet paper bag.

Just as title says. Under 30grand, a manual, rwd, 2 door coupe, non-turbo vehicle. Last car in the us. No more. Grab it while you can.  Huge improvement from previous model. Better look, more upscale, less rice burner style, better suspension, torque is improved along with acceleration. Comfortable yet sporty handling, quiet interior. The car is amazing for its price.   Sure some are better tech equipped but  for me, rwd, non turbo, manual was the key.

Long review because it deserves it.

I bought my 2017 BRZ 6spd manual new.  I currently have 91k miles on it with literally only 1 problem.....the center console charging port needed to be replaced for $20.  I have had to replace nothing but tires, battery, and fluids.  That's pretty hard to beat.  I'm a mechanic and have worked on a HUGE variety of cars, so you can trust me when I say it's a great car. Toyota and Subaru really let their engineers loose and the results speak for themselves.  I'm very pleased with the dependability so far.

Performance:
By no means the fastest car I've driven, but it's like driving a 205hp go-cart as a daily driver and is fast enough to be quicker than all the "regular cars" out there.

I'm currently averaging 36mpg combined, but mostly highway.  I can also have fun when I want to drift turns, do donuts, or mess around.  Name another car that can match that.....

The cargo capacity is really good for a (realistically 2 seater) sports car as well.  The rear seats are a joke though and I suspect a ploy to lower insurance costs. 

Summary:
Dependable, great gas mileage, loads of fun to drive, easy to work on, reasonable purchase cost, high safety rating, and comfortable.  Highly recommended.

Car has a very nice clutch. Overall sporty appeal and performance for the price. The car is not fast but it definitely handles and sounds amazing.

Garage kept. Never seen snow or cinders. Broke in the way i drive it.5,6,7 grand on the tach and over 110 and more every drive. Never had a car cut up the road like this one. Only thing i can ask for would be a turbo version / sti package with engine size.
Fun to drive and proud to own.  Four years later and I still get at least a dozen strangers each week asking about my car and saying how much they love it!

It is not the best, however, fairly decent car in performance for the price until the engine certainly stopped working at 43000 miles. Reached out to the dealer and the head office of Subaru in north America, basically I was told it is already passed warranty.
I started to search for a used engine and realized there were quite similar problems with Subaru BRZ.

I wouldn't recommend this car unless you don't have any respect for your money.

Just a basic car with slap together parts from Toyota and Subaru. It's just not a good choice vehicle. Cricket sounds from engine that gives a headache listening to it. Engine has to many flaws on rpm. Not enough horsepower. It has sluggish spots... For the same amount of money, I rather buy the wrx awd.

This is a car for driving enthusiasts and enthusiastic drivers. Not everyone will like this car or even understand it's appeal. The late Ken Miles once told an MG owner that he needed to drive his MG "like he meant it." This is a car that must be driven like you mean it. Zero to sixty is not this car's strong suit: acceleration from a full stop is always disappointing, but once you get this car up to speed and the engine revving between 4500 RPM and redline it is an amazing performer and a very satisfying drive. The problem is that the typical driver will be to scared to drive it the way it was meant to be driven. They will want to shift at 3000 rpm and keep the revs deep within the infamous 'Torque Dip' and will complain that the engine "has no power!" But the driver who keeps the engine from dropping under 4500 RPM will be treated to a transmission and drivetrain that can teach them how to drive like Sir Jackie Stewart. The pedals are perfect for heel and toe downshifts. Above 4500 RPM the engine is flexible enough to skip gears on both upshifts and downshifts. The seats, steering wheel, and instruments are very good. It is a fabulous driver's car once you learn it's foibles. 
Now, the shortcomings:
The Michelin Primacy HP tires that the car arrives on wear like iron, deliver awesome gas mileage, and handle very predictably, but they don't provide much grip. Replace them as soon as you can with the high performance tires this car deserves; you won't regret the purchase. The navigation sound system is mediocre at best and attached to low fi speakers. It is not very loud and can be difficult to hear over road noise. Many owners replace the entire system. I kept the head unit but upgraded to good quality, high efficiency speakers and it now sounds tolerable if not at audiophile quality. BTW: the cheap OEM speaker are VERY heavy; I saved weight by replacing them with speakers with neodymium magnets. Speaking of road noise, the designers didn't use much sound deadening material. They preferred to save cost and weight. When it rains the roof drums and when roads get rough road noise is loud. I added about 20 lbs. of sound deadener to the roof, doors, trunk, trunk lid, and rear fenders and it is now a smidge quieter. The back seat is not for full sized people and as a package shelf is better utilized folded down although that increases the road noise. Finally the engine: it is just fine at high RPMs but off idle it leaves a ton to be desired. I will admit I replaced the headers and cat back with high flow aftermarket parts and invested in a tune to eliminate the torque dip problem. The car has much improved drive-ability throughout the entire rev range with those mods, but it is very noticeable off idle and low RPMs. It now launches confidently from a full stop.

In Summary: this is a car for driving enthusiasts who enjoy thinking about the mechanics of driving, getting the best performance out of the car, and enjoy thinking about how the car responds to their inputs, It is not a car for people who can't be bothered to think while driving, the ones who drive with a Starbucks in one hand and a cell phone clamped to their ear  who never look at the tachometer. This car will disappoint those drivers.  It is not basic transportation for a minimally skilled driver. It requires attention and those who pay attention will learn to drive this car well and will enjoy driving this car for many, many years.
This is my first Subaru. I came from Lexus and I’m not disappointed. The ride is great and the car has been solid. Occasionally the touchscreen will lag. That’s one issue.
I love everything about my 2024 Red Premium Subaru ! Inside and out !!! Sharp looking car and rides so nice !

The Crosstrek just got a lot more fun! The wilderness brings the off-road look and capability you want and expect from Subaru. Great power from the 2.5L engine, great in the mud/snow, comfortable seats that are easy to clean with the startex material.

The 2.0L engine is wildly under powered. The options very so much from car to car, the only thing I can say is to start at the Sport model and go from there. Wind noise is like a Mitsubishi. No where near the for and finish of the older Subaru's. I wish I could trade it in for my 2014 Outback.

The 2024 Crosstrek (I have the Premium model) is a well-designed, refined vehicle that's very comfortable to drive. It comes with the smaller engine but provides me with more than enough power to get around the fairly flat roadways of coastal North Carolina. The one, rather major, complaint that I have is about the VERY large touchscreen. For some reason, the designers at Subaru chose to incorporate the HVAC controls into the touchscreen. I find it to be very cumbersome to make adjustments, requiring one to journey through several menus. A driver has to unsafely divert attention from the task of driving and focus on the menus, all the while having a steady finger in order to make changes. It can be challenging even on just slightly bumpy roads.  They should have kept the knobs and buttons from prior years. Otherwise, it's a great vehicle!
LOVE THE SPORT VERSION THE CAR IS AWESOME. I WOULD RECOMMEND THIS CAR TO SOMEONE WHO DOESNT WANT A BIG SUV BUT STILL WANT TO SIT HIGH AND DRIVE FAST

I have the new Limited and could not be happier. This is the third Crosstreck I have owned and it is by far the best. All of them were great though.  The big improvements this year are styling, the front seats are more comfortable, and with lumbar support standard now on the Limited. I like the big electronic display. The car handles great in the city and on the highway. This Crosstrek has the pick-up I need too. The standard safety systems, I feel are some of the best in the industry.  A great fun crossover.
BIG upgrade from 18 Premium Manual. Finally I have the style and tech from the Crosstrek. Speefy car thats great in snow! Mileage appears to be disappointing so fa though

Overpriced gasoline vehicles, new age all electric and hybrid version of this same car around the same price point. These cars have been nothing but continuous repairs. Mine has transmission problems already being new. Fuel mileage is not what they claim, it's way lower. Seats are way to stiff, no comfort after a longer drive. Hatchback has wind noise, gets annoying. Just a cheap car, they are dropping value pretty fast.

I was in a very bad accident two weeks ago while driving my 2019 Subaru Crosstrek that I had for exactly 2 years. A driver ran a red light going approximately 50 mph and T-boned me, directly hitting my driver’s side door. While my car was totaled, I walked away with only a concussion from the side airbag deploying. However, if it weren’t for all of Subaru’s safety features, I might not have been so lucky. 
My car had 50,0000 miles on it at the time of my accident, still drove like the day I picked it up, and had gotten me to quite a few backwood hikes and kayaking trips. It was an easy ride, drove fine in all elements, and had all the technology I needed for navigation and music. 
My only complaint was the acceleration, which is nonexistent in the Subaru Crosstrek.

First year owner ship -$6,000 dollar's. The trade in value is terrible. I'm wanting a truck instead of this lifted up car. I'm stuck in this terrible loan. Nobody wants to pay fair value now days. They say oh we can buy this same car at an auction cheaper. What a terrible experience owning a subaru crosstrek sport. "Walk away from these vehicles"

Fuel mileage is ok, and having awd is a good idea. Body style is a bit cheap, to much plastic pieces. Interior is decent, a bit mismatched. Stereo is terrible, seating is not comfortable especially on longer road trips. Cargo is a bit cramped. Hatchback and other things have rattle sounds. This gas car is old news, that's why they stopped making them. You can get the hybrid version for the same price tag.

Poorly designed, cheap quality. Stitching on these seats are coming apart. Dashboard rattle sounds from all this plastic garbage. Body is a tin can, and you call this car a off-road vehicle. This car is gutless, lacking performance. Plastic pieces around the body. Stereo system is cheap. Over priced pile of junk. No wonder why the resale value is terrible.

You can buy a new electric suv, or a car for the same price as a gasoline subaru. Gasoline vehicles are taking a huge resale value hit. This crosstrek car is going down. Only vehicle that is holding it's value are trucks. Sorry to Subaru, they are finished no more gas vehicles 2025.

WOW!! Talk about a vehicle that is not worth buying. It's these Crosstrek cars. Resale value is very bad, transmission sucks. Engine loves to burn it's oil. Uncomfortable seats, and the hatchback is weird. Rattle sounds from all this plastic pieces in the interior. Terrible gas mileage. It's expensive for maintenance cost.

Not very good in the snow, and it's fuel mileage. Value depreciation rate drops fast. Don't be fooled by these crooks trying to sell this car over priced, especially pre-owned. Interior is full of rattling sounds. Road noise gets annoying on hwy driving. Reliability is not that good due to oil consumption. Transmission is not impressive, hard shifting.

Subaru was not on my list when I decided to purchase a new car.  I decided I wanted a car that is reliable, has leg room for my taller height, easy getting in and out (knees), long list of features, and a good price.  The Wilderness Forester and Outback seemed to check all the boxes.  I went with the Wilderness Forester because of the engine (lack of a turbo also on my list - bad experiences in the past).  The acceleration isn’t top end, but it’s more than adequate.  Being able to beat the car next to me off the line wasn’t high up on my checklist.  If they had a larger engine as an option, I’d have gotten it.  That said, other than the space for the cell phone being too small, I have absolutely no complaints about this vehicle.  I’m a new fan!

Just got it two months ago, and I noticed there are issues already. 
1. Unintended acceleration is always an issue with Subaru, I had a 2018 Forester but didn't have this issue until drove it for a few years. However, the 2024 Forester I just got, has this issue after two months of driving.
2. My screen doesn't automatically go to dark mode anymore, and the dealer told me to adjust it manually, but now my manual control to dim down the dashboard light doesn't work anymore. 
3. Remote start doesn't work with the key based on the instruction provided, it only works with the remote start fob

After a routine oil change, I was told that there was a need to reseal the right side cam tower.  The mechanic explained that the sealant that was used in the original manufacture broke down.  Online forums indicate that this is happening to others.  The reseal is expensive (2K-3K).  The car has been great and I've done all my service through the dealer.  After just completing payments, I'm faced with a question to do the repair with no warrantee / guarantee or get rid of the car.

For those who wish to invest in a vehicle for longevity, practicality, and comfort, this is a great choice.
The main bad reviews from critics are the acceleration and looks. I find the look quite attractive as beauty is in the eye of the beholder. I put a good guard on and splash guards, looks even sharper now but it has the nostalgia look revamped into modern lines.
If you want to squeeze through traffic so bad you need to have a very fast acceleration…I guess look at the WRX or another sports car. I know there’s way too many people that shouldn’t be behind the wheel so I use caution or defensive driving, not needing more than this has.
Longevity….well, it’s been around and one of the longest kept brands by buyers for a reason. My grandparents in MN still have theirs with 300+k on it to tote around town and a newer one for long distance.
Comfort in this is excellent for me. I have back issues and shoulder issues, this cradles me (6’ 200lb) with ample head and leg room. Not to mention plenty of room still for my three kids in the back. A baby seat, 7yr old, and 11yr old.
Technology in it is very attractive along with lane departure, blind spot, frontal impact detection, and is even kind enough to let those not paying attention that the car in front of you has moved….and to check your back seat before you get out….

The Subaru Forester is the third Subaru owned by our family.  Beginning with the Subaru Baja, then the Subaru Crosstrek, and now the Subaru Forester, all three have been excellent family vehicles.  Thanks to Subaru for developing such reliable and beautiful family vehicles!

This is by far the best vehicle I have ever purchased. The safety features are incredible with its automatic stop in the front and rear of the car. The steer assist is pretty good given the price point you're paying for it. The only thing I cannot stand is the horn. Overall amazing vehicle that will hold its value well over time you won't regret buying it.
Never a problem.  Vehicle has a been great, we don't drive it much, just to local stores.  This is my second Subaru lease.
I added fog lights, hitch, tints, rain guards, bumper guard, cross bars, privacy screen and mat for cargo area. Rubber mats used since day 1 so original rugs are in great shape.

Purchased a 2017 Forester in July 2016 and my wife loves it. I find the seats - front and rear to be comfortable. It has a cd player/AM FM radio and the sound system is ok. Acceleration from stopped is ok but from 30-60 is awful. CVT is ok - not smooth like a CRV. Maintenance costs are reasonable and mpg is as published. We did not get any of the safety alarm options so the ride is quiet and annoyance free. It’s a keeper!

Near Everything's good about this car. Gas mileage, looks, features, acceleration, not having tons of repairs.  The cvt engine is a pro but makes it louder on start up and the interior defog is funny. I have to change it around to defog the inside windows. No complaints here. I'd buy one again and definitely recommend it for its reliability.
Not leather. Had this one for 3 years from Canada Drives. Not bad of a car but check out the recalls.

I'm so pleased with my Forester. It is almost unable to be wrecked with its side mirrors showing approaching vehicles, automatic stopping when your speed is higher than your capability to not hit the vehicle in front of you as it slows or stops, & with the great visibility & warning sound when you are backing out with a car coming from the sides. I absolutely love it!!!!

Bought our 2015 brand new, wife had wanted one for a long time. Around 50,000 miles it started burning oil. Took it to the dealer and they did several "oil consumption tests" and determined that the amount of oil burned was "within their limits". Now at 133k miles we are adding 2 qts of oil between changes and of course the engine is out of warranty. I drive a 24 year old Ford Ranger that burns zero oil. Subaru of America was no help at all. This year alone we have spent upwards of 5K dollars for repairs including both rear wheel bearings, the transmission valve body, and others. Stay away from any Forester in this year range. We bought 2 Subarus, our first and last.

I love my Subaru! The Forester has amazing visibility, handles well, is reliable, and fun to drive. I’ve put almost 100,000 miles on this car already and I expect it will keep going strong for several 100,000 more miles. I’m sold and will never buy anything but another Subaru.

When I bought this car new in 2014, I knew it would not handle, accelerate, or be as comfortable as a BMW or Lexus.  It doesn't,  but it does what it is supposed to without complaining.  Basically, this car doesn't call attention to itself in a good or bad way and that is what you expect out of a car that has all wheel drive and cost only $25,000 when new.  I did all maintenance and repairs myself.  Oil changed every 5000 miles and now shows full at each change--burns no oil.  Used about 1 pint of coolant in 95,000 miles.  Changed filters and spark plugs per the manual.  Transmission is perfect--never changed the fluid.  Needed a battery at two years old.  Has needed front brakes done twice and rear's three times--kind of excessive, but about right for Subarus.  Only non-regular repairs needed were two rear brake light bulbs and two rear wheel bearing replacements needed at 95,000 miles.  Wheel bearings are tough for driveway mechanic in rustbelt car.  Subaru did not design the wheel bearing/hub assembly for easy replacement in rustbelt car.  If you test drive one of these and hear anything like a rumble, it is probably wheel bearings and have it checked out.  They are expensive to replace unless you do them yourself.

The car has just OK brakes, just fast enough acceleration, and the power driver's seat is not particularly comfortable, but the car is perfect for the price we paid.

This car has had only one owner.  It is in excellent condition.   We have maintenance records, the tires are approximately 1 year old and we love the car.  We are just looking to purchase a 2023 model.  This is a great family car.

I went with the base model. This car surprised me with its price point but it didn't skip out on the features the subaru eyesight technology came standard allowing me to use my cruise controll without constantly adjusting it for the driver in front of me and it can also steer itself to a certain degree. My commute is mostly highway and I average 32.7 mpg although I accelerate slowly and drive to intentionally increase my fuel economy. I find the interior surprisingly quite coming from a full sized sedan. Not like dead quiet but there's hardly any engine noise if any at all when maintaining speed some wind noise and road noise. Seats are comfortable you can get heated if that's your thing but I pinched a penny there instead. It's been a really good commuter car for me and the fuel tank is surprisingly large too for its size. Super practical and affordable. If you're in a snowy area and looking for a good economy car test drive one of these for sure!
Good car, comfortable, no accidents or body work.Easy to park. Good trunk space for transporting loads. All weather, 4 wheel drive.

I bought this car new because it is just like one that had just been totaled by a large truck while I was sitting in it at a stoplight.  I say the car is sturdy because I was not hurt or sore afterwards.

It has leather seats which are stain-resistant, look great, & are easy to keep clean.  This is important because I often eat in my car.

It has five doors including the hatchback.  I find it easy to load groceries or luggage through the hatchback.  

The driver's seat reclines so that it is almost horizontal.  This feature makes it easy to take a nap at rest stops.

The rearview mirror has a compass that I rely on in places where the street signs are hard to read.

The exterior of my Impreza is white but it never looks dirty unless it is wintertime & our streets are full of slush & salt.  When that happens, I pull in the $2.00 do-it-yourself neighborhood carwashd & rinse it off.

The backseat is comfortable for adults.  I am a loyal Subaru Impreza fan.

Original owner of a 2017 Sport trim hatchback model. Currently has 63k miles, original factory brakes still have plenty of life left (I personally checked the pads and rotors during my 60k mile oil change). Factory tires last 60k miles, battery lasted about 4 years which is typical for a factory battery and I replaced that myself.

I don't drive my car hard or brake hard, I'm pretty gentle on braking and brake early, which is why I think my brakes are lasting longer. I suspect the pads and rotors will get me to 90k miles at this rate.

Subaru has been very diligent about recalls which I appreciate.

Only concern I have is the long term reliability of the engine because it is a direct injection fuel system. Time will tell if these engines end up suffering from excess carbon buildup on the intake valves. For now though, my car has been a solid daily driver and a good investment.

The car was great in bad weather but the windows go up and down and will not stay shut the service said “you smoke” so he sprayed silicone and resolved issue the radio goes on each time one starts the car and hard to turn off the battery went and it had 36,600 miles something drIng battery oh they made me pay 224 for a new one warranty was up it’s been doing this since 3 moths I have extended warranty and my phone looses calls calls random numbers ect and beeps all the time they r giving me a conmplemtary update and they said “u may need a new radio what beeps is the radio ant get the cruise to work  lemon
I bought the car new. Love the ride and comfort. Plenty of room. Feels very safe. Had a few close mishaps handled beautifully.

I love my Subaru it truly is the best car I’ve ever owned and I’m 70 years old. I haven’t had any problems with it at all after 5 years. It rides well looks sharp and the safety features are top notch. I may never buy another car.

After almost six years of ownership, my 2017 Impreza Sedan limited has lived up to Subaru's reputation: solid, comfortable, reliable, safe, and fuel-efficient. The sedan is a bit quieter than the hatch, and my particular trim came with the upgraded sound, leather, cornering headlights, and other safety features and bells and whistles that give it a fully premium feel. So it doesn't feel like an econo-box, even if the engine can be a bit noisy under hard acceleration. 

Power is more than adequate (but not a racer), CVT transmission responsive is not rubber-bandy at all, and body integrity, interior,and mechanical systems have all remained trouble-free. I get about 38 mpg highway and 30 in mixed driving. The all wheel drive has been handy several times during winter storms. Trunk space is good, and passengers find the car quite comfortable.

There were a few minor software updates and one hose recall in the first couple of years, but they were easy fixes. The '17s got a bad rap for those initial hiccups with the new model, but I think these all got ironed out for most owners in those early days.

I'm very happy I took the jump over to Subaru after years of VWs and Audis (which required significantly more maintenance and TLC as they aged, not to mention $$$). The Impreza Limited may not be a German car, but it handles great, is well built, and has many similar small thoughtful touches that tend to earn owners' affection over the years.

This car is a gas mileage sweetheart. I get an average of 34mpg, driving in a mix hilly highways and city. The eyesight and blind spot features have saved me from several accidents in the past 5 years. It is also nimble and steady on slushy roads. I would definitely recommend this car for college students on a tight budget.

Great job Subaru has done with this vehicle, can’t think of anything negative about it and I will continue to enjoy all that the XT Touring 2.4L Turbo has to offer a driver of all types. Only thing that I’m going to do is, swap out the courtesy door lights for the Subaru logo projection lights, they just look really cool.
Perfect condition. Driven very little. Clean with all the technology features. Adaptive cruise control.

I bought this car at the peak of covid as the dealer was really helpful with purchasing. I got the 2022 Legacy Limited 2.5 non turbo. Overall comfortable and great in snow. Commuting is frustrating sometimes as passing and merging power severely lacks. Technology is hit and miss, recently have been having a lot of issues with lagging/ some features not responding great. I am likely going to sell once the warranty is up due to the technology issues.

Everything is showroom perfect.
Am on Oxygen and can no longer drive.. Paid 35,500, and would accept 34,500.
You can purchase from me for $34,500. No extended wait.
Serious offers only.
I should preface this review by saying that I am no car guru-superstar, my knowledge on vehicles only stretches so far
economical around town

KBB says car not best looker. Strongly disagree. I think it is one of the best-looking cars on the market. For my money, the car ticks all the boxes, with reliability at the top of the list. I'm a bit concerned about the noisy engine but impressed by all other aspects. The car is a bit more expensive than the competition, but worth it in the long run.

I traded in a 2016 Buick Regal Turbo that was more fun to drive, a bit of a sporty feeling, which the Legacy is not. The standard engine seems to almost protest as you accelerate. However being 84 and with some eyesight issues, I am glad for all the safety features on the Legacy, including blind spot detection and rear cross traffic alert. So far the average miles per gallon with mostly city driving is less than I hoped for. But it is not bad looking, and I prefer it to the Crosstrek, Outback and Forester.
Why would most of us need something more than a, handsome, I've said it, sedan.

2015 Purchased new…in a past life I owned an MB SEL and my Legacy with Leather/Wood Grain option gave me the Luxury ride I wanted at a price range I could afford. Never a problem, lovingly maintained…but due to high mileage I am now forced to look for a new car :(  Legacy 2024/2025 here I come again :)
