My 2 grandchildren love my car . They both passed driver test first time.  It has 28,000
miles since I use it locally.  There are no scars and it has New tires at 25,000 miles
its Gray immaculate interior.
REALLY ENJOYED THIS CAR.   IT WAS RELIABLE, GREAT IN SNOW, AND ROOMY.  MY SUBARU IS EXCELLENT ON GAS MILEAGE, 4 CYLINDER.   LOVED MY HEATED SEATS ON COLD MORNINGS.  MY BEST CAR SO FAR.

My 2016 Subaru Legacy 3.6R has served me well for over 6 years now. The car is reliable, attractive, intuitive, and quick. The flat 6 engine does great with low end torque and speed. My legacy has never given me any problems, and is a very safe option for me  with its symmetrical AWD since I live in a snowy climate. The 2016 Legacy 3.6R isnt going to win any medals for anything. But for the price I payed, it does everything above average for a car of its class. All the gadgets you could want too. An easy to use navigation system paired with the 500+ Watt Hardom Kardon gives a stellar car non experience. Would highly recommend the vehicle still even 6 years later!
This car is so hard to handle, especially on the highway. The ride is very bumpy and LOUD. It doesn’t feel safe to drive when it wanders at high speeds. Cant wait to get rid of it.
Is a reliable and comfortable car.  I have been very satisfied with it and it is fun to drive.  I buy nothing but Subaru.
I would get another one.  Suburbs are great cars.  This will not be my last.''xxxx'xxxccccccxxxxxxxx

I had a 2010 Sub Outback for 9 years; minimal issues. Traded in for a 2019 Crosstrek and hated it; thought I'd go smaller to save some $$ on gas; but the gas mileage was worse than on my Outback; so traded it in for 2022 Outback Onyx XT.  Great power (at times) and fun to drive but many frustrating 'things' with it that finally drove me out of the Subaru family.  The windshield  was very noisy from the first day it "popped" and sounded like invisible bugs were hitting it. I brought it back to the dealer numerous times, even with a video of the noise (in which they refused to watch) and basically told me I was imagining things.  The large screen was great...until the sun was out.  It blinded me at times with the reflection.  The power was great...but not consistent.  Sometimes, I'd hit the gas and vroom vroom!  Other times, I'd hit the gas, get a stutter, a shrug and then vroom, vroom! Scary, not knowing how the car would respond....The auto shut off is a joke.  It would only stay off for a max of 30 seconds (no matter how hard or soft I pressed the brake pedal). Then the car shuttered to a start.  The auto brake was a bit too sensitive at times and nearly caused accidents at times. I have a sharp turn on way to my house and it would apply the brakes if I caught the turn at the appropriate angle and the car "saw" the tree on side. The seat belt reminder was beyond ridiculous.  If something or someone heavy was on the back seat, the car required a seatbelt.  The alarm hijacks the radio, the maps, the phone until the seat belt is clicked.  The final straw was the road noise became unbearable.  I was told my tires were cupping (yes, I had tires rotated and aligned religiously). They noise was dampened a tad after the  tech did a minor alignment, but not enough to keep it quiet enough to have a hands-free phone conversation.  Sad, because I really anticipated being a Subie owner for life.

This car was bad buy. Mechanically the car is solid. The electrical safety systems have given us driving issues. First lane departure is very hit or miss even after dealer calibration. Second the auto breaking system will engage when shadows on the road are detected.  This has caused unnecessary break wear.. third the seats are very uncomfortable for me.. smaller sized drivers may not have This issue.. if we would test drove this car it would not have been purchased.

this car been back to the dealer several times in 6 months of ownership. The car bucks while under acceleration. they say they cant fix it. the car has a backup alarm that goes off whenever it wants. the car gets terrible gas mileage averages 22 mpg with careful driving. I’m my second set of front seats the extra cost leather that needs to be replaced again.   I contacted their corp office several times but you have to get past the gatekeeper who will sandbag you and hope you go away. after five calls i was told it would be passed along to the next level ? HUH.  what a bad dream !!

We have a 2021 Outback Premium, nice solid car. A very nice ride and the base engine does have decent power. Having sain that you will never see anything remotely close to the EPA gas mileage. We get about 21 over the past 3 years. My Father in Law gets about the same in his Forrester

I bought my first Subaru in November (brand new Subaru Outback 2024). Until now I drove Honda and Mazda.
The true fuel economy is MUCH lower than what Subaru lists for this model which is 26-32 MPG. My MPG is 21.6 (in the suburbs not even "city") to 23.7 (highway commute). This is very disappointing. I took into consideration: my style of driving (I don't speed), the terrain here is rather flat, this winter is very mild, I don't use remote start function. The dealership says "this is normal". If this is "normal" then why provide 26MPG - 32MPG in ads? 
Other issues: the screen flickers once in a while, the radio comes on blasting (by itself!) at least once a day. The dealership doesn't see the problem. 
I drive a lot daily, which I shared with the salesman, but he confirmed the fuel economy range of  26 - 32 MPG. Now I know this wasn't true.

We recently retired and purchased a 2024 Outback Premium and love it! It’s got all the “bells & whistles” we need, plus the safety and reliability of a Subaru. We like to drive up to Lake Tahoe a lot and appreciate the AWD and “X Mode” for slippery driving conditions.

This is a perfect car except for three things. One, I find the seats uncomfortable for long trips. Two, the window up and down buttons are sticky and in very cold, frosty or wet weather if I put the window down it barely goes up and several times it wouldn't go up without heating the car up from the inside. Three, on the 12 inch touch screen, some of the regularly used buttons like the fan button are too small and I have to take my eyes off the road briefly to hit them just right. Gas milage is superb. I average 30 to 32 MPG and get 38 to 40 MPG on long trips. Overall a great car.

Except for the awful infotainment system, it is a great car in every aspect.  BUT, the infotainment system robs all joy from driving.  For example, driving behind a polluting belching dump truck and want to change the air circulation?  It would take numerous screens to even find the right button, and by that time it reverted back to home screen.  Try again, and again, find the right button, press it half a dozen times while driving 50-60 mph and you find Subaru is a major safety hazard.  Sometimes infotainment system just shuts down, goes to sleep, and later awakens, although good luck trying to find the music you were playing.  Their map gps is a joke.  I must have a Garmen on the dash and never use their maps.  An A+ car with a F- brain.
2.5 base with added mag wheels,fog lights, mud flaps,door mouldings 1 owner newer tires original steel wheels with studded tires

I’ve had this car for seven years.  And, my wife has had a Forrester for a little over 10 years.  You know that time the only thing we’ve done is the normal maintenance and replace a couple of tires necessitated by the terrible New Orleans streets ;-(. — not the cars’ fault.   Both are a pleasure to drive, much like my two favorite cars of all time: 1957 Ford convertible with air-conditioning and leather seats and a 1966 Chevrolet Impala two-door.  But believe me, those cars were maintenance heavy.  But I loved them.  
I have the next to the top model. It was about four years old before I stopped finding new buttons to push to accomplish things.  
I’m an old dude and have been told I no longer can drive ;-(   So sadly, I’m going to have to give up the Subaru Outback ;-(  thank goodness for my wife’s Subaru Forester.  It’s a 2014,  but it still looks like it’s maybe 2 to 3 years old.  And it runs like new.  of course we’ve had both cars maintained by Subaru according to the recommended schedule.  It’s the first time we’ve done that, but only the second and third car that we’ve ever purchased new.  And we definitely have a great service writer.  
I strongly recommend Subaru.  I also recommend to shop online.  I saved several thousand dollars by doing that when I purchased mine.  I wish I had done that when I purchased my wife’s!
If you can grin and bear it, I recommend having your Subaru serviced at a Subaru dealer if it is new, relatively new, or full of high-Tech features that a Local mechanic or national tire store might not know how to handle.
Good luck.

Smooth ride, 6 cylinder engine is more than enough power, I was discovering new buttons & features for 4-5 years.  Other than my ‘65 Mustang Convertible which was my most fun car, this was my most favorite car.  Have had it for about 8 yrs & other than 2 factory recalls, all I’ve done is normal maintenance.  Great buy.

after about 20,000 miles my 2015 outback started using oil (not burning) every 1,200 mile like clockwork.   Subaru said that was in an aceptable range and wouldn't do anything about it.  Now with 121,000 miles and many added quarts of oil it is still running good and using 1 quart of oil every 1,200 miles. I have the 2.5 engine.
I would absolutely give this vehicle a 5 star rating it is ever bit worth the price great milage, comfortable for bigger people like myself  280lbs alot of room and quiet ride
Bought this 2016 outback new in my early 60's and is the best car I have ever owned. I find it hard to state how much I love my CAR and will never be without one in my garage!

One of the best luxurious wagon SUVs out there, I’ve owned this car for a while. This Subaru is very fast and reliable, this car gives the driver and passengers a smooth ride, you don’t even notice the car is running. Rear seats are very comfortable with very high quality leather and interior parts 
It’s like an SUV Toyota Avalon in the rear seats. Trunk has a lot of space can fit 4 suitcases and 2 small ones comfortably. The only thing I dislike of this car is that I get bad gas mileage 18 mpg in the city and 19 in the highway the best mpg is like 24. I recommend this car to anyone

I looked to purchase a Subaru for our kids to drive because of all the safety features, well is it safe to have your car battery go dead every two days if it isn’t driven while your child is away at college?  Is it safe to park your car in an airport garage for four days and return to a dead battery late at night and have to wait for help.  NO- Do not purchase those Subarus with a class action law suite against it that only offers an extended warranty as their booby prize.

Gasoline vehicle's, terrible fuel mileage for even being new. These do not hold there value reputation. Cheaply made cars, not worth buying. I, traded in this car after the first year of ownership. Seats are not comfortable on long road trips. Lacking on safety technology. Overpriced car's, I do not recommend them. Same price tag, you can buy a AWD SUV or even a ford ranger truck. And the resale value holds better up from KBB, along with JD power.

Among performance cars, on a scale from 1 to 10, today’s WRX holds its head up proudly at a solid 9. If you’re old enough to remember the age before pollution controls and safety features, you won’t argue with me when I cite the 1971 Ferrari 365 GTB/4 as a 10 (“Relaxed at 140, undemanding at 150…controllable at 193…but acceleration tends to fall off after 155,” according to the contemporary Road & Track article). Back to the WRX, I hadn’t passed the break-in period at the time I started writing (see below), and the manual advises short shifting at 4000 until that point. I’ve been observing 3,000, because the WRX is turbocharged and boost comes on strongly a little above 3,000 so that stopping the acceleration precisely at 4,000 is a challenge. So, I didn’t experience the full performance of the car at first. Nevertheless, its capabilities are obviously huge, triggering a flood of cliches from the sports cars of the 60’s-70’s. “Corners as if on rails…steering direct and linear up to speeds where I don’t want to find out if it understeers, oversteers, or just slides sideways at the limit…glued to the pavement.” There’s no body roll, no squeal from the tires, and acceleration even in top gear is pleasantly lively through 55, without ever exceeding 3,000 on the tachometer.
When we consider that this “old fashioned” performance comes in a 4-door sedan with comfortable accommodations (at least in front) for a tall driver, yet, unlike BMW sedans at the time I bought mine, you can get it with a manual transmission, I hardly think the basic design could be improved. The seats are firmly bolstered; the designers obviously thought hard cornering would be happening a lot of the time, and so it should! The WRX is a Gran Turismo, though, not a sports car, as befits something with 4 doors and a useful back seat. Its cabin is fairly quiet and you won’t be pulled over because the exhaust is making such a racket that you’re making cows miscarry. (You might be pulled over because you’re going 80 in a 35 mile zone but that’s your own fault). Now let’s mention ride…another 60’s cliché comes unbidden to my computer: “if you run over a coin, you can tell if it’s a dime or a quarter.” The ride is tightly snubbed and very hard. For a GT, I question whether this is necessary. A similar odd decision from the designers is to deliver the car with summer-only high performance tires. To their credit, the dealer suggested I buy all season tires because this would have to be my only car, a daily driver, I can’t afford a sports car that I would take out only on nice days with another car getting the groceries. There are high performance, all season tires these days, and that’s what it’s riding on now. They cost $1000. Hard to imagine how summer-only tires could be better. The all weather tires should be a factory option for those who don’t have space to store the summer tires.
On the other hand, it’s no longer 1968. Some things are better but others aren’t as good as in the old days. The transmission has 6 forward speeds, which means it’s often not obvious with the optional “short-throw” shifter what gear it’s in. The manufacturer gave us a dashboard indicator to tell you that, but it’s low on the panel where it’s partly obscured by the steering wheel hub unless you adjust the tilt wheel and seat height carefully. (On the other hand it’s good there are many adjustments, unlike the sports cars of the 60’s). Worse, the indicator doesn’t show anything until you let in the clutch, when it’s too late to correct having selected the wrong gate. I understand why this is: it’s a “smart” manual transmission that won’t let you start the engine till you’ve floored the clutch, and the indicator evidently takes its signal from the same source so it can’t show you anything till the transmission “knows” it’s in gear. Furthermore, the movement of the shifter is a little unnatural in the top two gears with a deliberate sideways push necessary to get 6th when shifting up from 3rd, instead of 4th, and if you’re trying to downshift to 5th, the synchromesh wants to give you 3rd. Fortunately it’s a close ratio transmission so you won’t cause much trouble by getting 4th instead of 6th. Finally, like most post-1975 cars, the brake and accelerator pedals are placed at different levels and too far apart for heel-and-toe downshifts while braking. This is the unhappy result of a series of “unintended acceleration” incidents with automatic transmissions in the 70’s, and the decline of manual transmissions so that special pedal geometries for the latter are no longer practical from an industrial engineering point of view. Alas, my geriatric ankles are no longer up to the maneuvers necessary to double clutch while decelerating with this pedal geometry. The collar on the shifter you have to pull up on to engage reverse is another modern “idiot proof” feature but I think it's helpful – with the sideways push you need to engage 6th it would be truly a disaster if you got reverse instead and the gates are really close.
Moving on to more general interest items, shame on you, Subaru, for not giving us a boost gauge! I know where it should go, at the top of the panel between the analog gauges where the “mpg gauge” is now. I think the “mpg gauge” might actually be a vacuum gauge, so maybe it shows boost, but a direct calibration is necessary for any turbocharged engine. No one driving this kind of car cares about fuel consumption enough to look at the “mpg gauge.” There’s also a “cumulative mpg” readout that seems to be applied when you reset the trip odometer. This is somewhat useful and shows I’m getting about 28 mpg on the average, 31 highway, which for this lively a car is great! (Although, it’s premium fuel so it’s more expensive per gallon than most cars need). 
Then there are less important quirks. The turn signals, although there’s a stalk where you expect, are electronic with no detents. This makes you wonder if the signal has been engaged, making you look at the flasher on the dashboard to be sure the signal is on. Signaling a lane change is particularly clumsy. The high beams are “smart” – they turn themselves off when they detect an oncoming car, back on when it goes by, and keep them off when you slow down to 25 mph going into town. While this is useful, on principle I don’t think a GT should be “smarter” than its driver. Mercifully, the lane departure warning and other irritating alarms I’ve put up with on recent cars have been left off the base model I selected. The WRX is available with the continually variable transmission (CVT) that is used on many other Subarus, including my previous car, an Impreza. I think a CVT is a very sensible match for a turbo engine that has relatively low torque at low RPM’s, so if you’d rather not shift it yourself, you could rationalize that it’s probably faster with the CVT. Old timers like me often think their automatic is in the wrong gear so a manual transmission is essential. Then there’s the trunk release…the Impreza had a button on the outside while the WRX requires that you trigger the trunk release either from the dash or with your “smart” key fob. I prefer the button on the back of the car. And don’t get me started on the seat belt alarm! It’s a loud chime that becomes twice as loud if you ignore it for 10 seconds. And the low tire pressure warning still doesn’t tell you which tire is low or whether it’s so low you have to pull over.
The HVAC system has its own quirks. It has a thermostat so you dial in the temperature you want. This system has been available since 1990 to my certain knowledge, but it’s an example of “why-tech” rather than “high tech” (with apologies to Road & Track, which produced an article with that title). If you get into the WRX and it’s below freezing outside, you’ll discover quickly that the thermostat’s lowest setting is 60. That results in hot air pouring out of the heater. You then have to pull over and take off your outer layer, or turn the heater off. There’s no analog lever you can open just slightly so you’re still comfortable in your winter clothes. Air conditioning seems to work better.
But, the downside things are mostly nits. The WRX is an excellent GT.
After Break-in: Yep, it’s fast! Taking the engine to 5,000 results in the scenery behind shrinking rapidly with a satisfying pressure against your back. However, it’s not an abrupt surge of boost, another reason there should be a boost gauge. Turbo lag is there but it’s subtle. Acceleration off the line is nothing special. If you’re old enough to remember a V-8 with 4-speed, you’ll miss the need to back off on the throttle to keep wheelspin under control. In fact, with power going to all 4 wheels, it’s hard to get wheelspin regardless of technique. But in the midrange there’s a satisfying surge of thrust limited only by the redline that approaches with remarkable speed to the accompaniment of a subdued burble from the exhaust. Full throttle acceleration through the gears shows another quirk – a noticeable squat as each gear “hooks up” with the turbocharger. Possibly this is why such a hard suspension is necessary? The American solution would be a longer wheelbase but that would be a weight penalty and the car is big enough.
Bottom line is the WRX is an excellent GT! I’ve taken a 200 mile road trip in it and while it’s not a 60’s sports car, it gives you a combination of comfort and performance that is as entertaining as anything available today. If you like going fast, the WRX is for you!

Love the way it handles and drives. Sounds awesome even with the stock exhaust. You can hear it inside the house during cold starts, so awesome! I don’t think there is another car that compares in this price range. The AWD system is great and has no issues.

I was in the market for a new manual transmission car that I can enjoy driving to work and use for the family and kids.  The WRX won my heart over the Elantra N, VW GLI, Integra and Civic R type. 
Extremely fun to drive, great value, safe for the family and definitely put a smile on my face.  The gas mileage isn't the greatest but it's AWD and great for the snow days or track days.   My weekend car is the new M4 and I have to admit the WRX is just as enjoyable to drive.  The upgraded exhaust sounds great, the handling is amazing and the new 2.4 L engine has a lot of room should you need to increase the power.  The resale value is good so don't hesitate to buy one if you are in the market for a sports sedan.

Sporty, responsive and very fun to drive. If you are looking for a gas saver, then this is NOT the car for you. This car is for someone interested in feeling the road and handling every turn with precision! Such a joy to shift and hear the Boxer engine and cruise, in my opinion.

"A jack of all trades is a master of non, but often times better than a master of one" This is true for the 2022 WRX. The engine produces pretty good horsepower, excellent handling, comfortable seats and actual usable back seats for the adults and good space in the trunk, enough technology, good price and has good resale value. I dig the looks and the functional functional plastic surroundings of the car (not exaggerating). My premium manual trim cost $33k which I feel is a very good deal for what the car comes with. My brother had a 2017 WRX Premium and upgraded to a 2021 STI and both I've test drove, but the tuning of the 2022, in all areas (engine and suspensions), is just better. Are there any other car brand/model that'll offer what the WRX can (270hp, AWD) starting at $30k? Probably not. No, it's not as fast as the Elantra N, or has the gas efficiency of a Civic SI, but if you are looking for sporty, practical, and fun sedan, this 2022 WRX is a wonderful bang for the buck car!

I just got this car yesterday, and let me tell you this. You will never find another car with the same price, for the same performance and same feature, period. If you want to find your driving desire, this is the car for you. I owned over 10 cars, this car drives like a dream. I tried my friend's 180K 911 GTS, but this WRX, drives much fun than my friend's 911 GTS.

I wanted the STI unfortunately, this world is going to s#!  with Electric cars don’t get me wrong it’s whatever you want,but keep some gas or diesel vehicle around for those who want it. Anyway I absolutely love the WRX new motor and platform it’s built upon I always want to go out and drive it like a kid just smiling and glad for this one to be staying with us for little longer anyway it’s an amazing car so far only thing I noticed is on highway when go to do a hard pull up to 4-5 rpm I get a vibration but otherwise it’s a yes to saying get one and enjoy

This car is great and I plan on driving it until it wont let me.  I am a WRX slappy going all the way back to my 2002.  I drove it for all 240k and it still had the original clutch and turbo when I sold it.  I'm 53 yrs old and can say  WRX's are the best cars i have ever owned.   If in a winter area I recommend snow tires. 
Pro's: Fun, Reliable, 30+MPG Highway; Roomy for a small car; just looks cool; Holds Value.
Cons: Steering Wheel Volume button is touchy and can easily skip to the next chapter or song; Air Conditioning seems to struggle when over 95.
Once in the winter and once when someone ran a red light. It’s almost like the car listens to your brain. The steering is quick and turn radius is ridiculous. I love this car.

I have a 2020 WRX STI and I LOVE IT! The only issues I have is I wish they would have made it a little faster from the factor or able to handle more power with a stock engine for aftermarket modding. There is a HUGE modding community that really turns up the power o these cars. On the stock block (Type RA) you can safely get 400whp. Anything higher than that you will need a forged Aluminum block. Also next issue is if you don’t have the  next model up from base with Harmon and Kardon speakers you are going to most definitely want a new stereo. It’s like a dollar store stereo in the base model and that’s another $1500 investment for a good one with a new head unit because the stock one sucks. Anyways If you want power and the ability to drive year round with no issues then the WRX STI is going to be IT. Also now other tuner car sounds like the flat four with unequal length headers! It’s amazing once you get an exhaust put on!!

PROS: 
It's fun to drive - the power (with aftermarket), those sounds, the acceleration, every thing you want inside an AWD, sport sedan vehicle. 
I like the VA's interior (cabin) and exterior (aggressive look), something premium.
Its 0-60mph.

CONS: MPG, Maintenance
Handles great, super fun to drive. The awd makes steep hills and bends in the road a breeze. Super customizable for aftermarket beginners. (Do research) and have fun!

I have purchased numerous cars from the Lexus IS 200t,VW Jetta GLI, Honda Accord Touring 2.0t
4runner, Tacoma, Tundra, Audi A3, Civis SI in the last 6 yrs. No other car has been as fun to drive as the WRX. It's handling is second to none on the list of cars I've bought. The torque is amazing for a car under 36k. Simply a blast to drive. Cornering on this car is beyond ones imagination. I have 5ok on my WRX and not one issue. The growl of the engine will put a smile on your face and the manual tranny is my preference. The passing capabilities of this car is pure confidence.
Very fun car enjoy every moment of it best car I’ve ever owned excellent in the snow and rain. Very awesome car Subaru did a great job making it.

I've had no lack of thrills in my time owning my manual 2021 WRX, but there are some caveats that come with the fun. The style and interior quality of Subaru's are not at luxurious as some offerings by say Mazda or Lexus, but the quality of the parts but in all feel tactile, notchy, and solid. Doors shut affirmatively, and nothing rattles, shakes, or squeaks. A lot of leg room in the back seat, easily drive 5 around comfortably, however it kills the performance of the car (as expected). The only negative note is the small center tray for phones. any phone taller than 6" will not fit. When alone or with a passenger, you can experience the twin-scroll turbo putting you in the back of your seat at around 2500 RPMs, and the all wheel drive system to match it make this feel zippier than other offerings. But, here's were some problems start. The steering feels good, but the hydraulic steering in the STI certainly feels better, but it wont really affect most people and the daily drive. The clutch's bite point is VERY deep, considerably so from most other offerings. you almost have to "learn to drive" a WRX. Along with the gear shifter sometimes feeling like you're fighting the car, some people will look to other offerings like the Golf R, or a Focus RS. However, those come with problems of their own, and in terms of reliability and overall drivers experience the WRX wins for me. It's AWD system, snappy turbo, reliable block (when not making big power), and good build quality, its hard to ignore in todays market.

Last of the true Lotus drivers car, raw and ready.

2020~2021 were the only years the Lotus Evora GT was made and sold in the US market, it is like the best of the Evora series with all the best parts taken to make one super car!

coming for an Elise, this feels much the same but with more power and prowess.  The supercharges gives a constant linear feel, so you can count on the power when needed, no surging or ramping up, just always there and ready.

If you get a chance to own any series Evora you are lucky and if able get the GT!

Get this out of the way: I love this car. It's a joy to drive even in slow going.  It has been reliable, tight, and easy to live with.  Want something special without the pain and expense of owning and actually driving the average exotic?  This car is for you.

Very unique, great ride without being punishing, you'll stand out in the crowd of Porsche's and Corvettes.

Incredible steering feedback and a chassis that rivals any super-car.

Great car for weekend fun or occasional tracking.

I regret selling my evora so much. I had it for 4 years and literally didn't spend a dime outside regular maintenance. Even you get in the drivers seat of one it will be hard to drive any other car in the same price category

The Lotus Evora is one of the last hand made vehicles in the world. Lotus has a reputation of being a light performance car for the street and track.This car is the fastest Lotus yet 400 hp and 305 torque with a Toyota v-6 supercharged engine for reliability. This car drives better and handles better than my Porsche 911. It has also been more reliable than the 911 (electrical problems). The radio is not great in the Lotus but the navigation is accurate and I would much rather hear the sound of the engine. Lotus only makes a small amount of vehicles per year which also makes them special. I have had Porsches for 30 years and the Evora is better than the Porsche and more fun to drive due to not having computers take over or electric steering. Lotus still uses Hydraulic steering and gives instant drivers feedback.If you are looking for a true sports car that has handling, feedback and style then You will like the new Lotus. If you are looking for an executive car that is expensive to maintain then buy the Porsche.

I bought it used Base 67,000 miles. Paid $26000 with many upgrades over 13K in mods. Disappointed and regretted. I picked the Z over Corvette & Audi S3. Big time disappointed. This vehicle built for teenagers. Cheap seats, not comfort ride. In the process of selling.
Drives excellent this is not the most comfortable car but I love the engine and how the car drives, it’s very fast car and i love the way you can add custom things and looks much better.

I love my Z so much! I have the 40th anniversary manual and it’s so fast and sounds so nice when you do stuff to the exhaust. It’s very powerful! One of the only things that sucks for real is that if you wanna mod it or even replace things everything for this car is very expensive. Especially if you want good quality things for it. If you want some upgraded headlights and taillights (morimoto I believe) they’re like 2000 for both… just an example. I still love it and definitely recommend this car!!
I bought this car with 2000 miles on it.  It’s been an enjoyable ride for seven years and I couldn’t recommend it highly enough.   Pure joy

This car was nice at first, but it's just not for me. It's just a basic sports car, but nothing luxury. Seats are way stiff on long road trips. Hatchback space, forget it. Plus no spare tire, or even a tire repair kit. No safety technology of any kind in this car. They stopped making these car's three years ago in 2020. This is now the year 2023. Time to move on and find something newer and better.
Perfectly maintenanced car and in great/Perfect condition. I Nismo'd my car out, and it's nicer than ever. Brand-new tires. Michelin Pilot Sport all-season tires.

The car still runs like a beast; is very reliable and still turns heads, despite the reviews that say the body style is "outdated...".   With the top down it is still a very good-looking car. The downside: the dash is cracking prematurely despite being garaged.  Otherwise I would have given it a 5.

This car is awesome to drive and a joy to own. Nissan did an incredible job with performance and styling from the inside out. The interior is amazing with the Nismo badging, alcantara touches and Recaro seats. The Sync rev matching is just a joy to downshift and handling is as good as most 100k sports cars. As an owner of a GTR as well, the Nismo is just an entire different feel and much more track oriented. If you want an awesome Track/Sports car at a very reasonable price…Don’t miss your chance to own one!

I bought a 2021 Nissan Sentra and a 2021 Nissan Altima in April 2021. I had to have a brand new motor put in my 2021 Nissan Sentra in August 2023 with only having 13,000 miles on it. It was an hassle trying to get it replaced eventhough it is still under warranty. My 2021 Altima had to have transmission work done at 20,000 miles in August 2023. I only have 26,600 miles on the Altima now as of 02/26/24. My Sentra has 15,000 miles now as of 02/26/24 my mom drives the Sentra.

The 2020 Nissan Altima 2.5 SR (4D SEDAN) presents itself as a solid choice in the economy car segment, prioritizing practicality and affordability without compromising on essential features. One of its key selling points is its impressive fuel efficiency, making it an excellent option for those looking to save money on gas without sacrificing comfort and style.

While some reviews might criticize its performance, it's essential to understand that the Altima isn't marketed as a high-performance vehicle. Instead, it excels as a reliable daily driver, offering a smooth and comfortable ride suitable for city commutes and highway cruising.

Most trims come with front-wheel drive, which is standard for vehicles in this class. While this setup might not be ideal for harsh weather conditions like heavy snow, it's sufficient for typical driving scenarios. However, potential buyers in regions with severe winters should consider this limitation and plan accordingly.

Overall, the 2020 Nissan Altima 2.5 SR delivers on its promise as an economy car, providing excellent value for money, fuel efficiency, and practicality. For budget-conscious consumers seeking a reliable and comfortable sedan for their daily transportation needs, the Altima is undoubtedly worth considering

Nissan has not stood behind this major issue with their vehicles which are going into Limp mode when driving in the cold/snow.  My car has less than 18K miles and this has happened twice in 2 years and was towed to the dealer to have it reset.  I filed two complaints w/ Nissan customer relations as well as the dealer.  Both have denied helping with the issue.  Both times the sensor  was reset and they tell you the issue is fixed.  I live in the midwest and I do not have an option to not drive my car in cold/snowy weather even though this is a nationwide issue.  I hope anyone looking at Nissan will take time to google complaints as there are many talking about this happening due to the sensors in the front of the vehicles getting packed w/ snow and throwing the engine into failure.  When this happens it only allows the engine to go 5-15 miles an hours and your dash lights are flashing Eng.  This is a huge problem when your on the hwy in a snowstorm and have passengers in the back due to the speed is reduced down to just to find a safe spot to have your car towed to a dealer.  The worst part is Nissan  knows this is happening and the fear of it becoming a deadly issue, yet they refuse to acknowledge it.  I was told there will have to something such as a fatality before they will fix it from both the dealer and a customer relations representative.  This is my 3rd vehicle with Nissan in 30 years as I have been a loyal customer but there is no loyalty from this company in keep their customers happy and most importantly safe.  BUYER BEWARE!

Bought a 2024 Altima SV, I like the way the car handle but there's a couple of things that I don't care for. First thing is when I test drove the car It drove very good in the city but I took a road trip after I bought it and after an hour into the ride my legs started hurting and the seat started feeling very uncomfortable, I don't know if they made the seat shorter and not as wide but it was not a comfortable ride on the highway. The second thing is the last vehicle I purchased was in 2017 and the one feature that was a must for me was the CD player and this 2024 didn't come with one and I told my salesman had I known that I would not have purchase this car. Satellite radio is fine but it fades in and out at times and on the road I like listening to CD's.

I test drove other sedans but for the price I got mine brand new I wouldn’t be able to get a toyota for example. Who pays 40k for a sedan these days anyway? For 40k, get you a V8 sporty car tbh. Overall, love my leather seats and apple carplay. Keeping it for many years until the wheels fall off.

The seats are very comfortable, nice sound system, and plenty of storage spaces in the cab. It has great pick up and go, and handles very well. I think I'm going to keep this car for awhile. Highly recommend.

Had the Ariya for about six months now, after about three years with a Kia e-Niro 4+ as an intro to EV driving. It was fun but the newer version isn't, and the EV6 was big and clunky. The Ariya is a dream to drive in town and on long journeys. It is so much smoother, more comfortable and has better tech, plus chose the AWD Evolve version, so better stability and performance with added reassurance in the mud, wet, and of course occasional snow.

The Ariya is only a little bigger than the Niro and about 9cm taller but internal space is a world apart, as is just about everything else. 

There is more body roll in corners if you push it, but for an SUV that is to be expected.

Overall the only criticism I have is about the two screens, they are not Ultra HD, which is a shame, as that really would have placed this car in the pure luxury category.

2023 Nissan Frontier Pro X4 has exceed my expectations from my previous ten year ownership of three Chevy Silverados.  Yes, it's a midsize truck with less haul and payload. My RV trailer weighs 5,000 pounds and meets my needs in loading landscape and my building supplies in a 5 ft bed.

On gas, I'm saving money. On driving  comfort I'm loving it (5'11" and 223 pounds). Frontier has some get-up and go power and it very stable in turns and stopping under various road conditions. Everyone talks about heavy steering but I really don't feel a big difference, to me it's a truck.

Truck bed rail system is a big plus in changing tie downs loacation settings for moving furniture, refrigerators, and building projects.
Pro 4 Nissan frontier after owning Chevrolets Fords Dodge's is truly one of the best trucks I've ever owned highly underrated

I ran my 2011 Nissan Frontier SV king cab 6 speed manual 4x4 to over 200k miles until it finally starting giving me issues.  Figured my good luck w/ the Frontier would last into the 2022 model year.   I was mistaken.  In no particular order, my disappointments are;

- Sketchy technology.  Forward camera throws an error when driving into the sun.  Front radar will chime at what it thinks is an obstruction when there is nothing there.   A couple recalls to fix brake stop switch and a transmission issue as well. 
- While the truck is powerful, its woefully slow.  The 9 speed tranny does everything in its power to get to the 9th gear as quick as possible making it terribly unresponsive in city traffic.  I spend most of my drive just manually shifting it.  But, moving from one gear to the next is more like a suggestion to the truck rather than a command.  If it doesn't think it needs to shift, it won't.
- Lately it has decided to keep itself locked even after pushing the fob unlock.  Or, it gets stuck somewhere in between lock and unlock and wont release the door.  Climbing in thru the passenger side and operating driver door from there has fixed it up to now.  
-  There are areas of the body, especially around the engine bay where there is little to no paint.  
-  The intelligent cruise control is 'nervous' to say the least.  I can set it at highway speeds and it will work correctly, but, introduce a slight hill into the mix where the speed reduces by just a couple MPH and the system will jam the gas trying to get it back up to speed.  Only to be followed by a braking action to reduce it.   Even using the system as a normal CC has the same issue.  

This was a new redesign and it shows.  Just unhappy and I probably should have done more research before buying.  Looking to trade it in on a mid-size truck w/ a manual tranny.  Of which I find there are just two left.

I bought my 2000 King Cab Aug of 1999. Did the regular maintenance and 30k services every 60k.
Have replaced throttle body, starter, harmonic balancer, rear shocks, various belts and hoses and now have 225k on it. Should have kept the A/C condenser drain pan cleaned out as the drain hole clogged and water ran into the engine control monitor. A 30min maintenance that ended up costing $2000 before the problem was found. It started in June and we just discover why the truck would die and not restart but would run fine after towed to mechanic. Wet circuit board would dry out. Plan on keeping it 25 more years. Saved lots of money over 18 years of no car payments.

My Frontier was a base model I bought new to replace an old work truck.  At the time, it was the only base model truck in stock in my area.  I have very low miles on it and it has been dependable and a comfortable drive.  Fully loaded with my stuff it still gets out of its own way with the small, 4 cylinder engine.  I also added a fiberglass shell and a steel ladder rack so that added extra weight to it.  The only major complaint I have with this truck is the electronic throttle control sucks.  The truck will stall very easily and makes towing a trailer difficult.  Other than that, comfortable to drive, heat and air work very well and it has been dependable with no major issues or repair bills.

At first this car was great and I loved it. After about a year and few months I started having issues with acceleration and the check lights coming on. Nissan fixed an array of electrical issues and mass air flow sensors that spanned over two months. I’d bring it in, they’d fix it and light would go off. I’d get in the next day and light comes on, take it in and it was something different and the same cycle went on. Luckily I was still under the regular warranty. After replacing the mass air flow sensor and related pieces about three times I looked into the lemon law but was unfortunately passed the time. A few months went by and nothing went wrong. Then this past year , everything went wrong . I was in Nissan once a month and everytime id do one thing suggested, I’d be back with a new one. So many codes came up this year that I can’t even remember them. Then in June I was told again the mass air flow sensor needed to be replaced and spark plugs. Unfortunately the jobs were so expensive I could only pick one at a time. I chose the spark plugs . The same day those got changed my car started shaking without it being driven and was not accelerating properly. Went in again to be told I’m having multiple engine misfires. Luckily by now I was looking at getting another vehicle and did. But now I’m having so many issues with selling the car because of the current engine misfires.

Hi,  I've been looking to buy an NV200 for a couple years.  We own four, and most recently the best one I've found is a salvage title for a 2014 with 30,000 miles on it for $35,000.  Plus I'd have to pay to have it shipped and delivered.  Last year I bought a 2019 for $32,000.  KBB price of $15-17K is vastly under reality.

I've owned this van since it was new.  I like just about everything on it.  When new I kept losing a hubcap every now and then, so I bought custom wheels for it.  The heater takes a little bit longer to heat up than I like, but other than these two issues, I have loved it.  I have been getting high 20's to low 30's mpg!  
The four cargo doors and low load height are nice.  I bought my NV200SV to transport my ailing mother and her wheelchairs etc.  I could also put a twin mattress in and take her to the clinic or hospital.  The low entry height was ideal.  It's the most useful vehicle I've owned.
It's not made for towing trailers, however, which is why I'm considering trading.

Gets 30 mpg.  Can sleep in it on trips or get my rototiller in back. The shifter interlock solenoid has failed, so I use a paperclip in the shifter interlock to get it out of park.  It’s $1000 to replace. That’s the only problem that I’ve had with it.
It is comfortable, reasonably quiet even with aggressive tires.
This van runs and handles like a small car.   The seats are high enough to give you the van look.

We load this van with heavy batteries (32) driving streets and freeway.
No issues.
Just use recommend Cargo Tires!

I'm a service tech, I use my van for work. I have had various service vans over the past decade. If you or your company needs a compact service van, get the Ford Transit Connect or the Ram Promaster City. The Transit Connect is the best. If you need something larger, get a Ford or GM. I have heard good and bad about the M-B's, but their higher cost may be limiting.

Now on the NV200. My latest is a 2021 SV, previously had a 2018 SV and a 2013 S. The '18 was totaled with 40k miles in 6 months. The 2013 was from a tech that quit and it was given to me beginning of 2020. It had 200k miles. The driver's door would not stay closed (Nissan dealer could not find any problems). I told my company to get something a little safer. So I end up with this 2021 a month ago...

The good - it has Android Auto, Apple CarPlay and SiriusXM.
The bad - everything else.

It has a tachometer. Why?!?! Not needed as it has a CVT and the engine will not rev above 5k with a 6.5K redline. Anyway, anything above 3k RPM does not accelerate the van any more quickly, just adds about 10 more decibels to the already loud engine noise. Small fuel tank, and a small (3/4"), hardly legible digital fuel "gauge". The steering feels like the wheel is connected by a rubber hose. Braking is mediocre when empty, frightening when there is any kind of load in the back. Affected by wind gusts more than a sailing yacht. Fuel economy is good, 25MPG combined. Had a V6 mid-roof, mid-length Transit 250 with base V6 that got 23MPG combined. Oh, wait, that would make this NV200 just awful in terms of fuel mileage!

Also, I have yet to figure out how Nissan designed so much torque steer into this vehicle! The CVT saps most of the torque out this engine. Acceleration is glacial, but the torque steer is amazing. I thought they dialed all of that out at the end of the 1980s!

TLDR - Spend you money elsewhere. Do you really want a 21k delivery vehicle? Wait for Ford Maverick XL, I'm sure it is better than this. Or buy a used Ford or Ram compact van.

I purchased a 2022 Nissan Pathfinder S in June of 2023. The Mileage at the time of purchase was around 8300 miles. The dealership I purchased it from (Chevy Dealer) had it sitting on their lot for over 300 days, so I seized that opportunity to get a good deal. After test driving the car, the first issue started, which wasn't mechanic, but rather a bad battery, to which the dealership happily replaced. But up until the beginning of September, the vehicle ran fine and smooth with no issues. 

Fast forward to the week before 11 September and when the issues started. This is when I first started to notice a slight skip while driving down the highway, it wasn't regular sound that I would hear in a constant manner, just a slight misfire while driving down the highway randomly. After that, the following week, I started to notice that my car would randomly shift into neutral while driving. At first, I thought maybe it was my wallet (as sometimes I set it on the shifter) or my phone sitting nearby, interfering with the electronics in the shifter, but after placing both items away from the shifter entirely, the vehicle continued experiencing the same issue. While driving home on the 9th of September the car engine stalled out on me, forcing me to pull over on the side of the road. From there I placed the vehicle into park restarted the engine. At the time it showed an "Unknown Error" message for the remainder of my trip home. 

On September 11th, I took my Pathfinder over to the dealership first thing in the morning and dropped it off, sitting just at 15k miles. On the way there, I notice a sudden loss of power while going up hill, and again shifting into neutral while driving. Once at the dealership I explained all the issues above and the technicians took my vehicle back for a while. Once they found the issue, the service rep stated that the issue was from a bad fuel pump, but the downside was that they didn't have any in stock. So being that the car is still under its 3yr/30k mile warranty, the dealership gave me a rental. On the 13th Sept. I was called by Nissan and told that my vehicle was repaired and ready to be picked up. So, I went and picked it up and drove it out with no issues for the moment.

 On 21 Sept. on my way to work, the Pathfinder began to shift on its own into Neutral at random times and began stalling out while driving down the highway at 65+ mph. Also, while in transit, the vehicle seemed to have a loss of power while going uphill, it felt almost like a backwards jerking motion. Once at work I finally parked, but the car would not shut off, I would hit the start stop button multiple times, but the car would not shut off. I managed to get it to shut off by putting the E-Brake on luckily and from the point I called the dealership and set up an appointment to be dropped off the following day. 

On 22 Sept. I dropped the car off first thing in the morning, explaining that on the way there the car stalled twice on me while driving down the highway, again forcing me to the side of the road. I also took pictures and video clips of the error codes and messages displayed while the issues were occuring. From there I left while the car was being looked at and around noon, they I called after not hearing anything, and I was told by the service rep that the technician looked at the car and said that the transmission was "having issues" but they were going to go ahead and replace the entire thing. To top all that off, I was also told that Nissan didn't have any rentals they could loan at the time. When I asked if they could set me a rental up with a rental agency, the rep told me that would have to approved by the supervisor and that he would call me when he got back from lunch. They also put my name at the top of the list on their rental list. Being that I work an evening shift, this forced me to go to Enterprise and to rent a vehicle out of pocket so I could travel to and from work. Monday morning, they told me they had a rental available, so I returned the enterprise rental and am currently driving Nissans rental. 

After barely making into work on time, I called Nissan's Corporate number, and talked to a lower-level consumer affairs rep to file a complaint. After reading around some various forums online, I was able to discover that other people were experiencing the same or similar issues as well with their 2022 Pathfinders. This tells me that there is most likely some kind of defect with certain transmissions, that Nissan has not publicly acknowledged as of yet.

On Monday, I had a higher-level consumer affairs person call me from Nissan, to speak with me on the issues I have been experiencing. I told her about having to rent a vehicle on my own dime and she did state that I could be compensated once the repairs were done. While also speaking with her, I told her I no longer wished to have this vehicle anymore as it had two major issues thus far, and for a car to have transmission issues at 15600 miles is never a good sign. I told her my wife and I are looking to expand our family, and this was the original reason I purchased the vehicle. I explained to her that I did not trust the Pathfinder to not have major issues down the road and would not want me wife and child stuck on the side of the road because of the other potential defects that may emerge in the future. So, the rep put a request in for me to see if Nissan would purchase the vehicle back from me a good market value and was told today 28 Sept. that Nissan declined to do so but would fix everything while still under warranty. 

My opinion is this, if Nissan is confident that once these transmission issues are repaired and that there won't be any other major issues, why is it they won't buy the car or even provide me with an extended warranty? 

Before the pathfinder I owned a 2014 Frontier, and it ran fine all the way up to when I traded it in for the pathfinder (to which at this point I regret). I am not claiming that all Nissan's vehicles are bad, but I am saying the 2022 Pathfinders are. I'm also not claiming that if you own this vehicle, you will have these issues, but I believe in the future you're going to see many more major issues come to light as these Pathfinders age. 

Nissan's resolve with these issues for me personally, is enough to make me go with another auto manufacturer for ALL future vehicle purchases.

2021 Nissan Rogue SV Premium: An Owner's Journey Through Ups and Downs

Introduction:
I picked up a 2021 Nissan Rogue SV Premium, already a bit seasoned with 17k miles. What I thought would be a smooth ride turned into an eye-opening adventure, complete with unexpected challenges and some redeeming qualities.

The Hiccups:
1. 'Limp Mode' Frustrations: Imagine you're driving, and suddenly your car decides it won't go faster than a snail's pace, lights on the dash flashing like a Christmas tree. That's 'limp mode' for you. It's scary and super inconvenient, especially on steep roads.

2. The Pesky Water Leak: The real headache started when I noticed water leaking into the cabin near the driver's A-pillar after a car wash. This wasn't just a one-time thing; every time it rained or I washed the car, there it was again. It felt like a constant battle against the elements, something you wouldn't expect from a modern vehicle like the Rogue.

Dealership Drama:
Dealing with Nissan's dealers was like being in a maze with no exit in sight. Different places, different stories.

1. Dismissive Diagnostics: The first dealer kind of brushed off the limp mode issue, blaming a low battery. But that explanation just didn't cut it for me.

2. The Water Leak Runaround: The same dealer's response to the water leak was even more baffling. They suggested the sunroof drain was clogged and advised me to avoid parking outside in the rain and increase car wash frequency. That advice in rainy San Francisco felt almost like a joke. I was bouncing back and forth between dealers, getting nowhere fast.

The Turning Point:
1. Battery Breakthrough: A second dealer finally pinpointed the problem — a faulty battery. Once they replaced it, the limp mode issue disappeared. It was a relief but also a frustration that it took so long to find such a simple fix.

2. Water Leak Saga Continues: I had to become my own detective to solve the water leak mystery. After digging through Nissan's technical documents, I found a TSB about issues with Rogues' roof rail systems. Armed with this, I confronted another dealer, who finally acknowledged the issue and fixed it. But the real test was getting Nissan to recognize the seriousness of the problem.

Nissan's Involvement:
Getting Nissan's attention was a battle in itself. My initial complaints fell on deaf ears until I escalated the matter to higher authorities. I reached out to California's State Attorney and other key agencies, pushing for Nissan to acknowledge and address these systemic issues. It was a daunting process, but it eventually led to some real action from Nissan's side.

The Silver Lining:
Despite the troubles, the Rogue has its moments. It's a comfortable ride, efficient on gas, and the ProPilot Assist is a gem on long trips. The entertainment system does its job well, though I sometimes wish I had the Bose sound upgrade.

Conclusion:
This journey with the 2021 Rogue has been a rollercoaster of emotions and experiences. It's a decent car when it behaves, but the road to getting issues acknowledged and resolved was longer and bumpier than I expected. If you're eyeing a Rogue, be ready for potential challenges and know that sometimes, you might have to get a bit rogue and speak up against the dealers.

I purchased the car at 24,000 miles in 2018 and for the longest time it was perfect for me. I'm a college student with no kids so the car was the perfect size and price. It was reliable until very recently and it's good on gas. I would say the car is perfect as a first car assuming its in certain condition because it has space for three passengers to be very comfortable at any size and assuming they are about average adult sizes and below. If there are some who are bigger in the car you may have to play a little tetris with them, it's comfortable enough for short trips though. The number one biggest killer with this car is the CVT, typically from my research the transmission dies between 65,000-70,000 miles. If you are buying a Sentra over 70,000 miles you should ask if it has the original transmission in it, if it does you should turn it down unless you plan on breaking the car down for parts and reselling those, and if its on its second transmission you should ask how many miles it has specifically. I never once had problems with the engine or any other expensive repairs because I stayed on top of repairs, in part because I later learned about the cvt issues. You should assume that your car will stop working at 60,000 miles as the cost to get a replacement CVT, at least what I have been quoted, is $7,000. It'll treat you great until the car starts revving on its own, this issue is so well known that there was a class action law suit over the matter and Nissan extended the warranty on the drivetrain to 8 years ( which has since expired anyway so don't bank on Nissan helping you). Also an issue I had was the trunk would open when I wasn't looking, I guess my key fob would press too easily. I once had a back pack stolen out of my open trunk so after that point I stopped trusting it. Consider taking the battery out of your key.
Don’t waist your money. The car won’t last more than 100k miles. It has one of the worst cvt transmission ever built in a car. It’s very costly to repair.

I financed 2019 Sentra SV in March of '19.. It has been 4 years, 8 months & 85,000 miles later.
The only problem that has occurred was the electrical fuel pump that went out at $20,000 which was covered by warranty-other then that no major issues to report. I drive the Sentra somewhat hard reving RPM's for the 1.8 liter lacks power. 70,000 miles will be considered Highway miles which could be helpful. I had transmission fluid/filters replaced @60,000 miles, tie Rod boots replaced, A/C artic flush, brake system flush, tire alignment, 2 Batteries, oil change/filter every 4,900 miles, system connected to a Optima (Yellowtop) High performance battery pushing a 2,000w Amp for two 12 inch subs, & a 4 channel 800w Amp pushing 6 interior speakers for all 85,000 miles;  Never had a problem with electrical system.
Excellent vehicle if your on a budget and you need a daily economic driver. Gas is at 35-40 mpg of your driving speed limit entirety if trip. Go 5 to 10 miles over & you'll notice the had decrease.
Overall I would recommend the 2019 Sentra SV, if you have extra money get the SR version due to the sporty look and LED lights.. Take care of it & it'll take care of you.
I think this is a very reliable  & dependable car. I’ve had for several years and love it. Never had any problems with it.

Just over 17k miles 
Rides like a Cadillac 
Zero rust
Brand new Nissan battery 
Truck still like new

I bought my Titan seven (7) years ago. This thing is a hidden gem! So many safety features. So reliable,  I have only had to do routine maintenance,  toes,  battery, oil changes,  etc. It is so extremely reliable. No problems at all!  It also tows amazing! 
I love love love my Titan. No issues.  I highly recommend this truck to anyone!

I have had a great experience with my truck.  I just had to comment after reading your experts Cons, as I completely disagree with a couple of his comments.

The ride is awesome, my wife likes the ride even better than her Caddy XT5.

There is plenty of headroom the oversized moonroof is great.  Not sure who sponsors your writer but I disagree.  I have ridden in 2021 Dodge Ram and 2023 Chevy top of the line and I will put the seat comfort of my Titan against either of them.  Also the AC cooled seats are amazing on long trips.  You can drive 10, 12 or 14 hours and get out fairly refreshed.  Your guy has no credit with me.

I purchased a leftover 2021 Titan Pro4X 6 months ago with every single option Nissan offers for this vehicle.  Purchase price was 56K.  No other new truck came even close when you compare features to price.  30K more MSRP for other brands with the same features.  400HP, Adaptive Cruise, Panoramic roof, Fender Sound System, Leather seats with Red stitching Accents, NAV, Tow Pkg, Off Road Pkg and so on....truck has tons of power.  My previous truck was a GMC Sierra SLT.  Not sure I will ever go back !
Great Vehicle !! Everything to love about a truck… Reliable, Tough, and gets the job done.. Nissan hit this one out of the park!

Truck has been flawless for 40k miles. Ride is comfortable for a truck, easier over bumps than a ford or chevy. Decent fuel mileage for truck, 22.1hwy and 17.6 city. No major defects but gas tank does whistle when almost done fueling...it's kinda nice because I know when it's close to full. Power is good, no race car but gets moving quickly.

I could not be happier with my 2018 Titan SL. The styling, interior comfort, quiet cabin, sound system, tech features and smooth ride on pavement and dirt have all been outstanding.

The only downside to the Titan is a low payload capacity on the non XD crew cabs, on my SL it is 1322 lbs which is fine for anyone who just needs to grab stuff from Home Depot or move a friend but if you are really going to start hauling it is a bit sub par.

I like the Titans so much though that I am trading for an XD Pro 4x. Pretty much the exact same truck just with 1733 lbs of payload so I can haul my TT without being over on payload.

One of the best handling, most powerful trucks I have owned. Purchased a 2020 Silverado, dealer had to replace the tires with 1000 miles on them. Transmission torque convertor went out with 5000 miles on it. Dealer replaced convertor, flushed trans, new filter and fluid, but never seemed to shift right. Rear window rattled constantly. Went to Nissan dealer, traded Silverado for a Titan SV, was treated extremely well and received a great deal. What a night and day difference between trucks. I love my new Titan! One of the best riding trucks, plenty of interior room, quiet on the road. Great gas mileage, no cylinder deactivation, just smooth strong engine performance!  I have purchased Chevy trucks since 1979, NEVER AGAIN!!!
For the money this truck cannot be beat. No turbos or start stop or other bs. Super comfy. Reasonable gas mileage. Great Offroad.

I have owned the truck for just over a year and it has spent 6 weeks so far in the shop.  So far they have replaced the TCM, the High pressure fuel pump, the low pressure fuel pump and the IPDM. This does not include the transmission issue that has occurred  multilabel times were the truck tries to engage park while going down the road.  The transmission issue they do not have a fix for and is not part of the recent recall.

After owing a f150 that fell apart at 65k and a Tundra that was perfect except for bad mpg for 110k, the Titan is the perfect mix of comfort, style, reliability and reasonable mpg (17.3 after 3 years & 48k)  Will be my next truck as well.
Good all around truck. Good fuel economy. Great towing cap.

Glad nissan quit building these trucks. They are trash. First was a 2018 pro4x. Constant dpf issues. After 20k in warranty work, they voided my warranty. The truck needed an egr cooler. Sold it. Second is a 2016 sl. As of 2/18/2024 it has 75,017 on the clock. Has had to have the lp turbo replaced, the lift pump replaced, blend door actuator, and a window motor in the last year/1500 miles. Scared to drive it because of Constant catastrophic failures. It's now a yard ornament that's depreciating faster than a kia.

I've had my Titan XD for 6 years and 60k miles.  Regular service only. No problems.  Interior and exterior have held together very well.  It tows better than half tons that are rated to tow more - I know I had one.  And when not towing or hauling it rides better than the 3/4 tons out there.

The 2016 Nissan Titan XD Platinum Reserve has been a total let down. For what I paid for this truck, it has been falling apart. Transmission has been changed, the fan clutch went out, the compressor went out, the starter went out and now the a/c is out and going to cost another $3,000.00. Stay away from these trucks!!!

This is by far the best truck I've ever had. I bought it new in November 2017 and haven't had any problems at all but the rear camera. It's very dependable and at 6 years old and 105,500 miles, it still looks like new inside and out, and it still runs like new. I pull a 9,000lbs 5th Wheel RV and it's rarely noticeable at all. It climbs hills and ride on the interstates under load with no issues at all.  A very good and reliable vehicle. According to Nissan, this particular vehicle can tow 11,587lbs, and I believe it. Just and awesome vehicle. Considering purchasing another one soon.
Very comfortable ride with amazing pull power for any trailer I hooked up to it.  Can easily tow 15k plus
Has been a solid truck owned since 12,000 miles. Replaced the transmission at 155,000 no other issues.

After owning a 2018 Nissan Titan S I took advantage of the stellar covid trade in values and traded it in for a '21 Titan XD Pro4x. I shopped a couple other trucks as well but ultimately settled on the Nissan due to it's unbeatable warranty and "bang for your buck" value. I love all the tech, safety features, storage options, and creature comforts. Standouts include the adaptive cruise control, 360 cameras, back-saving zero gravity seats, and the incredibly handy and versatile Titan boxes. On the other end of the spectrum the Titan XD is a very large and clumsy truck in confined spaces and the fuel economy is absolutely atrocious (I'm getting 15.8 mpg combined) but any other 3/4-ton gasser would be subject to the same issues. Overall very happy with my purchase, no unexpected maintenance so far.

I towed my four winns 22 foot boat to Florida down in the keys and I didn’t even feel like I had anything behind my truck. This truck out does any pick up truck that I’ve ever driven and there is no smell to the diesel.
These trucks are too often overlooked. Best in class towing power and looks. Drives better than it’s American competition
Completely smooth ride, plenty of consistent power, absolute beast I hit a semi tire going 80 a week ago and the truck had no damage
Bought my 2022 Nissan versa with only 50 miles on the car is great overall but really SUCKS in the snow to the point you get stuck frequently on minimal amounts of snow.
The style has improved a ton gas gauge does not move much at all if you drive it normally the manual stick is very smooth an quiet, do not get cvt transmission, stick is the way to go.

Honestly, A brand new car that’s reliable, has great safety features as well as good MPG but still has power (has a “sport” mode as well) it’s a great car. Perfect daily driver with plenty of trunk space despite being labeled as a sub compact.
Never had a problem with the car regular maintenance.. I would keep it but I'm a big guy so need a little bigger.

Mine is the highest packages but still audio quality is terrible.
Slow acceleration
Seat tore just 3 month used.(they replaced)
Sensors are not reliable. Sometimes is braking suddenly with no reason. It started while car just 400 miles.
Balancing is easily may damaged.
No height setting for seats so I can't see front below front bumper while driving.
Need stronger fog lights
Led headlights are awesome.

The 2020 Nissan Versa has come a long way from it's predecessor of just a couple years ago.  This design has a more modern mainstream small sedan look.  It features most of the commonly desired features from a good sound system to backup camera and sensors around the car for safety and accident prevention. It's priced decently and the gas mileage is definitely a plus.

The Nissan Versa 2021 we just purchased this year is about the junkiest car we ever have had.  Our grandson, with my husband in the front seat, backed our Nissan out of our carport very slowly and it nicked the right front corner of the bumper.  The whole front end came off.  It was plastic!! The padding between the bumper and the car was styrofoam.
I like this car. however, it's too small for me. I think it holds it's value, is very endurable and good on mileage. Too lightweight for me.

Owner of 2016 Nissan versa with 170k on the dash. 2 sets of tires, oil changes, brakes. I drive stick and refuse to have a automatic transmission and my consequence was less luxury options and a high reliability low maintenance vehicle.

I don't agree with the Kelly Blue Book ratings.  Of course, they go by many reviews.  Having said that I purchased a used 2013 Nissan Versa with the CVT transmission.  The vehicle had 70,000 miles on it.  It now has 90,000.  It's been a relatively decent car until recently when I started having issues with the transmission.  It's gotten so bad that the transmission needs to be replaced.  Unfortunately, after the car started having issues I went on the web and found out there are literally 1,000's of Nissan cars out there with the same type of transmission that are having major issues.  So many, in fact, Nissan extended the very weak transmission warranty to cover the issues.  My particular vehicles extended warranty was only upped to 84,000 miles whereas some have been increased up to 10 years and 120,000 miles.  I wouldn't purchase a Nissan with a CVT transmission if my life depended on it as now I'm stuck and have no clue what to do......it most probably would cost more to fix it than it's worth.
A good conditions car ,no check angine light on. Smock chek passed,body in good shave. Good looking interior.
It's one owner car we don't use much mileage just drive back and forth to the bank and shopping and the grocery shop

37,000+ miles.  Drive it non-stop. Every day.   

The only issues (not wear related like tires...) thus far are:  1) The center dash vent spring... replaced under warranty; 2) Drivers seat heater switch was activating on its own... replaced under warranty; 3) Brake pedal switch failed, causing the car to go into limp mode... Ferrari picked it up and replaced it.

5+ years,  37,000+ miles.  Three trivial parts.

But...  zero rattles, zero leaks, zero anything but three small things.   That puts the car into extremely reliable territory.

I don't abuse it, but drive it hard.  Been top echelons of club racing and some pro racing for well over 18 years.   A race car it's not.  But no street car is.  But I will say it's the best day-to-day sports car I've ever driven (and I've owned well over 30+ 911's through the years of every flavor).

The car gets a 9.99 on 1-10.       

And yes, I'm going to buy another.
This Car is not as good as everyone says it is I got this for my birthday and hate it do not understand the hype on this

Driving this car is in so many different ways exhilarating. The fact it is so smooth and comfortable to drive and the way it has the ability to through you back in your seat is incredible. I have taken this car to the track and it performed beautifully, the 488 GTB was tight on the road and took off amazing coming out of the turns. I recommend anyone and everyone that loves the mind-boggling thrill of quick turns, intense acceleration and driving an amazing machine.
Fast great looking super car with a once in a lifetime driving experience jjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjjj
This car as not given me any problems but I needed to get rid of it because I needed a 4 seat car  . This car was very fun to drive while I had it and it was perfect.

We previously had a F360 F1 Spider and a 2020 Portofino.  The 360 was too much of a toy and the delicious howl of the engine freaked my wife out whenever I got a little overly enthusiastic (lol).  The Portofino was much more refined, including modern features such as BlueTooth and GPS Nav, but the look and ergonomics just weren't our cup of tea.  And then we ran across the 2017 488 Spider.  

Blue Corsa with a black wrap treatment to the green house and engine covers, plus some discrete carbon fiber touches.  She was flat-out gorgeous.  But I still had to test drive her.  The test did not take long.  Ergonomics are superb.  Forward and side visibility is excellent (Blind Side Warnings would still be very much appreciated though).  The view of the hood sloping away and the raised fenders is intoxicating.  And she is so refined.  In automatic mode, with the manettino switch in "Sport" and "Bumpy Road" engaged, the transmission shifts smoothly, and if you drive her "normally" there are no surprises.  The car can be totally effortless to drive.  Want to set your hair on fire?  Switch to "Race" and push the "Auto" button, placing the transmission into Flappy-Paddle mode, and hang on.  The engine revs so quickly that it's had to avoid the rev limiter in 1st (almost impossible) or 2nd gears.  Hit the rev limiter in third?  Ease off the throttle and wipe the grin off your face.  In 4th?  Might as well just pull over and collect your speeding ticket!  It all happens QUICK.  Handling is rock steady, glued-to-the-ground confidence inspiring.  The brakes are best described by someone who said, "If you stomp on the brakes, you'll think it had begun to rain, but the water on the windshield is actually the tears ripped off your eyeballs!". 
Bring your A-game with you if intend to take a 488 to its limits.  Oh - and it has an automatic Formula 1 Drag Reduction system that knows "not" to activate if it senses that the roads might be icy.  How cool is that?

She's comfortable - I spent an entire day in her without so much as an itch.  With the minimal center console, the interior really feels spacious.  Compared to the claustrophobic Corvette C8, the 488's interior feels like an arena.  

The standard stereo is actually pretty decent.  I can't see the value in paying an exorbitant amount for the JBL stereo upgrade (JBL?  Really?  C'mon Ferrari.  You're kidding me, right?).  

The retractable rear window provides good wind protection when top-down, and with the top up, you can retract the window to listen to the engine (a sweet touch).  Overall, it's quite a civil environment for a long trip too.  

Prior to the 488, the greatest GT I ever owned was an '03 Jaguar XKR Coupe.  It may still be the best GT ever, but where the XKR was more GT than sports car, the 488 leans the opposite way.  It is absolutely a GREAT sports car, but it's also a very suitable GT.

How great a sports car is she?  I don't know yet.  Despite having raced some small roadsters years ago, none of them compared to the mass and power of the 488.  I'll wait for a track day (and an INSTRUCTOR!) before I explore the limits of this fabulous car.

Trust me: You definitely want one.

I've always been a huge fan of the "practical" Ferrari's.
I thought the Modial 8 from the 1980s was awesome. A drop top plus room for you and friends and groceries!

So in my view this is the ultimate F car for me. A drop top, 2 2 with big trunk. I still remember when it debuted and I was floored.

I can load up the golf clubs, pick up a friend, and hit costco on the way home from the course with plenty of room to spare. All the while experiencing top down cruising and the full sound of the intoxicating exhaust note uninhabited by a roof or glass.

The suspension is beautiful. Hardly feel anything over rough roads, speed bumps or train tracks. By comparison, my fillings rattle loose when driving my 997 Porsche turbo over anything somewhat harsh. 

The front mid engine and rear drive makes for impeccable balance. I always get a lot of looks and compliments each time I take it out. 
Convertible Ferrari's are magical. 

And it has a reputation for being a "reliable" Ferrari that one could use as a daily driver. And many do...

I guess that's why they sold so many. 

FYI years 2014 and 2013 are know as California 30 as they are 30 pounds lighter and have 30 more HP.
Hard top it’s the best Excellent performance super comfortable Handle amazing

Car is very well fitted out, smooth to drive, comfort or sport. Quick and stable in high speed turns. The new F1 related improvements seriously change the handling for the good. Pretty good nav system and big screen. Only issue is the radio goes on every time you start the car and no one seems to know how to change this factory setting. Drives me nuts, but I just get used to turning it off. The next generation had a power wind blocker I understand, this one is manual, but works great. Bought it with 400 miles on it and love to drive it. Make sure you put the Xcel film on it. I have the Rosso portofino paint and it is extremely complicated to match as I understand.
I've owned my Portofino since its birth (built for me by Ferrari) and am truly in love with it. It is indeed the perfect high end daily driver.

I like the car but not the fact that it doesn't come with a manual transmission. Infact that is what's causing me to part exchange it for a Porch. It doesn't feel like driving when you just sit there with one hand on the steering wheel and one foot on the gas or brake.. 
Sorry Ferrari, but that's a deal breaker...
