I had so much fun this summer with my doors off and top down. It feels so free and easy to accomplish. Thought I’d be satisfied but now I am over the moon!!  Jeep is my new all around best vehicle!
We love it but it has had a electrical problem every year one so server that it has stranded us on the side of the road. We have never taken it off the black top road.

rides like a jeep, of course. runs very well. reliable and looks very nice. mpg is 18+ (my wife drives this more often than I) hinges are being replaced in a couple weeks, they are just beginning to rust.

I really wanted to love this car and yes it looks good but I’ve had so many issues on my 2021 Jeep Wrangler 4XE. Just be prepared to have your car in the shop all the time and know that most dealerships only have one certified mechanic to work on these. Always insist on getting a rental car if they’re going to have the car overnight and make sure they Uber you if you need to get around if they’re having your car for the day. And let’s not forget the ongoing recall..,

I have always been a fan of the Jeep Wrangler; I am currently driving my 5th Jeep; I love the versatility of the Jeep - I love its ability to travel deep into the back country and back out again.
Today's Wrangler has the ability to commute in city or country with ample power to tow a trailer and negotiate hills, the new JL comes with a top that is truly easy to open up on warm days.
The Jeep wrangler is a vehicle that possesses timeless beauty, it never ages.
The weakness of the Wrangler is its lack of practicality - I prefer the 2 door because it is goat-like when off-roading but there is very little space for groceries or lumber and bulky items. the cure is to own a light duty trailer, which I do.

I love being in EV mode around town and having sway bar disconnects and locking differentials on the trail. My MPG is incalculable because I have access to a free charger at work but no range anxiety of a full EV. Just fill up at any gas station and I'm good for another 320 miles. My favorite feature is the 1 touch sky top. This is my fourth Jeep and I'll never go back to a hard or soft top.

Over the years, I drove many different cars, BMW 5 series, Audi A4, A6 and A7, Tesla model Y, and even Toyota. My jeep wrangler Willys 4xe is the most fun car I have ever had.  While you should not really compare a non-off-road car with an off-road one, I’d say this jeep exceeded all my expectations. The 20 miles electric range is good enough for daily use. Love the look of the car.

I got a 2022 jeep wrangler Willy’s sport 6 speed manual 2D. It drives great for a jeep and I have taken it on long trips and it does great. I haven’t put a lift on it or bigger tires but I do think it’s a little under geared. I will probably invest into some lower gears in the near future.

I have a 2021 Rubicon 4xe (Billet Silver) and I love it. I have an electric step and also Clearlidz Freedom top on the way. I get more people approaching me about this vehicles looks than I did my 2017 Mustang GT  California Special. And that car won its class on a car show. 

This ride smooth. After installed the roof headliners is as quiet as can be. It has a ton of torque.  The seats are not comfortable for this amount of money. Had to have the battery cooler module replaced but that been it. Nothing else. And they gave me a rental. Better have! Steering wheel is too loose. Maybe I was used to my mustang. Its my 4th jeep and by far the best.

See title above. That adequately sums up the general consensus and overall correct evaluation of this majestic unicorn of a vessel of overland transportation. If you do not agree then i suggest some self reflection and deep thoughts concentrating on where and why you may have strayed from truth and salvation.
6th Jeep and 3rd Wrangler. Love it. Smoother than my Audi Q5. Never expected a vehicle this capable to be so smooth.

Put together the Tesla model 3 with the current supercharger network of Tesla and one has a vehicle that surpasses gas/diesel in all significant capabilities. In long trips, before the car needs recharging, the driver will need “service”. Add to this capability home recharging and the convenience of the electric motor, and one has the car of the future. Going back from Tesla model 3 to gas/diesel would be like going back from gas/diesel to horse and buggy.

Model 3 drives surprisingly sporty. Reliability is good. Tires changed a bit more often. Charging is a new experience, but a noticeable money saver for sure if you commute more than 100 miles a day.  Tune ups are a bit different too, brakes last up to 80% longer. No oil changes and it has a 12 volt battery that needs regular maintenance every 4-5 years. No not the main car battery lol. I've put 60k miles on this car and no issues and battery degradation is minimal. I still get around 285 miles on a full charge. My 160 mile commute is saving about $3k a year.

My biggest issue is the windshield wipers .  I have to use voice command to turn on my wind shield wipers when it gets to the point I can't see out my window!  When I was doing a test drive with Tesla service representative because my wheels were making a grinding noise, he told me the windshield wiper design was terrible.  The sensor to turn the wipers on is located near the top in the center of the windshield and the snow/rain must hit that exact spot.  I drove a rental car that costs $30 less than my Tesla and the windshield wipers worked better than my car.  Today, the volumn on my radio and Bluetooth is the same whether I turn it up or down.  My voice command stopped working too.  I know the car's functions are computerized and there is some user error involved, but you shouldn't have to be a computer whiz to work this car.  I gave it two stars because of the way it drives, but would never buy this car again.

So far I tried three model 3's and I always had problems with phone charging. Wireless chargers always keep disconnecting and failing to charge the phone at all.  So that huge space designated for wireless phone charging is useless, and can't even hold usb connected phone. 

There are no usb-c for driver and front passenger. Only for back passengers. So I had my cord connected from the back passenger's USB port, and my USBc cord was always getting damaged by back passengers. So phone charging is a huge problem on model 3 when doing rideshares.

2018 Model 3 LR AWD dual motor.  Had most all the options as a dealer showroom car including upgraded wheels and tires, white interior, garage door operation software, autopilot as standard.
This has been the best car I've ever owned. Great performance for price (4 sec to 60mph - very fast, value luxury, quiet, comfortable both front and back seats for long drives (reduced driving fatigue).  Super easy to find supercharges in the Tesla system including many venues offering free Tesla charging now.  Best most reliable charging network without comparison! Maintenance is almost free.  Most likely never have to have a brake job since regen does all the stopping! No gas lines or price gouging ever again - the best!! No smog certs or tune-up needed.  Over air software upgrades regularly, plus fun add-ons that no one else has (Fireplace mode and dance mode).  Super safe car always monitoring all around. No build or mechanical issues, one factory upgrade done for free to resolve a potential tail light/tail gate wire pinch point.  Came with silent run tire upgrade, nice but not necessary.  Quietest car ever, so much that it makes the wind or road noise seem louder!!  Home charging is the cheapest and easiest - car is always ready to go when needed for just pennies!!  Add solar panels on home and charging is FREE!!  Sound system is fantastic as is air conditioning.  Just need to get used to operating car from touchscreen system and driving via accelorator mostly.  AWD helps in wet/snow conditions especially with traction control even with summer tires.  Battery durability is great so far, estimated max range is currently around 295, plenty for long trips, and stop for recharge is just right for coffee/food break or stretch, about 15 min for nearly max charge to continue.  Tesla superchargers are most reliable system available, almost never broken.  Some charger wait times (short) for popular locations or time of day in busy cities around CA. but usually resolve in 5 mins or less. Many hotel  and winery destinations offer Tesla chargers, including AirBnB's to recharge overnight for free with stay.  Never going back to ICE!

It's been 3 full years and I still LOVE my 2021 Tesla 3. So easy to maintain, my local Tesla Dealer just comes to my home to do the few items to maintain: new wipers, air filter and tires. Costs so much cheaper than gas car. Save so much on gas and oil and maintain/repairs.  The ride is fast, responsive, and quiet. Everyone loves riding in it.
PS- I easily get by without a home charger- there are so many convenient Tesla SuperCharger sites to use while you shop or dine.

The first review I read was that the at home charging station could take a week or longer. This is untrue as I'm sure most people have already found out, it was a $1500 install into the garage same as a dryer, plug-in, and it charges overnight ...five hours max.

The thing few people talk about is how convenient this car is. Everything about this car is designed for safety, efficiency and convenience. Costs to operate are a tiny fraction of my previous vehicle. Fast, quiet, and fun. Just passed 50k miles, only expense was to rotate the tires. Beyond amazing!

Have had a 2023 model for over a month. Leased it as an upgrade to my then 5 year old model 3. Test drove the competition, BMX i5-MX60, Lucid, BMW i4 and Audi e-tron. In the end decided on the Tesla due to range, charging network for longer trips and superb driving dynamics. i4 too small and cramped, i5 and Lucid too big and floaty, Audi e-tron lacking in range and dynamics. Tesla fit and finish is great, new cream interior beautiful and hatchback practicality fabulous. At $74,000 and the $7500 lease credit, almost a bargain. Very very happy with my decision. Yes, Elon is a jerk but the Model S is still at the top of the EV heap!!!

I purchased it used in 2019 with 32,000 miles. Fully loaded even with Ludicrous +. Four years later at 83,000 miles on my way to Arizona in July, the AC shows a fault and the cool air turns hot. I have my dog with me and we’re dying for 2 hours. We get to Arizona and the next day I have a flat. Take it to Discount Tire and they say they might be able to get me a tire, maybe tomorrow. Luckily I got the tire replaced and picked the car up by 8 pm. 
For the AC problem. It reset itself until I returned home and the faults started reappearing more and more frequently, until it would not clear
I imputed the problem in my app for repair Service. The next day I get a email that/
The charge is $1,800.00
No loaner
No pickup
Find your way home
Get a ride back

I’ve never had a automobile AC go out!!!
Buyer beware: you’ll be alone once that warrantee runs out.

My Tesla Model S 90 D is fun to drive with instant acceleration. Has long range option 270 miles and cold area package, heated steering wheel and all heated seats. It has unlimited free supercharging. Just upgraded the computer and screen. Maybe looking for another Tesla but love what I have. Someone would have to give me a great offer to let it go.
The best car I have ever driven.  No comparison.  Never going back to an ICE car.  Nothing beats a TESLA.

This is the best car I have owned. It’s got speed, styling, comfort and low operating costs not available with traditional competitors (BMW, Lexus, Bentley, Mercedes).
The body is all aluminum making it virtually rust free forever! The range is reasonable at 270 miles after 7 years. This car has an unlimited life span as better replacement down the road will make it perform even better. I have down 92,000 miles and I figure it’s good for 1 million. Maintenance is much more reasonable than gas competitors. Another main advantage is the significant charging network available to Tesla owners. And the best is the car has an unlimited free charging that stays with the car should ownership be transferred.
10/10 recommended, I was hesitant about the yoke but now I can’t go back to normal wheel. Acceleration is beyond words.

What are model S 75D brand new in 2017 for $84,500, it came with free supercharging for life, a $7,500 tax credit, an insane 8 year unlimited mile warranty, and a 1% interest rate. The offer was pretty amazing compared to today, and pretty irresistible. We’ve never regretted the decision as the car has changed our lives. In terms of maintenance, we’ve had to replace one door handle, and two 12 volt batteries, out of pocket expenses for the two were $0, we did however upgrade our computer for $1,500 and it was a worthwhile expense as it gave us access to games, streaming and a much improved automated driving experience. With 82,000 miles on the odometer we estimate to have saved $20,000 in fuel and maintenance when compared to a traditional vehicle and we’ve easily recovered 100s of ours of useable time because of autopilot. In all the car is amazing, it’s still high tech by any standard, drives well and has caused us no regrets. My brother just bought a 2021 Plaid, though much faster, the driving experience is almost identical. These cars have held up well and likely million mile vehicles, don’t hesitate to get one, you won’t be disappointed.
Fast, good looking, high tech…nicest car I’ve had or been in overall. Prices are very high, but if you can afford it, it’s the best BFB value IMO, particularly w the crazy gas prices.

I've had my Tesla Model X Plaid for a year and a half and its absolutely the best SUV I've ever owned. In fact, it's the best vehicle I've ever owned. I'm totally spoiled because this vehicle is a technology dream and it's also extremely comfortable. The icing on the cake is that it's lightening fast and extremely agile and intuitive. The Tesla Model X is definitely the way of the future! Elon, you done well!

Walt Allen

It's my wife P100D and she has been driving it for 4 years since we bought it CPO from Tesla.
The previous owner paid $175k and upgraded absolutely everything Tesla offered. We even got the data connection for free for lifetime, no subscription required. What a great deal!
This car accelerates as fast as my 911 Porsche Turbo S from 0 to 60mph which it is an amazing supercar performance for an SUV, imagine that.
The Gullwing doors are great in tight spaces and they are head turners.
Software is updating constantly for free and the infotainment is excellent versus I have to pay Lexus dealership to just update my GPS in the car to get the latest map.

The only con is the cosmetic of the car which not as good as other high end brand like BMW or Benz or Lexus. But if you are a tech person and can overlook the minors cosmetic then this woul be a fantastic car to own.
I've been driving for two years now, and I still love, Love, LOVE my Tesla Model 3! My only complaint would be the navigation system. I wish it was more like waze

The car is in mint condition with all the bells and whistles garage kept very comfortable. All you have to do is tell it what you wanted to do from the voice command option and it does it very well put together car.
I owned a jaguar xf for a few years and this drives circles around it. I didn’t expect it to be so much fun to drive.

Bought this car for it's performance but I'm also impressed how comfortable the ride is with the adjustable suspension. The infotainment system on the Model X Plaid but also other Teslas is amazing. With the recent update, you can now play steam games in XBOX/Playstation quality.  My kids love the car as well, especially the falcon wing doors which make it easy to get in and out and they work great in tight spaces. I had zero technical issues so far. Took the car a few times to the Drag Strip and I'm running consistent 9.80's in the 1/4 mile which is quicker than Tesla states.  It's my all in one vehicle. It can haul our trailer to haul stuff around town. It's great for road trips with a very comfortable ride and great range and infotainment.  Charging speed is excellent too.  It's by far the best vehicle that I've ever owned.

I got 2022 Tesla Model X (7 seater) few weeks back after 1yr wait.  I owned two other Teslas - Old Model S and Model 3, hence I got Model X.  

Here are the 2022 Model X cons:
1. Yoke steering - not comfortable at all. Very painful when you a make sharp turns. Tesla doesn't give an option for regular steering - you can buy and install regular steering wheel yourself (costs ~$2500).  Since I have to mess with the Airbag, I am not comfortable in doing this. 
2. Turn indicators have moved to right/left arrow soft buttons on Yoke steering (no more mechanical knobs behind steering). While driving, you have to take your eyes off the road and look for this buttons and press - you will be distracted. If you try to make quick right/left lane merges, this won't work.
3. Sun Visors are not well designed - looks cheap. Width is small and vanity mirror is useless. 
4. Creep start is not available in 2022 Model X - Taking your feet off brake, doesn't move the car and you have to explicitly press the accelerator - painful while you reverse the vehicle. Hoping that this option will be available via software upgrade in the future. 
5. Not much space in 3 row seating.

Having said the above, this vehicle is awesome wrt to overall drive, comfort, control panel simplicity from one screen, Falcon wings, auto pilot and more.
Have higher visibility than M 3

Amazing technology with highest safety ratings. Best I car I've driven. Cost on average $.10 cents per mile (home charger and supercharger on road trips). Only maintenance required are tire rotations and windshield washer fluids.

First off, I didn't get the Tesla as a green alternative to save the planet. I took a test drive in a Model 3 and, like Will Smith in "Independence Day ", I said, "I gotta get me one of these!"

I bought a 2022 Model Y standard range (272 miles) first and drove it for 20 months, putting 52K trouble-free miles on it. Then, in December 2023 I decided to get a Model Y standard range (240 miles with 20 inch wheels). Sits higher, more room, Loving it!

But don't just take my word for it. Test drive one and see for yourself. It's not for everyone, but it certainly meets my needs...

A practical, fun-to-drive SUV that does 0-60 in 3.5 seconds and costs half as much as an ICE suv with comparable performance?  SIGN ME UP.  Actually, I already signed up and bought one.  I was able to get an in stock model Y performance for under 50k and got a 7500 dollar tax rebate on top of that.  If you are a car person and need something to haul your family around in, it’s impossible to beat a MYP without spending a whole heck of a lot more.
Cant picture myself every going away from Tesla. The technology is just so much better than any other car I have been in.

Fantastic car with superior charging network. We went on a family road trip in South Dakota with the fewest superchargers and didn't have any issues with charging. Plus, plenty of storage for all our stuff and the safest vehicle on the market and our kids love it!

Wish they had vented cooled seats, but I believe that will be standard on the new Model Y.
only in 6 month car value goes down 40-50 percent and 330 mile range you will get only 220 miles worst car to buy do not buy this car

We love our model Y Performance, I am however a bit surprised at how much winters effect the charge and of course wish we could squeeze more mileage out of a charge; even though it's advertised at a bit over 300 miles per full charge, you're advised to not max out the charge... ya da ya da ya da, but even at an 80% charge at around 230 to 240 miles showing, you are not going to get a full 230 to 240 actual miles. Other than the mileage limitations and cold weather effects on the battery, I still love this vehicle.
9 months, 14000 miles, zero issues. Charge at home mostly. Uses about $65 in electricity each month. Comfortable, quiet, great handling, great sound system.

Bought during covid before prices were out of range for most folk.
It's sleek and fun on curves. The interior I love (Grand Touring) White leather and black retro with red leather accents.
The back is a little snug, but we did do a 4 person road trip for 7 days and we got it in there. The back seat area surprisingly is roomy brother is 6'1 and said he was fine everytime I asked.
We did a part mountain trip. It seemed as we were doing a very curvy climb she shifted funny and tach would hit 4, it felt like she might explode, but only a 4cyl. so you know can only do what she can do. But she survived and drove the same she always does everywhere else. Probably next time will take a V6. The whole trip 33mpg.

This car performs wonderfully if maintained and treated properly. I get about 31 miles to the gallon overall and hasn't given me a single problem as of yet in reliability. The center armrest is ridiculously positioned and makes me nervous when I try to use it. It simply gets in the way of the center cupholders and sounds like you are about to break it off when touched. The front seats are extremely comfortable and I have plenty of space (I'm 5'11). Driving this is simple and when put into Sports mode, it packs a decent kick. It can keep up as my daily driver easily. The back seats are inaccessible to an adult with where I have to position my seat. I pretty much don't ever have more than 1 other person in the car with me for that reason. It has plenty of bells and whistles that I need and some more. It'll let me know if I'm safe to change lanes, shows me what's behind me clearly when in reverse, and performs reasonably for my life although I wouldn't dare trying to take this off road or try to race someone with. It good for the everyday use but not for the person wanting to take this on a crazy adventure.
The car excellent on gas great in all weather. Better the 4x4 I had. Best car all wheel drive for money. All the extras.

Bought this car used in 2018, and was immediately impressed with the amount of power this thing has for a 4 cylinder. I wanted an AWD that gets excellent gas mileage, which isn't something you can find with traditional SUVs, so I opted for the CX-3. It has not disappointed on the MPG. It handles very well in all conditions, and hasn't left me stranded anywhere yet. The front seats are THE most comfortable seats I have ever experienced, and I can drive for 10 hours without the usual resulting backaches, neck stiffness, and sore rear end, etc., that I have always gotten from every other car I have ever owned. The seat fits me like a glove. I'm 5'4", so whether or not that would be true for someone taller I don't know, but it works for me. Everything about that seat is ergonomically perfect. Having radio controls etc. in a knob down by my right side took a little getting used to, and while I have the hang of it now, I really wish they would put everything back up on the dash, because the layout where the cupholders are, well. . . . . . .quite frankly, sucks, AND, having to look DOWN to see what I am doing is not particularly safe. I HATE not having a console inbetween the seats to store things, like charger cords, etc. I had thought it wouldn't be a big deal, but it is, because the developers really didn't provide much in the way of any other good storage space within the car. The door pockets are not optimal. Yeah, you can put things in there, never to be able to get to them again, unless the car door is open, and you are squatting on the ground trying to jam your arm back in the recesses to reach what has slid back there. Additionally, the positioning of the cupholders UNDER the armrest makes no sense. So I can't drink my coffee AND use the armrest at the same time (and I ALWAYS have something to drink with me when I drive anywhere). Plus the cupholders are so far back you can only realistically use the front one, since your elbow smacks into the raised armrest if you are trying to get to any cup in the 2nd cupholder. Additionally, the armrest is flimsy. Anyone putting any appreciable weight on it is going to break it. While the car overall has held up well, bits and pieces of non-essential cosmetic plastic parts started falling off of it pretty quickly, which was a tad disheartening. And I noticed the other day that the silver logo in the middle of the steering wheel is flaking off as well. I would expect that on a 10 year old car, not on one that is now 5 years old. So if you are considering this vehicle for getting you somewhere you need to be, and actually getting you there, this is a good car, but be prepared for annoying things to go with it.
Superior car. Easy to drive. Good steering. Comfortable drive.  Quiet engine. Confutable seats. Easy to read car panel. Good radio convenient back  lift. Easy on gas  gas. Good brakes
This car is my daily driver and it’s awesome really good on gas consumption, sporty pretty fast. The interior in great shape super clean.

Very impressed with my time owning a CX-3 Touring in Black. Enough acceleration and agility to run through the city of Chicago and comfortable enough to cruise around for highway drive. Though classified as a CUV it drives like a hatch and keeps to the fun Zoom zoom factor.

Interior reminds me of European luxury without throwing down the big bucks or sacrificing on maintenance costs/reliability. Good enough cargo size for me and my fiancé and eventually when we settle down to have a little one and a dog. Does well in wet terrain, and have heard it can go thru 8 feet of snow (a couple of reviews on YouTube, but yet to test it out). If you want AWD, engaging handling, Japanese quality, and don’t want to drive around a boat, this should fit the bill for you.
3,500 miles-new transmission.  15,000 miles-corrosive conductor-no air conditioner.  23,000 miles-check engine and airbag lights are on. This car is a big disappointment!

I have the Turbo Premium. I should have opted for the Premium Plus but I'm still very happy. Transmission is smooth, ride is soft, the active driving display is so cool, radar cruise control, it has everything. 
My last car was a new Mazda3, but someone T-boned me and totaled it. I have a German shepherd and plan on getting at least one other dog so I opted for the small SUV this time. I am not disappointed in any way.
Great car, never give up for 4 years . 80000 miles never been in the shop for repairs. I’ll buy again new one next year .Thanks MAZDA

I've had my CX-30 for about a month and so far I couldn't be happier. The turbo engine is powerful and it's fun to drive. It's well-designed both inside and out, and minimalist interior feels upscale. (With the Premium Turbo trim, it feels like a pricier car from a luxury brand.) It's not a family car, but I'm single and only occasionally have passengers in the rear seats, which have limited leg room for large adults. Not a lot of cargo space, either, but it's been more than enough for me. If you regularly carry more than two people or a lot of cargo, you'd probably be better off with the CX-5 or CX-50 or larger. The front seats are comfortable, and there are lots of little touches that I didn't think I needed but are nice to have, like the heated steering wheel and memorizing the seat configuration for two different drivers. The cons are very minor, such as the wheel which controls the infotainment system, which I haven't quite figured out yet. Still, it beats using the touchscreen (which is large and well-placed) while driving.

Way to small inside. I feel shoved in the front. Rear seat is not appropriate for adults, need more leg room. Good for small kids, but as they grow get a larger vehicle. After a few months, I am not thrilled! Against my better judgment I don't know why I got this car!. I would love to have my money back, Or trade it for a RAV or a CRV!

The car is beautiful that's where this car stops.

Handling: Mazda's All Wheel Drive System is extremely poorly engineered. Wether it's from actual engineering issues or because the vehicle was pushed out, an All Wheel Drive System in 2022 shouldn't push or pull under acceleration or deceleration. The vehicle relies heavily on its Driver Assistance features to make the vehicle manageable. The fact that a close to 5klb CUV handles sporadically and is expected to be safe for families is a giant joke it seems. Also the 188hp and torque in a vehicle this heavy makes it so that to move the car initially takes a giant move of the pedal for very little effect to the actual movement of the vehicle. Going up and down even small dips and hills and keeping the pedal at close to the same range has the vehicle fluctuating massively in speed. 

One lesson to Mazda on this fact 188hp with 188ftlb of torque is not enough for a vehicle that weighs close to 5klbs if you want to be fuel efficient or even safe. The fact is to move a vehicle that weighs this much with its current engine has to have 3k+/- RPMs which takes the normal torque powerband and makes it respond sporadically by applying too much then applying not enough creating a jerking, yanking or massively fluctuating speed feeling. 

The vehicle needs to be, 
A: Engineered correctly, their are schools and YouTube videos explaining the Basics of AWD, to the Advanced.

B: Why is their No Steering column, electronic steering, braking and throttle are poorly executed, I would remove those systems due to loss in feeling between the driver and the vehicle. The servos and the ring sensors in the steering system is not sensitive enough for road driving over 40mph. It's hesitant doesn't always read 0 in the steering angle sensor causing lane drifting and delayed angle reaction in which it seems to try to auto correct for, wich it does incorrectly either by over correcting or under correcting.

C: Lane assist should work all the time if you're counting on it to make the car manageable. Sensors do not sense road lines all the time especially in quick succession,  wich happens a lot due to poor steering sensor reaction and programming. 

D: BRAKING! Brake pedal sensitivity is terrible and random thanks electronic brakes.

Body and styling: 90%. The paint Molding, Leather work, UI, and Head Up display are greatly approved  but the fact that the car has turn signals, blind spot sensors and caution symbol in the mirrors but no Side View Mirror Defrost is utterly not acceptable.

Entertainment: The Entertainment system is of poor quality, yes it looks great but is extremely slow for 2022, not touch screen, and in a $30k Vehicle. It works when it wants, you have to plug your phone in multiple times to get it to pick it up, Often. The Bose 12 channel speaker system is tuned to be appalling and the equalizer doesnt allow for enough changes to fix it. The Hz range of the speakers are terrible. It breaks and shatters sound quality more often then delivering it as a quality that deserves a premium or mark up. Mazda could of used speakers and a Bluetooth connector from the dollar store and given a better listening experience. I would advise swapping to a Pioneer Premier setup over Bose if they charged the company anything close what the customer was charged for half that you can get a 6.1 setup with more responsive user interface for less then half the price. Better quality,  connectivity for cheaper. Also you can't put a custom stereo in so once the system dies you have to pay the ungodly price to get it repaired or use a Bluetooth speaker in the car to get any audio. Hopefully that won't effect the subsystems but I'm betting with my experience so far that it will basically brick your vehicle. Or turn off half the driver features.

The Google client while in a message call is slow and recieves voice terribly making it unusable and unsafe to drive with, so why even include it?

I do not advise buying a Mazda you want a cheap decent car go with Toyota or Honda. Thier AWD systems are much better. Their Audio quality is greatly appreciated. They are worth your money not Mazda.

I bought my new CX30 on Saturday , Nov 28. the CX30 has to be the quietest , most well made car I have ever had. The quality rivals Infiniti/ Lexus . all be it a sub compact vehicle.  I have the premium pkg . Platinum quartz crystal metallic .

Got my CX-30 2.5 T Premium 2 weeks ago and so far so good.  The handling and performance, as many have attested is great!  Makes you forget you’re driving a compact SUV. Love the stylish good looks and interior lay out. Front seats are super comfortable. I’m single w/no kids so I don’t care about the tight rear seating. Fuel efficiency hasn’t been so bad for me. My biggest disappointment however, no front/rear parking sensors especially for this Premium trim level.

The ride is smooth, the engine is quiet, the 12 Bose speakers are like a concert, it handles beautifully, it is a very serene experience to drive and it makes me feel happy.  The soul red crystal finish cleans up easily and always looks great.  I would always buy another Mazda and no other brand.

As advertised!  More fun to drive than described!!!  Red color breathtaking…Leather everywhere in interior…nice additional features like walk away locking and remote start from app…The main review failed to mention that premium fuel for the turbo executes 256 HP and 320 lb of torque…I live on a hill, but in general 22 mpg is difficult to attain…it can be more like 20.5-21…it’s a trade off but well worth the extra HP..

Great car, great value. Mazda is such and underrated car company. If you want a reliable, inexpensive and great looking car with the bells and whistles of all the other cars in its class its worth every penny. Highly recommend. Have owned Mazdas for 30 plus years. Including the MPV.

Purchased 24' Premium a little over a week ago. We're still getting acquainted with newer features from our previous 15' CX 5 Touring. Best features... Android Auto w/touchscreen, safety tech, Bose, heated seats, power lift gate, leather surfaces, 4 USB connections, 6spd auto, auto hold, full speed cruise control, and power / memory seats.  We already took a road trip and the cabin was noticeably quieter, The 19's ride a little firmer but can tell the suspension was revised from older version in a good way. We were able to get a fair negotiated deal with the 0% during Dec. This is our third Mazda and can also atest to the reliability. Other than less than vast rear storage and middling gas mileage the CX5 is worth continuing with this next iteration.
I got caught in flood water that was up over the hood and this car didn't fail me it stayed running and got me home..super 😄

This is my 3rd CX-5 and 6th Mazda since 2008.  My first two CX-5 models were the GT w/Premium package, & those vehicles had just about every option imaginable with the NA 2.5 inline 4-cyl.  I finally got a Signature model in 2022, & while the standard engine was good, the Turbo is the way to go if you can afford it.  Mazda did not need a $60k RWD based jumbo SUV to compete against "premium" brands...the Signature series already did that and now that the supply is catching up with demand, sales are through the roof.  2024 is the last year for the CX-5, which is a poor decision imho.  All Mazda vehicles I've owned have had perfect reliability, great handling, top safety scores, & good mpg.  I was hit head on in my 2021 CX-5, which totaled both vehicles, yet I walked away. That left me with an even greater respect for Mazda's safety systems, & I knew that I would be getting another one right then.  The Signature series, and even lesser trims, make the CX-5 & CX-9 models compete favorably against Acura, Infiniti, & others...and it's been that way for a number of years now.  It no longer feels like an "under the radar" great deal, as prices have gone up quite a bit recently, & I see more Mazda's on the road these days.  Customers have obviously paid those higher prices, & so I really wonder if now is the time to jump up to a "higher class", as it's a risky move with prices as high as they already are; guess we will see. I may end up getting a 2024 model before they are gone, & maybe Mazda will modify their strategy just a bit to keep their best selling vehicle rather than force customers into $60k+ territory for similar equipment.  RWD & inline 6 cyl engines seems risky.  Again, jmho.
This is my third CX-5 and my favorite. Drives great. Great gas mileage 29 mpg around town. Comfortable.

I had a Mazda CX5 Carbon Edition, AWD. I've been very satisfied with the car, I Had a Mazda 3 before and I can tell you the acceleration and motor response is a lot better in the Mazda 3, but I expected that. Regarding to safety, it's just great. Unfortunately, I had an accident in my Mazda, another guy hit me in a crossing road in the back side of the car. The car spinned 180 degrees but the car is extremely stable, otherwise, it would have rolled over. The airbags came out instantly and everyone in the car was safe (4 people).  
On the road, the car is smooth and stable, fastest I've driven it is 90MPH.
The lane alarms could be better, I've driven a KIA, a Hyundai and their lane alarm feels a lot more robust, with higher vibration in the steering wheel, it also takes it back to the lane almost by itself (due to work I rent a lot of cars for over a month, I haven't own other brands, just Mazda)

Overall, I definitely recommend the CX5, did I mentioned the space? I don't have a bike rake so I put my two bikes in the back, just need to put down the back seats.

I know all cars have there special trademarks and all people have there preferences like storage space, the Drive, safety features, technology, reliability, gas mileage, etc. I believe that the 2022 Mazda CX-5 is the perfect suv for me. I have driven the tiguan, cr-v, jeep, and Santa fe, I believe the mazda CX-5 is the best overall. I have been driving my CX-5 for about a year now with almost 30,000 miles and I had no issues and a lot less maintenance fee's than the other vehicles. I'm proud to be a Mazda owner. Thank you Mazda!

The new and improved steering and suspension on this model year is such a game changer for this vehicle, it’s almost a cross between a Lexus or Acura it’s the perfect middle ground. Would absolutely recommend this vehicle.

Great handling SUV with premium interior and exterior design. A few features I appreciate include the wide opening rear doors, and the auto high beam headlights that turn when the steering wheel is turned to either side.
I went with Mazda because of all the positive reviews. It's not the quietest or smoothes riding vehicle. I do enjoy my CX 50 Meridian edition. It looks great and runs well.
We love this suv and when we brought it home are kids loved it just as much if not more i will NEVER Own anything but this Top of the line cant go wrong

Even at 90k miles, our CX9 drove as well as the day we bought it. Only maintenance included oil, filters, rotations, spark plugs, and brakes. Performance was always plentiful and handling was great compared to competitors.

I am a Mechanical Engineer with 40 years of experience in automotive manufacturing (GM, Ford, Nissan, Toyota, BMW, and various suppliers).  I am also one of the 100's of owners of the 2016-2023 CX-9 that has experienced the 2.5 Liter cracked engine cylinder head with coolant leaking out of the engine.  (I'm convinced there more engines with this issue but the crack is just leaking internally while it continues to grow and will someday experience the external coolant leak.)  In my opinion, these engines are ticking time bombs for this problem.  All CX-9's from 2016-2023 have experienced this issue.  Many engines had to be replaced by Mazda under warranty because they didn't even make it to the 60,000 mile mark before the leak was big enough to cause engine failure.  If you're buying a used version of this car, you may already be on your second engine.  The replacement parts have also been known to fail eventually.  They don't think it's enough of a problem to improve their design.
The 2.5 liter engine is also in the CX-5 and Mazda6 and believe it or not, those cars experience the same crack.  The turbo charged version of the engine in the CX-9 apparently fails more often than the non-turbo versions because the added weight to the engine increases the stress at the exhaust manifold where the crack occurs. Over 40+ years of driving and working on cars, I've driven many vehicles over 200,000 miles and have never experienced a cracked engine.  
We bought our CX-9 GT AWD with 112,00 miles and within three weeks, it wasn't running right and then started leaking coolant from the rear of the engine.  I was already aware of the issue but had falsely believed cars that made it to 80,000 miles without cracking were probably going to be ok.  Now I know better.  Mazda has issued a TSB (technical service bulletin - not a recall) for this issue (in 2021) and hides behind their 60,000 mile/5 year warranty stating repeatedly that a TSB is NOT a recall.  For cars beyond the warranty, Mazda quotes you $8,500 to $10,000 for the fix. (Easier for Mazda to replace the engine than have to rebuild it with a new head while a customer is waiting to get their car running again.  Those engines can then be rebuilt and used in other failed engine swaps.)  Independent auto mechanic's should be able to replace the cylinder head with Mazda OEM parts for about half the Stealership's price. (And still make a profit.)
Cause of the issue as identified in Mazda's TSB basically points to a weak design and/or parts that weren't manufactured right as if that makes it someone else's fault, and nothing Mazda can fix.  Seriously!?
I was excited about saving a little gas money with this engine because of the improved economy (over the 2011 CX-9 it replaced).  The cost of this repair just took wiped out that plan!  Coulda' got a Nissan Armada for less overall cost!
What I find amusing is the extended warranty Mazda issued for the 2016-2017 CX-9's with "CRACKS" in the Infotainment screen (they will replace it at no charge), but refuses to acknowledge any responsibility for the "CRACK" in the engine on the same model!
"Hey Mazda - The Customer is ALWAYS right." You are going to lose a lot of customers over this before you figure out how this works...
Mazda has lost me as a customer and my new hobby is spreading the word so others will think twice about falling for the "Zoom Zoom" line.
This CX-9 has been fabulous, lots of power, no mechanical problems, just regular maintenance. This by far my favorite car to drive other than my motorcycles.

I've been extremely dissatisfied with Kelley Blue Book's car valuation services over the past few weeks. The values they provide seem inconsistent and unreliable. I've been trying to get an accurate estimate for my car's worth, but the numbers keep fluctuating drastically, making it impossible to make informed decisions. This lack of consistency has caused me considerable discomfort and frustration. It's essential for such a service to offer reliable and stable valuation data, but KBB has fallen short in this regard. I hope they can address these issues and improve their accuracy to better serve their users in the future.

The 2020 Mazda CX-9 Signature is by far, the best car I have ever owned for the money. The fit, finish, drivetrain, interior design, quality of materials etc. make this an exceptional vehicle. And the human-centric design philosophy makes this a really fun car to drive!

The car drives nice but expect to replace the screen every 2 or 3 years. They spider crack and make daytime views difficult.  Mazda know it's a problem and offered a one time replacement, but 2 years later it's cracking again.  And at $2200.00 for a new screen it makes a nice car look cheap. Back up screens are a required safety feature, why they can't offer one that will remain clear is beyond me.

We absolutely love our CX-9! Plenty of room for the family, very comfy, lots of features you would expect in a "luxury SUV". It's only downfalls, I would say, would be the brakes are a little weak, and the fuel mileage could be a little better (ours averages around 19 mpg). Other than those 2 things, it's been a great vehicle! We will be trading in for a CX-50 or a CX-90 someday, but not Abby time soon!

I own the Inline 6 CX90 with 280 hp engine and 19 inch wheels. The car is very comfortable to drive and has adequate space for hauling kids. The car has no body roll or floaty ride like most other SUVs in this segment thanks to the stiff suspension. The ride is more like a car but is balanced and smooth. My only complaint is that the stiff suspension tends to be a problem at very slow speeds of 10 to 20 miles as you feel every little bump on the road. At higher speeds and freeway speeds the car is aa joy to drive. Long road trips of 300 plus miles are extremely comfortable. The car is an inline 6 engine but has a hybrid motor and the gas mileage is great.

Purchased and traded in a Durango. The Durango had more options, better power, comfort, drive. The Mazda has so much cabin noise. This is supposed to be Mazda’s luxury SUV… it has been anything but. The only benefit has been a little gas savings.

My CX90 Phev gives 3600 miles for two full tanks of Gas, a nice rich interior, Very good accelerator. Only feelings just 26 miles plugin hybrid range. If snow times this range goes to 15 miles at a time, if we have good weather like above 60's the range goes to 32 miles. If the snow and weather are below 10 the electric  wont work, the car runs only on gas. Good and Bad, my best part is this is 8 seater for a good family.

I own the Turbo S Premium Plus model.  Nice car, good power and extensive features.  Most of them work pretty well with the exception of the auto lock doors that only sometimes lock and the phone charger that overheats your phone.  For a new model they did a decent job and will likely fix these issues as time goes on.  What I don’t like about Mazda is their lack of support.  I called their support line because I heard that they were offering some type of good will gesture to customers that overpaid for their vehicles.  They did a $4k MSRP price drop in February.  I have spoken with their support team on 5 different occasions and just get the runaround.  They assigned this task to one case manager who is impossible to reach.  It’s ok if they do not want to offer anything just wish they told me this instead of wasting my time.  It’s truly not the money but the principle.  I don’t like to deal with companies that treat their customers so poorly.

Has rating of 25 miles when fully charged. I have never gotten more than 21.  25 miles is super poor. I would not have purchased had I known that it would get only 21 miles after being fully charged. Otherwise, a nice car.

Owned for about 6 months and had to trade it in. First, the pros. Looks amazing. Mazda nailed all of the exterior elements. The interior is very well done and feels of high quality. On paper, this is an amazing vehicle. It has all of the bells and whistles, and it promises the benefits of an electric with in a spacious 3 row package. I had the premium plus, which was nice, but the perforated leather was quite difficult to clean. I got the premium plus for the rear auto-braking feature, but after owning it, I should have gone for the premium. Anyways, the main issue is the drive. Specifically, Mazda still has a lot of work to do on the transitions between electric and ICE mode. I has multiple instances where it would feel like it was stalling. I also had many instances where it would lurch (suddenly jerk forward). And there is a noticeable delay between pushing the pedal and the gas engine kicking in to support additional acceleration when you need it. Overall, it wasn’t very fun to drive and couldn’t see keeping a $55k+ vehicle that wasn’t fantastic all around. Maybe they will fix these issues in future revisions or with software updates, but I was not willing to wait around for that.

I have owned this car for 4 months now, very good interior and exterior look. Smooth drive for normal, if needed acceleration sport mode is an amazing response. I use most of the time EV mode will charge more often, so very little gas is needed. Accommodates 8 people with only kids for 3rd row. No issues until now. I was using Accord still some features are not comparable with Honda. Honda was good.

I feel the luxury inside this car and has very good space in the 1st and 2nd rows, 3rd is only for Kids. We can accommodate 8 passengers with 27 Miles of EV. Most of my miles runs on EV. bought the car end of Dec, now it is 2800 miles 2nd time filled gas still 100 miles to go on Gas. Ev charging is also not cheap, now experiencing. Car is very smooth on EV and engine as well. Very good accelerators when we put it on Sport mode.

I own the Inline 6 CX90 with 280 hp engine and 19 inch wheels. The car is very comfortable to drive and has adequate space for hauling kids. The car has no body roll or floaty ride like most other SUVs in this segment thanks to the stiff suspension. The ride is more like a car but is balanced and smooth. My only complaint is that the stiff suspension tends to be a problem at very slow speeds of 10 to 20 miles as you feel every little bump on the road. At higher speeds and freeway speeds the car is aa joy to drive. Long road trips of 300 plus miles are extremely comfortable. The car is an inline 6 engine but has a hybrid motor and the gas mileage is great.

Purchased and traded in a Durango. The Durango had more options, better power, comfort, drive. The Mazda has so much cabin noise. This is supposed to be Mazda’s luxury SUV… it has been anything but. The only benefit has been a little gas savings.

My CX90 Phev gives 3600 miles for two full tanks of Gas, a nice rich interior, Very good accelerator. Only feelings just 26 miles plugin hybrid range. If snow times this range goes to 15 miles at a time, if we have good weather like above 60's the range goes to 32 miles. If the snow and weather are below 10 the electric  wont work, the car runs only on gas. Good and Bad, my best part is this is 8 seater for a good family.

Most of them work pretty well with the exception of the auto lock doors that only sometimes lock and the phone charger that overheats your phone.  For a new model they did a decent job and will likely fix these issues as time goes on.  What I don’t like about Mazda is their lack of support.  I called their support line because I heard that they were offering some type of good will gesture to customers that overpaid for their vehicles.  They did a $4k MSRP price drop in February.  I have spoken with their support team on 5 different occasions and just get the runaround.  They assigned this task to one case manager who is impossible to reach.  It’s ok if they do not want to offer anything just wish they told me this instead of wasting my time.  It’s truly not the money but the principle.  I don’t like to deal with companies that treat their customers so poorly.

Has rating of 25 miles when fully charged. I have never gotten more than 21.  25 miles is super poor. I would not have purchased had I known that it would get only 21 miles after being fully charged. Otherwise, a nice car.

I was using Accord still some features are not comparable with Honda. Honda was good.

I feel the luxury inside this car and has very good space in the 1st and 2nd rows, 3rd is only for Kids. We can accommodate 8 passengers with 27 Miles of EV. Most of my miles runs on EV. bought the car end of Dec, now it is 2800 miles 2nd time filled gas still 100 miles to go on Gas. Ev charging is also not cheap, now experiencing. Car is very smooth on EV and engine as well. Very good accelerators when we put it on Sport mode.

I’ve had my 2023 hatchback (preferred trim) for about a year now… It’s been fantastic and I fall in love with it more and more every day. The engine is perfect for a variety of driving conditions. The interior is so luxurious it reminds me of BMW. Yet only around 25K to pick one up. I’m excited to see how this car holds up in the future…

Bought 2021 Mazda 3 Hatch premium plus. Love this car! This is my third Mazda and not one mechanical issue since new. Smooth ride, quick and comfortable. Couple small issues with design and features but nothing that would change my mind

The Mazda 3 Hatch Is best in class for style and amenities. Truly a rare find, and it still turns heads. Reliability is phenomenal, mated with a driver-centric focus. It's not a race car, but a driver's car for those who understand and appreciate the value with a hint of luxury.

I love my Mazda it is fast has opinions of manual or automatic. Lot of safety features, it get good gas mileage. It's a good looking vehicle. It's a vehicle I would definitely recommend to others when look at vehicle
Great safety features and sporty looking car with vivid red metalic colour that has generated many compliments.

I'm so happy this car lives in my garage.  It has all the bells and whistles, safety equipment out my ears, and is a fun to drive, good looking car. The Infotainment system is my only complaint, as it took forever to understand and learn all the options. It works well with our iPhones, although it sometimes will load the iPhone in the house instead of the iPhone of the person driving the car, and it has to re-load Spotify when it's three houses down the block. The GPS is a pain to use, compared to the one in the iPhone.  To input an address, one has to dial a wheel to select each letter; a cumbersome and silly practice.

The safety warnings will make you jump at first: the noise is loud and scary, making you look at the dashboard to find out what you're doing wrong. Often, it's the car telling you that the lane markers are too close. The car also lets you know when you're speeding with a big red line along the speedometer, showing the difference in your speed and the legal speed. Your speed is also viewable on the windshield, handy unless you're wearing polarized sunglasses.

I am a whole five feet tall, and the car remembers my mirror and seat settings, and is easy to get in and out.  My six foot tall husband does not have as easy a time getting in and out, and if you're a big person, you might want to look for another car. The car remembers two drivers information, quite convenient if you're not the only one driving.

I'd buy this car again, although I might not pick the top-of-the-line equipment package.  We bought that car over the less-equipped car because our car had heated seats, automatic braking and was in stock at the dealer, a rarity during a computer chip shortage. We also got the car for a good price, and even a year later, the trade in value is more than we paid for the car. We also looked at Toyotas and Hondas, and were unable to find a car that had anywhere near this level of equipment at the price we paid.

I absolutely love my 2021 Mazda 3 premium 6speed manual hatchback.  It feels like a luxury vehicle and it's very fun to drive.  Great handling.  Pretty good gas mileage.  Very reliable (so far).  I hope to get a good 15 years out of this vehicle and I'm very happy with it.  #savethemanuals

I took delivery of my 2021 Mazda 3 Turbo Sedan premium plus package on February 19th of 2021 and I can say that the last year has been a satisfying experience with no surprises 1 way or the other. This car is kind of unique in it's class as it pampers you with craftsmanship and features that you typically don't find in this segment but at a price point befitting Mazda. It nails the elusive trifecta of price, performance and quality better than any car I've ever owned.

Solid well built and reliable. What more could you want?? Excellent fuel economy is a bonus. High 30's mpg running at 80 mph! Remarkable. Have about 50k miles with zero problems. 1 battery and 1 set of tires; nothing else after 8.5 years of ownership.
Great car for one or two passengers.
Added a trailer hitch to carry bike rack.
Adequate power will keep up with any traffic situation. Paint work is amazing.

This was the first Mazda I have ever owned and I was not persuaded by a dealer. It was a car guy that driven many cars for the insurance company. I use to have a BMW and paid much more money than I needed on that car. When I had tried 11 other cars and took this one for a test drive, I knew this car I could drive day to day. I did get the S3 with all the bells and whistles though. I have been vey happy with this car for the past 7 years. Only complaint was hearing the road noise through this model. This car was good on gas and virtually maintenance free. On schedule changing oils and fluids. of course tires and brake pads periodic replacement needed. The S3 Mazda is a car to be driven not just to your destination but to be enjoyed on the way to your destination.

I've been driving little Mazdas since 1986, when I bought a new 4-door Mazda 323 for the wife.  As time went by, and the kids got bigger, the time came for her to upgrade to a minivan.  By then, I enjoyed driving "her car" so much I figured I'll just inherit that ride from her, and just sold mine.  This became the first car to survive my tough driving (think x-country outback rally), and it didn't need a new clutch (it was stick) after my first 20,000 miles driving it.

I drove it through 215,000 miles on the odometer.  I got another little Mazda, and by then they were known as the "3".  That replacement Mazda had to be automatic bcs I'd developed "clutch foot".  Fast forward to my 2010 Mazda 3 and I got the pleasant surprise of the most amazing 6-speed automatic ever made, which allowed shifting without a clutch.  By the time I got the 2018 model I'm driving now, it had all become second nature to me:  we had become one, a modern-day centaur.  My dealer wants to buy it back from me.  Can't believe what Kelley Blue Book tells me it's worth.  But, hell, she's part of the family now and there's no one on this Earth coming between us.  <3  :)

This Mazda is in good shape, has only 73000 miles, I bought it 2 years ago from a dealer in Steven Creek. 
I am selling the car because I am moviing out of the country, If I get an offer the potential buyer should knoow that the car would be ready for delivery by the end of March

Super fun to drive, flawless reliability, comfortable for 2 people and luggage even on long trips and 30+ MPG.  Love this car.  The 2.5 engine in sport mode with paddle shifters is great fun with good front wheel drive handling.

Basic but so advanced. Many features and components of the car are so basically designed yet so sleek and luxurous mapped and placed. Quite economic  for it's mpg and mrsp though with Mazdas niche being handling over power. You feel full control of the car as she glides through corners almost ten miles faster yet still somehow smoother then majority in it's class. Like the Miata you truly feel every bit of power that car offers without that "wasted" or "unused"  Hp and Tq feeling. I am 6 foot 4 and honestly feel genuinely comfortable and snug even on long drives. Though the interior spacing on the hatchback does feel more like a three door coup.  I've driven many different vehicles in my life, while not knowing a single thing about Mazda besides the kid saying zoom zoom. I now find that its gonna be hard to switch makes in the future.
Overall experience with this car has me wanting to keep buying mazda vehicles.  My Mazda3 hatchback been the most reliable car I've ever had.
Classy car, exceptional ride, fantastic features, beautiful sound system. Excellent mileage. Performs beautifully. For a car in this price range your getting a lot for your money.

I upgraded to a 2018 Mazda 6 Signature and love it. The engine has such an awesome sound to it, and has a great sound system. The heated seats in the front and back are a nice touch, as well as the front ventilated seats. This car has a luxury feel, without a luxury price. Highly recommend!
Great design, fuel economy is good and overall performance is excellent. Interior is little bit noisy but it’s okay for me.

This is a great car, I bought it cash money. In the summer on a trip, it gets 39MPG and around 30 to 31 in town. I bought it to give to my granddaughter when she finished high school and got her license, I got myself a 2016 Mazda CX 5 because I am 68 years old and overweight and it was hard for me to get out of due to my health conditions. We are at a time when almost all American car makers are making cars that they know are inferior and have problems with them. I would put this car up against a Toyoda any day. It rides good, drives great, and is a solid over all well-built car that is dependable.

Mazda's paint trim is beautiful to look at. To live with the paint is to endure chipping, flaking, and rust bubbles above the front windshield. This is the weakest point, bar none.  I average 27 miles per gallon, even with a heavy club foot. With a full tank of gas, I get 365-400 miles of mixed city and highway.  Although a four-cylinder turbo, it feels like a mighty six-cylinder engine beneath the bonnet. Others say the car will pace at 80-90 mph and return 25 mpg, sounds good to me.  I have owned, or a family member who has owned and driven a 2005, 2013, 2014, 2018, and 2019 Mazda 3 & 6, and every one of their front brakes warped prematurely.  I finally asked the shop why. The response is that Mazda OEM rear brakes are smaller in diameter than the front brakes. Also, the leather trim on the steering wheel noticeably wears and dis-colors which is not something one would want to look at daily.  If you opt for anything other than leather, the driver's seat eventually looks like it was singed with a hot iron.  The factory tires are good. Over the years, my best experience with tires is Falken and Continental Tires.  Both cases work as one with the suspension more seamlessly than any other brand.  

Germain Mazda Service has taken care of my family for years.  Whatever the shortcoming that may come with the car, the care has stepped up in every regard. I am delighted with my own experience because they care and our knowledgeable. Bottomline, the Mazda 6 is not without its quirks, and clearly, there are areas that Mazda can improve upon, but I trust that they will do right by me because they have since 2005 to the present. I believe they will do the right thing in the previously mentioned areas concerning the paint finish, the seat, and the steering wheel. 
And if they don't, they cannot. Right.  Sometimes they have limits too, just like you and I.  

I highly recommend the Mazda brand and Germain Mazda because they care about the experience of driving Mazda.

This car has been a true joy. It is very comfortable and is fun to drive. There has been no problems. The original equipment tires were garbage and the car rides and handles better since they were replaced. The interior and exterior finish are superior and I still get compliments on how it looks. It is a shame that Mazda discontinued this model rather than update and improve.
The best  sedan I have ever owned to date, it gets 38 mpg on the open highway and has been maintenance free so far at 55,000

I bought a 2018 Metallic Gray Grand Touring Reserve a few months back and it has been a great experience so far.  The car has every option I wanted and was overpriced, but I didn't care because these are hard to find.  This looks and feels like a luxury car with a quick engine and a great sound system, how can you go wrong with that.

Car is in great shape. It is maintained as required by owners book. I have been the only owner Heated leather seats are really nice in the winter. Nice dash display. It has really good safety features: lane departure, back-up camera with cross traffic warning. Side mirror notification for blind spots.

My red miata RF is a manual transmission. I use it mainly on weekends. Mileage has been just over 35 mpg combined. I recently took it for a drive in nearby Yarnell and thoroughly enjoyed the winding roads. This vehicle handles unbelievably and where it lack straight away speed it makes up for in precise handling and sheer fun!!!  I barely used my breaks and navigated these fun winding roads easily catching and passing other vehicles too timid to try to handle the turns. Can’t wait to head up North to Jerome and handle those roads. Smiling as I write this.

The MX-5 RF with the six speed manual transmission is a fun car to drive with adequate power. It has more body roll in corners than I expected. The Bridgestone tires that came on it are terrible, flat spot and rated very poorly by Tire Rack. With the relatively narrow tires, low horsepower and being light make it is extremely fun to drive and throw around corners at reasonable speeds. It is a momentum car and will teach someone how to drive a slow car fast rather than a fast car slow. I traded a Porsche Cayman GTS in on this car. Both my wife and I are enjoying it more than the Cayman.

After 2 years it still feels like a new car and I still love the design. Handles great and I’ve enjoyed a couple of road trips in my Miata. It’s comfortable for myself and passenger, unless they’re on the tall side. I was torn about getting a hard top but very happy I did, it transitions to convertible so quickly and effortlessly. This model does have a small glove compartment located in between the seat backs, but it’s not very convenient to use. As many have pointed out, no spare tire is one of the only drawbacks.
It is just what the doctored ordered…sleek, beautiful, fast and fun! Black with red interior…I LOVE IT. It’s a true sports car and handles accordingly.

The first car I look forward to driving every day.   The positives are known.  
Negatives include a horribly underpowered AC, shameless cost-cutting on the Sports trim ($28k car with $5 paper speakers that fell apart in less than 3 years, uncomfortable plastic elbow rest, worn shifter knob and other pound-foolish material savings by Mazda) and substandard service experience at dealerships in the Miami/Ft Lauderdale area.   Road noise is bad but unavoidable and easily controlled with earbuds.  
Still 5-star after all of that, for the unmatchable fun to drive factor.

Like new! Tinted windows. Clear bra!
Apple car play. Low mileage. Second owner. Clear title. Fun driving car.

Daily drive this car in 4 season weather. Under rated as an All Season car. Not a garage queen so it gets snow / ice / extreme cold / monsoon rains & extreme heat. Thru all these conditions this roadster has surprised me at how it drives with the proper tires. What is also great is the after market parts available to make it just a little better. Very reliable. I immediately bought PPF to protect the paint ( front only plus side mirrors ) well worth the extra cost. Added benefit is if you like to DIY its easy to work on. The new ND2 models have improvements but love my Club so no trade in ( got a great deal when I bought ). No spare tire as you get an electric air pump & fix a flat kit. I live close by work so miles are light. Simply the best car I've ever owned.
I'm 6' and I spend at least 3 hours a day commuting in total in this car and it's easily the best part of my day. It's a little noisy inside, but it's a soft top. Totally recommend.

My red miata RF is a manual transmission. I use it mainly on weekends. Mileage has been just over 35 mpg combined. I recently took it for a drive in nearby Yarnell and thoroughly enjoyed the winding roads. This vehicle handles unbelievably and where it lack straight away speed it makes up for in precise handling and sheer fun!!!  I barely used my breaks and navigated these fun winding roads easily catching and passing other vehicles too timid to try to handle the turns. Can’t wait to head up North to Jerome and handle those roads. Smiling as I write this.
