I have a 2022 Accent which is no longer being sold in the US Market.   I paid 19,300.00 for the vehicle brand new.   My vehicle is the SEL version which I think is the best of the three and  I easily get over 40 mph on the highway and about 33 in town.  I have had it for a year and a half and it has been problem free so far.    I don't get the no power knock on the Accent.  It has more power and less noise than my 2008 Toyota Corolla that I had before I made the Accent purchase.   This has been a great car so far.  Sad to see small cars disappearing as if everyone has tens of thousands to spend on an SUV.
It’s tight handling with plenty of power and comfortable. A lot of fun to drive with enough room for a subcompact.

I am a senior and this is a second car for me. It is brand new so I cannot speak to reliability etc.
In mostly city driving I am averaging over 40 mpg, which for not being a hybrid is amazing. California's crazy high fuel prices necessitated this purchase as I am on a pension. Thank Brandon!  
I can say that for its price, it is very comfortable, reasonably quiet and has good ride comfort. What is called a basic car today was a luxury ride when I first bought a new car. No power accessories, no A/C and an AM radio only. The Accent's 7 inch infotainment is super easy to navigate and my phone connected quickly and voice quality and command recognition is very good. A/C blows very cold and strong, it gets well over 100F where I live. The engine idles very smoothly which was a nice surprise. Materials are hard plastic but look good and fit and finish is very good. Don't confuse lack of colors and soft touch surfaces with build quality. All panels and moldings are fitted well and there are no squeaks or rattles so far. The seat lacks long distance comfort but a padded seat cover helped that. I have the SEL trim. I researched heavily and this is the best value of the 3 trim levels. LED lighting is the rage but wait till you have to replace an entire assembly for $500 when one fails instead of just a bulb for $10 from O'Reilly's. 
The trunk is not rated high in space but the shape matters and the Accent's trunk has a great shape for luggage and takes a surprising amount plus my golf bag fits easily in the wide opening.
In summary, you get real value in this vehicle especially when you factor in the warranty and maintenance. This is likely my last new car and I am fine with that. With age you learn less is more. A sub $200 monthly payment is the cherry on top. I considered a Nisan Leaf but I will probably croak before I hit break even on it compared to the Accent. Oh, almost forgot, the 6 speaker stereo in the SEL and up has surprisingly good fidelity to it and has a lot of adjustments in the head unit. Sirius XM sounds especially good due to signal quality.
Nissan Versa SV was the competition for me. It had more safety tech but I know how to drive. The mileage was comparable and my son's Versa has been good so far at 53K miles but the CVT transmission is the unknown there. We had our's dealer serviced, they are the only ones that will do it, and it cost $600. So Nissan buyers beware you have that big service coming at you.
The Accent uses a new Hyundai CVT design with a chain instead of metal belt. However, the Versa uses simpler port FI instead of the high pressure GDI that the Accent has. Early Hyundai GDI has leak and engine fire issues. Google it. But they have been building them for 10 years now so I keep my fingers crossed. The Sport mode in the Accent really does liven up the car in town but fuel economy will drop a few mpg's. Overall if you are an adult driver, seek high fuel economy and keep your vehicle a long time, the Accent is an excellent choice. Especially if you already have a larger vehicle for stuff and you like the style and driving characteristics of a sedan. The higher profile tires contribute a quieter and smoother ride and will be cheaper to replace! I hope my research and observations help.
Car is new, getting rid of car due to a death. Been kept in garage. Has clean title. Very clean with no scratches.

The car is silver gray with a sun roof. I have not used it much so it only has 6000 miles on it.  Have taken it for service when appropriate.
My dealer keeps asking to buy it!!!!
Great car, very reliable, great on gas. Low cost of maintenance. Only selling my car because I want to upgrade to a different Hyundai.

I just drove off the lot today in my new 2021 Accent SEL, after trading in my 2020 Elantra SEL, given that the Elantra's been in for servicing 3 times in one year with under 6500 miles on it.  The 2020 Elantra has had 37 complaints with the NHTSA.  I had to have TCU/ECU updates, an actuator replaced, and a range sensor replaced.  FORGET IT...it was time to say goodbye to that car.  There's good and bad about every car, but from my research, the Accent is Hyundai's most reliable car, and a reliable car in general, and it certainly gets good gas mileage.  I don't know why some experts complain that the performance is sluggish.  I drove 80 miles back from the dealership today, and the Accent had more zippy performance than the Elantra I traded in.  There's also been complaining about outside noise coming into the cabin while highway driving.  I'm certainly not experiencing that.  My Accent has no more wind noise, etc. than the Elantra.  Although the interior is roomy ...no less roomy than the Elantra(in the front seats anyway), I gave a 4-star for comfort because I haven't determined if the seat's lumbar support is good enough for longer driving distances.  However, my Accent has tilt/telescopic on the steering wheel, so I didn't totally adjust that properly before leaving the dealership, so it'll probably adjust my posture to a better position when I do.  The bottom line is that I gave up a car with the bells and whistles of blind spot monitor, lane assist(which I never used anyway), and rear cross traffic alert, because reliability's more important to me.  Reliability and good gas mileage are the two main things I seek out when car buying, and with a very good track record of reliability and with the good gas mileage I've found in this vehicle, the Accent was an ideal choice for me.  Plus, you're getting a 5-year/60,000 basic warranty, 10 year/100,000 drivetrain warranty, 7 year/unlimited miles perforation warranty, 5 years of roadside assistance, and 3 years of maintenance.  I'm sure I've made a smart decision in purchasing the 2021 Accent.
Perfect for a small family. Great trunk space.

Love the styling, ride, high mpg (getting 41-46 mpg) and roominess but transmission had to be replaced at only 7,500 mi. Dealership had the car for more than six weeks. Several recalls for various things. Have a friend with a late model Sonata in which the engine had to be replaced. No more Hyundai for me when the lease is up in a couple months.

Amazing car, bought it for gas mileage. Its non hybrid, i get average 42 to 46 mpg consistently. I drove it easy once about 150 miles mostly highway and got up to 54.3 mpg. All the features are fantastic. My car recieves updates from Hyundai automatically. The other day it up dated the head unit in the car. The few minor things i wasn't crazy about all went away with recent update. This car with mostly self drive on the highway. Way cheaper than a Tesla. I drive about 38000 miles a year.

This model is simple with great gas mileage. 
Plenty of power for everyday travel. Seat design is comfortable. No major blind spots like so many of its competitors. Interior integrity holds up; however the vents for ac/ heater are at awkward positioning, making it hard for people in the back to feel the heat or cold . Also with the interior design of the car, there’s no real great place to position a cell phone for hands off accessibility. ( vents and dash -bad for holders)  It’s low profile front in is high enough to clear for most parking pylons, and curbs which is a plus - unlike some of the competitors ex: Ford fusion . Handles well on turns and suspension is average. Includes lane correction  and modern screen for BT .  Only  issue so far is that my back up camera has stopped working which may be a simple fix. Not really sure why the car tells me to take a break after only driving 6-7 miles on my way to work with a coffee mug pic on the dash but Overall 👍
Not a scratch or ding on it. Color is electric shadow. Interior is in immaculate condition.Garage kept.

Even the base model has features like lane assist and ignition off and if you drive normal not being a lead foot you can get easy 36 mpg at an average but put the drive mode into speed mode it will give that extra giddy up you need to keep up with any car in its class
Saves great money on gas and is an excellent car for traveling. I would definitely recommend this car with the rising gas prices.

Definitely have the windows tinted if you are sunlight sensitive, the windshield is huge. Traction on snow and ice isn't as good as most front wheel drive vehicles, but not the worst either.
The technology and features on the vehicle are amazing.
love the look and style of my car it’s very comfortable and fast also great for long road trips best gas mileage. Best warranty I’ve ever had this is my 3rd Hyundai can’t get enough of them

I bought my 2018 Elantra with 6 miles on the odometer, now six years later it has 87,150 miles on it and I've not spend a dime on maintenance other than oil changes, and filters (including cabin) and to replace the cheap tires that came with it.

I have this vehicle and it has only been 4 years since buying it from a Rental car dealership. Since owning this car I have had continuous electrical issues from Ignition coils, spark plugs, to my car being stolen (#TheKiaHyundaiChallenge), to now having a P0017 code not going away even after multiple repairs. This car truly is great on gas and is somewhat reliable but repairs wise, it IS NOT great. Hyundai is also TERRIBLE with repairs for it. Seems like continuous issues pop-up at certain mileages, which has just happened to me at 140,000 miles. If I would've known this I would have gotten a Honda or Toyota because they are much more reliable and easier to fix. After my car being stolen and recovered, I swore I was never going to get a Hyundai ever again! The dealership car service department in my area is also TERRIBLE! They seem overworked with not enough technicians and with so many issues popping up on the car you can already imagine how difficult it is for me to repair it. 

So just overall, it WILL continue to run but considering I have had a Toyota before this car and seeing the amount of electrical issues I have had with this Hyundai I wouldn't recommend it to ANYONE.

I love my 2017 Elantra.  I bought it for delivering Amazon packages in 2020.  It was a previously leased vehicle and I've put 130,000 miles on it and it still loves to go.  I average 35-37 MPG.  It does burn oil and I have to add to it every couple of weeks just to be safe.  This is due to poorly designed piston rings that have become worn.  I'll drive it til it dies.
I love this car. Excellent fuel economy and clutch provides a smooth shift. I have had 0 problems with this one or the 2011 that I owned. Smooth ride for the money

I bought my 2018 Hyundai Elantra new with six miles on it, it now has 85,000 mostly freeway miles, but It's had two official recalls, one for programming, one for the locks and one "quiet advisory" for a steering wheel that makes a grinding noise... even after the repair in-warranty the noise is back after only one year.  The door button sticks so the car thinks the door is closed when it's open.  Oh, the car sits so low that if you get too close to a curb, it'll rip the plastic air dam off the bumper... nice. 

Now for the good stuff, it still looks brand new inside and out, the engine, transmission and everything else not mentioned has been trouble free.

Best car for the money I've ever owned.  After 6 completely trouble free years this car continues to impress far above its price class.  The Limited with Ultimate Package is an honest 'near luxury car' experience.  Leather seats with memory, full tech driver assist features (like adaptive cruise control, lane keep assist, auto emergency braking, etc.), and even dynamic headlights that turn (aim) as you turn the wheel.  And very fuel efficient .  I get over 40mpg (gas used per miles driven) at 72-74mph which is consistently beating EPA estimates.

Do not buy this car. They get stolen easily. No engine immobilizer, no alarm, nothing, total junk. These don't go pass 100,000 miles. If you are lucky to even get that with the engine recalls. All are bad. Engine and transmission issues. No wonder why these used cars are $13,000-19,000. Definitely not worth it. Save yourself. I traded mine in 3 days ago so it won't get stolen. What a headache. Noisy engine even at 5,500 miles
Hasn't given me any problems and it has plenty of power on the highway. Would recommend it to everyone that wants a affordable price car

Definitely have the windows tinted if you are sunlight sensitive, the windshield is huge. Traction on snow and ice isn't as good as most front wheel drive vehicles, but not the worst either.
The technology and features on the vehicle are amazing.
love the look and style of my car it’s very comfortable and fast also great for long road trips best gas mileage. Best warranty I’ve ever had this is my 3rd Hyundai can’t get enough of them
This is my 4th EV and by far the best EV, and car in general. Very comfortable and quiet. Underated in many ways. Getting better than rated range in winter.
I recommended it to anyone who is still in the middle of making a decision of buying an electric vehicle, I definitely made the best choice.

We're in love with our unit. I bought it for my wife, but I absolutely love driving this unit. Is our first EV and we were kind of worried, but is been amazing this 7 months. Our shooting star matte finish, have been easy to take care (not as hard as you usually read). Almost 12,000 miles and is giving us a range between 320 and 340 miles per charge. We live in Puerto Rico and the weather is perfect for the unit, which is SEL RWD. Highly recommended!!!
This car is amazing on all levels. Sport look, luxury style, great drive and handling and most people can't take their eyes off it.

Very cheaply made vehicles. I, personally wouldn't recommend this. It's new under warranty, but continues to liyin the shop. Absolutely the worst vehicles out there. Stop being eye blinded by looks. JD power and CP Value Estimator shows these are at the bottom of the list for terrible resale value.
Four months in and we still argue over who gets to drive.  Stylish, comfortable, good storage space, fast and fun to drive.

My first EV and it’s a winner. Enjoying everything about this car. Glad I traded in my 2020 Subaru Outback for one of the best electric cars around.  There is limited inventory so dealers are adding premium charges to sticker prices. I took an SE because it was the only version available in my desired colors. SE could use a better sound system. Otherwise it’s a dream car.
Nice car, so much fun to drive snd do easy to own. Way underpriced fir yhe quality.  I got one for all six of my kids

I’ve owned the Ioniq 6 for six weeks and 1200 miles.  The car has exceeded my expectations.  I admit to being a hyper-miler having previously owned a Prius.  With those practices in an Ioniq 6 SE long range, I’m achieving well over 361 miles of range.  The DC fast charge time is also very fast.  My only complaints are ones other reviewers have noted - a cord connection to use Apple CarPlay, a small trunk, and the need to get used to window openers in a center console.  These are minor compared to its range, very smooth and quiet ride, spacious interior, and sporty but aerodynamic exterior design.  This is a great car that’s better than the Model 3 and without all of the Tesla “baggage.” I highly recommend this car.

Yeah it has road noise and it can get uncomfortable after driving for 4 or so hours- so I have a cushion and lumbar pillow for that. As for the road noise- I turn up the radio.  As far as anything else goes I have had ZERO problems with this thing and am at 40,000 miles.  The gas mileage is on average (winter through summer) about 55mpg.  I get as low as 48 and as high as 63.  I paid 20K for this and it was a new dealer car with 1000 miles on it.  The car is perfect for what it is. An unbelievable deal.

Good things: Fuel economy, clean and simple, hatchback room for filling car full of your stuff, slick look, no issues at 90,000+ miles.

Could be better: road noise is super loud in cabin (probably due to simple, light weight design) so I wear airpods while driving to mitigate noise and easily answer phone calls. Car dealerships don't sell a spare tire with it (why?).

This car doesn't necessarily pin you to your seat when you accelerate so don't buy it to drag race but honestly it's the best commuter I've had and seriously have had zero issues. Obviously small things wear out like every car but this car gets a 5 star rating nothing less.

I tried driving a Prius and it seemed OK but lacked apple CarPlay, the styling wasn’t as appealing and was more expensive. The 6 speed DCT is superior to Toyota’s CVT in my opinion. I bought this white 2019 SEL trim used with under 19k miles in late 2020. I now have 37.5k miles on it. The only problem I had was the windshield washer fluid pump went out and they replaced it under the awesome warranty. None of the competitors offer a 5 year 60k bumper to bumper warranty. Here in south Florida I easily get 54-57 mpg with mostly city driving. Follow the maintenance schedule and this car should last a long time.

I love my Ionic hybrid!!  I have had no problems with this car. I get 58 MPG on the freeway.  The ride is comfortable.  The seats wipe clean with a wet cloth.  The hatchback is quite spacious and the back seats can fold down if you need more room.  Great car!!

Bought it used in Pittsburg PA, drove it 1,800 home to south texas - SUPER efficient! Averaged 5.6 miles per kilowatt. Getting 200 miles per charge (instead of the advertised 170miles) going 65 mph with the Driver side A/C on and radio on.

I have always researched extensively and then leased my cars because I wanted the 'out' of giving it back after 3 years if I didn't deem it worthy of a purchase.  That said, after coming across the Ioniq hybrid plug-in, I knew I had found my 'first purchase' and, after 3 years of local driving and road tripping across the U.S., I am still in love with it.  Sure, there are minor annoyances, like off the line momentary lag for acceleration, however, that is just something I know and got used to when driving a leased Ford C-Max plug-in hybrid that engaged immediately from stop to start and can give you a nausea if you put petal to the metal.  If you are an impatient driver, this might annoy you.  When I have tested the Ioniq hybrid Plug-in to get up to speed, it takes a bit but it's not a race car and I can overtake on a highway with confidence.  The MILEAGE is AMAZING and with between 600-700 miles per tank, depending on relative humidity and temperature when you fill it up, I can easily drive a 15 hour stretch without the need to fill up.  When road tripping in relatively isolated areas, where AAA will take a while if needed, I have no qualms about pushing my car and getting to my goal destination.  I've driven it in winter conditions and been confident in the Ioniq hybrid plug-in to get me where I need to go, although i'm not under the illusion that it will act like any 4-wheel drive, since it is still too low to the ground for taking that chance.  It is not powerful enough to tow but who would want to compromise the mileage you can get.  This would be a car that you would tow instead, behind your RV, so that you could camp out and then use it to drive around a local area without the worry of needing gas; especially with the great feature of 29 pure electric miles when you plug it in.  Which leads me to another thing I like about being able to add 29 miles to each day's 'tank':  you can plug into a regular household outlet in the garage and within 7h mine is all charged up.  With the driver's seat adjustable so my over 6ft 2in sons can drive in comfort, it would be nice to also have the passenger side adjustable too.  Maybe they are doing that in newer models?  I like to adjust the driver's seat each season because the sun's position changes and can blind you if you aren't positioned to use the window visor efficiently to block it out; front passenger not so lucky without that option.  I still love the car enough to be happy with my purchase and recommend this highly for someone who wants FANTASTIC gas mileage coupled with the ability to add an extra 29 miles each day after an overnight charge.   I love Hyundai's warranty and didn't have to pay for a thing for 3 years of initial warranty for regular check ups and oil changes.  NICE.

I purchased this vehicle in November of 2021. I've put a lot of miles on it (75 mile one way commute to work, 5 days a week).

The car says my gas mileage is 60-75 mpg, however when manually calculating this I get 58-62 in the winter and 61-68 in the warmer months. The trick to this car is to drive her nice and slow, try not to go above 60 mph or the gas mileage starts to tank...

Car wasn't perfect. Within the first 5 months my transmission started slipping. Hyundai warranty covered it and fixed the issue within a day at the dealer. Has been smooth ever since. No issues otherwise! For a new car, that is to be expected though.

The hybrid battery is nice, no lead battery to change anymore. When in electric mode, the car is nice and quiet, unless you're going under 30 mph, it then has to make noise (by law) and it sounds like a space ship...lol

This is not a performance car. Even in sport mode, it's a bit slow. Enough to get on the highways, but don't expect to win a race by any means. But this is good. If you're into maximizing your gas mileage, you learn to drive safer and more conservative. Keep in mind it's not the slowest car. If you've drive a Mirage, you'll understand.

The styling isn't bad. I like the front end. The back dual window setup is a bit annoying. Top window isn't tall enough, and the bar in the middle is an awkward blind spot. A bit irritating at first, but you get use to it. 

Overall, I'm saving significantly on gas now. The lithium-polymer battery should last 10-15 years, and by that point should be fairly affordable to replace. The battery is located under the rear seats, and is easy to get to. If you're mechanically inclined, I'm sure you could replace it yourself, sort of like a Prius. 

Oil, intake filter and spark plugs are easy to get to. HSG belt (their name for the serpentine belt) is easy to get to, but you will need to order a custom tool to actually install it (eBay for $20).

For $25,000 for the Blue trim, I've never owned such a feature rich and fuel efficient vehicle before. Highly recommend unless you're going through a mid-life crisis or something. Affordable, cheap to maintain, long warranty, what more could you ask for in a new car?

I have had this car for five years, and had to go 400 miles just to get it.  I absolutely love this car!  My daughter has been driving it now, and I really miss it.  It is a perfect size, has a ton of trunk space, and has every convenience that I could wish for.

Yeah it has road noise and it can get uncomfortable after driving for 4 or so hours- so I have a cushion and lumbar pillow for that. As for the road noise- I turn up the radio.  As far as anything else goes I have had ZERO problems with this thing and am at 40,000 miles.  The gas mileage is on average (winter through summer) about 55mpg.  I get as low as 48 and as high as 63.  I paid 20K for this and it was a new dealer car with 1000 miles on it.  The car is perfect for what it is. An unbelievable deal.

Good things: Fuel economy, clean and simple, hatchback room for filling car full of your stuff, slick look, no issues at 90,000+ miles.

Could be better: road noise is super loud in cabin (probably due to simple, light weight design) so I wear airpods while driving to mitigate noise and easily answer phone calls. Car dealerships don't sell a spare tire with it (why?).

This car doesn't necessarily pin you to your seat when you accelerate so don't buy it to drag race but honestly it's the best commuter I've had and seriously have had zero issues. Obviously small things wear out like every car but this car gets a 5 star rating nothing less.

I tried driving a Prius and it seemed OK but lacked apple CarPlay, the styling wasn’t as appealing and was more expensive. The 6 speed DCT is superior to Toyota’s CVT in my opinion. I bought this white 2019 SEL trim used with under 19k miles in late 2020. I now have 37.5k miles on it. The only problem I had was the windshield washer fluid pump went out and they replaced it under the awesome warranty. None of the competitors offer a 5 year 60k bumper to bumper warranty. Here in south Florida I easily get 54-57 mpg with mostly city driving. Follow the maintenance schedule and this car should last a long time.

I love my Ionic hybrid!!  I have had no problems with this car. I get 58 MPG on the freeway.  The ride is comfortable.  The seats wipe clean with a wet cloth.  The hatchback is quite spacious and the back seats can fold down if you need more room.  Great car!!

Bought it used in Pittsburg PA, drove it 1,800 home to south texas - SUPER efficient! Averaged 5.6 miles per kilowatt. Getting 200 miles per charge (instead of the advertised 170miles) going 65 mph with the Driver side A/C on and radio on.

I have always researched extensively and then leased my cars because I wanted the 'out' of giving it back after 3 years if I didn't deem it worthy of a purchase.  That said, after coming across the Ioniq hybrid plug-in, I knew I had found my 'first purchase' and, after 3 years of local driving and road tripping across the U.S., I am still in love with it.  Sure, there are minor annoyances, like off the line momentary lag for acceleration, however, that is just something I know and got used to when driving a leased Ford C-Max plug-in hybrid that engaged immediately from stop to start and can give you a nausea if you put petal to the metal.  If you are an impatient driver, this might annoy you.  When I have tested the Ioniq hybrid Plug-in to get up to speed, it takes a bit but it's not a race car and I can overtake on a highway with confidence.  The MILEAGE is AMAZING and with between 600-700 miles per tank, depending on relative humidity and temperature when you fill it up, I can easily drive a 15 hour stretch without the need to fill up.  When road tripping in relatively isolated areas, where AAA will take a while if needed, I have no qualms about pushing my car and getting to my goal destination.  I've driven it in winter conditions and been confident in the Ioniq hybrid plug-in to get me where I need to go, although i'm not under the illusion that it will act like any 4-wheel drive, since it is still too low to the ground for taking that chance.  It is not powerful enough to tow but who would want to compromise the mileage you can get.  This would be a car that you would tow instead, behind your RV, so that you could camp out and then use it to drive around a local area without the worry of needing gas; especially with the great feature of 29 pure electric miles when you plug it in.  Which leads me to another thing I like about being able to add 29 miles to each day's 'tank':  you can plug into a regular household outlet in the garage and within 7h mine is all charged up.  With the driver's seat adjustable so my over 6ft 2in sons can drive in comfort, it would be nice to also have the passenger side adjustable too.  Maybe they are doing that in newer models?  I like to adjust the driver's seat each season because the sun's position changes and can blind you if you aren't positioned to use the window visor efficiently to block it out; front passenger not so lucky without that option.  I still love the car enough to be happy with my purchase and recommend this highly for someone who wants FANTASTIC gas mileage coupled with the ability to add an extra 29 miles each day after an overnight charge.   I love Hyundai's warranty and didn't have to pay for a thing for 3 years of initial warranty for regular check ups and oil changes.  NICE.

I have had this car for five years, and had to go 400 miles just to get it.  I absolutely love this car!  My daughter has been driving it now, and I really miss it.  It is a perfect size, has a ton of trunk space, and has every convenience that I could wish for.

Decided to make the jump to electric - have a 2022 Tucson PHEV and had a 2023 Elantra Hybrid, traded in the Elantra for the Kona. Went with the Limited trim, black exterior and sage green interior. Very zippy, comfortable, and tons of amenities. Debated getting a used Kona, but with current cash back from Hyundai, it made sense to go new, and it’s bigger and more comfortable than the previous model. Will be using this primarily for commuting; my employer offers free Chargepoint charging, which helps a ton.

I have the base trim in Mirage Green. I drive 60 miles one way to work and compared to my 2015 Jeep compass it gets amazing gas mileage. Has great features for a base model and it doesn’t break the bank. Love the wireless Apple car play. Overall I’m extremely happy with my new vehicle.

So far I have had no issues with this car to be honest it's so much easier to drive then my tesla was I felt the tesla was very aggressive with everything built in to the center display...the knoa feels more like a normal car has normal controls simple to charge with the charger port in the front of the car  I do have to say the navigation feels a bit behind

This car is the worst car I’ve ever owned. I traded in a 2014 Hyundai Tucson, towards the new Kona. 
Despite having a 2.0 liter engine, and the possibility of that being enough engine power for the car, it is woefully underpowered. 
The car looks good, but can’t get out of its own way. 
If you’re ever in a situation that dictates you move fast to avoid an accident, you’re probably going to have an accident. 
Please, please, please, learn from my mistake, and buy something else…. Anything else. 
This. Car. Is. Trash.

4100 miles. 2 Recalls + 5 injectors misfire and now entire sunroof assembly needs replaced but parts on back order till 60 days out!!!  We have owned 4 konos and loyal to the brand but now its a lemon and done!!  DO NOT purchase this car and their customer service is non existent. BY Hyundai forever .. Dealers to service your car are a 30 day wait .

I have the Limited trim of the 2024 Kona Electric and I have to say I find this car to be pretty good. The only con I would have would be the charging times of course, but I have found it to be not a big deal, due to me charging at work. The ride is smooth and the features on the inside are very good. If you are looking at the 2024 Kona Electric definitely go for the Limited trim because the extra features are well worth the extra $3k. 

I'll post another review after a couple of months on the road with it.

Awesome vehicle with good storage in the back. The only issue is the back seat is not conducive to passengers if people in the front are tall. If using for 1-2 people plus storage, it is an amazing vehicle.

First off, I have to say that I am very impressed with Hyundai as a manufacturer. The quality of their vehicles, the fit and finish, and everything that they have done is really calm class. Hyundai is as good as any vehicle made by anybody else anywhere in the world.

The vehicle itself has been great. Had no problem with it, and it is silent and powerful. I’d love the electric performance and the regenerative baking. Everything about it is just superb. I would have no problem buying another Hyundai vehicle in the future. I’m completely satisfied with this one.
No other vehicle I’ve brings as many smiles per mile.  Very practical and descent gas mileage.  I’ve had no problems with it except needed to change tires to all season.
I love this car.  It's my first small crossover and it truly perfect car for me.  It turns on a dime and has style. Mine is loaded so really nice ride and sound! Highly suggest.

I special ordered my 2019 Hyundai kona ultimate AWD. Lime green twist color with black accent...my favorite color! My favorites in options. Love seat adjustment, heated seats, steering adjustment, storage space....the only things i would have added...lift kit, sits too low to the ground. Ambient lighting to match car color, in car vacuum

I'm on my second one.  Loved the first one, but dealer offered me a great deal to update and I did.  Recently was in an accident and the safety features were definitely up to par and saved us from any injuries.  the gas mileage I get is anywhere from 38-42 mpg.  I do drive mostly highway and that helps in this horrible economy.
Love this car very smooth and the road. Uypu can chance to the sport or smart mode that save more car

The Kona N is only going to make sense to a certain subset of people. Those people will really, really love it. It seems like Hyundai's attempt to give us a hot hatchback in a shape that the market is really into right now- the compact SUV. As a former GTI owner, the Kona N still has some of the same characteristics of the GTI and other hot hatchbacks of days gone by- a practical shape for folding down the rear seats and shoving in a bike or a dresser on occasion, a reasonably small footprint, and performance numbers that will shock people who judge cars by their badge. The Kona is just a lot less subtle about all of it. The styling is good looking but definitely not understated, lots of red trim and vents and diffusers (some of which are for looks only). The exhaust pops and snarls and crackles in sport mode which will either make you giggle like a kid or roll your eyes, maybe both. The suspension is very firm, probably to make the car corner well while maintaining its compact-SUV ride height. The turbo 4 can pull very respectable mid-30s mileage while cruising on the highway if you're cautious, but will drop to low 20s in the city. And in maximum attack mode on back roads, it is an absolute delight, but one that requires a lot more involvement than a GTI. It torque steers, it can get skittish over broken pavement because of the firm ride, but god it is FUN. It is a car that has a very distinct personality when driven fast. You don't just point the steering wheel and watch the revs climb. You have to get in there and make sure it doesn't go off into the bushes. And that's the enjoyable part.
It's not available as a stick, so manual purists won't like that. The cruise range is short. The interior, while full of features, is a little tight in back and doesn't have the near-luxury feel of a GTI. I keep referencing the GTI because that's about the closest thing to this car for now! It feels like an evil twin of that car, one that is a little more raw and powerful and unafraid to make compromises in the name of hold-on-tight driving fun. Maybe the Kona N is going to kick off a wave of tiny angry performance SUVs, since the American market is not always kind to tiny angry hot hatchbacks. I hope so. If you're looking for a way to go very fast for $35k and still maintain some practicality, and the GTI feels a little safe, this might be the ticket.

Awesome vehicle with good storage in the back. The only issue is the back seat is not conducive to passengers if people in the front are tall. If using for 1-2 people plus storage, it is an amazing vehicle.

No other vehicle I’ve brings as many smiles per mile.  Very practical and descent gas mileage.  I’ve had no problems with it except needed to change tires to all season.
I love this car.  It's my first small crossover and it truly perfect car for me.  It turns on a dime and has style. Mine is loaded so really nice ride and sound! Highly suggest.

Love seat adjustment, heated seats, steering adjustment, storage space....the only things i would have added...lift kit, sits too low to the ground. Ambient lighting to match car color, in car vacuum

i just recently bought a used 2020 NEXO (Limited) and I love it! - price was superb! the car rides super quiet, smooth, has three drive modes (ECO, ECO+, Standard), it feels like you are driving a flying machine, not a automobile.
Everything perfect, but i kept thinking... "what's the catch"? a car that retailed for ~$50K new, and now a mere 25% of that? 
Well, it turns out that H2 (Hydrogen) is extremely expensive ($36 per kg) , and there is only 1 functional H2 station in all of San Diego County.  
I have to drive about 35 miles one way just to get to the "pump". So a 70 mile (~ 1kg of H2) reserve is already established for me, based on this distance. It holds roughly 6 kg of h2. - So, about $240 to fill up!!!! ( should give you close to 500 mile range).
All the experts say it is going to start being a viable investment in the next 3-5 years.! If, and only IF Hydrogen goes down in price.
So, do your research. And if you live near a H2 station, then it may be a better deal for you.

I have owned the 2024 Hyundai Palisade Calligraphy since September 2023.  This is a great vehicle, overall handling is great, the perks, can't ask for a better vehicle.  Smooth handling,  when I step on the gas, it moves out...before we Purchased this vehicle, I had a 2019 Sierra Denali.  the Hyundai Palisade have more perks and a much better warranty.  Much more for a lower price.  Great Vehicle

Overall happy with everything, the only knock on the 1st Gen model is the you hear a lot of outside noise because the windows don't block it out the greatest but it isn't that bad. Sometimes it sounds like a window is cracked, but the wind goes through the seals. I would strongly recommend the palisade to anyone just because I think it's the best bang for your buck before you get into a luxury brand.

I have had many vehicles from Jeep Cherokee, Jeep commander, audi Quattro, Toyota 4 runner, Buick le Saber, and Honda civic, nissan xtarra (and many pickup trucks). This car I bought new for my wife in late fall of 2020. We have the lowest base model and it has all-wheel drive, in colorado its much needed! I have changed the oil every 5k, changed the transmission fluid and serpentine belt @ 65k, just replaced rear brakes and rotors @ 71k (front brakes still look good surprisingly) it handles smooth and I've had no issues with this car. Does great in snow, really all weather. We absolutely love this car and we both agree this is the best car we have ever owned. Thank you hyundai for making a great vehicle at an affordable price! 👏
Excelent car, very perfect conditions inside and outside. Very sure of driving and super elegant to enjoy with your family.
This is the best car you can get for the money...fantastic value and quality. The entire family loves this car.

I will never buy another Hyundai. My palisade is only 3 years old and my sunroof broke a couple of weeks ago. Today, my a/c broke!  Not to mention the seatbelt in the third row isn’t working, the stink that others have complained about, and a piece of the side of driver chair broke off. 42000 miles, $50000…buy from a different company. Oh! Hyundai also continues to put the extra money I pay onto my interest instead of principle. I’ve argued with them about this twice. They just kept lowering my next car payment.

We bought a 2020 XLS because we couldn’t find a limited at the time and after a year bought a 2021 Limited to get the HUD system and have driven this vehicle back and forth from Mass. to Florida and got 26 mpg and except for the last infotainment system upgrade which both us and the dealer couldn’t get the maps to work and they took away the 3 split screen which was awesome this vehicle is the best we have owned and we buy new vehicle every 2-3 years. Now we are buying a second 2023-24 Calligraphy Edition. I just wish they had better colors and electric steering wheel controls. Love this SUV.

Love the palisade, have had it for 2 years, driven about 25000 miles. Have not had any issues, rides like butter, its been an amazing buy. The only small little nagging thing is the voice search for destination, it gives network error most of the times. This option may have been removed in  the newer models, other than that i have had no complaints. Mileage is great, handles really well, it is pretty sporty in the sport mode, very comfortable on long rides........go buy it without hesitation .....i heard the newer ones have a massager in the front seats! Cant wait to upgrade!

If you are like me and miss a truck when you are driving a SUV,   the Santa Cruz is the answer.   This vehicle is so versatile.   It rides like a well built car,  has room for 5,  and has a bed that is the perfect size for most weekend trips to Home Depot and outdoor adventures.   A few weeks ago I bought a new SC,  SEL trim without the Activity Pkg.   I did not want the built in bed cover,   I had read it shortens the length of the bed a bit.   I have not taken any trips yet,  but around town I am getting a solid 22 mpg.   The vehicle is very well built,  secure on the road and quiet.   The only thing I would change is the some of the shiny plastic trim in the interior.  It seems to be a dust magnet.  I did find some carbon fiber trim on Amazon that really looks good, giving it a personal touch.  You cannot beat the warranty,  3 years of free maint,  and the dealership here in Lawrence KS was great to work with.   Take one out for a test drive,   you will be pleased,   and maybe,  like myself,   you will drive home a new one !

I have owned my 2024 Santa Cruz SEL for 6 weeks now and I am pleased with the overall performance of the truck. It rides like a luxury car not a truck, which is very nice change from the stiff suspension of most trucks. It has a self adjusting suspension, which gives it a smooth ride when it is not under a load. It has a 2.5 L 4 cylender engine. This provides plenty of power while also saving gas. I drive over 60 miles to and from work, so this is a must. The best gas mileage I have attained is 35.3 MPG while driving 65 MPH. I don't us the cruise control while in hilly terrain. The cruise control tends to overreact and will go from 1.5k RPMs to 2.8k RPMs if the MPH drops just 1 MPH. Needless to say that will impact the MPG. I simply maintain the current accelleration and let the MPH drop a mile or two. Maintaining a steady RPM ration is key to better gas mileage. The 8 speed transmission helps to keep the RPMs low both while accerating and at speed. The truck is a crew cab providing ample room in the from with limited leg room in the back. The bed of the truck is 4'x4' and will hold a full sheet of plywood with the tailgate down. Just not between the wheel wells. There are adjustable tie downs, making securing the load an easy task. The tailgate itself, is soft opening and can be operated from the remote. Both the tailgate and the tonneau cover will lock with the vehicle. One feature i discover by accident was that you can lock the tanneau cover at various positions. This allows you to keep most of the bed covered while allowing for taller items at the rear of the vehicle. The bed cover does not roll back and forth unless you unlock the latch. Under the bed is a water proof trunk which also locks withe the truck. Its fairly large and sits above the spare tire. I am fairly pleased with the truck thus far. I only have two complaints. The first is the overly aggressive cruise control, this really needs to be toned down to make it actually useful. The second is the locking system. If any door is open, the vehicle will not lock. It simply refuses to. Whether from the outside door lock switch, the remote or from the inside. This is not only frustrating, it's a security/safety hazard. Frustrating from the point of needing to wait for everyone to exit and close all the doors to a hazard from harrassing individuals. If I am loading groceries in the back seat (driver side) and my wife is in the truck (passenger side front), the doors cannot be locked unless I close the door. If an individual approaches, my wife cannot lock the doors until I close the open door. Thus allowing any perpetrator to access the vehicle and/or my wife. This issue needs to be addressed. This provide an opertunity for theft and assault that could easily be prevented. You can configure the locks to only open the door when opened from the inside. We would need to both enter the vehicle and lock the doors, the I could exit and proceed to load the groceries. Is it doable? Yes. But very inconvient. Simply allowing the doors to be locked regardless of the state of the doors would resolve this easily. The truck already does a check for the key inside the vehicle, so there is no reason to NOT allow the doors to lock. If I had known of this issue, I would have second thoughts on buying the truck. As a small truck, it's a good value. The locks are an issue though. I hope this insight helps.
The technology, comfort, performance, warranty and price make this an excellent option to consider. I'm very happy with this purchase.
Had over 2 years.fun to drive reliable dependable. And great on fuel...the Santa cruz is quality with sporty style .

Coming from a 2019 Nissan Frontier with very little tech and and that slippy rear wheel drive in the rain.  In 5 years ownership of the Frontier, never towed, never off-road.  The Santa Cruz rides like a sports car compared to the Frontier.  All-wheel drive is amazing and when I need to transport  gas cans, mulch or project waste it's all in the back and not on my nice SUV carpets.  The composite bed is a dream and it has a real shifter.  Santa Cruz has port and direct injection (no carbon build up), no VCM and no "start/stop".  I do miss the naturally aspirated 4.0L V6 in the Frontier but those engines are a thing of the past.  I don't care what you call it but most most truck guys spend 90% of the time not doing truck stuff.

I purchased the all wheel drive base model in December of 21. Being that the Santa Cruz is based on the Santa Fe I felt comfortable with the purchase. It does ride well and gets good mileage on the highway, but people need to be aware that there are limitations as to what they can haul in the bed. Plywood, sheetrock, can fit. However, anything over 8 feet in length is pretty much a no go. A friend has the turbo version and surprisingly he gets better highway mileage! He also has the ability to go around slower traffic without having to compensate for the lack of power line has. The interior finish is quite cheap. For example, the door closer pocket is already delaminating! The back seat has no adjustment and is quite cramped unless the front seats are moved forward. There is a bit of storage under the drivers side back seat. The passenger side contains the jack and tire iron. The vehicle has depreciated 10 grand so far.

Good - Best heated seats of any vehicle I have owned.   Comfortable to drive on short and long distance trips. 

Bad - Poor fuel mileage.  I have another, larger, AWD SUV vehicle with a 3.6L engine and it gets better fuel mileage than the Santa Cruz with a 2.4L.  Few, if any aftermarket products, I.e. can’t find a kayak rack.

I absolutely love my Santa Cruz, lots of power, fun to drive, but it has a transmission recall, the issue could cause the car to lose power and stop on the road. The manufacturer has no fix at this time. They have no timetable for the repair. I have a $40,000 car I don't want to drive for fear it will die on the freeway. The local dealer washed their hands of the issue, telling me I have to deal directly with Hyundai. Have you ever tried to contact a manufacturer???
Good luck. I am not sure if this falls under the lemon law or not>

A great balance of everything but ugly rear end.   

Likes: 

- Power 
- interior features
- Warrany

Dislikes:  Rear end design

From the moment I test drove this car, I felt in love with it.  As soon as I got on the highway, I liked the turbo acceleration, its quietness, the view is majestic (the boxy style opens up the view), spacious (my wife likes the open space in the middle console below the controls and chargers to put her purse in) and the wrap around dash board.  We got the SEL model because was the right price for us but the Limited is sweet!  Maybe next upgrade..

I like the 3 rows and the fact that it fits easier than the Palasides in my garage.  The 3 Users choice to select my preference vs my wife’s or a Guest is a nice addition.

I drive mostly in the city and highways around the city and I consistently get 22 mpg.  I can’t wait to take it on a long trip.  I am sure I won’t be disappointed
The problem I’m having is when I walk past the back of the vehicle my trunk keeps opening even though I’m just passing by this is proving to be a bit of an annoyance
It definitely gonna stand out in the crowd. Practical and modern cockpit. It is more of a comfort car.

The cheap plastic front bumper breaks so easily and when it does you also have to have the camera replaced. Very costly. I will never buy another Hyundai. We bought this one because we had so many problems with the other one. Thought it was just a bad car. Never again. Cheap, Cheap, Cheap

At about 40,000 miles paint started chipping off my car. Within another 5,000 miles 1/3 of the paint is missing off my hood and paint is chipping from EVERY SINGLE part of my vehicle. 
The lights on my side mirrors to indicate someone is passing me quit working. There have been multiple recalls. The forward collision warning screams at me when I am not at all close enough for an accident. Hyundai will recalibrate it for me, for just $300. I’m so utterly disappointed in this car. I can’t believe I chose this over a Toyota.

Nice vehicle. Lots of bells and whistles. Rides good. Gas mileage not so good. The higher trims are pricier and not worth the markup. Downside. Depreciation is terrible..I wanted to trade my $36,600 MSRP with 9,000 miles for a hybrid Santa Fe if the same year. They said they would give me $26,000 for my car. Imagine losing $10,600 in less then a year

I purchased a 2022 Santa Fe new, and of all the new cars I have purchased in my life it is by far the WORST.  I had it 21 months and have only 10k miles on it.  It has had four recalls, and a serious internal engine issue which Hyundai cannot fix.  It will suddenly lose power, slow down , and stall.  It has happened three times, twice on the highway which was terrifying.  The engine generates DTC codes which indicate something is wrong, but they still can't fix it.  Hyundai 'Customer Care' is a joke.  The vehicle also has a poor anti lock braking system in the snow, and the paint on the car is unbelievably thin.  It chips just by looking at it lol.  All in all, if you value your life and money, don't buy one of these.
From great acceleration to silky smooth transmission, panoramic sunroof and top notch sound system, limited edition Santa Fe is a real joy ride. Best car I owned.

50000 miles factory rims start peeling 
Take to dealer won’t tell me if it’s covered until I give them 220$
Rather put the 220 towards new rims 
Already paid dealer 220 to tell me broken smart Cruz isn’t covered
Great suv 4 years  Zero problems napleton Hyundai does a great job and I've had three of them a 14 a 17 and a 19

This Sante Fe is top of the line, and has some great features.  But there are some really stupid ones.  Like when you put it in reverse, the warning lights and bleepers go off if there is something in front of you.  Also, the push button transmission is dangerous, if you are in drive, get home and absentmindedly push D instead of P, it beeps once.  It also beeps once if you hit P.  So you may think it switched to P, but it did not.  And you take your foot off the brake, and you idle into whatever is in front of you. Smash!  I hate that.  It caused $1500 damage so far.  Hopefully no one will get killed.

The GPS is very bad.  It induces anger and doubt.  And there should be a ONE BUTTON way to end a Nav.  As it is, it is difficult to even decide which button will give you a chance to push END NAV.  Very dangerous, and it could actually kill somebody by distracting the driver who is trying to study the monitor while driving. I have had this car for 18 months, so I am not just some new owner.
Hyundai didn't want to do another recall and so they discontinued this engine. So buyer beware. It has the same engine problems as the 4 cylinder Hyundais with the huge recall.

Just expect to replace an engine due to Hyundai's lack of building a quality product.   Doesn't matter if you take care of it and do routine maintenance and preventative maintenance.  Chances are it will not financially fall in your favor with a Hyundai in the garage or driveway (more like side of the road or repair shop).
Quoted 8k from dealer for replacement  engine....... not including labor and basically its highly recommended to pretty much replace everything under the hood.  I will make a wiser decision and take my losses now instead of pouring more money down the Hyundai rabbit hole.  Outrageous!
It will without a shadow of a doubt be the last Hyundai I ever purchase and if I can help it...... anyone else from making the same mistake I did.
At the end of the day, unfortunately,  Hyundai is just another greedy corporation that has paid millions in fines to avoid the higher amount of honoring what was supposed to be a quality product.  
Make good choices!
120k miles and engine blew!  Well maintained, love my car and have taken good care of it!  Very sad

I've had my 2016 limited ultimate AWD SF for 4 years and am the second owner sitting at around 93,000 mi. It's fully optioned and very comfortable. I love my giant pano sunroof, my a/c seats, heated steering wheel, the sound system and the space. I don't really love the exterior look of the car but I spend 100% of my time inside the car and I enjoy the cabin. Otherwise, it looks like every other circa 2016 SUV out there. It's grey too so it gets lost in parking lots all the time. Pretty sure my family has walked up to other grey suv's about a dozen times since we owned it. Very BLAH!  

Like many other hyundais, and other manufacturers, it suffers from the dreaded oil consumption problem. We've had two other hyundais and were the original owners and hyundai swapped out our engines with little hesitation after they went through the oil consumption testing. As a second owner, the warranty is not the same and you will not get the privilege of entering the car into the oil consumption testing phase to qualify for the new, free to you engine. The current guidance is that you have to do all your recommended maintenance and oil changes and SHOULD the engine fail, hyundai MAY provide you a new engine, but it's still not 100%. We've been watching oil levels almost weekly to ensure I'm not driving around with no oil and it's been maintaining some weeks but others, it's definitely eating the oil. It's frustrating and somewhat concerning, but after doing some research, I learned many other car manufacturers, (Honda, Toyota, Kia) also have oil consumption issues. Outside of the oil issue and regular wear and tear items, our Santa Fe, has been good to us. I would not hesitate to get another hyundai but would consider new for the enhanced warranty.
I like the car overall, but it has had several major problems. The engine was replaced at 75K (Thank god for the 10Y/100K warranty), but the transmission went out around 120K.

This car is no good. We did regular maintenance and no accidents with this car. Other than minor repairs covered under warranty, all seemed good. Engine randomly starts clicking and stopped working out of no where! Checked the oil and its bone dry even after having an oil change less than 2 months ago. Researching, we found class action suit for blown engines and large oil consumption. Same thing happened to us with no indications or lights on the dash. Only after this happened did we find all of the reviews and issues similar to ours. Dealership won't replace due to mileage and no warranty, and quoted 18000 for repair. Save the headache.

Bought this vehicle used with 54k miles.
75k miles: A/C compressor $1400
85k miles: transmission coupler $1100
88k miles: driver side power seat switch $60 DIY
95k miles: front tie rod $1000
100k miles: blown engine due to the dreaded burning oil issue. My wife was religious about oil changes every 3k miles. Repair estimate $16,000. 
Took the car to an auction house. I’ll never buy another Hyundai again.

We bought this Ultimate brand new in 2016. We have loved it every day since. The 360 degree camera, the blindspot detection and alarms that go off when someone/something is behind you are worth every penny. The 360 camera is hard to find in other cars.
We love having the extra 3rd row and when my daughter was younger it was a treat to be able to bring more friends to more places. Everyone loves the panoramic moonroof. Heated seats front row and even second row passengers, and a heated steering wheel. Ventilated seats in warm weather, we feel pampered. 
I would buy this car again, no question. We have had to go in for a couple of recalls but the dealership made it easy and I don't know of a car out there that doesn't have that at some point.

We (wife's vehicle) own a 2021 Hyundai Santa Fe Hybrid Limited (1.6L turbo/$42k+) it has all the bells and whistles.  Purchased new in Aug of 2021.  While it is fun to drive and has a ton of safety features (cameras) and can dang near drive itself with its lane assist, smart cruise control, etc.  Braking is a bit touchy, if I'm driving, I feel like I'm giving my wife or the passengers whiplash.  But that's not my beef.  My beef is with Hyundai and/or the dealerships.  On Aug 2, 2022, the "Refill Inverter Coolant" indicator comes on. The first thing I do is look under the hood, via the manual, observe if this coolant is low, it is not.  I look throughout the engine compartment and under the chassis just to make sure nothing obvious is happening (leaks and such), there is nothing.  I call my dealership tell them about the this indicator and they can't schedule me until 3 weeks later, Aug 22.  I ask, is it safe to drive?  I'm told as long as the engine light don't flash I should be okay.  On Aug 22, I take it in, I'm told by the service tech there is nothing they can do and is waiting for Hyundai to give them a resolution, what the heck.  Fast forward to Jul 2023 (11 months later) my dealership can finally take care of the "refill inverter coolant" issue.  But, I only find out after inquiring about it, during one of my many oil changes.  Also, my rear hatch sometimes does not want to hatch properly. Meaning, it will not close and secure itself.  I thought it might be something physical in the way.  The back hatch area is empty and there is nothing observable in the latching mechanism.  After closing it like over 10 times it finally decides to latch itself properly it has done the just a couple of times, but still worrisome.  I told the dealer about this they simply said it's nothing they can do unless it was happening on-site. I understand this reasoning, but I'm wondering how common is this issue.  My lastest gripe as of present (Apr 2024) is engine DTC P0471,  I have been getting DTC since Feb 2024.  The first 2 appoinments with the dealer they could find nothing wrong.  On the 3rd visit (Mar 28, 2024) they replaced the DPFE Sensor (differential pressure sensor).  The very next day the same engine DTC returned.  I returned to my dealer on Apr 2 as a walk-in.  After a number of excuses about something being active vs inactive, it hard for them to troubleshoot.  They also mention their tech(s) were inquiring with Hyundai's tech support I ask if they needed to hold the vehicle would it help.  I let them hold the vehicle, I finally get my vehicle back on 10 Apr.  And to be honest, I  doubt if they did anything other than drive approx. 18 miles & clear the code as I did not get any paperwork from them holding the vehicle for this time period (Apr 2-10).  Not to mention I had to be pro-active as for the status of my vehicle.  A tech was present and said he reconfigure such & such and Hyundai tech support said the only thing it could be was the DPFE sensor they replaced.  The DTC returned the same day approx 10 miles into some city driving the DTC P0471 returned.  I called no answer going to voicemail and return calls.  I vistied them today 11 Apr and it appears the only option given is to set yet another appointment for the same problem they can't seem to repair.  So now I'm to drop the vehicle off on Apr 17, 2024 for more diagnotics.  I would think some supervisor or manager would notice the same customer coming in for the same thing within 6 to 8 weeks time...but who knows?  And to add insult to injury, within this timeframe I received a cold call from the sales dept. trying to sale me on the new 2024 Santa Fe...SMH  For our next vehicle I will look at other makes Toyota or mabe a Subaru...

My 2023 Santa Fe Hybrid Luxury is good because of the smooth drive, interior space, fuel efficiency, warranty etc. but I found a few glitches in the first 9 months of using a brand new model viz.: 
1. Navigation suddenly stopped while in use and the system was not able to communicate with satellite (or whatever it tries to connect to), I stopped and restarted the vehicle but to no avail

2. Stop & Go technology works well for the most part except once the car did not stop/ reduce speed by itself when the vehicle in front stopped at a traffic signal. The crash alarm started sounding and hence I had to manually slam the brakes! This can be VERY DANGEROUS, so please keep an eye on how your cruise control function is working.

FYI - The warranty is NOT 5 years / 60,000 miles for everything. E.g.: The navigation, audio, gear selector console is only covered for 3 years. For some reason Hyundai does not advertise that. I was fooled about this and found out on the day I was taking the delivery - GRRR.

I purchased a brand new 21 Santa Fe hybrid in June of 21. My car has shut off driving down the highway, lost acceleration completely in a roundabout, has 16 registered codes, more than 50+ check engine lights that they can’t figure out, 2 recalls, several repairs, and has been sitting in the shop for more than two months with no solution.
I drove about 1000 miles and satisfied with performance and safety features of this car. There is no transition roughness between gas and electric mode.

The mpg was rated at 33 around town.  How about 39/40 aroudn town.
Yes, I baby it a little.  I go the speed limit and avoid tramping on gasg.
Very happy about mpg.

Only negative--no sunglasses holder.  The paint upcharge for white was a rip off other than that all appears as expected.
Extremely well built, imported from Korea. Not made in the USA which is a huge plus and the car is very well designed and engineered too.

This is the PHEV. It can go 30 miles on EV, but that takes care of 90% of my driving. Only used gas for going out of town, and still got 30 mpg, no charging worries with the turbo gas engine. Smooth ride, great value for the latest technology in a vehicle. Does not rely on touchscreen, I like the buttons for climate and the radio. Uses voice for commands if you like, I have used it for calls and for Google maps on Android auto.
Just a couple of small tweaks. No eyeglasses holder up top above the driver? No biggie. Also, Android auto does not automatically connect, would be a nice feature.
The home plug-in option works great, just plug it in at night when you get home.  Cost about a dollar to fill up the 30 mile EV range. Great vehicle!

Most quiet care I’ve ever owned. Numerous and useful safety features. Comfortable seats. Love having buttons for things such as climate control instead of having to search through a display window for everything. Great panoramic roof. Have used only 3.5 gallons on first 360 miles with mix of city and highway driving.

Comes down to an engine that didn't work to begin with and a replacement that was worse. 136,000 miles total - 100,000 on first engine & 36,000 on second engine. At 120,000 all the other parts started breaking. Couple that with other recalls (security, latches, brakes) and you live at the dealership. Don't even consider a Sport with mileage.

I bought this Hyundai set up a sport back in November of 2023 have had nothing but problems with it from the first so far it's cost me almost $3,000 for different things going wrong with it so I definitely would not recommend it too many problems and cost too much to maintain

I bought my Hyundai sante fa sport in 2018… I absolutely LOVED it! It Hit 50,000 miles and my whole hood starting peeling paint… had to pay out of pocket for that… THEN at 75,000 miles found out I had an oil leak, had to pay $1200 out of pocket to get it fixed just for the engine to blow not even 1000 miles later. I kept up with all my maintenance and have had nothing but problems.. hopefully the new engine will last at least a year. I definitely do not recommend getting a Hyundai… I would rather have a Honda or Toyota.. def learned my lesson.

Known engine issues!
Hyundai is a nightmare. They sell literal lemons and expect you to eat the cost. Research please!!! Excessive oil consumption since 60k miles! Garbage
Don't walk away. Test drive this and I think you'll be glad you did. My next car will be another Hyundai Santa Fe sport.

Easy to find/enter the specific information necessary to complete the application.  In my opinion the INSTANT CASH OFFER price arrived at by KBB is a fair value of my SUV.

I completed this the morning, 3/10/23, I was headed to the dealer to pick up a new SUV, so I can't address any down side, if any, to the dealers acceptance of the offer as trade in value.  Keep in mind, trading in your auto saves the sales tax, in the trade in amount, on the new vehicle cost.

Used to love this car until this recent experience:

One day, my car acts odd and is leaking fluid.
Take it to this dealership.
They inform me the Transmission Drain plug has fallen out of the transmission and all of the fluid has leaked out.
As only this dealership and whoever built the vehicle have touched the transmission, I ask them to explain how such a n event could occur.
They have no explanation.
They put it back in, filled it up, charge me of course, and I hoped for the best.
This took about a week.

Less than 20 miles later, it is not shifting or accelerating correctly.
There is a LOUD Clunk and the check engine light comes on.
I call first thing on Monday morning. Wait on hold for awhile and get disconnected.
Call back and leave a voice mail.
A few days later, since I did not get a call back, I call again.
Leave a voice mail.
Call back after 2 more days of not hearing from them. Ask for a manager, leave a voice mail. Get a call back from someone else. It was not a pleasant conversation, but the service manager said I would have details Saturday or Monday. 
Have my car towed there. Wait.
and wait.
and wait.
On Wednesday I call back, as it has been several days, the expectation the Service Manager set was NOT fulfilled and I am upset.
Leave ANOTHER voice mail.

Get a call back from someone else, tells me that Hyundai won't repair it under warranty and since I cannot PROVE that this service center was at fault, although and again, NO ONE ELSE HAS TOUCHED THE TRANSMISSION, I am responsible for replacing the transmission.

They don't even give me a quote.
They still cannot explain HOW the transmission drain plug fell out of the transmission. (I had even called a few other mechanics and transmission shops to see how this could happen and they all said manufacturers defect or service error.)

It took ANOTHER 6 days of calling and texting trying to get a hold of someone to give me more details, and then finally I have up and just arranged for a tow truck to pick up my car.
They did not even clean their service protectors out of it.
Left one of the interior panels open with the door on the passenger seat.

The way they dodged my calls and texts really implies some guilt IMO, but of course they won't admit to anything, or even meet a long time customer halfway. 
Nope, just a big old nothing.

This experience has changed me from a long time loyal customer to someone who actively encourages people to buy another brand.

Running each Santa Fe 50,000 hard miles a year for the 1st 5 of those years with no difficulties, none at all except being rear ended while driving 60 mph and pushed into another vehicle. We both walked away from that totaled vehicle with absolutely no injuries. Wouldn't you hope to be in such a truly great, safe car if you met that drunk driver?
Hyundai didn't want to do another recall and so they discontinued this engine. So buyer beware. It has the same engine problems as the 4 cylinder Hyundais with the huge recall.

Just expect to replace an engine due to Hyundai's lack of building a quality product.   Doesn't matter if you take care of it and do routine maintenance and preventative maintenance.  Chances are it will not financially fall in your favor with a Hyundai in the garage or driveway (more like side of the road or repair shop).
Quoted 8k from dealer for replacement  engine....... not including labor and basically its highly recommended to pretty much replace everything under the hood.  I will make a wiser decision and take my losses now instead of pouring more money down the Hyundai rabbit hole.  Outrageous!
It will without a shadow of a doubt be the last Hyundai I ever purchase and if I can help it...... anyone else from making the same mistake I did.
At the end of the day, unfortunately,  Hyundai is just another greedy corporation that has paid millions in fines to avoid the higher amount of honoring what was supposed to be a quality product.  
Make good choices!
120k miles and engine blew!  Well maintained, love my car and have taken good care of it!  Very sad
