This is the biggest lemon I’ve ever owned. 
Steering rack had to be replaced (very expensive repair ~ $3,900) at 70,000 miles (problem with wonky steering actually began when car was only 3 years old with less than 40,000 miles, but the issue wasn’t diagnosed). 
There was a recall for this exact problem for the same make/model, but my VIN was not included. According to online reports and my service advisor, this is a very common issue and the recall should’ve been expanded. Honda is aware of problem and doesn’t care. 
Even after replacement with new steering rack, car still makes popping and creaking noises when turning the wheel. This is not normal, but dealer claims it’s fine, which puts my family’s safety at risk. This is an ongoing issue.
Beware! Honda isn’t the reliable brand it once was. Lots of customer complaints of engine problems too.

Purchased new. We let the vehicle drive itself as much as possible. 33 to 35 mpg
city, 40 to 42 mpg highway. I am 6’ 4’’ and feel the interior is quite roomy. Handles well. Turbo works great when passing.
i owned 2017 honda crv without single problem . now i buy a 2024 hybrid and so happy so far. honda crv all the way

The interior is upscale, the exterior is eye catching, the fuel economy is amazing, the cabin is super quiet, it is loaded with technology, even when using nav through Apple wireless Play it also shows the navigation info on the instrument cluster as well. The Sport L has wireless charge and wireless Apple Play so you do not need to go to the Touring unless you want the 12 speaker Bose and 19" wheels. I worked for Goodyear for 30 years and 18" inch wheels are plenty large and cost less. The ride quality is firm but comfortable and the seats have memory and lumbar and even the passenger front has electric adjust. I have owned three Toyotas, two Hondas, and a Mitsubishi and they are all reliable, I did my research before buying and the Honda was by far the best vehicle.

I just retired from the Auto Industry after 40 years, I was an ASE-certified technician, service manager, and store manager for Goodyear, and for the last 5 years, I worked as a commercial parts manager for the dealerships in Broward County. I have owned three Toyotas, two Hondas, and a Mitsubishi. All gave me great service. Decided to buy a Hybrid and researched thoroughly, I narrowed the search to RAV4 or CRV. Test drove them both. The Honda was more refined inside and out. The interior quality of the CRV is much better. The ride quality and quietness of the cab in the Honda was superior. I could not have gone wrong either way, but I am loving my CRV Sport L!!!!

I have had my CR-V Sport-L (2024) for a four months now, and love it. I have had multiple Accord Sedans (5) since 1999, and have always loved them. I am a dedicated Honda customer.

By the way, I have driven many MANY models from other manufacturers over the years - I travel 2 weeks out of each month on business and have had many Hertz rental cars over the years... I have experienced many of Honda's competitors every year.

I went with the CR-V because I was at our local Honda Dealership, helping my grandson buy a used car. I sat in the 2024 Sport-L out of curiosity and was very impressed, so I took it for a drive. I was very surprised to find it to be MUCH quieter and smoother during normal driving than my Accord EX-L (2019). If you have been considering a CR-V Hybrid, you may have seen reviews that say there is engine noise when climbing a steep hill, and that is true. The engine does wind out a bit, and during hard acceleration is is not a quiet performer when pushing hard.

Other than that (99% of the time, in other words), the vehicle is butter smooth and quiet. LOTS of room, and very comfortable. For me, the Sport-L is the perfect balance of features. Honda hit this one out of the park.

So far, my combined gas mileage is about 35.5 mpg. Not quite as high as they say, but I do a 50/50 mix of highway/city driving. City driving is in the high 30's.

Downsides? Yes, a couple. No longer has the "home" button (for the garage door opener) on the rearview mirror. I now have the opener on my driver sunshade (clipped on). I mentioned noise above, during "hard acceleration" - if you're looking for a "sporty" experience, look elsewhere. The engine will move the car at a reasonable pace, but not as quickly as my past Accords.

One more downside is the "All Weather" package that the dealer in my area adds on. They cleverly claim "no dealer mark up!", but add all weather floor mats, cargo mat, and wheel splash guards for the eye-watering sum of $3,000. IMO, these are actually quite flimsy - especially compared to WeatherTech. Oh - and you can get the whole WeatherTech setup for about $600, and they are MUCH higher quality (I have used WT for many years). So - it really is added markup in my case, because the dealer refused to remove these "installed" items.

Do I recommend this vehicle? Resoundingly, YES!

I love my Crv I’m a first time Honda owner after owning Toyotas and Lexus. The car holds up well I’m getting good gas mileage about 39-40 mph. There are little things that could be improved quality wise like the seals but it’s a very minor issue. Other than that very comfortable to drive and has good power.

battery caught fire. it was parked in garage whole house burned down my mother is a single mother of 3 saved up for this hunk of junk just for it to burn everything she has down. less than 5k miles on it 2023 crv hybrid sport purchased brand new
You will very impressed with crv overall quality. Doors open 90° interior is spacious and comfortable. Don't pass on this car.

Bought my 2024 CRV hybrid before our cross country trip. We needed a bigger car than our 2018 Audi Q3. We bought the Sport model. Gas mileage averaging 65 + 50 percent of the time was not great about 32 mpg. Since arrival to our destination city and highway about 35 mpg. Blind spot sensor needed to be replaced at around 4.5k miles. Dealer had to remove rear bumper and now need to fix both rear well moldings which popped out a bit on both sides after a few weeks of driving. Android and Apple Auto have had issues. I'm not sure why. I only wished I went and bought the L version for the parking sensors and trunk release, etc but didn't want to spend an extra 2k. Instead put the 2k into an extended warranty. Handles well and comfortable. I'm 6 ft.

I bought this car new and I have had it for over three years. It is a Pearl White EXL Hybrid with beige interior.  The latter is a bit two tone with black and some faux wood as well.  I love love love this car.  It handles really well and I like the extra weight of the hybrid as it seems to kind of hug the road and feels more stable than the non-hybrids that I test drove. Only a couple of times has my mileage hit 40 miles per gallon - on long road trips and driving 60-65.  However it regularly gets 34 - 35 mpg.  Thus far I have had no major issues with the vehicle performance.

I love the beige interior - it was a top feature for me and one of the reasons I didn’t buy a Subaru - and the cabin is roomy and very comfortable.  My uncle weighs over 250lbs and is very satisfied with the passenger seat.  Two things that I really love:  There is no gear shift, simply buttons that you push to change gears.  This is GREAT!! No useless tall unnecessary post in the middle of the space.  I also absolutely love the dash info design. There is one informational window where you can change what you see (gas / mileage / miles remaining; music; engine pull; tools; etc) and there is not one analog dial, let alone two. I mean, who really looks at a tachometer anyway?  I love the clean streamlined view that I see, at least in my peripheral vision, 99% of the time.  From what I understand, Honda quit making the push button gear shifting mechanism. AND they have changed the info screen and cluttered it up again with two windows.  I will concede, the infotainment system is dated.  I wish I could see both my Waze trip and the music info at the same time, and / or more easily switch between the music view and the Apple Connect view.  I might knock off a 1/4 of a start for this last factor.  But overall, I love this car.

I've had my CRV Hybrid for almost two years (31,000 miles). 

Pros: It's stylish, comfortable, and solidly built. I appreciate its slightly more compact size. When the back seats are folded down there is plenty of cabin room. Overall, I've enjoyed the car. 

However, I'm not sure if the "hybrid" feature was enough to justify the $40,000 price tag. 

Cons: 

Acceleration is not the best. Noise level on long road trips can be better. I was a bit disappointed in the gas mileage. I average about 33 mpg. 

Bottom Line - For the money,  I wouldn't buy it again. I actually prefer the HRV. I've decided to look for something else for my next car.

Love my hybrid. Averaging just over 37 mpg after 31,000 miles. Have to use sport option to get pep. This is my 3rd CRV. I did get the touring with tire upgrade which has a smoother ride. MPG good in traffic. I live in midwest, and yes, mpg does decrease with heater but still much better than my husbands crv.
Very comfortable to drive and more legroom and trunk space when compared to Same range vehicles.

But I'm ready to trade it in. The car lags in speed especially when merging traffic. 

For $40k for the 2022  I expected a lot more out of this car. The mileage is not that great. However, I am not one that drives very far so I have less than,7,000 miles

Comfortable ride with the exception to outside noise. If you're using heat/air, that is where the gas mileage decreases to approximately 31-33 mpg. Also the built in navigation system is not dependable. I have to use my auto connect to the phone instead.

The Honda CRV is built well , but engenders made some mistakes. It should have been 2 inches higher for an ,( All wheel Drive). It should have been in Front cabin at ,( least ), 4 inches wider to give passengers a more roomier feel. In the rear length at least 4 inches longer for more cargo space. And the should have attached a space saver spare on the back lift door! Not having a spare tire is INSANE! Same goes for ANY Care maker who leaves an air inflator in the back!! Sheer stupidity! People want a SPARE TIRE! 
Also the 2022 Honda has too much road noise, and they totally misrepresent the fuel economy. In town I never get more than 33!! That’s not enough for a small hybrid SUV. The Best I have ever gotten on Hwy was 36.5! Do the actually think people are just going to drive 55 mph?! How !!STUPID! 
Honda really misrepresented how many mpg the Honda CRV will actually get, both city and Highway! It’s only about 2 miles more than the Regular CRV! It’s just not worth it! The lied big time about miles per gallon, or I never would have gotten this vehicle. Road noise is terrible and for an All wheel Drive vehicle it wants to ,( drift) and not hang tight with curves like a subraru!!
Finally the front seats are to short and make your legs go numb on a trip of more than 30 miles!! UNACCEPTABLE!  
The steering wheel at it highest position makes getting in and out of the Honda CRV;( challenging) the touch screen radio is glitchy and changing stations driving on their touch screen , could cause a person to have an accident!! Oh yes on the highest setting; the windshield wipers ,( do NOT ) , get job done in a moderate rain!
The positives are; good sound system, no wind noise, but again ( very poor gas mileage and lots of road noise! I’ll never buy another HONDA!! The NISSAN ROGUE is a better value!!
The EX is a good little suv that tops out at 101 mph. The mpg test must be done somewhere really flat because in CA this car only gets 30mpg combined.

My car is mostly reliable but has some major cons. 

Pros: 
1). Great safety features with side camera, as well as rear camera angles. I’ve heard some people complain about their side camera not working, but I figured out the hard way that it’s quite easy to turn off without realizing it, and easy to reset. 
2), It’s got some pep for a smaller car, and the small size is great to navigate around in and can be helpful with narrower roads, parking spaces, etc… 
3). Gas mileage is great
4). Design is cute and love my moon roof, accessories, blue tooth capability, seat warmers are great for cold days. Leg room isn’t an issue for me (I’m 5’10” and have had people over 6’ drive without feeling inconvenienced in room).
5). I’ve had few mechanical issues needing repairs

Cons:
1). The odometer display has a mind of its own. I’ve looked this up and it’s apparently a common issue and there’s not much to do about it. Battery and everything (including weather outside) can be great, and still the display will act up/freeze randomly. It’s usually temporary but can last long enough that it is highly inconvenient if it acts up when you’re trying to keep track of mileage, fuel efficiency, and re-setting oil monitoring, after oil changes, etc... Thankfully the gas light and other alert lights are separate from the display screen. 
2). Batteries aren’t great for colder climates. I’ve never had to have a car jump-started, due to cold weather-related issues, until I bought this car. I don’t know if this is a general issue with Honda (there seems to be a theme with people I know having similar issues that own Hondas), but it’s definitely something I’ve run into with my car (also my first Honda). 
3). It sits pretty low, so a snowier climate can present issues, but if you’re acclimated to such a climate, you likely know the tricks to accommodate snowier days. 

Overall, if possible, I’d give this a 2.5. I think in the right climate, this car likely can be much higher rated. I live in a 4 season area that can dip well below 0 F, as well as can accumulate enormous amounts of snow. The snow isn’t an issue to me, as someone who has driven and dealt with snowy winters for decades,  but when it’s frigid out (usually if it dips into -10 weather), you better make sure  you have a jump-starter and/or park your car in a garage, as well as ensure accessories are turned completely off before starting the car. Your battery could be brand new with no wiring issues, etc… and it will still not start until it’s jumped by something powerful.
There are so many things wrong with this car. I can't begin to list them all. We will never by a honda ever again. Wish we could just set the thing on fire.

20.Nov.2023

Bought new from Garcia Honda in Albuquerque, NM. Driven by woman with light and careful touch. Husband reviewing.

Made for in-town Los Angeles. Fast off the line but not much after 40 mph.

Mileage consistently only 22 in town 30 on highway...even in eco-mode with egg under foot.

Stiff, rough ride on factory tires.

Little legroom in front for 5'9" person. None for rear passengers with front seat all the way back.

AC isn't as good as my restored '96 Geo Tracker.

Huge blind spots from front windshied supports.

Weak headlights.

Rear seat fold-down latch broke first year.

Paddle shifters completely superfluous.

Radio volume control worthless.

Front door hinge too close to seat....not enough room for legs. Hard to get in and out of.

This has got to be the “Swiss Army Knife” of sun-compacts! So fun to drive using the paddle shifters! Rear seats fold up multiple ways for various cargos…have had mine for 7 years and have had no issues!

I love our Fit.  It gets phenomenal gas milage and has been extremely reliable.  One of the little things I love the most are the paddles for shifting on both sides of the steering wheel.  It has saved us more than once on icy roads.  So easy to shift down when necessary.

I recently purchased a 2015 Honda Fit LX in a pinch when my transmission went on my 2016 Buick Enclave(leather edition) for the third time. It is the most basic of basic models. Nothing fancy, just a back to basics fuel economic vehicle. Electric widows and locks, blu-tooth connection for music and calls, manually adjustment for the seats and nice cloth interior. At first I was very skeptical of this car but had heard some great things about it. I commute 45 minutes to work, so at the least the great fuel economy was going to benefit me. 
What I've liked: handles great, has some pep in sports mode, great on gas(I average 35mpg), I'm only 5'1 so it has more then enough leg room for me and head space. I was also able to fit a washer in the back with the seats folded down and room to spare. The openness of it with the light it let's in makes it feel bigger then it is.
What I've disliked: it's light weight makes it a bit of a hair raising ride in the snow(it's traction control does kick in better then my Enclaves did though), the sounds system is definitely subpar, handling can be a bit jerky when driving, the center console is so far back and down it isn't even functional as an arm rest and the cup holders are just in weird places in the center, they're too far forward under the dashboard and you can't use it for any tall cups.
But overall I'm happy with my Fit and plan to keep it and pass it down to my daughter in the next year.

We bought this car used in 2020 and love it. It easily holds an 8' surfboard on the folded-back passenger seat and gets fantastic mpg: 39+ around town. Thanks to the split folding seat, you can actually put 2 people back there with multiple surfboards stacked. I use it like a mini enclosed truck. I haul around big beach chairs, costco loot, luggage, visitors, guitars, all with the 8' surfboard riding shotgun. It is really impressive how much this little gas sipper holds. I also like the powerful A/C, and the stereo sounds good. The brakes are strong too. It's not super fun to drive like sportier little cars, but that's ok; it handles predictably and safely. No repairs have been needed, and I expect this Fit to last a good long time like our other Hondas (2003 Odyssey w 220k mi; 1983 Civic wagon sadly sold; 1991 Hawk motorcycle).

Overall the car is ok. Great gas mileage, handles decent (somewhat sporty), CVT operates flawlessly. That’s the good. The bad…legroom for driver and especially front passenger is horrible, very cramped. As for cup holders, could not possibly be designed poorer. And the center arm rest is set so far back, it’s useless! And finally, storage is poor. Wish I would have noticed these things right from the start but shame on me. Will be trading soon for something more user friendly. Oh…forgot to mention the Honda Safety systems..in a word..frustrating! Very much so.
Honda upgrades made this vehicle worse. They should  have  left the HRV alone. Only good thing I can say good is the gas milage is great. I loved the old 2021 hrv.

I owned the Older model 2021 and loved it. The 2024 model had lots of changes. 12v to charge is in cargo area which I use with my job. So this was a huge inconvenience. Most of the changes  I didn't  like.

I hav e the highest trim for my bad back and it is pretty nice the heated seats are cool you can feel it in 2 minutes but no ventilated seats. Trunk is much heavier to open than other 5 seaters but nice features those are pretty low grade cons so buy it liked the 2 years free Sirius xm

It’s a great car to move around especially if you’re not a speedy  because this is not a speedy car. This car gets you from point A to B and last for long time. Car is attractive n price too  for this segment with led tail light n headlight. Nice speakers n sound. Down side of this car is no vent in the back, mpg is ok. Engine bay gets dusty very quick due to poor gap cover.

I can say that I bought this car September of 2023, it’s now Feb. I’m at 6k miles. I agree with it picking up speed slow but they made this model based on the Honda civic when were those cars ever picking up speed fast unless it was the type R or one’s that came with turbo? It picks up speed slow but it’s not a bad slow, people are over dramatic saying they can’t merge on the freeway due to this, simply don’t know how to drive or push the gas more like you should when you merge. A lot of the times when I’m driving it will pick up slow for 3 seconds (literally) and then next thing you know I have to slow down because you don’t notice the speed has picked up tremendously. The seats are 7/10 they aren’t that comfortable but of course they need to be broken into. I drive it Mon-Fri to and from work so they are more comfortable than they were the first time I bought it. The style is a 10/10. I love the orange stitching and leather. Dashboard is a bit noisy I noticed but it could be because I have a box in my glove department. Truck is huge to me and that’s me coming from a Honda civic. Overall this car rides smooth but not as smooth as you think it should. It’s a bit bumpy, I like the noise canceling where you can barley hear anything outside. You get what you pay for if you want a car that drives like butter you’re gonna have to spend way more than 25k. But if you’re thinking about getting this car, get it! I got it based on reliability that Honda has been known for and plan on getting a Toyota to add to the collection soon. Very fashionable car and definitely makes a statement, who cares about otherwise!
Car drives smooth for the first 15k miles but gets really rough after that. Has an issue were the car idles extremely rough and has some acceleration problems.

I am 6 foot and I have to bend over very low to get in the car without bumping my head, I have several times.  It becomes very noisy and you will bounce around on a bad road, and there are many where I live.  You can't accelerate on a hill with the air conditioning going, it stalls to the point of ridiculous. The gas mileage is ok but no better than the Accord I traded in.  I wish I had never bought this car
Excelent like new  pain new everything new tire new inside clean motor perfect new air conditioner new

My HRV Has a lot of things I really like. I get on average 36 miles per gallon combination city and highway driving. It is very stylish and has Honda quality. Up until I bought this vehicle, I had only owned Toyotas. Overall I am pleased with the vehicle but I must have confess that I drive like a grandma So fast acceleration is not a high priority. That's a good thing because the vehicle is quite sluggish and the engine noise is louder than other vehicles I owned. Also, It does not absorb bumps as well as I think it should. It's definitely not as smooth as my Camry. But in general I don't regret buying the vehicle and may consider buying 1 for my wife when she gets a new car in the next year or so.
Most uncomfortable drivers seat I have ever owned...and the headlights are turned in and are useless when turning at night.

Bought my 2016 HR-V EX-L in December 2018 with just under 18k miles.  It is super fun to drive and you can park it anywhere.  It has light gray leather (heated) seats and moonroof.  Rear seats fold down or up, your choice. :-)

Excellent gas mileage.  Love the interior color schematic, so nice.

Absolutely fun to drive.  If you want an SUV that sucks the gas, this is not for you.  Otherwise, this one leaves more money in your pocket for fun!

I've had this car now for almost 2 years and I really have very few issues with it. The biggest issue I have with it is really just the driving performance can lack at times. Occasionally coming up hills, the car will struggle with it's tiny little horsepower and the handling can feel a little off at times but other than that I love my baby blue. It rides smooth most of the time, the rear and side cameras are great, the infotainment center is great though I wish I went with the nav trim. It has decent storage and space though a space to put my sunglasses would be nice. The trunk is nice and spacious and with the drop down rear seats I was able to put a whole dresser in there!

Overall a fantastic car, just wished it was a little bit of a better driver as well as some minor things here and there.

Love this vehicle, great on gas , space is great if you are under 5’8”, easy to maneuver on the highway if you are a cautious driver, love the right side camera, accurate view of your he right lane or changing into the right lane especially if you are exiting, love mostly the brake hold, if you travel long distances often and stuck in a bumper to bumper traffic the brake hold put a ease in your leg while in any traffic jam or at a stop light.Lots of trunk space. A great vehicle to invest in.

My previous car was a CRV which I absolutely loved. I hate this car. It rides rough. It feels cramped and I think the biggest problem is because it is so much smaller than my CRV was. I am looking to get rid of it and buy used CRV

Bought this in AR, drove to FL, shipped to US Virgin Islands.  It is the perfect size for the relatively narrow roads and parking spaces on St. Croix.  Car has more than enough power, the Magica Seats (The bottom cushions of the rear seats are flipped up, providing a deep well between the front and rear seatbacks for taller items) are great b/c I can take the easily-removed front wheel off my bicycle and just put everything behind the front seats w/o having to deal with all the "stuff" in the rear storage area.  This SUV is surprisingly fun to drive.  It is nothing like my Civic Si or BMW M235i were but not many cars out there are.  Our Sport model has paddle shifters, "competition pedals", a Sport Mode, 4-wheel drive, and slightly more ground clearance.  The engine is responsive, handling is good but ride is bit harsh on bumpy roads.  We get about 28 mpg combined, not great but not a deal-breaker.  Overall very happy with this peppy little SUV.

Traded in my 2018 accord for this junk (2022 HRV). The Interior is small and poorly designed, very small center console, small trunk space, cup holder design is an absolute nightmare my drinks constantly spill. My a/c sucks, car has no speed or power also not a smooth ride I can feel every little bump. Safety features, What safety features my accord had so much more and was 4 yrs older, no push to start. Weird back door handles that no one can find when they get into my car. Sound system sucks. Basically everything about this car sucks I absolutely hate it. Wish I had retuned it after driving off the lot I was waiting for the Redesign so I settled for this in the meantime. Huge mistake.  Would give no stars

We've gotten 48 mpg consistently for 21,500 miles.

Got an EX, ignoring that an EX Insight does not include nearly all of the desirable features of the Accord EX.  In this case, EX not = EX.  Got it for higher mileage, which didn't happen.  Way too noisy for a Honda, too.  Wish I'd sprung more $ for an Accord or CR-V.
Purchased my 2022 Insight 11/2/2021. Incredibly dependable, comfortable, quiet, and I easily get 50 mpg on the highway.

This car is THE BEST hybrid I have owned. Around town driving I get between 73 - 89 mpg.  On Highway I get in the very high 60’s.   Extremely comfortable (luxurious) to drive. The car is so very easy to drive and it helps you get the high mpg if you pay attention to the information the car gives you.
Best car I have bought so far ! Stylish, comfortable, lane change I had to get used to..

I have driven several hybrids and found this car to be the most comfortable,
the most stylish, and the most fuel efficient sedan I tested. Comfortable ride and roomy with a large trunk. Performance is good too because it uses the civic platform and handles great. Love the styling both exterior and interior. Honda did a great job with this hybrid and I would highly recommend to anyone looking for a quality hybrid.

The insight is well designed and very comfortable to drive. I get excellent mpg,
around 55mpg so far. It looks and drives like a normal sedan, and I think the styling is very attractive. I enjoy all the infotainment screens regarding hybrid functions, and think Honda should continue building this excellent sedan. It is the most impressive hybrid car that I have driven, especially given its affordable
price.

On the whole, the Insight was a nice car, but the seats were misery. The cushion rolls your hips forward into a weird slouch, and the seats are maybe 4 inches off the floor. Passenger seat is laughably low. Not height adjustment, either, so you just sit on the floor and you like it. Getting past the seats, you've got mileage that is spectacular around town and disappointing on the highway at any speed above 65MPH. Cruising at 70-75 netted us a high of 40MPG, which kept creeping lower and lower. The faster you go, the worse the mileage gets. The engine, when it turns on during energetic acceleration, sounds like a giant blender that keeps a constant rev regardless of throttle position. The car is quick, and it rides very smoothly. Switchgear is top notch quality. Hood buffets at speeds over 60MPH, fluttering in your view and making you wonder if it's going to come off.
The touring model is loaded with about everything you would want.  Great mileage... styling is also great..

I've been Honda loyal since I started driving at 16, and every Honda I've owned has beat my expectations...except this one. I purchased the Touring trim back in January and I have mixed feelings on the car.

It drives well, has a higher HP than most hybrid sedans, improved backup camera, and Honda Sensing makes me feel safer on the highway.

Unfortunately, it suffers from minor electrical issues that make it not worth the cost to fix, but enough to be maddening over time. The infotainment system regularly disconnects from Bluetooth. There's about a 1 in 3 chance it will connect on the first try.  The car throws an error that the key fob battery is low even though I replaced the battery in both fobs just a few months ago (this error appears intermittently). The autolocking features also only work intermittently. These issues were never a problem in my 2016 Honda Civic (which I still have) and seem to be widespread as I've read several forum posts of Insight owners encountering the same issues. Honda appears to be slow in addressing these issues since they aren't a safety concern.

I'm hoping that Honda won't repeat these mistakes in the Civic Hybrid.

I can't say enough good about the Honda Insight.  50-60 miles to the gallon as advertised. Have had no problems in 3 years of driving.  Love everything about this car. The seat is great for my back. Many car seats aren't. It's reliable, easy to drive. On highway and around town. Yes, a little noisy sometimes going up a hill.  Doesn't bother me. I have the radio playing. Why pay for an electric car when you can get 50-60 Mpg for $25,000?!  And with the price of gas?  So glad I bought an insight.

Great overall car. In the warmer months you can expect to get about 45 to even up to 60 mpg if you do a lot of city driving. The colder months I average around 38-43 mpg. Normal design for a hybrid and interior is pretty comfortable considering the size, I am 5'11" and am comfortable. It's easy to work on if need be and is a great car. Engine can be noisy at high revs, but so are v10s and 12s so.

This is an excellent vehicle overall - I've owned it for 9 months and put 10,000 miles on it, averaging 47.7 mpg during that time. I regularly get 60-70mpg on my drive to and from work during the warmer months of the year. The Insight is much cheaper and more efficient than a hybrid Accord. It looks great and is fun to drive, the technology is easy to use and the wheel/button control on the steering wheel makes the electronic display very easy to navigate while driving. I love having this vehicle and can guarantee the average consumer looking for a hybrid that won't break the bank will enjoy it. 

My complaints are minor:
1. the rain-sensing windshield wipers fluctuate inconsistently and often give the driver little to no control over their speed
2. after turning off the vehicle, the display automatically shows an environmental score. Mine always shows me 5 leaves out of 5 leaves (they're literally little green leaves) but I have no idea what this actually means. It would be nice to be shown some actual metrics instead of having to manually navigate to a sub-menu to show trip stats before turning the engine off
3. the voice directions of the car's GPS (available with the navigation package) can be turned to a volume of 0 but music is still interrupted as if the voice were speaking
4. the remote start has kind of a short range

Don't let these take away from an otherwise excellent vehicle. I'm not sure why I don't see more of these on the road.
A perfect car I really like it. Very reliable and safe car with a lot of features. Beautiful exterior and interior design and the gas mileage is just great

I purchased my new 2021 Honda EX Sedan during late May 2021.  I paid about $27,500 with tax and tag out the door and got very low interest financing from Honda.

I have already driven it over 12,500 miles in about 7 months.  It is dependable and I normally get over 45 mpg per trip, sometimes over 50 mpg per trip.  It really depends on how fast you drive it.

If I drive it about 80 mpg on the Interstate, I get lower MPG, closer to 40 mpg or less sometimes.   If I drive it on rural roads, averaging about 45 to 50 miles per hour, I can sometimes average about 60 mpg on those trips.  

It likes being driven about 45 to 50 mph.  That is its zone.

The gas tank only holds about 8 gallons of gas.  However, that can be a 400 miles range depending on how fast you drive it.

The Honda sensing stuff is helpful too.  It avoids helps to avoid accidents when changing lanes, etc.  The high beams can also be set to automatically switch back and forth from high to low beams when you are driving.

The exterior paint has already developed about 5 chips on the back.  I should have the dealership check that out.

My first Honda always waiting a hybrid, this car is better than the Prius I test drove, it feels like a normal car getting average 53mpg. Honda made me a life costomer by sending me a letter telling me I might have a defective condenser coil for to ac and will cover it for 100000 mile. Being a former GM costomer I know they would have not fested up to that. Great job of caring for your costomers Honda.
Excellent response on the highway, quiet cabin and plenty of trunk space. The back seat is removable and the handling is really good that sometimes I forget that I am driving a minivan.
Clean , no damage.  Has a lot of safety features, lots of pep  fun to drive.  It is blue wife wants a red one.
Super comfortable and tons of room. Also love the gas mileage. Seats 8 although we usually have the middle seat in the second row out for easy in and out.

The private party sale price listed for my car is completely off. It is giving me values for a different version of this car. It’s no where near comparison to the same car with the same mileage that’s actually for sale in the market.

The Odyssey is very roomy and comfortable minivan,  it is fun to drive and has plenty of power driving up and down mountains and hills, it has all the common features that any other car or SUV would have. I would definitely buy it again.
Perfect for family with 3rd row seats. Fuel efficient. Has bells and whistles people love. Honda has great quality.

We bought this ‘22 Touring in May ‘21 and 14 months later we have just over 10,000 miles on it. We absolutely love this van! The features on the Touring are incredible and we felt it was the best of the different trims since the Elite didn’t offer enough additional features for the money. It’s very comfortable and smooth on the road. I did a ton a research before we landed on the Odyssey. I liked the look of the new Sienna, but the Odyssey won out in all other categories. Safety was the most important to us and the Odyssey is the safest van on the road. I understand there were numerous problems on 2018-2021 Odysseys but so far it seems that those issues have been fixed for 2022.

So spacious and plenty of cargo space. Nice features and very well made interior. BUT..... After 10,000 miles we began having transmission issues. Slipping, jerking, and grinding noises every now and then! We brought it into the dealership only to be told there were no issues. These issues worsened and were happening daily by 30,000. At this time we had the transmission fluids changed and normal maintenance that was due around this time and still told there were no issues found. Shortly after maintenance, while driving down the interstate the van has a louder than its normal daily grinding sound and throws itself into neutral and transmission problem warnings light up and the car will not go into any gear other than Park or Neutral. We had it towed to Honda where they replaced the Transmission Control Module, which corrected the problem for a little bit longer. After getting it back it shifted better than ever before and stopped the daily grinding noise but started making a loud zipping noise about once a week. We then took it back to the dealer where no problems were found! We went out of town where we ofc break down and our transmission goes completely out. We are at around 65,000 miles and had to fully replace the transmission. There are no NEW transmissions so we are forced to replace it with a used transmission. I for see the same outcome out of this transmission as well. Avoid a car with a CVT transmission if at all possible! We really thought buying a Honda would get us 200,000 miles before these drivetrain issues!

I consider this SUV as middle ground between 4runner and CR-V. Good size for city parking, drives good on highway and ok on fire-roads that is main reason I bought it to deliver me from Seattle to trailhead.  99% paving and the rest 1% gravel off-road.  See no reason to buy 22-24 versions. Next my SUV will be hybrid as this passport consume 22.5 mpg.
To newbies - the first upgrade you will desire is to have 18' rims instead stupid 20'.

I really loved driving this car on long trips and in my city. It has a quiet cabin and has plenty of room everywhere.  I like the simple dashboard and the clean lines. It has an amazing trunk so helping my niece move back from Bard to New Jersey was a cinch.  I may buy this at the end of the lease. Obviously with a 3.5 engine the fuel consumption is high.  I get about 18 mpg.  On the open road I was able to get 28 which is good. So if you don’t mind paying a bit more for fuel; it is a great option. 
The car has great apple play system. Overall it has been my favorite Honda product.

Bought a 2020 brand new and had no issues until just under 3 years. My battery died at a stop light with oncoming traffic after the auto start/stop did not restart! I could not even put the vehicle in neutral to move out of traffic. This caused undue wear and tear on the battery and they have not got a fix for it.  Honda disappointed me on this one. The less electrical parts the better!

I have owned two of these and have a 2022 Passport Trailsport and love it. I have never had a issue with any of them. Had a couple minor recalls that was took care of quickly when took to dealership. Gets 25mpg on the highway. In town I wished would get a little better but it is a v6 and pretty much a full size vehicle.

We think this is a great SUV. We hope we can purchase it after our lease is over.
Sure is not the strongest OFF Road Truck but it is not our reality. It is super comfortable, has all the + required bells and whistles, handles perfectly for our needs and has all the room and engine when things get tough.

Coming from a 2016 Porsche Macan S most recently, and a 2006 Land Rover Range Rover L322 before that, we were hoping for a combination of the two vehicles, and this Passport Elite does not disappoint. 

It has paddle shifters like our Porsche did and a better ride than the Porsche and handles not quite as well, but very very good for being a taller vehicle than the Macan. The interior is spacious, and the seats are very comfortable definitely more comfortable than either of our last two vehicles, which is saying something. It’s a solid car and has a good deal of cargo capacity for how long it is (referring to the fact that this is shorter than the Pilot, so easier to park / a better choice if you don’t need a third row).

We get 20 miles per gallon on the freeway/road trips, with oversized A/T tires, so perhaps you will get closer to 21 or 22 miles per gallon with the stock tires/wheels.

- New car,  I don't know why??
Nice to drive in a comfortable seats (a lot of legroom) . Great 6 cc. Engine. AWD do the job with a bold acceleration. Good good looking SUV for adventures on/off road.

If you're looking for an SUV to do it all the Honda Pilot Trailsport is it. We live on a farm and need a vehicle that can do light off roading and towing without sacrificing drivabilty and safety on the pavement. We are really excited there's an option like this still available. The thought of a turbo 4 cylinder in a vehicle this large is scary. The vehicle is very quiet considering it's lifted, slightly with all terrain tires. The Pilot is much more solid versus the offerings from Toyota, Hyundai and Kia. Thank you Honda
Awesome vehicle. We absolutely love our Pilot. We enjoy trips. Smooth drive. We look forward to driving our Pilot for years to come.

I use this vehicle for my taxi business!! Very good No problems with engine or drivetrain Just minor issues... The passenger rear seat belt gets used a lot and the sensor must have went bad in there or something... Replaced it recently hasn't been an issue again, same with the driver side window it went up halfway and then stopped so they replaced the window regulator and the tracks, seems to be working fine now... The plastic trim in the back is flimsy and will break if you have a lot of traffic through there..Automatic high beams work when they want to... Any kind of crazy snowstorm and the dash lights up like a Christmas tree none of the safety features work when it's iced up... I wish you didn't have to rely on your smartphone for navigation through Android Auto It should have on board navigation just like the old pilots.. Other than that I'm in it more than 12 hours a day and it's very comfortable, My customers like the room you can fit six smaller (5 McDonald's Eating Americans) people in the back comfortably... There's a lot of room to stack suitcases... People are always amazed when I tell them that it's a Honda pilot because they think it's a Dodge Durango... But anyways it's okay on gas... lifetime mpg combined is 16.4. I got it last April 2023, I have 44,000 miles on it currently ... To tell you the truth I love how aggressive this looks compared to the old models that look like soccer mom minivans and I will be trading this one in soon for the 2024 I hope this review helps you in your decision in my opinion it's a very good buy but a few minor things will get you aggravated

We bought our 2023 Pilot Trailsport brand new in October of 2023. It currently has 4,300 miles. It has had a computer issue since day one. The dash randomly lights up like a Christmas tree with every warning light and error message. There are times when we use the remote start the doors will not open with the remote we have to use the key to unlock the doors manually. The automatic high beams work sometimes and sometimes they don’t. The tailgate is power and it wont open half of the time. If we shut the car off and start it again sometimes that will fix the issue and allow the tailgate to open. We had it in the local Honda dealership and they told us the issue was resolved but it was back to square one the following day. They now have parts ordered that our on back order and have been for over a month. We had a 2021 Jeep Grand Cherokee before this that had electrical issues that’s why we got rid of it. Now we are back to square one with this pilot. We bought a Honda for their dependability and this may be a lemon but I would not recommend the new body style Pilot.

I was sold on a Jeep Grand Cherokke L and test drove a lot of them.  I got tired of the bad salesmen in the area and decided to give the new looking Pilot a try.  I went in for a used 2023 model and ended up leaving there in a new 2024 Elite for less than they wanted for the used model.  It has everything you would want.  Are there flashier vehicles with bigger screens or Nappa leather?  Sure.  Do they have the reliability, ease of use, or 2 years free maintenance? Nope.  I am more than thrilled with my purchase.  The vehicle is sharp, has everything I need, and drives amazingly well.  Heads up display, wireless Android auto and Apple car play.  Heated front and second row seats.  Ventilated front seats.  Wireless charging.  It's a great vehicle and comes with an outstanding reliability reputation.  Just drive one and you'll love the seamless 10 speed transmission and great driving assist features.

I've been a Honda owner since 1986. THIS vehicle (purched brand new) is a grand disappointment. 2022 Honda Pilot EXL. Constant issues. I currently have approximately 35,000 miles on it and have had multiple issues with two window regulators and a window motor replaced. Today is the 4th week in a row that I'm once again sitting at the dealership because there is almost zero air coming out of my dash vents. It sounds as though the fan is running hard but after pulling the cabin filter cartridge where the fan is located, the fan is not running so evidently it's the rear fan on the back of the console that I'm hearing. Honda has really fallen from being the front runner in quality. For a vehicle in the 50k price point market, I expected better.  I left GM and Ford almost 40 years ago because of quality issues. Beginning to wonder if it's time to go back?

Honda dropped the ball. Buy an old car and restore it with the money's worth of this new junk technology.

I have owned approximately 15 Pilots over the years and I've never had a problem one on any of them. They drive like a car, handle fantastic, gets outstanding gas milage. I travel quite a bit in my business and I couldn't find a better buy for the buck in a Honda Pilot. Safety ratings are excellent and safety equipment saved me from serious injury when an idiot ran a red light as I started through the intersection only to have my Honda stop dead before I could react saving me from being T-Boned. The only complaint I have is Honda's GPS. It's not the best but I use Waze instead. Best buy for the money, you can't go wrong.

I love my suv so much <3 I have had sedans and toyotas, odyseeyes, bmw suv..etc. but wow this has all the tricks, elite package, movie for the kids, 3rd row seating, easy maintenance. Tech is really good and cruise control is nice (could be smoother but I think it's decent for the year it came out). Overall this is a reliable, comfortable, luxury vehicle and I'm sooo attached. I will be driving this baby til her last breath. Then getting another!!
247000 no rattles or squeaks runs great expect at least  another 250000 and I average 24 to 26 miles to a gallon
Plenty of room and good value for the price.  The cabin has plenty of room.  Honda has issued many safety recalls on this year's model - 3 so far.

I have driven and owned  Honda since I was 17 years old. I bought the Pilot as my first SUV in 2019 and I love it. It is comfortable in more ways than one, especially if you love car camping. I have had no problems thus far and I have over 100,000 miles on him. I did change out the tires to all terrain, but that was my preference because my lifestyle is outdoors very much.

I’ve had this car since it was realized back in 2017 and it’s the most comfortable car I’ve ever ridden. The car drives really smooth and I enjoy all of the features it comes with. So far the car hasn’t given me no problems and still handles like brand new.
Just picked up a 2024 Ridgeline Black Edition.  Nicely updated solid truck. New features are outstanding, Ride is more truck like then my 2019.

My first Ridgeline but my 8th Honda. Love this truck. Rides great, reasonable MPG at 20 and plenty of power for me. Cab is like riding in a luxury SUV. So quiet and so far zero problens.

And it corners amazing with the SH-AWD. I owned a 2020 Tacoma TRD. For 40 Months. Went off road 3 Times. Used Low range 1. Hatted the Engine, No torque. Six speed trans was terrible. Six gear is way to tall. Was never in the right gear,shifted alot. The RL is always in the right gear especially in Spot mode. It has 4 terrain modes. Normal,  Snow , Mud, Sand.....There is no Rock? Its NOT made for Rock crawling. It is great for blasting down dirt roads. It will put a smile on your face. It really is a GREAT  Car/ Truck. My wife has a Pilot. That I also Love. RL is like a Pilot with a bed. So hope this helps. Thank

This is a great car. As the review mentioned it is an easy ride that is well balanced. The digital cockpit is very user friendly. As my wife says it is like driving an Audi A7 without paying the price. The spacious cargo space is great for people with kids that have to move them to dorms or drive around with lots of sports gear.
One item I noticed is that the review mentions that it comes as a 7 speed automatic. However the specs on my R-Line SEL premium mentions an 8 speed dual clutch. The same as in a GTI. This makes 0-60mph in Sports mode in 4.4 seconds which is very fast for a large heavy car.

This car is an unicorn in the sedans class. Aesthetics are incredibly elegant. The materials are upscaled to an Audi sibling. Comfortable and fun to drive. The functionality checked all the right boxes yes, but doesn't not perform as many of the premium brands. Ventilated seats works perfect, seats position provide a wide range. Stereo is incredible good and that is about it. Massaging seat is sloppy and turns of by itself. Digital cluster lacks essential information, navigation isn't bad at all but finding the code to reach the right address requires programming skills. The infotainment works as expected if you forget about the gesture commands. And wireless Android Auto keeps disconnecting on specific locations. But at least is proportional and symmetric on the dash. Not like those disgusting floating screens. 

The engine is extreme and intense for a sedan. The transmission is impressive but requires engagement to reach the full capabilities. Do not expect the dual clutch to do everything right by itself. For some unknown reason the cooling fan will stay operational some times after turning off the unit. You will deeply miss fog lights as they just don't exist. And be sure to select a beautiful aftermarket 19 inches rims, as the factory 20s will be eager to flat you tires on every small opportunity the get. 

This car is es as beautifully as a sedan can get. But comes with big sacrifice on functionality. Which you will quickly forget once you step on the gas a find out how enjoyable it feels at high speed.
 
Do what you want but take this into account. Those 20 inches will keep you bussy replacing tires. Change those to 245/40/R20. Those will make all better. But not the spare, because it will not fit the designated space.

I’ve owned and driven this car for almost two years now and it hasn’t disappointed me yet.  I get so many compliments on its looks and feel.  I too added a stage 1 upgrade by APR and WOW, it beats everything in its class…handily.  So it negates the only complaint about “turbo lag” and being “underpowered”.  It will put a smile on your face every time you hit the gas.  I’m 6’1 and needed a comfortable, quiet, roomy car to accommodate my family on occasion but something daddy will look cool in and something I can shame all those “tuners” who think this car is too big to move this fast.  Additionally, it’s loaded, (Premium, R-line, 4motion) did I mention it will parallel park itself like a champ.  Auto lift gate with a secret access under the VW badge. A full size spare and subwoofer to boot.  It has grown on me over time, I went from I think this is a pretty cool car to I freaking love my car. Pearl black on black rims with some tinted head lights and the question asked by everyone who sees it is “What are you driving?”😁

Pros:  Acceleration, Styling, Sound, Roominess and all the compliments I get.
Cons:  No Home Link to open my garage, (optional but come on, I bought the top of the line) and Premium fuel.  Thanks Joe B for not so cheap gas.

don't lose the power even if your over 100 mph,

I decided to try the Arteon and have really enjoyed everything about it. It has everything I need in a vehicle and I have received many compliments from other motorists while traveling. Purchased my car at Leith Volkswagon in Cary and everyone there has been exceptional from sales to service.
Beautiful car and style and updated. This car is very futuristic and I lot of fun to drive. So many people ask me what kind of car I'm driving, its  a eye catcher.

I have owned this 21 Arteon SEL 4Motion for 6 months now and love this car!  It runs great, is comfortable and has all tech feature you will ever need.  The 4Motion AWD is a bonus and is great in snowy weather.  I don't know why this car isn't really that popular and the price is well worth it!  I received a large discount from my dealer and never regretted ever buying this car.  I traded in my 2019 Tiguan SE 4 Motion for the Arteon and have almost the same trunk space. the volkswagen atlas is a great car for a big famaly and seat warmers are one of the best but the underwhelming engens anda so-so fuel econamy sour the atlas's famly frendly apeal

This vehicle is comfortable, looks great, and is ginormous inside.  2nd and 3rd row seats fold flat.  Android auto and Apple car play seem to work well.  MPG is really good for the size.  2.0t engine gets close to 24 MPG on average.  My SEL 4motion came with a ton of amenities and value.  Panoramic roof is impressive, and the digital dash looks nice.  Bought it new, and zero reliability issues.

Have been driving the new 2024 Atlas SEL since August and everything about this car on paper fits our family's needs perfectly. More than enough cargo space, comfortable seats, great amenities / cool tech, a 3rd row that's actually usable for adults, great visibility, great styling (I like it at least but I recognize that it might not be for everyone), etc.

The touch infotainment / climate control isn't the best but I also don't think it deserves quite as much hate as it gets. It's much simpler to use than industry reviews suggest and you get used to it within a few days. However, the lack of illumination on the haptic temperature "buttons" can be a pain at night (thought I believe they're fixing this in the 2025s?) and I also have to acknowledge that the system infrequently does some funky stuff (e.g. the backup camera showing a black screen and/or freezing and the AC randomly un-syncing). I've only experienced these issues maybe 3-5 times in the 5 months I've been driving the Atlas and they usually go away on their own or after turning off/on again, but they're definitely irritating when they happen.

That aside, the main area that could use some improvement is driving feel and performance. The car has good acceleration and passing power at highway speeds, however, I've found that it wants to settle in around 70, maybe 75 at most. Anything faster and you can feel the engine struggling to maintain speed. And though it has plenty of torque and is responsive enough, it can be a little jumpy when accelerating from a dead stop and doing errands around town. Body roll is also noticeable when going around turns and on/off ramps. Nothing I just said makes it a bad car by any means, I just love to drive and I personally would have preferred a slightly more engaging and smoother driving experience.

On the positive side, comfort and cabin space can't really be beat. We look forward to taking road trips in the Atlas because of how much space everyone has. Even adults in the 3rd row are perfectly comfortable on longer trips and the panoramic sunroof makes the car feel even more spacious. 

I wasn't expecting it to feel like my old GTI or even my Jetta, but I was hoping for a better driver experience in the Atlas. I know it's a family hauler first and it really is a great car for our needs right now, it's just not the car I personally want to drive long term.
One of the best handling suv I have ever owned. Great features and easy to navigate. Gas mileage is so-so. Around 18-20 in town. Maybe 21-22 on trips. Very spacious and comfortable.

Our entire extended family considers Big Blue, our 2018 Tourmaline Atlas SE, a treasured part of the family. The cavenous interior let's us all go places together with room for luggage to spare. The space is very flexible while still fitting into standard parking spaces without a problem or being overly tall. The engine runs smoothly and the 4-motion all wheel drive provides a safe ride in all weather and road conditions. The few problems we've had have all been covered by the long comprehensive warranty. The infotainment system and back-up camera display are large and intuitive to use. The air and heat system get cold and hot quickly even in the most extreme weather. If I were to nit pick, the mileage could be better and the interior dashboard finishes could be less plastic but overall, we have enjoyed our ride so far and look forward to many more trouble-free miles.

I purchased my 2018 new at the end of 2017 and still have it with about 75,000 miles on it.  This was a new model for VW. 
I love how the seats fold down completely. Lots of leg room for the 2nd and 3rd row. 
It was technologically advanced for 2018. Love the adaptive cruise control and lane change warnings. 
Had issues for two years with check engine light coming on almost daily. Finally, after many trips to the dealerships they replaced the catalytic converter and now it’s fine. 
I would say that the VW dealership in Columbia SC was a nightmare to work with. 
The dealership in Naples, Florida was amazing to work with. Gave me a loaner Atlas while warranty repairs were done. 
Would buy an Atlas again but would be careful of service reputation for any needed repairs.
Reliable and smooth ride. Lots of space inside. Enough power and technology packages to connect are great.

This vehicle is exactly what I needed to tote around my family of 5, as we routinely use the large 3rd row seating.  Most midsized SUVs are quite cramped, but the atlas can easily handle adults comfortably.  This doesn't quite have the car-like ride over bumps that my Infiniti QX60 had, but the MPG with the 2.0T engine is about 5MPG better on regular fuel than the Infiniti was.  I love the squared-off look of the atlas, and so far zero issues with reliability after 34,000 miles.  You can't beat all the features (digital dash, panoramic moonroof, LED lighting, etc) you get for the price.

I owned a 2022 Atlas SEL Premium and this is my second Atlas. I love the style, interior space, comfort and reliability. Two Atlas in 5 years and never had one single issue, really impressed with VW quality.
Safety features and standard gadgets are incredible and something that you wont find in other cars with the same price range like Toyota, Hyundai or Kia, you feel more like in an Audi or BMW.
Something that could be better and I don't like is the fuel economy, around 18 mpg mostly city and jump to 22 mpg when driving highway at 75-80 mph, however this is a big heavy car. Ride quality is good and quiet,  V6 engine is reliable and powerful, it feels really fast from standstill when the red light turns to green.
I recommend this car to anyone looking for an SUV with style, enough space for a family and great reliability. You will smile after you own an Atlas.

Runs and handles great. 4 Cylinder Turbo is excellent power when you use premium fuel...eliminates hesitation as well...Only had a software update thus far. While not considered fuel efficient the handling, power and acceleration are excellent and has very spacious interior front and 2nd row. Great looks and great fit and finish too.
Its very unreliable the older volkswagen models are better for reliability and quality. The interior quality is very cheap your better off just getting a used audi.

I have owned my VW Atlas Cross-Sport since Nov 2021. I live in MA, where we have winters. There are several features or design flaws that drive me crazy in the winter.  First, the windshield wipers don't stand up; they barely come out of the well, which makes it difficult to clean snow/ice around them.  The remote start does NOT START the front defrost--that only goes on when you enter the car and turn the car on with the key--and you cannot program it to start w/ remote start.  The way the door/roof is designed, even if you clean the snow off the top of the door, snow will ALWAYS fall onto the drivers seat.  And if you have any snow or ice on any of the sensors, your car will annoyingly beep at you--and it's too challenging to find a way to turn it off "in the moment".  Lastly, the driver has to manually put the car in AWD (or "snow") mode.  Sometimes I forget to do so.  Or if I do remember to turn on the AWD, and make a stop, and turn off the engine--when I restart the car, it is back in "normal" drive--so I better hope to remember to turn in back on AWD.
Saying all that.....those are all nuisances that I put up with.  The car does actually do well driving in the snow.  And I do love the roomy interior. This car replaced an Acura MDX, and although the outside dimensions of the two cars were very similar, the interior is much for spacious (for people and cargo). I also believe the displays, controls, electronics, etc on the dashboard are very well designed as well.  For this, I give the car an advantage over the MDX.   However, even when I bought the car, I read a few reviews where the drivers complained about the rev/gutsiness/transmission of the car.  After driving the Atlas Cross-Sport V6 for over a year now,  I will agree. It is not a smooth ride; it does not shift gears nicely. Several times I thought I was getting whip-lash.  If I had a re-do, and knew all about the car that I know now, I don't think I would have purchased it.

Love the car. Wish it had a few more options for the price. The one problem with this vehicle is it eats gas. I have the 4 cyl turbo and I thought it would get better gas mileage than it does. I drive about 40-45miles round trip to work and home. Run a few errands on my days off. I’m filling it up once a week at $75 each time. The gas mileage is the only reason I would get rid of it. If you live close to work and don’t do any major commuting than I would recommend it. Fun to drive.I think it’s fast.

I’ve really had no issues with this car besides the windshield breaking. At first I thought that something hit it on the freeway. Turns out that a lot of other people have experienced this issue with it. All in all a stylish, fun car. Especially if you get a good deal on one.

The car had a wind noise in the driver's door from day one went to the dealer three or four times never repaired it car developed thumping sounds when going over bumps and of course thumping sound in the front end

Next it toke three garage visits to fix a board in the door to fix,I was almost good fore a lemon
Never a VW again,service sucks

This little Beetle never give me any problem. We took a road trip, car run like a dream!

Beetle sel convertible white dark brown top shipped from Jacksonville FL to Hollywood Gunther VW did not have this model color.My first Beetle was a middle model I just wanted top of the line
