The Best Ever.  My wildest expectations.  Relived my younger. Years.  I would buy a new one again.  If still made them.
Never have had a problem with it. Good gas mileage. Totes adorbs. Only thing I would change is more advanced technology within the car!

I’ve loved driving my turbo beetle for the last six years. It’s extremely reliable, quick and smooth to drive. It also gets excellent gas mileage. Very comfortable driver seat and perfect for a single person’s lifestyle.

I bought this VW new at my local dealer but he had to get the car shipped to me here from PA dealer.
I wanted the 2.0 turbo 6 speed with leather 19" aluminum tornado wheels and the special headlights. 
This red auto is a attention seeker. I bet in the 9 years I have owned it dozens of people have commented about it! Believe it or not but one day I had to go several place in town and THREE people commented to me about the looks of the auto.  
I had went to Wal-Mart one day and when I came out a semi driver had pulled into the parking lot and was taking pictures of my VW with his carmera. He could not believe the auto was as old as it is because it shines like NEW!
I have thought many times about trading for a new car but it would not draw the attention this VW beetle draws!

The 2019 Volkswagen Beetle is agile and quick.  Turbo engine gives it plenty of zip on city and highway roads.  Ride is smooth and stable.  This Beetle has plenty of modern amenities without needless extras.  Great vehicle for people who enjoy driving and not playing a video game.

6 year warranty is an excellent value.

These little VW EV's are a Lot of fun to drive, in no small part due to the quickly adjustable shift lever regen! Volkswagen did a smart thing with the design of how you control Regen 4 seperate levels with only a quick flick of the Shift lever. I absolutely LOVE to drive this car, it is more fun even than any other VW's, smooth, gapless, silky, no play, no looseness, and the best part is using the shift lever to easily go in and out of Regeneration modes, being able to use it as brake on and off on the fly instantly as you drive, or switching between the 3 lower regen levels all so easily in seconds with the twich of the shifter. I use lower regen levels when going down long grades so it doesn't slow the cars momentum down too much. This feature ALONE is why this car is superior cars like TESLA REGEN is ALWAYS ON ALL THE TIME you are UNABLE TO TURN IT OFF and that my friends SUCKS! 

Sometimes you want to coast without regen, and some other EV's won't allow this or make it a long drawn out or almost impossible to adjust while your driving the car, Fit and Finish, QUALITY is MUCH BETTER than any USA built car, there's just no comparison with attention to detail, Quality, door gaps etc. VW has their fit and finish quality down pat. They also RIDE much smoother and comfortably than a Tesla Model 3 for example, which has a stiff sports car ride quality not to mention costs twice as much $$ even used unless they have over 100,000 miles.

E-golf looks like a regular car but faster, can go 130 miles per charge. Charges in 4 hr. Cabin is quieter than tesla. Smart car. Lots of great features: 2 screens, self parking, heated seats, line keep, emergency braking, dynamic headlights, auto high beams. 
Car can be charged on a super charger - 45 min to 90%.

Have loved this vehicle since I bought it in 2020. My only complaint about it is that the "next departure" feature seems to be unreliable (sometimes doesn't turn on the environmental controls). Literally everything else about this vehicle is awesome. The range isn't stellar, but it's fine for the price and makes it capable of road trips if you plan ahead a little. As with any EV, plugshare and abetterrouteplanner are your friends here.
Snappy handling, low stance, and all of the other things that are great about the Golf apply here. Have fun!

Purchased this E-Golf 2 months ago. Great car for around town driving. Not an over the road vehicle with limited range (125-130 miles per charge). We use as second car for local jaunts. SEL Premium trim is outstanding. Heated seats/mirrors, adaptive cruise, blind spot monitoring, sensors all around, great backup camera. We charge on 110V and electric use is negligible on monthly bill.

Great styling (if understated), very comfortable, great interior, excellent visibility, superb rear-view camera. All switches and controls nicely laid out. Extremely easy to maneuver, very smooth velvety ride. Solid build quality, tight and precise fit. Practically maintenance free. Beyond great value. Absolutely love it.
I have not had to do one thing on this car for maintenance.  I have the Premium so it can quick charge and is very comfortable.

I gave up on a Ford Focus ST because of uncomfortable seats. VW was clearing out inventory of the 2019 e-Golfs and offered a price so low that after federal and state incentives the net price was less than I could sell the ST for.  Further more I figured I could sell the e-Golf in 2 or 3 years for my net investment.  The seats in the e-Golf are comfortable. The 125 mile range is sufficient for me (I drive about 6,000 mi per year).  If I have a 200 mile round trip occasionally I can get enough juice to get home with 15 or 20 minutes on a DC fast charger.  If we take a long trip we take my wife's hybrid.  I was worried at first about range, but it really hasn't been an issue.  I love the electronics.  Apple Car Play and Android Auto are great.  I like that I can pull back on the shift handle to toggle between coasting and regen braking when I take my foot from the accelerator. Quality and fit and finish have been excellent except for a door handle and a charge port cover which fell off and were replaced under warranty. I thought I would miss the performance of the Focus ST but the E-Golf accelerates quite quickly.

Car is excellent although not gorgeous and latest tech design but great to move around. Not for long distance travel. No gas bills and drives beautifully. Best car ever if one is not particular about looks. Real sporty feel.
2018 VW Golf TSI with 170 hp gets me up to 44 mpg on long interstate trips , 38 mpg around town … best car ever !!!

No issue whotsoever over the almost 3 years ownership. I love the precise steering, responsivness in any of the 6 gears as much as the low fuel consumption. The collission avoidance system saved me from a bumper run-in once.  Comfort? Absolutely, within the limits of its size.

I bought the TDI and I won't buy anything else. The diesel isnt the quickest but can maintain exceptional fuel mileage. The handling is what you would expect with a compact. Light and agile with a 50/50 weight ratio. All you could ever need in a car is fit into a compact.

I have the Golf SEL TDi and love it, made a trip from AZ to MN and back, 2 adults, 2 large dogs, and luggage, set the cruise on 80-85 (for the most part) and averaged 44 mpg. That so called "diesel gate" was a crock of BS and should have never happened. The rest of the world still gets these awesome efficient engines, but the US doesn't.

I absolutely love my 2017 Golf TSI. I’ve had it since I was a senior in high school and it has been so reliable. I’ve had a recall once and Volkswagen took care of it no big deal. Only Con I would say is that people will try to race you all the time because they assume you have a GTI or R Golf. So if you’re looking for a Golf will high Horsepower, I recommend the GTI or R.

I got a 2021 Golf as a replacement of my 2017 Golf, a decision I deeply regret. I've been a Golf lover for a while, considering it an excellent car per $1 of price. The 2021 model is a completely different thing. After three months of driving it I must conclude that I hate it. 

Here are just a few things that are wrong with it:
- The 1.4 engine (vs. previous 1.8) is underpowered with a very narrow range. It has virtually no power until 2,000 revs and "deflates" shortly after 4,000 revs. It vibrates like a diesel, especially while idling at a stop light. To summarize: in the 2021 model you get a smaller, weaker and overall less pleasant engine than in 2017 which has  the same real-life fuel consumption (see below) for the same money.
- The fuel efficiency that VW claims only holds up if you barely touch the accelerator, but because the engine is so weak, you have to push it a lot harder just to keep up with traffic. And when you do, the fuel consumption goes up to about the same level as my old 2017 Golf. Which had a more powerful and much more pleasant 1.8 engine.
- The muffler is awfully loud, and when the engine is running at about 1,500 revs under mild load, it comes into resonance with the engine which produces very annoying noise. 
- The sunroof is creaky, although my 2017 model had the exact same problem. No improvement here.
- The engine bay has zero sound insulation in the 2021 model. Again, the smaller and weaker engine means you have to rev it much higher, which means noisier drive.
- The trunk has a lot less sound insulation than before. From the driver's seat I can clearly hear the exhaust sound, resonating muffler, tire noise... 
- The steering wheel is no longer upholstered with real leather, but with some kind of pseudo which appears to have been made out of recycled plastic bags. It feels rough and overall unpleasant to touch. 
- The handles that adjust the height of the front seats are flimsy and wobble left and right. My wife and I take turns driving this car, and being of different heights, have to adjust the seat every time we switch. I already had cases when a pump of the handle didn't have any effect (must have skipped over a gear occasionally), waiting for it to break altogether to take for a warranty repair. 
- The lane assist so far mostly tries to stop me from changing lanes in normal course, and when lane markings on the road suddenly disappear or the lane widens, tends to freak out and erratically steer the car to the side.

I can keep going, but tired of typing. On a plus side, I must admit that the overall handling of the car is as good as before (oddly VW hasn't ruined it). And the blind spot monitoring is better in the 2021 model (in 2017 it had very dim lights which made it essentially useless on a sunny day).

Conclusion: if you care about how a car drives, don't buy the 2021 Golf - you'll be disappointed. On the other hand, if you don't care about how a car drives, you'll be better off getting something else: for the same money it will be at least more loaded with features - so don't buy it either. Really no reason to choose the 2021 Golf over its competition.
Nothing but continuous mechanical problems.
This car is a pile of junk. Transmission problems

These are wonderful. I am a maniac and love to drive fast, so I drive cars that aren't anymore. I cant do it. This car, satisfies my need to fly if I have too. Never have gotten it stuck and  really rolls.
4motion smooth turns DSG transmission smooth and responsive. all around pleasure to drive with roomy interior

Great space, 30+ MPG, has all the storage I need, great ground clearance, had one moon-roof leak repair and only visits the dealer for oil changes.  Also looks great and the VW bike rack with the lower roof height allows me to put my bike on the roof without any ladder needed.

My Alltrack SE, 6sp Manual handles great on curves and is a blast to drive. It's great in snow, good on gas and can haul lots of stuff for it's size. It's also appointed very nicely- love the saddle brown. Everyone comments how pleasantly surprised they are once they get inside. I especially appreciate the 6yr/72K bumper to bumper warranty that came with it. I just had a new turbo put in free of charge (as it should be).

Amazing performance. I can be first and ahead in green. Comfortable and serves all my needs.
Great for taking my grandkids.

We bought the VW Alltrack GLS it has all the bells and whistles.  Including lane assist, adaptive cruise control, apple car play on a beautiful screen, it is slightly lifted to give a little more clearance which is nice.  It handles amazing and the seats are very comfortable.  The panoramic sunroof is beautiful.

I traded a jeep renegade on this best decision  I have made , I live in Minnesota and AWD is a must have the drive train on this vehicle is incredible the 1.8L motor mated to VW's very best 6spd manuel transmission and the 4motion AWD system is a dream come true incredibly capable in the winter , this car is a real live unicorn with A high build quality, installed a premium ceramic window tint, premium optional tires ( Yokohama avid ascend LX tires) , splash guards,  3m paint protection film. Can't say enough about this vehicle.
Corners better than SUV. AS AGILE AS GOLF. NO NONSENSE STYLING--GERMAN NOT JAPANESE. DSG TRANSMISION NOT BELT DRIVE. TALLER SUV does not EQUATE TO more interior space.

I got this car 8 days ago. Prior to buying this car I was focused on a hybrid compact car with high mpg rating. You probably guessed what it was - a 2024 Prius. Confusing price structures with various models and the total cost was way too much. VW came with GTI 380. I was lucky to get the last one that was available. Am I glad that I got this. Power, performance, and smoothness are unparalleled. It is not hybrid - but performs with rest to mpg. This is one of the last model that VW is producing with 6 speed manual transmission. I always liked the manual transmission and it is difficult to get one from other car manufacturers. I did not test drive the 7 speed DSG automatic one. Surprisingly, the manual one is slightly more expensive. But the manual one gives you larger 19 inch black sports wheel and adaptive sport suspension which I like.

Had a 2016 GTI that I wrecked after falling asleep at the wheel.  Wanted to keep the GTI because I really fell liberty love with it.  The 2018 is a facelift and mechanically the same as the MK7.  The one thing I love about the changes is the lights and the interior info display, because the lights are way brighter and the infotainment screen is larger.  I’ve made basic mods to it including an APR tune and a race line intake with the turbo muffler delete and a rear sway bar and I’m so happy and plan on keeping this car till it won’t run anymore (maybe 200,000 miles?) when this car dies I’m going to look for another manual transmission car because that’s the best way to have a daily driver

My first GTI (SE) and it makes me smile every time I get behind the wheel. Really wanted a manual transmission and choices are limited.  Does everything well; nice looking, capacious, comfy, agile, corners well, solid build quality, and just plain fun to drive.  Acceleration is decent, and I pulled 41mpg on a recent trip from Los Angeles to San Francisco without trying too hard.  Love the iconic plaid interior and golf ball shifter, tech touches like wireless phone charging, puddle lights, and Car Play. I can fit adults in the back seat without complaint, and have had no problems with the haptic controls that other users complain about. It could be quicker, and clutch could be a bit stiffer. But overall, it's been money well spent 7 months into my purchase.

Car is everything expected and more. Under the radar sportiness and excellent fuel economy. Solidly built. Heavy doors. Creature comforts. Ton of interior space. Accommodates 4 adults comfortably plus huge room behind for anything. You already know if you're reading this far. Not for sale.

I've had a 2007 Jetta and a 2012 Golf, so when my daughter needed a car in 2020 I gave her my '12 and bought a new GTI. What a great car it's been. I have a second set of wheels/tires for winter in Michigan, and it's great in snow and ice. After 17,000 miles I still love to drive it and I've had just a couple of minor problems: 1) console storage door jammed and I fixed it with help from youtube, and 2) driver's door electrical threw a code and dealership replaced it under warranty. It's probably too complex for true high-mileage durability (dual variable valve timing, direct injection, etc) but still worth it for anyone who loves cars but needs a practical daily driver!

Very fun to drive. Whips in and out of traffic quickly.
Hidden backup camera that will never get dirty.
Very safe and reliable.
Looks great when driving.
Easy to tune and modify.
Great handling around corners.
Functional inside.
Nice comfortable, heated leather seats.
Can be a little sluggish since the computer is running the transmission.
Has dual clutch DSG transmission.
I am 47 years old and went on to buy my first GTI. My only regret is that I didn’t buy one earlier.

This is for a 2022 Golf GTI Autobahn review. 
I'll start by saying I am not a pro car reviewer or paid to review the car. I purchased this car on Dec 24, 2021.

Depending on your expectation, you could be very happy or somewhat disappointed with this MK8 generation car from VW.

The Good:

Nice overall design, a bit longer than prior MK7 generation, car is reliable, packed with nice features, plenty of leg room. 

You can fit 4 adults somewhat comfortably, although the back seats are not designed for those 5.9 plus. For passenger in front seat, plenty of room.

The ride is comfortable, nice safety features (e.g. lane departure warning, proximity warning). Good gas mileage.

Automatic transmission is very responsive, car hugs the road, in all honesty overall the car is fun to drive but with conditions.

The bad:

If you are expecting strong acceleration from a car with 241 HP and 273 ft/lb turbo powered 4 CYL engines, I'd say you will need to adjust your expectation.

There is a noticeable turbo lag. The car simply lacks power for its class. You will need to floor the gas pedal for some 2 seconds before the engine comes fully responsive.

The Information/Entertainment system is like dealing with a mini tablet. Way too many menus, sub-menus. It is a learning curve for sure.

For some reason or another VW engineers elected to over design this interface, for whatever reason. Personally I think simpler and less complicated is much better for a sporty hatchback.

Is the car worth $40K price tag? Not based on what I have seen so far. If VW Golf is your thing and want better performance, then wait for the 2022 Golf R or consider other Honda Type R or the Volester.

I bought the car with 83k (my mistake I guess), two months later, it broke down and stranded me on the highway. Cylinder 3 had low compression and it was a costly fix. It's very fast and super fun to drive, but I have literally never had a car strand me in my 40 years of driving experience. I've owned chrystlers honda's, volvos, subarus and toyotas. None as fun to drive as this car, but more reliable.

Dealers in my area are charging $5-7K over MSRP for the Golf R, putting it out of my reach. This is assuming you can put a deposit on a car that is "expected in" but not yet delivered. I worked with a dealer nearly 400 miles away in another state who offered a much better deal and made the drive worthwhile. As a long-time VW driver, I find this care a combination of great, understated looks, plenty fast, and well-equipped. All-wheel drive is a big plus in my part of the country. Yes, the infotainment system needs a knob because changing climate values requires interacting with the touch-screen, but it's not a deal-breaker. Just takes some getting used to. The car is perfect for daily errands and way too much fine on twisty and hilly roads. Since this is the last year for 6-speed transmissions, I'm happy to have bought a car I'm crazy about at a price that was more affordable.
Very sad to sell my 2015 VW Golf. I had to do it because of a move but it was an amazing car. I got it used for $15,000 ish and sold it in 2023 for $11,600. Amazing value and will be dearly missed.

Highly recommend the golf R for anyone in the market to buy one. I have the 2018 model I have a stg2 tune pushing close 440hp the car is a hoot to drive. Still decent on fuel economy my best was 34.5 mpg. It's been reliable and no issues the perfect allrounder  comfortable on long drives

Launch control is amazing!  Because the car is AWD, there is no tire spin or other drama leaving the line, but shifts are hard, instant, and chirp the tires on the first two shifts.  After that, you've exceeded the legal speed limit, but wait for the next light and do it again!  It's a blast.  If you want to be a sedate, little hatchback, engage ECO or Comfort mode and enjoy the ride.  I get over 30 mpg on the highway when driving at or under the speed limit (up to 75 mph around here) in ECO mode.  The inside of the car rivals Audis in fit, finish, and overall panache.  Love the digital dash.  Seats down, tons of space for carrying the groceries, or whatever.  Most fun car I've ever had!
Probably the best car I ever had.  My only criticism:  noisy tires at high speed and a few rattles in the cabin.   The suspension is generally fine  but becomes choppy on bad roads.
Worth it.
See above

More comfortable than Focus RS - not difficult, let's be honest.
Less ridiculous than Civic Type R - again, not hard.
Believe it or not, quicker 0-60 than Subaru STI WRX.

If you want a well-rounded, fun daily driver, every press article you read will tell you to buy the Golf R for the reasons above. I haven't driven any of the others, but everything they say about the Golf is true. Almost luxury-car comfortable, mature styling inside and out, loaded with features. Launch mode is a blast; beats a Mustang V8 away from the lights. I've owned this one for 3 years, since 2500 miles. Reliability - no complaints; it needed a new drivers window regulator under warranty - the one-touch up/down stopped working. 

Back seat is a little tight, but I don't have a need for one. Cargo space is impressive with the seats down. Doesn't come with a spare tire. Android Auto can be a little glitchy sometimes, but I think that's true in all cars. My average mpg is 22, but can get 25 when you behave. Requires premium fuel.

I can't think of another car I'd rather be driving right now. I love it.

This car is the Total Package.  It does everything you ask it to do, and it’s willing to do more.  Intuitive and well designed cockpit with an excellent Fender sound system.  Really, a pleasure to own and drive.  The DSG is just another example of German engineering at its best!!!  Can’t say enough good things about this Golf R.
The 2015 VW Golf sports wagon can just do anything. Average around 40mpg consistently on high way, amazing!

My car is now 8 years old. It has been impeccably maintained and has offered not a moment’s trouble. It still has the same ride as when it was new. The engine gives the feel of a much bigger car, due to the snappy turbo. It handles curves and mountains like a sports car. The interior and the paint have held up beautifully. The interior offers so much more than an suv. I’m reluctantly considering selling. I hope my next ride is as good as this one has been. Hard to find a wagon anymore.

The title says it all...

A roomy but compact AWD station wagon with a manual transmission, powerful 1.8L turbo engine, heated cloth seats, a great stereo - I can't think of a better vehicle at the price point - or even at twice it's price point. My absolute favorite car I've ever owned.

This is such a great car. Lots of cargo room and great driveability with excellent power and handling. Looks great, drives great, lots of cargo room. And all for a reasonable price. I have a 2018 and at 80,000 miles I've had zero reliability issues with very low maintenance cost

For real, the vehicle tells you exactly what your average mpg is. The sunroof is almost the length of the roof. Back seats down and you can fit a twin mattress and sleep under the stairs. I love this car.

I've had this car for three years, and absolutely love driving it. Very sporty feel. I use it for hauling all kinds of things including my drum set, furniture, and so forth. Gas mileage is much better than estimates - 38 mpg overall, 44 on the highway and it is NOT a hybrid or diesel. Absolutely no problems with the car for three years (with 3 years remaining on a 6 year bumper to bumper warranty that I believe is transferable).  Great feel of the road, even in snowy, icy conditions. Grab one if you can!
wonderful

I’ve had my 2021 PRO S for almost 2 years now. Range was so-so but with the free charging for 3 years at the electrify America charging stations I was not complaining.
It started taking a dark turn towards end of 2023. After months of waiting the recall service was scheduled. it took 6 months followup  and 1 instance of wrong scheduling by the recall service customer care/ mis-communication with the service center to finally schedule the software update service.
A week after the recall service my car wouldn’t start (with around 60% battery juice left) from a normal stop at a rest area/ gas station in Parsippany. Awaited for the tow truck for 2 hours which wasn’t completely covered by VW. I should appreciate the person who towed the car, after 1 hour of work he was finally able to get the car on the truck( please note that if you think you can tow your EV easily, you are probably wrong) .  Paul miller VW service like all other VW showrooms were in back order for loaners. I was 90 miles away from home without a loaner and not much help from VW. After 10  days waiting for my car service I got a loaner, they found out that the 12 V battery was gone. 
2 months later one main battery cell has failed. They are not allowed to do service at every center so I need to get it 30 miles from home at a service station that can only repair 1 car at a time??!
Please keep away from this Car and if possible VW.

I've had 3 EV's (Nissan Leaf, Chevy Bolt, and my current VW ID.4) in the past 5 years and all have been great vehicles.  We wanted a larger vehicle and the ID.4 is a great car.  The technology is awesome.  The ride is smooth and comfortable.  It is very spacious and comes with 3 years of free charging with Electrify America, which has nearly 4,000 stations across the country. We will soon get the Tesla Supercharging adapters, which will open up another 15,000 stations for charging.  Visibility around the vehicle is very good, especially when driving in heavy traffic on the freeway.  Some people don't like the touchscreen options, but I love them.  Things like heated seats, heated steering wheel and temperature controls can be adjusted by voice command from the driver or passenger.  It is by far the best value for the price than any of the other EV's I've purchased or looked at.  With dealer incentives and the $7500 government rebate that I qualified for in 2023, the overall price was less than $40K.  Other than rotating tires, I have not invested a dime in maintenance over the past 5 years and I actually get free tire rotations at Discount Tire.  The safety features are outstanding.  I am extremely happy with my 2023 VW ID.4 Pro S.
Awesome electric vehicle. Owned a 2017 Chevy Bolt before the ID4 which Chevy gave me back my $ in full in 2021 due to battery fires.  VW ID4 is the way to go no issues at all.

i got the last batch from germany really work great for me and my wife we drove it for 22k miles in one year the only adds it has no spare tire but the rest it’s a very good car for me no issue so far still runs strong i have no complain very roomy everything works for me drove it to salt lake city from vegas runs so smooth really great running errands around the city

The ID.4 is smooth, responsive steering and good pep. The cons are that there are major design flaws. The backup camera is poor quality and is poorly placed on the rear of the car. It quickly collects dirt. Visibility at night with the backup camera is 20% at best. The infotainment system is horrible. The screen will lock up or go blank rendering you unable to operate the climate, navigation, or audio system. By design, the controls for sound are not visible at night. It is not equipped with lighting.

Voice navigation/command is the worst ever. I have had my car for 18 months and I don't even try to use it because it does not respond to any commands and instead begin spurting out instructions on what commands you can use (of which none work). The handsfree liftgate operates sporadically at best. Interior light work intermittently as well. I accidentally pressed the SOS but and got an error message.

The ID.4 looks good inside and out. I wish it worked, but as for now; ID-4 stands for Inadequate Design 4 or Idiotic Design 4. Take your choice. In summary I do not recommend the ID.4 at this point maybe the 2023 or 2024 model will do better. There has been promises of  software updates, but none so far. I have a Tesla, which get updates frequently and not one in 1 1/2 years (2 model years mind you). Thee are other good choices out there and until Volkswagen figures out how to correct the numerous problems I've mentioned and properly train the technicians at local dealerships, I suggest you look at other EV's.
Excellent ev suv that hits the mark in everyday use. Spacious with well designed exterior and interior.

I think this car is fantastic.  I really like the infotech, the handling, the power, the interior, and air handling.  I would say its the best air conditioning system I have ever experienced in a car.  I have had several electric cars and this is by far the best.  I do have the AWD Pro with gradient package, so all the bells and whistles, and every one is worth it.
Surprisingly responsive. Very good value for money. Really did not know what to expect and was pleasantly surprised by the overall experience.

Purchased brand new in 2019, this vehicle was garbage. Among 37 vehicles I owned this is the worst. Catastrophic electric issues. My car almost burned down. It would suddenly come to a stop driving at low speeds, it happened twice. Rides like a old Buick. The suspension does not feel like a VW. I was in the dealer since day 3 after delivery, about 6-7 times in 11 months. 
Piece of advice, stay away from VW.
Plenty of power, excellent gas mileage, just big enough, handles well. Nice ride with above average gas miles, very important !

Spacious , comfy and good on fuel . Turbo engine makes this car really nice , the moonroof awesome and the CarNet by VW is excelent , another good option is that comes hotspot ready with Tmobile and you only pay$20 for high speed unlimited data on your Jetta (Rline) 2021

I bought this 2019 S Manual transmission last year (2022) with 42,000 miles on it. It’s my first VW and German car. So far I like it, it does have some minor annoyances like the back doors that some how are leaking water. It’s mainly going thru the car wash that water gets
 inside. It’s not a lot of water, but noticeable . Also, the doors do rattle with music playing and it does burn oil, but I think since its a small turbo engine that runs on regular gas its normal. The clutch seems a little “clunky” and loud, but it is fun to drive. I just took it on a 3,000 mile trip out to the Grand Canyon and loved driving it that far. I owed a 2010 Camry LXE that was way less comfortable then this Jetta. The Jetta had all the power I needed to pass even in 6th gear. There was a period I was getting over 56-MPG, but I would say 44-MPG was my average. Still great MPG i think. I am planning another trip to Canada later this year in this car, so i’m excited to see how it does on that trip. 
As of right now I would buy another one, but I would like one with leather seats and maybe a sunroof. Unfortunately I would have to step to the SE, but they don’t make those with a stick shift. Right now I have about 56,000 miles on to and hope to get it over 100,000.
I bought this car in September 2022. I was in a service center 10 times already. Check engine lights on every single month without any reason. Also, there are line assist doesn't work good.

Heavy solid fast great handling big trunk lots of room fantastic fuel economy. I got 42.8 MPG driving 500+ miles on RT 80 in Pa and a lot of the driving was at 80+ MPH. I worked for Volvo for 15 years, have BMW's also and I know cars well. No issues the best car for the money I have ever owned

If you're looking for a reliable fuel efficient commuter this car is perfect. It's very practical and roomy yet gets amazing fuel economy. I almost always get 30+ mpg without even thinking about it. One downside though is it can be a bit underpowered if fully loaded and you say go to pass someone at highway speeds. In the city though it is quite is zippy and responsive. I love that is uses a traditional 8 speed transmission as opposed to a CVT, it downshifts when it needs to and usually does what you want although it is tuned for fuel efficiency and will sometimes want to hang on to a higher gear for too long before dropping down. Interior wise it's very well put together and although I don't like how much hard plastic there is inside it's in places where you won't notice it as much as opposed to other compact sedans. Overall it's a great commuter car that'll definitely save on gas.
Beautiful sexy fun. Everyone compliments this vehicle. Gas mileage is amazingly good. Feels like higher class of car than those its compared with.
Runs great no problems great gas mileage new tires a few dings light colored interior needs an oil change

My Jetta has 372,000 miles and still going strong. Tires, brakes, and oil changes only repairs I have had on this vehicle. I am a salesman and have lots of different cars in my career but nothing compares to this 2011 Jetta. Best car ever!!!!
Best car ever, 14 gallon tank gets mid six hundreds of miles, amazing! Virtually no maintenance, easy to own car!

Had this car for 7 years now and have had NO mechanical problems, NO anything problems.  I have driven in town, on highway back & forth from desert state, to mountains, in weather, cold and hot conditions; ALL were great!  The TURBO on it is FANTASTIC, but 5 speed is a bit much for my legs and arms (I'm old) but was cheaper than the automatic and manual is best for performance, I think.  I would highly recommend this as a starter or great 2nd car.  I used it very little as it became our 2nd car, and only put about 5K miles on it!  Am thinking of selling it, but will break my heart to see it go, but we will stay with VW, they rock the road!  (Our 1st car now is the 2022 Taos which we love too!)
Ok. Needs tire changes and deep cleaning . Brake pads etc.. some cosmetic changes …………………………………………..
It’s a Volkswagen GLI great car and very low miles despite the years. The maintenance is every year and I don’t any problems with it. Just need gas and oil

Great car especially when driving on highway. Noice reduced as you pick up speed. Overall steering wheel has all control for radio, climate, etc. recommend as a starter car as well as regular car. Buy manual.

Purchased brand new Fall 2017.  At 55,000 miles - no issues - NONE!
Fuelly.com calcs just under 41 MPG for miles noted above.
Huge trunk, easy shifting, positive clutch engagement and fully independent suspension make for high "fun to drive" rating,

I've owned several VW's (Rabbit diesel pickup - diesel Quantum - JSW TDI 6M - VW Bug) - - - this one is hard to beat.  (Plus the out the door price was just over $14,000 here in NorCal...............

Heavy solid fast great handling big trunk lots of room fantastic fuel economy. I got 42.8 MPG driving 500+ miles on RT 80 in Pa and a lot of the driving was at 80+ MPH. I worked for Volvo for 15 years, have BMW's also and I know cars well. No issues the best car for the money I have ever owned

If you're looking for a reliable fuel efficient commuter this car is perfect. It's very practical and roomy yet gets amazing fuel economy. I almost always get 30+ mpg without even thinking about it. One downside though is it can be a bit underpowered if fully loaded and you say go to pass someone at highway speeds. In the city though it is quite is zippy and responsive. I love that is uses a traditional 8 speed transmission as opposed to a CVT, it downshifts when it needs to and usually does what you want although it is tuned for fuel efficiency and will sometimes want to hang on to a higher gear for too long before dropping down. Interior wise it's very well put together and although I don't like how much hard plastic there is inside it's in places where you won't notice it as much as opposed to other compact sedans. Overall it's a great commuter car that'll definitely save on gas.
Beautiful sexy fun. Everyone compliments this vehicle. Gas mileage is amazingly good. Feels like higher class of car than those its compared with.

The vehicle performs now as it did when new. It delivers a comfortable ride and has ample space for passengers and cargo. You do need to check the oil level every three to five weeks, as it tends to be thirty for it.

Great family sedan- roomy, with long range comfort for 4 and with an enormous trunk which easily accommodates the whole family’s suitcases.
Cruises quietly at highway speeds, with enough reserve power for passing.
Tons of options and a great value for the money.  I would buy this car again and highly recommend it

My '21 Passat SE is a super mid size sedan that I'm enjoying very much.  I've driven to Las Vegas and Southern California in the year and a half I've owned the vehicle. (I live in North Bay San Francisco)
In both trips the car performed beautifully and attained about 36 miles to the gallon with good acceleration and handling. It was reasonably priced and has held it's value quite well. 
My only real complaint is it sits low and is not easy to get in and out.  But once in it is quite comfortable even on long trips.
I'm very pleased with my Passat SE would recommend it to folks looking for a reasonably priced mid size sedan.
Great economic vehicle that blends ergonomics and luxury. This vehicle is sharp and clean. The contrasted color (tourmaline blue) is accentuated by a beautiful cream leather interior and a sunroof.
Everything I have experienced with this car over the past year has been great. No issues, good gas mileage, and overall a solid sedan.

A lot of professional reviewers overlooked the passat and I think that's a huge mistake. The passat offers a luxury European car at a price point affordable to most Americans which is totally overlooked by reviewers that only focus on how big the touch screen is and how much horse power it has. Sure the screen is slightly smaller then others but the passats best in class interior looks better because of it. Most other interiors look like bloated cheap plastic messes. Not the passat, everything is Volkswagen quality. The steering wheel and shifter are leather rapped, the plastic doesn't creak or warp when you push it and when you close the door, its completely silent. It also has the most trunk and cabin space out of all the large sedans so you're not squished in like a clown car. You could get more horsepower out of the engine but then you lose put on the 36 mpg fuel economy and in this market that means a whole lot more. 0 to 60 in 6 seconds is more then adequate for public roads anyway and the turbo makes up for most of the power difference. And even though the transmission is a 6 speed it's Japanese quality and extremely smooth. The best part is the ride though. Volkswagen group vehicles have always had the best suspension on the market and this is no different. Excellent ride quality and corners like a dream. Many people worry about up keep with European cars and it's true that parts are more expensive but you pay for what you get. As long as you properly maintain and take care of one of these cars it will last. But if you neglect it it will bite you. These are fantastic cars and everyone I've met with one loves it. You would be insane not to get one before they dissappear.

We are normally Honda people - but wanted something a little different this time and on the advise of my brother in law -who is a big VW guy bought the Passat.  So far (knock on wood) glad we did. It much more fun to drive than the accord and has more features than a comparable Accord.  Hope we get the same kind of trouble free driving miles as we have with our Honda’s!

This Car was my first and it was amazing. So much room, nice features and rarely gave my issues. And any issues it pushed through them till I had the money to replace.
In reference to the title, I did end up totaling my car in a bad accident. Even though most of my drivers side front was completely destroyed I was safe inside and only have bruising from the suit belt that locked before I could even smash into the airbag that deployed. 
Always felt so safe in here and till the very end I'm so grateful she saved my life. Such a good structure,  especially considering I got brake checked going full speed on the freeway... 
Bought her at 80000 mileage and left her with 96000.

My most recent trip from Maineville, OH to Woodstock, GA netted 40 MPG, with 73;000 miles on my 2017. Nothing but normal maintenance to date. Had a 2014 similar model before this one. I have had Jaguar, Mercedes and Volvos. Volvos 1985 to 2002 were trusted cars but my VWs are the best for mileage and maintenance.

2014 Passat diesel very good condition
Owned by Mary in Beckemeyer Illinois have had the vehicle for 3 years
Quiet smooth ride, super comfortable seats. The infotainment system is a little glitchy sometimes but not enough to make me regret my purchase.
I was apprehensive about buying a VW in 2016. But this car has been rock solid, no issues at all. It excels on road trips, gets about 40+ mpg on highway with cruise set at 70.

Originally, I was looking at the Tiguan or Jetta. Once I saw all of the extras that were standard like the Safety features for front, back and side, as well as the sunroof, I chose the Passat. I'm glad I did. I love the tight suspension and responsive engine that only German engineering can provide.
Both types of mats were included in the price too. 
It's a very spacious sedan but not a huge boat like other sedans. It's sporty enough to be fun yet ultra safe with to ratings for air bags and crashes.
Very happy.
Where that car is located, i`m looking to buy one this week, i love diesel engine, less maintenane and reliable

These cars are super reliable they handle very well and I know all too well for me experience that when in an accident as my daughter had where she flipped three times on the interstate and landed on the top of her car, she literally walked away unscathed. She didn't have a bump of bruise a scratch nothing whatsoever she was in her seatbelt and everyone was blown away that she was safe I mean it was God and the fact that she was in a super safe reliable bar that saved her life.

It's a great entry level small SUV.  The vehicle is heavy, don't expect it to accelerate or decelerate quickly, motor is small, brake rotors are small too, it's not a sports car, so don't drive it like one.  Comes in 3 trims levels, I bought the SE model with glass sunroof. 

Driven on 2 lane highways at posted speed limits, 50 to 65 mph, one foot driving and not hardly using the brake pedal at all, if you drive smoothly on and off the throttle, 44 to 46 MPG tankfuls, are possible, consistently, with good driving techniques, far, far above the rated 36 mpg on the Monrony label.

That said, drive it hard, or with poor techniques like most drivers in the USA, slam the doors shut, abuse it like some Korean or Japanese sardine can car, and it will reward you with breakdowns, failures, broken door locks with cracked electrical solder joints, very frequent and expensive brake jobs, as well as heartaches and big financial repair bills.  Volkswagens, like all German transportation product, don't take abuse well, or late services, or not using the correct fluids during services.  There are some people that just should never own German cars, the service requirements are beyond their limited budgets.

I believe the head gaskets blown problem with the earlier year models has been remedied and fixed for good by the vendor that supplied VW the head gaskets for this model engine in 2021 and 2023.  Hence why I bought a debugged 2024 model. 

I recommend it if you want a very frugal to operate small SUV and you can keep your foot out of the 'go fun and fast" pedal, instead treating it utilitarian as something to reliably and frugally get you from point A to point B.

I honestly feel, as a long, long, long time VW owner, I got way more in this than I bargained for. Especially in the actual MPG's I am getting in the FWD  8 speed automatic version I bought.

I am past the age of being concerned with how a car makes me look, just want efficiency, reliability and at 6'5" a German car that I can still fit into. The Taos fits the bill, nicely

We had this car for a year and a half now. Still in warranty and they replaced the transmission once at 30,000 miles a month later we couldn’t put the car in drive! Eventually pulling the shifter back until it popped something in the transmission. The car will not automatically shift gears and when we park the car it rolls 3 to 4 feet before it stops. They are probably going to need replace the transmission again. Never buying a Volkswagen ever again, First ever VM purchase too. The worst part is we paid it off 4 months ago.

I had my car for almost a year and it has handled nicely from the hot summer days in the desert and the winter days in sequoia. I haven't had any issues expect for then the entertainment system didn't turn on because it was to cold. After reading the manual, it does state that it can happen but it will turn on after the car warms up, which it did after resetting the entertainment system (just hold down the volume button). I know the transmission was an issue with the 2022 model but it doesn't feel like its an issue with the 2023 model. Overall its a great suv car and it has done everything I thrown at is from road trips and a daily commuter. Please keep in mind that this is a GERMAN engineering car, so if you take care of your car, your car will take care of you.

This vehicle handles really well and drives like it has something to prove while bringing all the gear along. As others have mentioned, the transm can be lurchy but driving in the right mode can lessen that. Amazing gas mileage (45+ in the mountains where I live) with plenty of room for the crew. PHOTOGENIC

Our first new car purchase in 10 years, we are a family of 5 and looked for a sub-compact SUV that was good on gas.  Within 2 months, car was at the dealership for engine lights, EPC and a few others.  Lights were turned off, came back on 2 days later, back to the dealership two more times for the same issue.  Car runs in "safe mode" I was told, start/stop does not work, no acceleration.  Dealership said to put different gas in it so I tried them all, premium, regular from 4 different suppliers, no change.  It only happens in the hot months in CA and end result was a problem that had no resolution.  Fast-forward a year later and it's back, I was told a software update was coming to fix it, never happened.  I've never written a review in my life like this but I'm so frustrated, headed back to the shop again for the 4th time.  Never mind there's something wrong with the brakes that last 10,000 miles only (rear ones ironically that usually last 25-40k miles), back up camera didn't work....it goes on.  So disappointed in this vehicle, so much time, rental cars...don't buy this car or the 2023, read about it, they are cute but horribly unreliable.

Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car Great car

Leased the car just over a year ago as of this review. Initially all was amazing preppy little car great features for the price then the issues started, first the rear brakes failed, next a fuel issue, multiple check engine lights all culminated with a head gasket failure 14 months 14k miles into ownership. Being the first model year of this car I don’t see it lasting if the issues persist. Dealing with a buyback now as VW corporate says the parts to fix the car are no where in sight.

This was my third VW car because they have been so reliable. The interior was great, the seat very comfortable, spacious backseat for a small SUV....when I drove it off the lot I decided I wanted it. I was originally thinking of the Atlas when I went car shopping. Sadly, this car has turned me away from VW completely. I have less than 20k miles and it has been in 3 times for ECS codes that can't be replicated and once for misfires that cant be replicated. I am told I am sorry we can't do anything for you.

Knit picky complaints-
-You have to shut of the auto start system every time you get in and out. Didn't seem like a big deal when I was test driving until after I bought it and felt how rough the switch on and off was. 
-You also cannot open your back hatch from the inside of the car.  The only way to open it is from the fob (which does not work while inside the car) and the outside manual lift. 
-While driving the 2023 Taos for my loaner I cannot turn off the lane assist. If your blinker is not on long enough you will go to change lanes and have the steering wheel jerk you back into your lane. 

.

Roomy and comfortable interior..good power and handling..smooth ride and great gas mileage..
A good all - around vehicle for nearly everyone..

I have been renting a 2019 Tiguan for a week. Granted it does have 63,000 miles on it (I can’t believe a major rental company rents out a 5 year old car with this much mileage) but I would have expected it to be holding up a little better than this. The engine (I assume it’s the base engine) is loud and the transmission is not smooth- you feel every shift . The worst is the auto start/stop. Several times it has failed to start after stopping and I had to start it manually (with a key- I didn’t realize any cars still have them?). I use the auto start/stop override but you have to remember to push the button every time you start the car. The controls for the information screens on the stalks are not easy to figure out without a lot of trials. 
The interior is not holding up well, the light gray cloth seats look a little stretched out and they look like someone had a problem with incontinence (but it is a rental so I’m sure an actual owner would clean them regularly) and the matte black coating on some of the surfaces is peeling. 
It does handle well and the steering is precise. The braking is also quick and responsive. 
There is a good amount of room for passengers and cargo but the third row is best for someone without legs. 
I have to say used to own a Volkswagen Passat that I was not fond of and was curious if VW had improved  since then. This vehicle did not sway my opinion.

We bought the Tiguan just under a year ago. We were actually looking for a smaller SUV to replace our full-size Lexus, that we had for many years. While looking at the VW Taos we took a look at the Tiguan.

For the price you get a lot of value and options. It is sturdy, comfortable, looks good and so far has been completely reliable. For cars close to the same price I think the Tiguan was a great choice for us.

We have been nothing but happen with our Tiguan. Ride great, goes great in the snow, has not had any problems with 60k after 4 years. One of the most reliable suv's we've had in 25 years. We liked the 1st one we bought so much that our Daughter bought one also. For the price, drives and feels the best. Compared Toyota, KIA and Chevrolet. Get one!

Since purchasing a new 2018 Volkswagen Tiguan I have replaced the emergency start, the catalytic converter, two wheel bearings, a fuel line, two fuel injectors, the fuel injector wiring harness, the coolant reservoir, the waterpump/thermostat housing, the mass air flow sensor, the pcv valve, and countless oil drain plugs. This car is full of plastic parts that are literally melting over time. It’s had three recalls and three class action lawsuits since I’ve purchased it. Volkswagens solutions to these faulty parts is replacing them with the same faulty parts. Would never recommend a vw or Audi to anyone after my experience with this money pit of a car.

Bought used 1 owner 2019 VW Tiguan SEL Premium after driving Q3, CRV, Pilot, Escape, and Landcruiser. By driving the first mile, the Car was so comfortable, and handling very nice and responsive. I owned a Ford Explorer (yes much bigger car), but the details of the technology, safety, and almost 1 up the Audi Q3. Yes, it may not be a V6 acceleration, but I've had NO issues with acceleration getting on to Freeway or in the passing lane. in the details from VW, mechanically:  
-Safety with lane changing, sound system lowering when backing up, Oil change notification, technology and safety is far superior to the Ford I had that was only 2017. 
-Interior: Interface easy to use, lighting top of the line, Fender Soundsystem, best I've ever had!  Moonroof is delightful, Kids love it. Backseat has more room than my Explorer had for my teenager! My 2nd car was a VW Jetta, committed to VW for Life!

The worst car I ever had. Way too many mechanical and performance problems. Water pump and transmission problems just won't go away no matter how many times you repair them.
My 2016 Tig was a blast to drive.  Great acceleration
The clock spring is under warranty but the dealer cannot get the part. The airbag and horn do not work and we have a car that you can’t drive.

Bought this car new. The sport model was exactly what I wanted. I love the styling, the performance, the handling. It gets lots of looks and compliments. Lots of "Oooo, a GTI."
A lot of pride in ownership.

Bought with 68,000 miles and in one year put approximately 25,000 miles on it for long commuting. A really zippy fun car but one day it just didn’t start even with very routine maintenance (husband mechanic). Timing belt went out and then the valves became bent. $8000 fix. No thank you! Also premium fuel… expensive.

My 2011 Jetta was excellent and reliable (155k with zero problems), and this 2017 Tiguan does all I asked of the old car plus being taller and roomier yet very familiar inside. I like that ease of use. It's very good-looking, too, being classy, Teutonic, and will be attractive longer than the competition. This little crossover does it all well. Performance and ride are quite good, steering is fine, transmission shifts smoothly, seats are comfy, good standard features on S model. Love the all automatic up/down windows, keyless entry and start, though start/stop button could be higher on dash. Gas mileage could be better, regular fuel would be nice, and iPhone connection can be odd and random at times, but my Jetta had the same issue. No biggie since I drive less than 6000 miles a year and rarely use the stereo or maps. I really am happy with the Tiguan.

My TIG is my second favourite car of all time. When did I know this car I was taking my TIG home? The Second I opened the door and looked inside her I screamed ‘Oh Hell Yeah!!!’ Then I sat in her and squealed ‘Oh Hell Yeah!!!” Then we took it for a ride. The salesman had me make a dead stop on the On Ramp and simply snapped his fingers: “HIT IT!!!’ 200horses (Turbo) then kicked in as We rocketed to 60mph. I shouted “MINE, MINE, MINE!!!” The Salesman said “Not so fast, Pal—-Let’s do some S Turns!!! He took me on this Rain Forrest of a Twisty back road and all I could do is nod my head and smile NICE!!! I then bought the car. 

INTERIOR: Early 21Century MAN CAVE: My TIG S came in Panzer Grau, textured Dunkel Grau and a light grey—-which looks stately, BauHaus & Plush. It’s back lit in Red/Yellow/white lights which look cool at night. I love the Instrument panel which is dished in and not Squishedlike a RAV4 or Soup Canned like a Honda CRV

ROOMY: I love the concept of a CUV—-loose the trunk & give the passengers the Room. I am six Foot and the back seat is SPACIOUS with its own heater/AC. She comfortably seats 5 adults but not their luggage—-but who ever does that?

PERFORMANCE: Zippy!!! VW ruined the car in 2018 by making the TIG a foot longer and shoehorning in a GUTLESS 185HP Lawn Mower Engine. You only want the German 2013-5 TIGS and not the wretched Mexican 2016-2022 models. FYI, I just updated to Michelin Defender T&H P215/65R16 Tyres with StopTech Slottrd Rotors & EBC Red Stuff pads and it’s a beast now!!!

COMFORT: Rides high on truck tyres. The seats are like sitting in a LazyBoy Recliner. I drove 345 miles to see a hot Turkish band in LA and my back was still on speaking terms with me!!!

TECH: The most Tech forward car I ever owned. Mine came with the radio package & the phone package meaning all commands are from yer steering wheel. Add on the Blue Driver & Garman GPS and it’s like a spaceship!!!

RELIABILITY: I’ve owned my TIG for 3 yrs and have never repaired ANYTHING—-just the replacement of worn out parts. Parts are Threw the roof expensive if you don’t perform scheduled maintenance. Gas mileage SUCKS with the A/C on 9-16mpg in summer else 23street 29 Highway mpg

I tried out several large and medium sized SUVs and this was the only one with GREAT leg room for 4 guys that are 6’5” or taller. It easily fits 7 tall people for shorter trips. Lots of rear luggage space with the 3rd row seats folded down. The seats are very comfortable for long trips as well. All the SLT features are easy to find and use. My whole family has enjoyed driving and using this vehicle.

I bought my mine in 2022 it's a 2019.. that model has issues with the thermostat and electric control module. Not cheap to fix it should be a recall issue bc it is very well none with the dealership I had to take it to to get it fixed and it's on YouTube to show you a quick fix for the time being.
This is a great vehicle. I bought this vehicle new from my local dealership here in cedar rapids Iowa.

We bought our Acadia Denali new and it now has 120K miles. For the first 2 years I put nearly 70K miles due to my work commute with mostly highway driving. I love how it handles and drives - it made my trips somewhat enjoyable. The safety features, especially adaptive cruise control with full speed automatic braking and the surround vision system are awesome. The 3rd row seat works great when we have a bunch of of our grandkids with us. I'd give it a 5-star rating except that I'm just now having some issues with the transmission (torque converter). After some online forum research, I'd highly recommend doing the transmission flush and refill every 50K miles (my bad since I only did my first flush @ 112K). Other than that, I've had no issues or complaints at all.

Love my Arcadia  - SuV good looks with power and easy handling. Multipurpose vehicle especially glad we upgraded to get rubber mats so can use the plush when being fancy and the rubber for practical school runs or trips to the trash centre. 

 Middle captain seats  makes front and middle seats luxe feeling. seating heating in all four seats, steering wheel and cooling also in front seats makes any weather very comfortable! Remote start is a live safer in both hot and cold weather. 

Optional onstar full service including crash detection and auto call emergency and in car WiFi is amazing/ 

Loads of room to turn it into a hauler when all the rear seats are down, easy in and out for young kids and teens. We bought a roof carrier so we could fit extra bulky gear like seating for six, tents, sporting gear for the whole team and tow bar for our multi bike rack all a bonus addition. 

Looks slick and doesn’t feel like a momsy car suits all of us in the family who drive - it has a learner driver mode which keeps track of the driving of a specific key fob, earlier cautions on following distances and the rest. 

Love love love the safety features! vibration seat alert and the visual flash up on the window when it calculates your speed and direction is headed for a stopped vehicle/obstacle or the car in front is braking more than you are, passenger and cross traffic altert is a life saver. 

Easy maintenance and great handling!

I recently traded my 2019 GMC Canyon simply because I was tired of the aggravation. Within a month of taking delivery in July of 2019, the steering wheel had to replaced, it was falling apart. This should have been an omen of what was to come. During the warranty period, the differential went, the heater core broke and the serpentine belt was replaced twice. Within a few months after the warranty expired, I had to replace the radiator, A/C compressor and several water and oil lines and the serpentine belt (for the 3rd time), and there was more.  The truck had just 49k on it when I finally said, enough is enough. Over the last 25 years we have been a loyal GM family, owning 10 new GM vehicles in that time frame, but because of GM's total lack of responsive to these issues, we now own  two Honda's. The Canyon is a real nice looking truck, but that's as far as it goes. Steer clear.
This ride is great for me, very nice looking and the MPG is great for what I use it for. It is an AT4 but have not taken it off-road. Great looking and running.

I had recently owned a 22 2500 HD Sierra and I loved that truck. Not one single squeak or issue. This truck has been in and out of the shop 4 or 5 times now in 6 months. It makes a horrible squeaking noise over every bump. It’s been in for 3 visits just for this issue and they still can’t figure it out. First it was the parking brake lines rubbing (false) then it was the suspension it had a recall on some bushings (nope) and they had my truck for two days. They said it would make the noise for like 1k until the new suspension components adjusted (wrong). I just made a 4th appointment for this. The nav screen blacks out all the time also. It’s one thing after another. I’m furious. 50k truck brand new and makes noises like a car with 130k?! At this point I’m cutting my losses and selling it to Carmax because GM is garbage. Should have bought the Tacoma or frontier.
Yes, a fancy Colorado. But for the value it’s a step up. Just enough “luxury” to make it worth the difference in price
The trucks runs good looks great but for 2022 and money should of had more of the basic technologies found in imports.

This Canyon is absolutly awsome and it is the best vehicle I have ever owned.it is beautiful on thei inside and the outside.It rides very well and it handles the offroad very well.

I have the Elevation trim and I love everything about it. At it's price it is by far the best midsize at this level (better than TRD, z71, Ranger, Frontier SV, etc...)  The Goodyear Wrangler fortitude tires are so smooth, quality interior, stylish exterior, and excellent performance. Mine is black and you can't beat the look of a black on black truck. Absolutely love my truck. The 3.0 diesel gas mileage is crazy great(37.2 mpg) from Fresno to Monterey. So comfortable, great looking , stylish , and would not buy anything other than this GMC 1500 Denali.
In less than two years, I’ve put over 75,000 miles on my 2022 Sierra 4 x 4 5.3 L. It runs smooth, tight and quiet.

Purchased this truck as my town ride new in spring of 2021.  It was fully loaded from wheels to even power rear window.  I had read about the turbo 6 cylinder Dura-Max getting great fuel economy but way a little concerned about power/acceleration not being great.  OMG I couldn’t believe a diesel could perform like this!  Quite like a well oiled sewing machine.  
The combo of this motor and transmission is just the best ever.  Great performance and fuel economy too.  I am seeing 29 to 31 mpg with a 4-wheel drive crew cab!  Fit and finish are great on inside.  
My only dings are slightly soft ride, but handling is decent anyway.  (I understand future timing belt change will require a transmission removal too for access at 100 k).  I am a GM fan having owned Suburban’s, Tahoes, and Silverados but this one is by far my favorite.
like new;        this truck has been driven like a car the time that I have had it. I just need something a  little smaller. This is A. denalie.

Bought the truck with 9,400 miles used last September.  Was hesitant buying used, but so far pleasantly surprised and very happy.  Everyone who rides in it or drives it loves it.  Time will tell but so far no complaints.
Gets good gas mileage for a full size V8 truck. Got 25 mpg on vacation on the interstate. I have not had any problems yet. Rides and drives like a Cadilac
