The 2022 Chevy Malibu is a commendable midsize sedan that offers a well-rounded package of style, comfort, and performance. With its sleek and modern design, the Malibu catches the eye with its refined exterior. Inside the cabin, passengers are treated to a comfortable and spacious environment, with supportive seats and ample legroom. The Malibu's infotainment system is user-friendly and compatible with popular smartphone integration features, ensuring a connected driving experience.

On the road, the 2022 Malibu delivers a smooth and composed ride. It handles with confidence and offers responsive steering, making it enjoyable to maneuver through city streets or cruise on the highway. The available engine options provide a good balance between power and fuel efficiency, catering to different driving preferences.

Safety is a priority in the Malibu, with advanced driver-assistance features available to enhance peace of mind. From lane-keeping assist to forward collision warning, the Malibu is equipped with technologies designed to help prevent accidents and protect occupants.

Overall, the 2022 Chevy Malibu is a solid choice for those seeking a midsize sedan. Its combination of attractive design, comfortable interior, and reliable performance make it a compelling option in its class. Whether for daily commuting or long-distance travel, the Malibu offers a satisfying driving experience that won't disappoint.

I got this car used in 2020 with 35k miles. It lasted me 2 years of daily driving, and a cross-country roadtrip before I had a clunking whenever I was reversing, turns out it wasn't an issue, just a bothersome noise. Knuckle had to be fixed, that ran me about 2000$. Another year was great. After about 3 years and 70k miles put on it, I started feeling play and loose in the steering wheel. For commuting 1hr and 30 minutes everyday at 75 mph, it felt unsafe. I enjoyed my time with my LS 17' Malibu. Not a long-term car. Mine had tint and fancy rims that made the black on black look superb. 

Would randomly get "reduced power" and it would kick me to 25mph. Shut off, turn back on, it was fine. That hadn't happened in a year or so. Only happened about 10 times total. 

Another HUGE issue I faced, if you throw it into park too quickly, it'll tell you it has to be put in park before it can be shut up. Sometimes one wiggle would turn it off, sometimes 5 minutes of wiggling my shifter, it wouldn't register, but if you leave it on, it'll kill your battery.

The auto stop/start was a nuisance, and I wish it had the choice to turn it off indefinitely. It states it only saves 50miles in a year. I never had to replace the starter but I can imagine the 50 miles a year doesn't mean much when a starter is more pricey.

I really like everything about this car, except.... It is TERRIFYING to drive in snow when 2 sets of tire tracks are running through unplowed snowy roads.  I have a good friend with the same car and same complaint, his car has a different rim and tire package so it's not the tires.  The rear end wants to step out in these conditions.  The first time I drove it in snow the car turned sideways within 100 yards at 35 MPH.  I took it to my dealer and they checked alignment and showed me all is well with it.  Hopefully a good set of snow shoes will help it out next winter.

I bought the WT model in fall 2020. Choose this model because most models with lots of extras don't pay back at resale. Basic truck. Steel wheels, V6, vinyl upholstery. Have a few extras like safety pkg and convenience and bed LED light and step bar. One thing I noticed on the silverado was the thinness of the rear cargo door. Standing on it makes it flex. So I am careful placing heavy items on the down cargo platform. This effort to lighten the door is not judicious in my opinion. I like a strong cargo door. I do like the vinyl interior. Easy to clean, it holds you in place, it looks fine. The reason for 4 stars instead of 5 is the engine/trans relationship. I think it could be better. But I have experienced this on other trucks from 2017-2020, including a V8 Tundra that had trouble finding the right gear frequently. Many of the higher number geared transmissions are better now. Replacement parts nowadays can be expensive. I have a cracked rear light from parking lot unknown when I was shopping. I have to change the whole unit and cannot simply buy a new plastic cover. This manufacturing process is way more expensive than old methods for the customer, even though it may be helpful to manufacturer. I will assume this plays into the higher cost of repairing a vehicle nowadays. It is a good truck in my opinion. Some of the very negative experiences I read in a few reviews must be outliers that are unfortunate. Mileage is variable and unpredictable. Some fill-ups are great and others mediocre. I drive the same style so I can't figure the why difference. I always have the Bruce Springsteen feeling when driving a Chevy, which I don't have with Toyota or Ram. I do wonder why some customers like the black Chevy emblem instead of the gold. And I wonder who at Chevy chose this crazy marketing idea. The gold is so much better.

Lets start with the only positive thing about the truck. It looks good that is it everything else about is junk. Transmission shifts hard whenever it shift below 3k RPMS It will jolt the whole truck when trying to accelerate. The oil cooler line is leaking, the transmission oil cooler line is also leaking. Have replaced the idler pulley twice. A/C clutch pulley is now squeaking. It rides like a brick can’t corner for nothing body roll is bad. Radio works about 75% of the time and when it does it is maxing the volume every 30 minutes. Brakes suck. The paint is extremely thin. Just avoid it do not buy one no matter how good of a deal it is.

2023 Chevy Silverado 1500 Zr2 . Best Truck Ever 6.2 L Super Power, after 1 year Driving this Truck and after me driving others truck before this one, I can Say I  have everything I Need, Elegance, Beauty and Super Power.  Forget about Ford, Ram . Zr2 Best Truck Ever. Thanks Chevrolet.

My absolute favorite is the HUD. Too many great things about this truck to even mention.  Only wished they would offer a light tan or camel color interior rather than black or black/brown

My 2015 Chevy Silverado 2WD 5.3L Work Truck has served me well over the last 3 years.
I bought it at 120k miles.
This basic work truck was just what I was looking for.

I've been able to tow my trailer with mowers and landscaping materials without issue.

Do NOT purchase the hybrid 2017 Silverado model. The AC/water pump serpentine belt is discontinued by GM and the part is obsolete. The belt cannot be reused from another vehicle and cannot be replicated due to the stretch tension. So basically my truck is dead in the water bc I cannot source a $35 belt.

We purchased this vehicle used from a dealership and it was a one-owner with mileage of little over 17K. This pickup has been a great vehicle and the only thing it has had to have done yo it was the recalls, regular maintenance and a tires.  We love this truck!

I am a disabled combat veteran of the viet nam war. My disabilities require special needs for fit, comfort, and ability to drive my truck. This is especially true as i am a large built man, not fat tho. The full size Silverado LTZ meets my needs exactly for comfort and performance. Got that beautiful blue metal flake paint, light color leather interior with vented seats, chrome exterior package. The truck is absolutely perfect. I have had this fabulous vehicle for 6 yrs with now having 28000 miles on it. This truck will be traded in when I have 84000 mi on it and I will be 86 y/o. Best truck in the world.
Love it. However it does use premium gasoline because it has the same engine the corvette has in it, 6.2 420 hp.  but with the 8 speed transmission, highway gas mileage is really good.

transmission starting having issues shifting before hitting 10k miles. Took to two different dealerships (one chevy and one GMC dealer) both told me that i wasnt giving the truck enough gas when driving from parked position. Vehicle would lunge forward when shifting gears anytime it was under 40mph. After 89K miles I decided to take it to a mechanic friend who found metal shavings throughout the transmission and found that the valve body needed to be replaced along with the transmission. The trucks computer was not sensing 2 of the valves and causing it to slip gears. The dealership stopped returning my calls when I requested to speak to a manager and denied any issue with the truck. This will be the last GM product I ever purchase. DONT WASTE YOUR MONEY ON THESE PILES OF GARBAGE

If you want a winter truck this is a joke when you get stuck. Only 4x4 low let's you spin the tires but only after a delay so ya back up and stuck again you'd think you could get past your previous stuck point but no they have a 1.5 second that won't let er rip past this is the worst restricted truck I've ever owned 345 hp my butt try 45 hp take off max hp was 185 truck is beautiful sharpest they've built but to restrict me so badly that I get 12 miles to the gallon is ridiculous

hey, I have 2 of the 2024 2500HD with the Durmax.  One is a high country and the other is a LTZ.  Overall appearance I really like.  I like the small changes they made to the outside appearance. Makes the truck look better.  I do like the interior in the High Country better.  The leather doesn't seem as cheap as the LTZ.  Both trucks interior are nice but i like the High Country better.  I have 20k on the LTZ and 6k on the High Country.  I have had the LTZ in the shop several times for emissions issues.  Check engine light was on a lot, truck ran rough, wasn't sure if it would keep running.  The dealership said they had to flash the ECM, said that it is a software issue.  The High Country had the same thing done at 3k miles.  Not overly impressed with the emissions issues.  I had a 2022 Ram 2500 with the Cummins in it prior to both these trucks and was more impressed with that.  I do kind of miss that pickup.  The one thing that I have noticed on both trucks is this, not a major deal but bothers me as I am fussy when it comes to my trucks, they both have the fold out running boards, I noticed on both that the black paint is rubbing off on where you step.  it happened right away too.  I noticed at 1000 miles both trucks started doing it.  Not a major but not overly impressed especially for the price tag.  The LTZ ran right at 80k and the High Country was at 93k, so that shouldn't be happening.  I could see that happening if they both were 10 years old plus but they are not even a year old.  Overall performance is good, has a lot of power for towing.  I do like the Allison Transmission.  Fuel mileage is really good on the highway as well, both trucks average around 20mpg on highway just normal driving which is really good right out of the gate.  The biggest thing I do not like is emissions issues but you will have that with anything that uses DEF.  To say I would buy another one, not really sure yet.  Not saying I would not, but I think I would probably go back to the Ram 2500 with the Cummins.  Now that the 2500 in the Rams have the digital display I would go back, the main reason I went to the Chevy was for the technology it had to offer but I wish I would have waited because the Ram has a lot to offer now too.  I do wish that the Chevy would come with the air ride system in the 2500 like the Rams have.  Not to beat up on the chevy as I own 2 of them but I would really think hard before buying one again

No issues with truck at 19k miles. Seat makes terrible noise every-time i get out because the plastic under it rubs on leather. I want value for my money and a plush ride isn’t on the list of needs. Ford has a great truck but you’re going to pay several thousand more for it. Rams are fine, but not for me. I traded my 1/2 ton Ford for this truck when deciding to get some to get something with more power. I’ve owned Chevy trucks in the past and none of them let me down.
Look at the towing numbers on this type of truck and compare it to Ford & Ram. Look at the power plant reliability of Chevy trucks compared to Ford and Ram. When all of that has been researched, check the prices. You’ll find Chevy has an excellent argument to be considered.
My buddy who owns a Ford diesel (of the DEF generation) drove mine with a loaded trailer attached and said he was impressed how well it moved. Ironically, it was a car hauler with a Ford on it that was attached.
I use it for work, play, daily commute, and long trips. It’ll do all of these things very well.
It’s not perfect. This truck has the same rattle by the driver’s left knee that my last truck had. It also has that rear view mirror that auto switches from day to night, and vice versa, that I hate. I hate it during dawn/sunset times when it thinks it needs to be on day and some yahoo is behind me with NASA quality headlights. It also has the same interactive infotainment flaws my Ford had (and I understand all brands have). It’ll shut off on its own and come back a little later. It’s a nuisance that gets frustrating when Google maps is telling me how to get around in city traffix.

I use this to toe a 20 ‘ gooseneck ..only thing I’ve replace are brake pads and all the rest is normal maintenance. Spent 2000.00 in repair. Since I bought it! Best truck I’ve ever owned . Will never
Own another diesel !!

By far hands down the best truck ive ever owned. far exceeded my expectations. 
would reccomend to anyone looking for a truck that is reliable, looks great, will tow almost anything you put behind it, and a very powerful and fun truck.

Disappointed pretty much from the beginning.  Pros: seating, durability, wifi
Cons: Poor headlights.  At night it was impossible to see much of the road on dim.  I
  Interior lighting was poor as well.  I kept a flashlight handy.  CP4 injection pump was a $10,000 repair bill just waiting to happen. (the reason I sold)  Steering was never good and tight.  With a bit of crosswind, it was hard to keep it straight.

Buy the 2017, skip the 2016.

The 6.0 gasser is plenty powerful enough.  I don’t even feel my 6500 lb boat on the back when cruising down the highway or maneuvering around town.  Very comfortable.  It is set up with a B&W gooseneck too which is handy.  I was worried that I would not like the less torque gas engine but was pleased by the power it delivers.  Well worth the savings over the Diesel engine.
I’ve had it for 3 1/2 years and wouldn’t trade it for new one. Great quality and reliability are just a few of the great features.
Great truck, little too much for my altered needs, perfect vehicle for long extended journeys. Ok, I hope these additional 7 letters will satisfy the letter requirement

This machine pulls a loaded 34ft 5th wheel like nothing is back their, barely touched the throttle from a full stop at the base of Cottonwood Pass! Averaged 13.5mpg on that trip.
On a trip to drive up Pikes Peak (not pulling or loaded) averaged 41.2mpg round trip...grade matters of course as that is not normal mpg.
Creature comforts and technology are incredible. The info system even displays the grade your on so you can park your trailer on the most level piece of land.
Bose sound system and interior comforts are great. 
The new material their using for the seats are the best way to go by far... Longer lasting and more durable than the leather and they breath!
It’s in the shop way to often. About half the time it’s emissions related. If I could go back I would not have bought this truck. If it was reliable it would be a good truck , but it’s not.
mileage goes down pretty fast when pulling ,but can pull anything, very smooth ride. heated steering wheel is awesome

I purchased my 2020 3500 HD Duramax the fall of 2019. This truck is a unit, very large vehicle to live in the cities with but I make it work. Very powerful, I pull my dump trailer confidently. 0 issues mechanically with this truck. Everything feels heavy duty and well built compared to some of its class competitors. Highly recommend, trading mine for a 2022 GMC 3500 AT4.
AMAZING TRUCK!!! what can i say its a duly and 3500 diesel. truly a amazing truck . its my 3rd 3500 .i will only buy chavys and 3500 .
Great truck, bought it to pull trailer seemed to do ok with empty trailer haven’t loaded it yet. Going to load it to 40,000 lbs

This truck has been amazing. Pulls great, handles a truck camper and a towable so well. Mileage has been outstanding on the 10 speed Allison and 6.6. Duramax. Towing I've been averaging 12 to 13 mpg hand calculated with the Montana fall conditions at roughly 65 mph. Unloaded, I've gotten almost 21 mpg at 70 mph on trips, highest mixed driving has been 19.1 so far. This is with Duratracs. Great truck, love the power and comfort. The truck has such a huge range with the tank and mileage. Marked 600 miles with still 120 left to go on the reserve portion.

Great truck,pulled 35 ft fifth wheel fully loaded,no problems.Has plenty of power and nice options.Glad i found one when i did,it was very hard to find late last fall,now with chip shortage...who knows...
The 6.0 gas vortec has the power and the 6.6 diesel, both engines paired with a 6 speed automatic transmission and the 6.0 vortec has 360 horsepower plus the 6.6 diesel has 445

2018 Chevy High Country diesel 3500 single rear wheel standard bed crew cab 4x4. Bought this used with 9000 miles on it, no issues, some minor software updates and an engine block heater recall, twice. Truck is loaded and it’s my work/personal daily driver, tows anything I put behind it, carries 3000 pounds of equipment all the times and averages 20 mpg with a 25 mpg unloaded high and a low 13 mpg loaded and pulling an 8000 pound trailer in the mountains! The color is Cajun red tintcoat and is absolutely stunning with the black leather interior! A little big and hard to park in the city, but very well behaved, lots of on tap power even when loaded, Ford claims more hp, but I can take em’ at the start and lose em’ in the mountains, bought an 18 because chevy was going with a 10 speed transmission and 3.42 rear gears ( not good for towing!) in 2020, mine has 3.73 gears and a 6 speed Allison that’s always in the right gear and I’ve never had to use the tow/haul mode button! Keeping the 18 forever as I don’t like the looks of the new Chevy’s, apparently the dealership agrees, every time I go for service, they offer me more than I paid for it! Perfect truck, get one if you can!!!!!!

Originally bought this truck to pull our 5th wheel RV . But over the last 3 years I have used it to get back and forth to work,  pull the RV and tow other trailers.  Never once had any doubt about what the Duramax engine would do and put many Dodge and Ford dually pickup to shame pulling my trailer up hills. It has never given me one reason to regret buying it.  Have heard how rough they ride, well I have owned every make of full size American pick up and it rides great. And gas mileage is equal to them all. And as far as price I found it to be better priced than Ford or Dodge which I feel are far over priced for their flash and lack of gas. Just felt that for the money it was the best value for what you got.

My 2019 Silverado 3500 HD with the Gas 6.0 has been a great truck so far.  I've had it since it was new, I broke it in following the instructions in the owners manual and I've been very happy with it.

I bought it as my old truck couldn't pull my 5th wheel.  Fully loaded I'm pushing about 10,000 pounds.  This truck handles the 5th wheel with ease.  I went from a 1/2 ton to the 1 ton and the difference is night and day.

The truck works hard, it goes easy down the road, and it's been a joy to tow with it.  I do wish it had a little more getup and go when towing, however, I'm not drag racing and the diesel undoubtedly would be fulfill what I feel I'm lacking.  I'm not saying it doesn't go, once you get into the sweet spot at the higher rpm's she like to go!

I'm also impressed with how the truck handles towing going through the hilly and windy terrain of ND.  It performs flawlessly every time.  The temps stay low on the mechanicals, the cooled seats are so nice during the hot summer months, and the truck is very comfortable.

One little thing that surprised me was when I went to back in to hitch up my 5th wheel.  I can see the hitch plane as day when I go to line it up.  I just turn my head and there it is.  It was a nice little surprise that my F150 didn't offer.  The box seems to be lower and the back window is bigger on the Silverado where you can see the hitch perfectly.  This has been especially helpful when I'm setting up to go.  It's actually taken a lot of time out of the equation which is always a plus!

Another thing I love is that I haven't had to modify or change anything.  On the F150 I had airbags, 10 ply tires, a RoadMaster Active Suspension installed and those helped, nothing compared to the factory everything the Silverado came with. I realize this isn't an apples to apples comparison to my previous truck.  The F150 I had just wasn't equipped to do what I needed it to do.

Overall, the Silverado 3500 is a good truck.  I enjoy having it, my kids love it, they always want to take the truck.  If you're looking for a hardworking, stylish, and overall reliable truck the 3500 is a great choice!
Replaced my 2013 2500HD with this vehicle and this truck is even better, power, style, comfort- love it.  Looking forward to my 2021 High Country coming soon.
had emission  problems
I tow a 11,000lb trailer and barely know it’s there.  Only complaint is with placement of def tank and fill up.  The price was the decision maker for going with a 2019 instead of 2020.

Spent $64,000 on a truck that had radio issues, transmission issues, regen issues and surged when in regen mode. Radio would be stuck on full blast, clock wouldn’t hold correct time. Transmission would lock up the rear wheels when coming to a stop.

My sonic been having problems since it was under warranty! Had to replace my thermostat 3 times timing belt, coolant system, throttle body just insane I was ok with the fixes at first because it was FREE but afterwards still had the same problems once each year so this year 2024 I will finally sell my car I also needed an alignment at least 3 times I had to change my sun visors just once great on gas also changed the windshield wipers and I believe that is all for now until sold inside of the car looks great but I will never buy this car again even if it was a newer version I just refuse! You guys I’ve had my car for 10yrs it is paid off but it was not worth it I kept it this long cause who wants a car note? Everything is so expensive I wanted to say some money but whew I decided to think twice and yeah I’m getting rid of it I put way too much money in this car over the years! I hope this help you all on what you would like to purchase

It's in pretty good condition it has 4 doors which is a plus when u have a small vehicle.its 4 cilander so cheap for gas nice shade of gray has blue tooth and it also has remote startots a 2013 so not real old trunks is a pretty decent size and the back seat goes down heat and ac work fine so very decent car battery and tires are  fairly new also

2012 chevy sonic LT 1.8  Worst production auto ever made. Fun to drive and for that I give it 2 stars. 
Transmission failer 4 times and still Under 70K miles. Twice under warranty, once under recall, and now I am stuck with this P.O.S..... Its not just the transmission. Both sun visors are broken blocking view. Cruse control switch broken because the wire wrapped around steering wheel. Paint faded less than 1 year old. Started skipping during idle with 20k miles. Dealer said it was normal. Turned out to be the timing belt. I could go on and on with the cons of this car. Do your research before you buy. Others having same issues

The 1.4l turbo engine gaskets fail easily allowing coolant to seep into the engine.

This problem can be simply resolved if caught quickly by adding coolant sealant to reservoir and running the engine.

Other than engine problems that occur. This vehicle is good to have

Good car good tire very dependable !
Great starter car for young man to start ?
I need your price range please ?

Love the car.  Is very liable
No issues except having to change out thermostat about 6 mo ago
Excellent on road with good gas mileage. Very easy to handle. Will keep it for a while!!!

My 2017 Chev Sonic is in excellent condition. The car handles very well. It is very comfortable.
Heater works well, heated seats, heated steering wheel and adjustable seats.
Driver's seat adjusts up and down and adjustable steering wheel. 
Lane safety warning, and crash warning.

Good car but made cheap . It does not have cruise control, which sucks if you plan a long trip but the gas mileage is amazing so that is a positive. It fits a lot. It may look small but it can fit so much. It drives great but I swear it has stuff messing up all the time and they say it so not recalls but I feel it so the car

I got my spark in 2021 with 45k miles, and two years later the only thing I've had to do is replace the battery. Yeah it's not the fastest, but I really don't know what you'd expect from 98 hp. Gas mileage is almost as good a driving a Prius, and for how small it is nearly everyone who has rode in the back seat says they still have plenty of room. Really sad to hear they discontinued them.
This won’t let me give it five stars I tired  3 times not good when you love your car so it’s fast and handles great and it’s a fun car

bought this car in 2020 its 2021...Already had too bring it back twice for ac compressor failed really?  wont be keeping it not happy with this car..Just Beware.. Should not have issues less then 2 Years old.
This is my families 3rd Spark. dependable,  comfortable,, great gas mileage. I would recommend this car to friends and family.

The car is a wonderful little car. I wouldn’t get rid of it, but there are so many trucks on the road in Oklahoma, I don’t always feel safe with their driving.  I’m going to miss the great mileage and the fact it doesn’t cost anything to run it. And it’s fun to drive.

I was sad to learn it was been given the boot. It is slow at first but it runs great. I have taken many long trips with my daughter.  It is very comfortable. She says she has lots of leg room in back.
Great little car, comfortable 4 passenger. My son is 6'2" and finds driving my car very comfortable.  Great for road trips, excellent gas mileage

I like the standard shift model. 
I also had a 2016 Spark drove great in the snow too. 
 Traded it in 116,000 miles on it and the dealership turned around and sold it for 2000 less than I paid for it 8,000. 
Never had any issues 
I changed the oil regularly 
And had one alignment 
Great all around vehicle and the best part I got 41 mpg. City and highway driving.
Haven’t  purchased a car in a decade but we needed to upgrade for space and towing capabilities. So far everything has been amazing. Lots of compliments.

I paid extra 5k to buy My Chevy Suburban after I had already put a deposit down for a Chevy Tahoe and couldn’t get it in Florida on the original Delivery date. My Sales guy called me said he had a Black on Black with black interior suburban that came in that you would probably like it is not the Tahoe but for only 4 k more it has the panoramic sunroof & bucket seats.I said okay that will work Well worth the extra 9k the money I put down was basically eating up the upside down ness as I drive it off the lot. Highly recommend thanks Stu at Chevy in Sanford Fl Tell them Matt Referred you. They will give you 1ST CLASS TREATMENT! Guaranteed! 🙌🏻

I have owned 3 Suburbans including a 2002 LS a 2003 Z71 and this 2021 RST Durmax diesel. It is 4WD with the luxury package, power folding seats, panoramic sun roof, rear media package and sliding center console. My new Suburban is like going from the stone age to the space age with all the technological advancements. The rear media package is a must for long trips where we can watch Netflix movies and other things with a connected Amazon Fire TV stick. The mileage is great and the torque is amazing. If you are looking for a luxury good looking large SUV this is the one to get

I have owned two Tahoe SUV's a 2007 & 2011. I purchased my 2021 Suburban which is just a bigger Tahoe in September 2021. I wanted a Tahoe, but the shortage issues put me in a suburban. I loved my 2007- Z71 and let it go at 80,000 miles to buy my 2011-LTZ. Which I still own, and it has 195,000 miles on it. The only problem with my 2011 was a bad Torque converter which I caught very early and saved my Transmission. My 2007 had the same problem and it took out the Trans. All was covered by warranty. The only other issues were a cracking dash which chevy pretty much covered. Other than that, it was just normal maintenance. So, I took the leap and bought another because over all these trucks have been awesome. The key to the mileage is service. I was a mechanic in the Army and service my vehicles early and often. I have been under my new 2021 and it doesn't look as heavy duty as my 2007 or 2011. But it is built the same V8 rear wheel drive on frame. Framed vehicles are much safer and hold up better in my opinion. I have put 5500 miles on the truck and the only issue I have had is the third-row seat belt beauty bracket in the headliner was broken when installed. Other than that, no issues. I believe the quality is there and don't expect any issues after looking it over. What I don't not like about the vehicle is the lack of a key (push button start) and the buttons instead of a shift lever to put the vehicle in drive / reverse. I am keeping my finger crossed but expect this will be problem points later when the vehicle ages. I am hoping for another 200,000 miles out of this truck, time will tell. As far as comfort these trucks are like riding in your living room. I love them.

Absolutely the space this car has. I have the RST w/ Luxury package . Little upset this still did not come
With Navigation with this price tag. With four kids this has all the space you need and rides smooth. Had a 2021 Tahoe before . Still worried about this Engine (same as my Tahoe) as it failed at around 3,500 miles….GM knows they have a lifter /pushrod issue with these cars. Still nervous on all our summer road trips !

Rented this gorgeous vehicle in California with only 3k miles on the odometer. In about 2 weeks, drove 5,000 miles across several states. Almost all highway, with maybe 5 miles of unpaved roads. Four people and 4 carry-on pieces of luggage. Car is very comfortable. The ride is good, given the size. A lot of space. The glass roof is amazing for sight-seeing. It is huuuuuuuuge. I love everything about this car, especially the numerous outlets for devices.

Two problems: Carplay integration isn't perfect. One time the screen became unresponsive and jittery. Had to turn off the car and let it cool. Also, no built-in navigation. Not cool for when you are beyond phone service.

Then, in the middle of nowhere...the engine began knocking. With no warning other than a sudden light on the dash. Was afraid we would not make it to the nearest city. We did, but it was scary to drive with knocking sound. I say engine knock because the sound only became worse when car was under load, such as when pulling uphill. As if someone took a metal rod and banged it on a metal bucket. Really, really not cool for a car of this caliber with only 8k miles on it. No load, just 4 passengers and steady highway speeds. Before this issue, I was seriously considering purchasing this car for my needs. But after this happened, I will hold off.

If you purchase the 2021 Suburban, go for the Duramax Diesel, you won’t be disappointed. It’s smooth and gets great gas mileage. 

The size of the SUV is deceptive, it rides like a much smaller vehicle. 

Make sure to upgrade to get all the relevant safety feature, I recommend the luxury package.
I bought this car to go on trips for my huge family it’s so comfortable and there is nothing it doesn’t have!!

I love my 2016 Suburban LTZ. It has all the bells and whistles. It has plenty of room for the whole family and keeps my kids entertained on long road trips. I had to have work done on the front struts, which were expensive and the transmission, but the ride is so smooth. I love this truck!

I have dropped so much money into this car after buying it with only 16K miles.  I would not recommend this for anyine who travels often.  New brakes often, sensors out, cruise control not working anymore, sounds in the, new shocks,  engine, rough idle and the list goes on and we are only at 110k this is all after regular maintenance.

I love my car/suv, I just didn't think it through very carefully when I bought it. My husband and I planned on going camping and on impromptu mini vacations. I have the most luxurious bed in the back, all made up and ready for sleeping. I even have been collecting various maps. This beast checked all the boxes for me and I bought it from Hertz rent a car, a business that uses cars every day, so they keep them maintained very well and they have an excellent reputation. I wouldn't sell it except that my husband and I have gotten older and in worse shape, there is so much wrong with me that one good bump and I'll be in a body cast, lol! This car gets decent gas mileage too for as huge as it is. Everything works, tires are in good condition, I've kept the oil changed about every 6 months. It's a tough car, I'd venture to say that if in an accident, it would come out mostly unscathed. It's never been in an accident, there have been no recalls. It has I'd say, quite a few superficial scratches and none through to metal. Stops quickly, has a huge back up camera. It has been good for me, it's just too big for me now. I'd buy one again.

I own this 2015 Chevy suburban for 4 years with 310,000 miles, Never had any major issues and it’s still running strong! I bought it with 120,000 miles and at 310, 000 miles still running the same as it was, when I purchased the vehicle!

My Chevrolet Suburban LTZ has all the creature comforts of a home. It is equipped with push button start, heated and cooled seats, sunroof, captain seats, adaptive cruise control, onstar, dvd and mp3player, rain sensors, collision control, heated mirrors, front and rear cameras, 4x4,
leather seats, premium chrome wheels, 31 gallon gas tank, magneride and a pearl white paint.
No mechanical issues and a great ride with plenty of comfort. The paint loss gloss in the roof and hood and had to repaint.

Pros: This vehicle fits my large family, is comfortable for long rides and gets decent mileage given its size.

Cons: We've had a lot of repairs over the years - satellite antenna (under warranty), A/C (under warranty), A/C again (this time not under warranty), rear shocks (at 82k miles seems early), water pump, transmission cooler lines, ball joints, etc.  Grand total of around $6,000 in repair costs in 6 years (which does not include what the warranty repairs would've cost).   Some of these are wear items, but I had 197k miles on my F150 and didn't have nearly this many repairs.  

Overall it's fine.  Costs a lot to keep it on the road, but when it is on the road it is a comfortable vehicle.
This 2017 Suburban is beautiful and in near perfect condition.  It has been well maintained.  We are wanting a smaller vehicle.

We got our Tahoe right as the computer chip outage began. It was a special order that the customer did not take in the end. Brown on brown high country. We have put 39,000 miles on it. It has been to the shop once for a hvac diverter that was getting “stuck”. We never experience an issue with it but the dealer was proactive and took care of it. A few updates to the ecu some recall work,  no issues found. I also drive a Chevy Silverado 2500 and my recommendation is find a dealer that you can trust and you will enjoy you car. I would buy the Tahoe again we love the great mpg of the diesel, the room and interior.

We bought our  Chevy Tahoe 4x4 diesel a year ago and it spends more time in the dealership repair shop than on the road. We just got it back a few weeks ago and it’s back in the shop.This time when we get it back it’s getting traded in on a Toyota.

Coming out of a 2018 Suburban LT 4WD, I'd hoped Chevrolet would at least maintain its levels of quality and comfort, if not continue to improve upon them.  This is not the case.  The dash is cluttered with buttons with some of them redundant in the infotainment system.  The seating is less comfortable.  The fit, finish and materials are a step down.  The tight, solid feeling I had in the Suburban is not present in this vehicle.  The air ride suspension does nothing to improve ride and may be a detriment to handling and overall driving confidence.  The black chrome grillwork began chipping and pealing almost immediately - a common problem both the dealers and factory seem to ignore.  I would rate my 2000 and 2018 LT 4WD Suburbans as having been competent; 4 stars.  They were bigger, heavier and still got better gas mileage, and they handled and drove better than this thing.  This Tahoe, even with the upscale Z71 trim package, is only adequate.  With a $78,000 sticker price, you'd expect more of the basic comfort than you receive.   It has been a disappointment.  I cannot recommend this vehicle.

This SUV has more bugs than a cheap motel. The cameras also have a known issue for not working, GM knows about this and only pretends to care until your warranty expires. Customer service is worthless. The camera has had to be replaced twice and they are on back order because they literally have to replace so many of them they can’t make it order them fast enough. I’ve had this car for just over a year- bought it new, and I’ve taken it in no less than 6 times for repairs, recalls and 4 times for the front camera. The first YEAR we paid for features we never could use. They finally sent a new camera after an entire year and it failed immediately. Second camera- failed. Third is on back order now and they sent the wrong co-ax cable (for a Colorado). Don’t buy this car. Just don’t buy Chevy period. I knew better after my Impala in college but I figured I’d give it another shot with a new car. This is literally my first selfish splurge car purchase and I’m LIVID.

This Tahoe is the best chevy I've ever driven.  The quality of the fit and finish of everything is really good.
Gets good mileage  plenty of power and pulls a 6500 lb trailer impressively. 
It is easy to park for my wife.  Has room for 6 adults comfortably. 
It is just really a comfortable, well made vehicle.

Buyers be very beware. My family and I purchased the 3.0 diesel for $80,000 out the door. I currently have 29,000 miles on my car. At 1,400 miles my car would randomly not start (long crank no start - research this online as there are forums with thousands of other 3.0 duramax owners experiencing the same). The dealership has been unable to replicate, and therefore GM Corporate refuses to approve a buyback or repurchase. We are now retaining a lemon law attorney to sue GM. I have been stranded numerous times with my children in the car. We do not feel safe in our car. Every day my heart sinks when I go out to start my car. Will it start? It's not started when taking my kids to school. It's not started late at night in the thick of the city, and so on. We have been stranded nearly a dozen times. All documented at the dealership. There is also a rattling noise in the third row seat side panel that surfaces when on the freeway when we hit about 70 miles per hour. The windows in the front drag when rolling up and down. We do not feel safe in our car. Chevy has been unable to fix any of it.

I bought a 2021 Tahoe in Oct. 2020.  I have been back to dealers 3 times about the rattles & squeek noises.  This Tahoe has extremely loud road noise anyway & add the rattles & squeeks and it makes me want to scream!!   
First Service man at Altus, Ok told me “Oh all the 21 Tahoes are that way”.  Different dealership (75 miles away) Wheeler, Tx worked on it.  I had to go pick it up from that dealer!!  I called back & told him i still had the rattles & squeeks.  His reply, “we have done all we can do to fix it”…
I called first dealer in Altus, Ok. today, talked with manager of dealership.  He assured me the service man would call me after he returned from lunch.  My warranty is about to expire & I will be stuck with this rattletrap!!

I purchased a 2021 Tahoe new in April 2021. It has just under 29,000 miles. It has broken down on me twice and I have had to have it towed. Lifters gone out both times. This was covered under warranty, thankfully. Chevrolet’s customer service each time was extremely disappointing. No help with loaner vehicles and Chevrolet would only pay half of my rental. The first time my Tahoe broke down, I was two hours away with my daughter in a large, unfamiliar city. I had to have a family member come pick me up because Chevrolet was absolutely no help. It was horrifying.

I bought this car from a Chevy Dealership used with 72k on it. Fuel eco was good on freeways. then comes the dreaded 100k mark. AC and Transmission broke. Ended up costing 7k after everything. I've never seen so many reviews about bad transmissions on a car. Take this as a warning and avoid this vehicle unless if it specifically comes with a warranty or already had these parts replaced and has a transferable warranty on the parts.

2020 chevy tahoe Lt

Transmisión no good this car need a recall from Chevrolet is a 100k miles transmission for v8 motor ridiculous
One of the best suvs around good space for passengers built quality is good aswell just the paint needed to be more stronger but its alright for me but overall i give it a 5
OEM parts are expensive. These vehicles do not compare in quality to Toyota! The radios give problems in these models. Screen goes blank for no reason.

Great in the snow but after 100,000 miles things seem to break. Had to replace a wheel bearing, transmission, windows all have leaks. Loved the car in the beginning, gas mileage is not that great, but would not purchase again. For the price we paid for the vehicle I would expect it to last a lot longer.
Enjoyed driving! Have a work vehicle now, so no need to own it any longer. Please post your questions.

Mechanically sound, nice heavy body, easy driving reliable vehicle. I was going to trade it in for a newer model but they are NOT as well made as these previous years, the interiors are flimsy and lots of plastic compared to these years' models...Chevy blew it when upgrading to the new models, now they look and feel average. 
Mine is a 2017 all leather LT, smoothest ride out there, I feel confident and very safe driving this vehicle. The BEST!
Handles great. Great performance for a having a 3 cylinder engine. Plenty of leg room. Fun to drive. Easily keeps up with freeway traffic.

Shopped for a front wheel drive smaller SUV. Needs were nimble handling, and fuel efficiency.. the equinox was too soft, and 30 mpg., and had owned one back in 2016../ Lease.. 2024Trax was too course and loud, and that 1.2 is lethargic. Poor fuel economy. Compared to 1.3 ltr  .. Buick encore gx was fine but too pricey$$$ . My wife loves hers..I do the maintenance duties. So there's ample room for that., well engineered., My neighbors Subaru is too tinny, road noise. (2021 outback .). And he gets 28 mpg. So pass. I achieve 36 mpg. Driving 5 mph. Over posted speeds. @ 60% highway driving..speed avg. Says 49 mph. , only negative is halogen lights .. but LED's weren't an option in 2022.. paid $23k. / Fwd. 1.3

It's fantastic really! peppy, maneuverable, efficient,.. I could go on and on. I can barely think of any negatives- blind spots; but that's expected of any SUV. 
The 3 cylinder turbo engine is extremely surprisingly powerful at low rpm, but it does feel a bit weak at higher RPM. It's not bad. 
It's a great car!
It a great car I really appreciate the work and style of it and how it runs and good reliability.would recommend

I bought this car last June with 2 miles on it. I like some things about it.  Very maneuverable. Peppy. Super cute RS in crimson red with black top/front. Why 3 stars? The blindspots are really bad. I added blind spot mirrors to my side mirrors to help with that. The seat is pretty uncomfortable IMO.  I just can't adjust it to wear it's comfortable. It's small, I wish it had more room. I ordered it without test-driving it first. I daily drive on a few miles of dirt road and mainly on the highway - it averages about 30 miles /gallon, which is okay.

We bought ours new, it has not disappointed. We did opt for the turbo, which I am glad as it gets great pickup, and very stylish. It is not great for larger people as it is kind of cramped for myself being 6'4" tall, but it still works for me.

I unfortunately bought this car without test driving it or even going inside it. Huge mistake. I didn’t realize how unbelievably small it was. The back cargo area was so small I couldn’t even put in the sunshade from my Toyota RAV4. It was also unbelievably uncomfortable. The pedals are too close together there’s really no space for foot movement down there.. Armrest is tiny. And there’s really no armrest in the door. So your arms are going to suffer. Horrible acceleration. This thing is slow and has no power! Aside from all that, things kept breaking. The tailgate is supposed to open with a swipe of your foot. That wasn’t working two days after I bought the car. Had to take it to Chevy and drop it off for a week while they fix the sensor. Two weeks after I got the car back, the kick sensor stopped working again! So back the car had to go. Two tires got flat for no obvious reason. Let’s not mention Chevys horrible policies and nickel and diming you for everything including oil changes. I’m going tomorrow to get rid of the car and I’ve only had it for a year. I cannot take it anymore

I loved my 2019 Chevy Traverse LT. Very comfortable car and smooth ride with enough power to get moving when you needed to. The side airbags deployed just as they needed to, the anti-lock brakes did their part, and we walked away from what could have been a fatal accident. I'm now looking to buy the exact same vehicle again - they have my complete trust and loyalty. Great vehicle and I miss it greatly!

Also have had the shift to park issue, can’t keep brakes on it, not sure if design issue but have replaced rotors on front 3 times, and they warp a day after installing, have tried stock and premium rotors, both same issue. Throttle body has to be cleaned every oil change or will stahl, maybe I just got a bad one, but they say 2019 was not the year for Traverse!

Absolutly love this SUV. I got mine brand new on March 6th and it has been amazing. The price point was good, and it is worth mentioning that I traded in a chevy malibu for this Trax. I have read a lot of reviews on the Trax and some of the likes and dislikes are inconsistent, but while I have had mine, it has been wonders.

Before buying late last year, I researched and compared prices and features from all non-luxury new SUV models. 
PROs: From a purely bang-for-your-buck ratio, the 2024 Trax has no rivals. Even the base LS trim with Convenience Package includes heated seats and remote start, and still comes in under $22.5k including fees. Styling is ahead of its time, with a lot of competitors' future releases appearing to follow its lead. Radio and climate controls are simple to use. Ride is super quiet. Nimble handling. My actual MPG has actually been coming in above the 30 mpg combined estimate. Ample passing power on the freeway; you'd never know the engine is just 1.2L.
CONs: Suspension is firm; great for small bumps but not so much for larger ones. Poor side visibility due to thick pillars and high window line, which also gives off a 'sunken-in' sensation to the driver. Steering wheel is near vertical, making it hard to find a comfortable grip. Doors are heavy.

Just purchased this great vehicle on February 14, 2024. No problems yet. Well made, lots of room (front and back) Engine is just what I need around town. And this "entry level LS" doesn't feel like it at all. If you're 
not looking for a "race car", but a nice, reliable, around town, low-priced, quality vehicle, pickup the 2024 Chevrolet Trax LS. You won't be disappointed. Take care

Really enjoyed my 2017 Chevy Volt until Chevy stopped making parts for the car. I had my EGR valve fail which was covered under warranty, however GM/Chevy is not making the part. I waited for 6 months until I had to initiate a lemon buyback request. Currently waiting to see what Chevy offers.

This is my third Volt. Previously I leased a 2013 and then a 2016, and lastly a 2019 after which they stopped making this car so I bought it at the end of the lease (low millage during COVID). Never had any problem with these cars. The interior design, range and efficiency improved over those years. Range is about 50 M. Yet I drive about 80% of the miles on electricity - all my commute miles and some more. I charge it at home. During the first years I used just the provided 110V charger (it took all night to recharge, but same for me :). Then I installed a level 2 charger so it takes 3-4 hours for a full charge, and I set the car to charge only during the off-peak electricity rate. When traveling I never worry about running away from a charger because of the gas engine. And it is about 40 MPG on gas, which is pretty good.

I've had the 2017 Volt since 2018. It's by far the best car I ever owned. With an overall 100 miles per gallon at 60,000 miles, if I didn't take long trips over the last 5 years, the MPG would be at least 150.

I bought my Volt end of 2020 and it has had nonstop issues since then. About 3 weeks into owning it I already had a check engine light on, then another a month after, then another...it has gone to the dealer for issues about 6-7 times in the last 2 and a half years. It has been towed to the dealership twice. Constant issues and has become one of the most unreliable cars I have ever owned. It is now to the point I hold my breath when driving it and hope I can get to my destination and back in it. 

Not to mention the fact it was discontinued, waiting for repairs takes forever. Parts are nowhere to be found and the "certified" specialists most of the time have no idea what they are doing. The reason it has a 10 year/100,000 mile warranty is because it can barely get down the road without failing.The average wait time I experience when bringing it in is 5 days. It is now at its own personal best of 83 days at the dealership with no return time in sight. If I ever do get it back, it's going straight to a dealer and I am getting a Honda or Toyota instead. So for a good 6 months out of the time I have owned it and have been making payments, it has been sitting at dealerships waiting for repairs.

Other than my own personal gripes, this vehicle is just OK. It is actually a 4 seater as the battery blocks the middle back seat and would make it impossible for a grown adult to sit there. I chose this vehicle due to it's stylish counterpart of the Prius but I wish I bought a Prius instead.
Local driving around Chicago- no gas, only electric. Only burns gas on trips. People that ride with me comment on how smooth and quiet the ride is. Shame GM doesn't make it anymore.

If you drive less than 50 miles a day or if you can plug in at work. This is a perfect car. Plus if you need to drive let’s say 300 miles you just keep going and the car switches to regular gas. I save about $160.00 a month in fuel alone that’s including the price of charging at home with a grizzly 240v home charger. When on gas you still get amazing mpg! It truly is a shame GM quit producing these! At $40,000 it’s not worth it, but at $25,000 on the used market if you can find a nice one all day! I would not hesitate to purchase one at the $25,000 range which is what these things are going for.

We bought this vehicle in 2019, just before the tax credits were set to decrease.

Must haves in addition to the Volt itself!
Reading various blogs we made two additional purchases at the same time. (1) A full size spare tire and tire changing tools to keep in the trunk (taking up a lot of space there!) and (2) a home charging station.  Both were great investments. 
We've had several flat tires, (3 in the first 3 months).  Not having to be towed to get a flat fixed is great.   And, because we charge at home and my wife's commutes to work are generally short (less than 40 miles round trip), we have been able to go over 9 months without purchasing gas.  In fact, about once year now we run it without recharging it for a few days, or take long trips in order to burn the old gas out of the tank. We found that in the first year, the gas could grow old before it was used up.

Quality and Comfort.
(A) The interior is plasticky, and a little cheap.  Plastic parts, in the trunk area used to hold the tools that come with the car, and the hold in place the privacy cover in the back broke off within the first two months (and that had nothing to do with the spare tire we purchased!). Mechanically, the car has been excellent.
(B) My son is too tall (over 6 foot) to fit comfortably in the Volt.  But that is true of most cars, compact or otherwise.

Acceleration. 
We test drove the Clarity before purchasing the volt.  It had anemic acceleration.  On the other hand, the volt accelerates as well or better than our Mustang (6 cylinder ICE).  

Gas savings.
We've been very happy with this car for what we use it for, our everyday get around town car.   We've even experienced lower gas bills for our two other cars (a Highlander and the Mustang).  That is because they sit parked most days.  

Other things we like.
Love the backup camera, proximity warning systems, and the Apple Play.  Love the fact that we can (and do) take long trips and are not worried about finding a charging station (or waiting a long time for the car to recharge after finding one!). When running on gas, the car handles well.

Conclusion.
Too bad they don’t make them anymore.  I have recommend the the Volt to my friends.  However it is very hard to find used Volts for sale.  I’m glad I got ours when I did.  I have also concluded that for our driving, an all electric vehicle would work fine for every day driving if it had a range of 200+ miles.  But the same car wouldn’t work for longer trips.  Those trips are rare, but when you need to go 200+ miles, you don’t want to be scrounging around to borrow or rent an ICE car or truck.

I owned the 2017 Volt Premier and loved it.  My round trip commute was 60 miles and I could charge up some at work so mainly just on electric.  I lived in Oklahoma so limited chargers outside OKC .  I drove to Dallas some and was 250 miles one way.  With the Volt, no problem just fill up with gas every 300+ miles and keep going - most electric only cars would be getting close to their full range and be hunting a charger to recharge it.  No hunting for chargers here.  I liked it so much, when I found out that the Volt was being discontinued, I bought one of the last 2019 Premiers, fully loaded.  Now had for over three years and not driving near as much but so nice to have the electric car for around town driving but the ability to drive across the country if needed.

Consequently, first service over $800.  This was an impulse buy and the worst financial decision I have ever made.  Back to Porsche for me if I can ever sell this money drainer.

I had a 2016 Ghibli S which treated me very well, but after having a few kids, my wife and I made the ill-advised decision to switch to a Volvo XC90 for the past 3 years. Well, mistake corrected. The Levante somehow manages to look and drive better than the Ghibli, while also being a supremely comfortable family car. Although you would never guess it from the outside, our childrens' car seats fit more comfortably in the Levante than they did the XC90.

But, look, most of you are probably not shopping the Levante for its car seat space. And the good news is that it doesn't fail to punch above its weight anywhere else, either. I owned a 911 Turbo for 8 years and as mentioned above, a Ghibli for another 3. In one week of Levante ownership, I've already received more compliments and wide-eyed stares and thumbs up than I did in all my years with a 911 turbo and Ghibli combined. It is hard to overstate how visually stunning this car is in person (can I highly recommend the Grigio Maratea paint? Well, I'll do that whether or not I can). People's jaws just drop when they see it, and I live in Silicon Valley, where Ferraris and McLarens are not uncommon sights. I'm not suggesting that strangers will be running up to take photos with your car ... but I wouldn't completely rule it out either. 

And then let's talk about how it drives. Wow. Depending on which model you choose, it may not win a drag race, but you will definitely have a bigger smile than the other driver. I imagine that driving the Levante is about as close to riding a Kentucky Derby horse as one can get in a vehicle with four wheels and doors. 

I've only had it a week, so I'm not going to claim to know it's idiosyncrasies inside and out. But the Ghibli was the easiest car to own I've ever had - more so than even a pair of Lexuses - and I expect the Levante to be better than most in terms of its reliability and ease of ownership. 

The one downside: the tech is a few years behind its peers. No way around that. But who cares, you're buying this car to drive it, not for it to drive itself or to have the biggest video screen. The technology that is there works and is easy to use but you won't wow a Tesla fan or anything with it. You'll just have to be satisfied with having a much better looking, better built, and more enjoyable car for that.

I was in the market for an SUV and narrowed it down to the Porsche Cayenne and the Maserati Levante. I previously owned a Porsche for 18 years and loved it. Going back and forth between the two dealerships, test driving, pricing, at the time made it a really tough decision. I decided on the Levante and I could not be more THRILLED with my choice. The styling is so beautiful, both interior and exterior are stunning. People wave at me from the sidewalk with the thumbs up. The interior is so lush (I got the brown interior and it is gorgeous!). And the engine, designed by Ferrari, sounds like a Ferrari. Every time I start the car it makes me smile. The ride of the Levante is every bit as good as the Cayenne, and I think the handling is even better. I drove the base model Cayenne and bought the base model Levante. They are only 10 horsepower apart, and yet to me, the Levante has FAR better acceleration. I just was not impressed with the acceleration of the base model Cayenne. But when I put the pedal to the floor on the test drive of the Levante, it was almost scary. It screams. I even invited the Porsche salesman to give me a good reason why I shouldn't buy the Maserati. He couldn't. I know after 2,000 miles and having the car for two months now, I would have been really disappointed if I had "settled" for the Porsche. I've owned BMW, Porsche, Mercedes Benz, and this is the most thrilling, beautiful, and spectacular car I've ever owned in over 40 years of car ownership.
