This car is an unbelievable value.  I have a 3.5L Twin Turbo with AWD and the Prestige package (I highly recommend the Prestige package due to the Heads Up display and several other luxury options included).  The owners manual leaves a lot to be desired.  It is hard to find explanations of the numerous features.  For example, I have two buttons, cryptically labeled, on the overhead panel where the dome light and sunroof controls reside.  I cannot find the difference between the two buttons in the owners manual.  Both light the dome light but I cannot figure out why there are two buttons for the light.  That is just an example - the manual must have been translated from Korean, and poorly at that.  Ride is smooth as silk, with windows closed a boom box next to my car is silent, acceleration is remarkable for a car as heavy as this.  Gas mileage is terrible though.  Around town, I get 16 mpg with a light foot.  On the road, I get around 19 mpg.  Wondering if there is something wrong with my fuel delivery system.  Have not asked Genesis for valet pickup and drop-off of my car for service but based on comments in the G80 blog, dealers are reluctant to deliver on the promised service, not to mention they say loaner cars are not available.

First let me say this is my 3d G80 and the first of the new design. The new G 80 looks great but is a giant step backwards in terms of build quality. In an attempt to lighten up the car they have gone to a 4 cylinder engine and lots of cheap plastic parts. The car feels more like a AWD Sonata than my prior G80. Build is disappointing as many interior plastic parts don't fit together well,  the engine is power4ful but shakes and shudders like a tractor, gets worse gas mileage then my prior 3.8L G80 and the emergency braking system just plain doesn't work. The lane control feature is erratic and the car feels unsafe to drive when it is engaged. The worst part is that the factory support team is unable to properly support the vehicle due to the incompetence of ALL the dealer service teams and the manufacturer has refused to fix issues claiming everything is "normal". REALLY!!!!  They are doing this as a way to work around the lemon law in my state. This has a been a very stressful experience and I warn anyone considering purchasing a G80 that if it can happen to me as a 3d time loyal Genesis customer it can happen to you.

Wonderful  overall look. Interior is special, but leatherette in the low end car?
I went from a 3.8 six cylinder to a turbo 4. Maintains performance, improves gas mileage, but sounds like the 4 it is.

Interior feel and look is a step up which is immediately obvious. 
It is a bit more difficult to exit than my previous G80, but is spacious once inside.

Wonderful safety features and I look forward to my 5th Genesis.

Took delivery about a week and a half ago. This is my fourth genesis, 2012/2015/2018 g80 sport htrac, The new one 2021 g80,3.5 twin turbo v6,AWD,prestige. I think that the change is more revolutionary than evolutionary. This thing is a pleasure to drive. Highly recommend. Huge value for dollar spent. The issue is the dealerships. Genesis is a luxury car being sold in not so luxury environment.

I’ve driven my used G80 from 45k miles to 99k and it still handles smooth. No real aging in the past two years keeping the wear and tear almost nonexistent. My favorite part of the car is the Luxury feel that rivals that of a Mercedes at near half the cost for some models. I’ll take that over brand recognition any day. All in all some may prefer better performance on this car, however I love it for just cruising around in.

I purchased a 2018 G80 Ultimate in December and love it. Potent V8,AWD and all the creature comforts of any of the high end brands. Have yet to find an issue with it. What an upgrade from my Sonata Limited!!
I have owned Mercedes, BMW, Audi, Cadillac and a Chrysler 300.  There is no doubt that this car beats them all in every category. Very happy with the performance, the looks and the reliability.
I have owned BMW 528i M Sport and I can honestly say my Genesis G80 is a better ride, and more powerful.
Luxury without the high price! The ride is smooth! I have owned it since 20,000 miles and have never had anything go wrong.

Bought my wife one in 2015 and traded her 2013 Lexus ES350 she loves it. Decided i wanted one so I bought the 2017 5.0 and got rid of my 2017 RX 350. It out performs and looks better in my opinion. Nothing like having a back seat of groceries after shopping and shaming a Hemi Charger or 5.0 Mustang in the process......Great value.
I've had Jags, Lincolns, & Cadillacs. This is the most advanced car I've ever had. Own this, drive this...you will be happy.
If you are looking for mid size luxury car and don't worry about badge on car then G80 is for you. Beautiful car inside out and drive like charm.

I have owned a car garage for the past 18 years. My first Genesis was a 2010..4.6. Just bought a 5.0 Ultimate.. 420 Hp. Picked it up at Naples Fl. Drove to Tallahassee. Torrential rain, dark roads.. My friend owns. 550 Benz.  This car worth 34k on it ? A steal.. Uber quiet and incredibly comfortable. Still has a warranty and purchased an extended warranty making it good through 2029. Looked at Benz, BMW etc. For the money? Cannot be beat..

An executive level sedan, with unobtrusive, tasteful good looks.  A solid, pliant ride with good road feel, variable ratio steering, and good brakes that keeps the vehicle nimble and quick despite its size and weight.  Comfortable leather seats, lots of legroom, extraordinarily quiet cabin with a silky smooth V8 engine that whispers.  Lots of bells and whistles for the money, and the car has been reliable.

We have had the pleasure of owning, driving and enjoying this great vehicle for over 6 years. It is as much of a pleasure to drive it today as it was when we received it. In fact, we are in the process of trying to purchase a new G90 with the turbo, power closing doors, massaging rear seats and premium stereo. Can't wait.

I did allot research focusing on maintenance, dependability, and overall cost to own. I found that though the big three (Lexus, Mercedes, and BMW) live up their their name, the Genesis G90 is making one for itself. 
I did buy it used. Thought there is not an extensive history to rely on compared to the big three, I found that owners are happy with their purchase. This seems to have made the trade in value of the G90 pretty good. While I do understand that many cars a benefiting from the increase in used car equity, the G90 is certainly comparable to other luxury brands. 
It is too early to say anything about repairs. However, I have not seen many bad reviews. They have mostly been bad mechanics. So, I definitely believe a trip to the dealership is a bargain considering some of the reviews with main line repair shops.
The ride is excellent. I can say no more. It is has all the bells and whistles. With that being said. Get a maintenance plan to cover future cost.
Looks, styling, rarity are all awesome. Beautiful leather throughout including the dashboard, rocking sound system, and plenty of room for the whole crew!

The Genesis G90 simply does not measure up to its own standards or the standards of the luxury sedan market segment.  First of all, no Genesis dealer in my area actually offers the much-advertised and touted valet pick up and delivery service, which was the major reason I chose this car over its competitors.  Second, its navigation system froze and an interior light malfunctioned within the first few days after delivery, which never happened with any of my other cars, let alone my luxury cars.  Third, the Genesis service departments in Orange County, CA are run like they are servicing Chevys instead of high end luxury cars; they could learn a lot from the local Lexus and Mercedes dealers.  Fourth, despite all of the leather, wood, interior lighting and fancy gadgets, the car simply lacks the refinement of its competitors, exhibiting driveline lash, harsh gear changes, and transmitting noise and vibration from the road to the occupants far more than a Lexus LS or Mercedes E or S class.  Fifth, the B pillar between the front and rear doors is about four or five inches too far forward, making it unacceptably difficult for anyone six feet tall or more to enter and exit the vehicle.  This is the result of Hyundai's effort to make this a quasi-limousine by making the rear doors huge at the cost of making  that intrusive B pillar way too far forward.  It is an amateur car design.

This is 2nd G90 5.0.  I started with the 2017 Genesis G90 5.0 and I wa s not disappointed with the luxury, the horsepower or the style of the car.  The only thing that was missing was TV in the rear seats.  The 2020 model added that feature at which point i upgraded to the G90 5.0 ultimate.  There were 2 things that I truly missed about the 2017 G90 was the comfort of the seats and the smoothness of the ride.  The 2020 G90 seem to be lacking in these areas.  However, I still love my G90 so much so I am waiting on the release of the 2023 G90.  I have heard that the 2023 will not come in a V8 which is very disappointing because I like the power of a V8 engine but I am excited about the overhaul that Genesis has done with the 2023.  I can't wait to get mine.

Wish it came with a panoramic roof and dual sunshades. Everyone stops and ask me what kind of car is it. Ask, what it’s like to drive. One of my friend that I had just purchased a, Bentley. I did trade my, Mercedes S 550.
This vehicle has it all.  All safety devices you need or want.  It drives like a luxury sedan.  Interior comfort is great, highway noise is almost zero.  Fit and finish is impeccable.

While this vehicle looks pretty drives reasonably well over all quality of the 2024 is lacking from the manufacturer. You wont find one near the starting price unless you order and even then im not sure you could. The company has no replacement parts in inventory. I've "owned" this car for three months and the dealer has had it for half that time. And wouldn't you know on day 26 the repair is supposedly made there just waiting on parts. Funny that theres  recalls and they just shorted the lemon law in my state

Stay away electronics suck heat never turns off, remote starte works sometimes and in winter mode turns on the AC. 3 buttons before you see a radio screen. The most annoying car i have ever owned. Big regrets.  also Value drops like a stone.
Love the Advanced. But the steering wheel is hideous. And at this piece point they have to be fully digital in the gauges. You can only fix these big problems with much more expensive sport package.

My gv 70 cuts out on the roadways without warning.  It decelerates and accelerates also without warning 
My daughter and I have driven and have experienced these occurrences repeatedly.   My car now in
The dealership for last 3 weeks without any communication from dealer until initiated it. Corporate keeps telling me they need to talk another department.   Never able to return phone calls to corporate which are infrequent as the voicemail immediately responds.  I am concerned about others safety.   This situation is far from being resolved.

A great riding car, but it stops right there.
The electrical system is terrible right from day 1. The GPS says it is outdated and should be updated but Genesis says there is no update available. All the settings that the owner has to install like the radio, which doesn’t hold any channels, the doors that i set to open auto when the car is turned off, don't work. If you are sitting in the back seat your stuck in there and in case of an accident back seat passengers are stuck. Clock goes on and off, speedometer on screen works sometime, all the settings have to be reset every week or so.
There is no heat in the back., the back hatch continually gets lower every time it is opened, it hast my head several times. 
I have had the car in for servicing 5 times, and i get the same answers that it cannot be fixed. The Genesis company cannot fix it. Under the NYS lemon law, i asked the company to fix it or take the car back. They cannot fix it and they refused to take the car back.
Unfortunately the service departments reall dont have any idea of how to work in this car.
I asked a tech how come there is no engine temperature gauge on the car, he told me they dont need one, wrong one day i hit a button and it cane up along with a bunch of other gauges that i guess should be on the dash.
Then i asked a tech why all the electrical settings keep going away and he told me the car thinks there is another driver so it cancels your settings, wrong again.
The company takes no responsibility for their auto. The Car now has about 8,000 miles on it, i do not recommend a Genesis.

Purchased the GV70 in Oct 2021,  in January 2022 with less than 5,000 miles, my car was back at the Genesis Dealer.  The dealer had my car for 3 months and installed two transmissions before determining ( with Genesis Corporate) it was the transfer case.  In October 2022, my radio/Modem failed,  It is now Mid December and Genesis is stating "it will be likely that the part will not be here for another month".  Nothing definitive, seems like just a guess so that I stop calling Genesis Consumer Affairs.  I have a real problem with Genesis Consumer Affairs, they are useless and clueless.  While Iike the car, I cannot count on this being a reliable car.

3.5 engine, all the bells and whistles.  I will admit I was  peeved when the transfer case started whining at 12k miles and it took 3 weeks to replace it - I wasn’t sure I would enjoy the car as much when it was returned.  But I do.  The car is quiet, responsive, comfortable, sporty, gorgeous inside and out, and feels very sure-footed in inclement weather.  The controls keep your focus straight ahead - the heads up display is great to see mph and speed limit, along with the next turn if navigation is on.  The turn signal with camera activates a screen view on the dashboard.  The sound system is great.  Touch the seat controls and a diagram of the seat shows up on the display so you are not just fumbling.  I could go on.  I am not a techie by any means but I find the controls of this car pretty easy to navigate and it’s capabilities just make me smile.  So do the compliments it receives.
Really good!...You wont regret when you get this car....I bought this car since 2021 and is still as strong and beautiful as first day....

Last year I purchased not one....but two GV80's. They were both low mileage used cars. The first one started having electrical issues within 2 months. The dealer received another and offered a trade which I took. Within a month I found out I couldn't get the oil changed anywhere except two places completely 300 miles either way. Then the back window blew out. No...it wasn't vandals. It blew out onto the driveway. The Navigation system needed to be rebooted every trip we took. The sunroof quit working as did the interior overhead lights. Service has got to be the biggest joke that I have ever encountered. Honestly....a YUGO would probably been as good as the Genesis. Maybe because they were used, maybe because the dealer didn't tell me truth about the history of the car. Lousy gas mileage and constantly having to update the navigation system was enough to make me scream. You get to get Genesis to give you a memory stick and then you get to spend two days trying to figure our how to update the system. These cars were nightmares. I'm so very happy that the major car reviewers love them so much. They should buy one themselves along with some strong meds to ease the stress.

I traded my 2017 Genesis G90 3.3turbo for my 2023 GV80 Prestige in April of 2023.  I had 66000 miles on the G90, and it was STILL perfect.  I went to the SUV (Prestige trim level) as I have a bad back, and the sUV is FAR easier to enter. I have 7200 miles on my GV80, and love it too.  There is not anything I don’t like about my GV80 except the frustrations I’ve had with the Genesis dealer, which fortunately changed ownership in the past two months.  I experienced frustration within an hour of trading my 2027 G90, when, while I was still at the dealership, I told the finance manager I had left my Oakley sunglasses in the roof sunglasses compartment.  I was told 5 minutes later that he’d checked, and they weren’t there.  I had a HUGE issue with the dealer I won’t go in to here, but I’m delighted that new ownership has taken over-otherwise I’d even chosen to use another Genesis dealer 15 miles farther from my home for service. I’ll close this review by sharing that I’ve now had two premium Genesis cars, and I’ve loved them both.

I owned a 2021 Adriatic Blue with the Dune interior, I love this car haven't had any problems and hope not to have any.  I've owned it for over a year and on a weekly bases I have someone stop me or come to me asking me about the car.  I have all the features and I use most of them.  You could not go wrong with this veh.
Great SUV! 3.5T AWD Advaced Plus. It still remains fairly unique on the road, not too many out there. We have the blue exterior with the tan interior, we get thumbs up or compliments all the time.

Rear differential issues along with rear-end needed alignment, tires were cupped, transmission in sport mode was rough not shifting properly. Front left headlight had dead spot in it

They replaced rear differential and gave it an alignment but refused to change out cupped tires caused by rear differential and alignment, they supposedly replaced head light but it still has dead spot.

West palm dealership and Genesis very difficult to get an appointment as well as getting service done. They would not replace tires that were cupped.

The car is ok hard to understand all its features. No one shows you how to use them. I am sure they would be great if you knew how to use them. 
I had to replace a tire nail, and they couldn’t find a tire to match the other three I am driving a $90,000 car with unmatched tries. Stupid. The quality is not the high standard like the BMW’s. The cabin is noisy.  I only have 10,500 miles. It’s a year old. It’s a bad penny for me. I am Seriously thinking Of trading it. It's not worth the money.

The quality of the car include the performance, quality, service. Service play very important role of  the overall car reputation. Genesis car has 5 stars quality, but because of the under 1 star service, I have to give them low rate and will not recommend to anyone. With the money paid for the luxury car, not worth to get all the headache due to the poor service.

Excellent vehicle with great ride & handling. Avg mileage around 26mpg & 32mpg highway.
Always Garaged, new tires & brake pads.
Dealer service records.

This car gets great gas mileage! The car is light but drives very stable. Very good looking car inside and out. I bought this car used in 2021 and immediately drove it cross country, very happy! And the backseat is HUGE.

I bought my Cadenza new, back in the Fall of 2016. It's been a beauty with zero problems! It's 2023 and I still LOVE this car...best car I've ever owned. This was my 3rd KIA and all 3 have been amazing. Prior to KIA, I was a Honda owner....and I'll say both are equally great, reliable and fun cars to own!

Kia was so dumb for discontinuing this model the cadenza is an amazing ride snappy acceleration and great handling make this car so fun to drive plus luxury comfort one of the most comfortable cars I have ever been in. All of this plus it is a head Turner everywhere I go and people can’t believe it is a Kia they think it is some expensive import

Typical Kia.A lot of car for the money.Drives well.Lot of features even in the base Premium model.Pretty good on gas also.Got 33 mpg on a short 100 mile trip to Daytona Beach.Purchased 2019 as a used car with 11700 miles on it for $24900 and traded in a 2018 Mazda 6 with 35000 miles that was just coming out of warranty.
For the money I am very happy with the car.

290 HP and a sports mode built in for the 2019 kia cadenza limited I found it to be one of the most affordable cars that provides a luxury look and feel. Only con for me is that it's not AWD but that's not a big deal. Gas mileage is decent at 20-22 mpg average when driving around town if you set your drive mode on smart. It will adapt to your driving habits and adjust accordingly as you drive. The heads up display is a nice feature along with the leather seats and sun roof(something I've used much more than I thought).

I own the 2020 Kia Cadenza. This is my second Kia cadenza I also had a 2014 that I sold after buying my 2020.
The 2020 is amazing between the new exterior design and the interior features it easily compares to some BMW's and Audi's but at a much more affordable price.
One of my favorite features on this car and my last Cadenza was a simple feature called auto hold that allows you to remove your foot off the brake when you are stopped at a red light – a simple feature once you had it you'll never want to be without it.
Best warranty on the market and it's one of the reasons I continue to go to Kia vehicles.
My wife owns a 2021 Telluride.

I wasn't even looking for a car, took in my 2017 for recall work and saw a 2020 model. I was blown away! Two days later, I drove it away. This car has all the bells and whistles you could ever want. Very comfortable. Engine has plenty of power, put it in sport mode and it really takes off !  You don't see many on the road either (because Kia doesn't advertise this model). I got the white Snowy pearl color and it looks gorgeous. I didn't realize all the technology features this car had till I got it home and read the manual. I knew it had the adaptive cruise control and lane departure, I didn't know it can actually steer and keep you in your lane.

I highly recommended to the big family looking a affordable and luxurious MPV Car.
Best on my experience 10 out of 10 also fuel efficient, I love the car…

First let me say we have been loyal Kia fans. We had the sorento, optima and then traded in our Sedona for the Carnival. Less than 30 days my dash board started coming apart. From then it’s been never ending issues with the front end of my car. I think my car has been in the shop over 10 times for repairs. Kia corporate didn’t do anything to resolve the issue. Honestly stay far away. The tire traction is awful, the car constantly feels like it jerks no matter what weather when you accelerate. Buttons are backwards. Sliding door smashed my sons hand. Bumper looks like it’s sticking out (I have never hit anything and no one has hit me). My window needs to go in to get replaced because the motor. It’s just a very poorly built car. They should have kept the Sedona because while the carnival is pretty on the outside I’ve never had so many issues before with a vehicle.

I have this car for more than a year now and no major issues so far. There are few thing that I think Kia needs to improve on.
1. Kia app is absolutely useless, never works.
2. Driving on highway cabin noise is very high.
3. The paint quality needs some improvement 4. Inside of the car is noisy when the road is not smooth.

Drive this car is safe  with all the amenities for safety I like it .Especially when I change lines,When people in front of me go and tell me to go.let me know in how many days I need services.I save on gas.Spacious.

Had engine trouble knocking at times kia put a paten on oil filter no aftermarket filters, I took to dealers to get it serviced went 1000 miles over recommended because dealers couldn't get oil filter they were always on backorder checked with 4 dealers, so I traded it off

This car was not my first choice, in fact it wasn't a choice of mine at all, it was my husband's. We went to see it last just so he can shut up and boy do I love him for bugging me. I love everything about this car. I have the beautiful blue with the black rims GORGEOUS. People are always asking about it. Its spacious, comfortable, nice display screen and the TRUNK SPACE is a bonus.
loved at first driven in it . awesome prices for a luxury minivan compared with other minivan in 2022

what a minivan! the crysler pacifica has bad reliability, the toyota sienna's seats are not comfortable enough , the oddesey {the 2018 model} is getting old. the carnival dosen't have any of those cons.

This is hands down the best car I’ve owned. I know, it’s a Kia, but they have stepped up their game. I take this car on 5 hour road trips all the time.  It charges in 18 minutes, enough time to eat a meal or stop and stretch. I have had zero issues with it. It’s comfortable, roomy and drives great. In the summer, the range is around 250 miles, winter drops to 200 miles, sub zero temperatures shorten the range to 150 miles. It also has physical buttons and controls for HVAC/radio and other options. The only downside in my opinion is the style.  It’s too sporty for my taste, but that’s fine.  I bought it for its range and charging speed.

Love the style, handling, etc.  Owned it less than 9 days.  Front and rear "inverters" failed, coolant leak, and went into "zombie" mode.  Look it up.  Additionally the electronic parking brake would not release so it couldn't be towed/pushed/rolled.  KIA CUSTOMER "CARE" IS ALL ABOUT BREAKING YOU DOWN UNTIL YOU GIVE UP.  ABSOLUTE TRASH.  ONCE YOUR CASE GETS "ELEVATED" BE PREPARED TO DEAL WITH EVEN MORE AGGRESSSIVE ATTEMPTS TO BEAT YOU DOWN.  IN SUM, IF IT WORKS GREAT, GOOD FOR YOU, IF NOT, YOU WILL HATE YOUR LIFE, SPEND DOZENS OF HOURS ON THE PHONE, AND THE SOLUTION MAY BE MONTHS DOWN THE ROAD.....IF THERE IS ONE.  WOW.  JUST WOW.

250 to 275 mileage on a full charge. Resale value is terrible. Over priced suv for what it is. Reliability is not that good because of the weather changes, it messes with the battery. Seats are a bit hard on road trips. Just a typical electric vehicle that is not worth buying.

I’ve owned a lot of cars and most recently a X5 and Q7. The EV6 caught my eye and I had to test drive it. I had reservations about KIA and their EV, but then did some homework and was sold on a GT-Line Limited Edition. Three months into ownership, I absolutely love driving this car. Drove it from MN to TX and back and I still find out it does cool things. Masterfully designed with excellent quality materials. I get questions and comments about it almost daily - it’s a real head turner and you don’t see these like you do T**la.

I had been talking to my wife about electric cars for a few years, but never got off the fence. Recently, after talking to two EV owners at a charging station, I went home and added up what we spent on gas for our mini-van and sedan. I was shocked. I researched the EV6 and one search was surprising. When I looked up "Kia EV6 awards" there was page after page of awards the car has won. One page even said "This car is so good its even winning awards that aren't for cars." But we still test drove a few others and eventually purchased a Certified 2022 EV6 from a Kia dealer. That means we were able to get the balance of it's 10-year / 100,00-mile warranty, which includes the EV6’s battery. Also, we were able to switch our electric supplier to one that is 100% renewable. That means that every mile we drive will truly be zero emissions! It has the comfort of a very pricey luxury car. Its so quiet. On the highway we feel more like we are gliding in an airplane. The handling and acceleration are exceptional. I love driving this car. While customer service at the dealerships isn't on par with the vehicle, the EV6 is still extraordinary.

This was my first EV and first true purchase of a car as an adult for just myself. I drove a Camry ‘07 until it finally died on me. Overall it is wonderful. I have a ‘22 AWD (non-GT) model. 

Pros:
Fast and fun to drive—in regular mode it’s great and in sport mode it’s really great. The acceleration is shocking as is the handling. It absolutely feels like a sports car. And it’s an electric. Kia. 
Apple connectivity and Bluetooth connectivity—it is annoying to get apple play you have to plug it in instead of syncing thru Bluetooth tho 
Quick DC charging—reportedly the fastest in the market when I bought it
Had a rebate when I bought it—I think this is expired
Beautiful, sporty car, unique style externally, I particularly enjoy the lights 
Nice interior, high quality computer, connectivity options, tons of charging spots 
Trunk cover is very stylish 
The console is great. Very user friendly. In contrast to Tesla which I felt was too laptop oriented this feels more like a iPhone type interface. And you still get a few old school knobs and such to make it feel still old school for those of us who like some hardware in the console. 
Adjustable regenerative breaking is really nice. My wife loves this when she  drives it. You can fully turn it off or make it drive full regen and have several settings in between. This is helpful for people new to EVs to get used to it. I use full regen now tho.
Warranty. It’s Kia. They take care of you. 
Accessible service centers 

Negatives: these are annoyances for me rather than deal breakers. 
Range is over estimated in my experience: this is the thing that bothers me the most about the car. I’ve never been able to go longer than 280 practically. This May be possible if you were driving in a flat desert to make the 310 but it’s not practical for most. I live in hilly North Alabama and I just adjust accordingly. If it had 325-350 it would be perfect. 
It’s not a car with much storage space. The trunk is not tiny but not big either and the frunk in the AWD model i have is a joke. It may fit a small purse and a water bottle. That’s about it. 
The DC fast charging network is a work in progress. In my opinion unless you have a Tesla this is a risk you have to accept for the time being. 
Initial technical issues when I got it which I expected because it was such a new car in a new market space for the company. Regenerative braking was buggy but brought it in and it was fixed in a week. Got a free rental for that time. There were some software updates that fixed some glitchy things with temperature control that were minor and are now fixed. I’ve had zero issues since. 
Back seats are fine for 2 people. Not for 3. It’s a problem for most cars in this class though I think. 
You have to pay after a year for remote start and remote climate control and remote lock/unlock features. Kia needs to make at least one of those things standard (remote lock/unlock). 
The key fob has pathetic range for locking/unlocking the car. 

Overall:
I love it. I would buy it again in a heart beat. I decided between this, a Tesla 3 and a Polestar 2. Seriously consider it if you’re in the market for an EV at this price point and size.

Like may others, I searched for an EV that was not a Tesla and addresses range anxiety, charging time, warranty period, and features - in that order. It came down to the ID.4, Ioniq 5, and EV6. Software update problems eliminated the ID.4. Styling made me select the EV6. 

After 9 months driving one nearly every day, I LOVE my EV6. I've driven 190 miles one-way over some hills as well as flat highways on one charge (90% to 18%) with the A/C on and slightly over the speed limit.  That same charge level would get me nearly 250 miles around town. But climbing hills and moving a ton of car at highway speeds chews up energy - even on a Tesla.

ONLY ONE BUG: the intermittent USB CONNECTION DROPS that plagues many Hyundai and KIA models. Still not officially resolved. And the most recent software update has made it even worse!
KIA knocked it out of the park on this car!

One of the worst resale value reputation vehicle's. They are not like a honda civic, this is a cheap version of them. This car is under powered, terrible fuel mileage for being a small compact sedan. Transmission feels terrible like pulling a rubber band. Seats are not comfy on longer road trips.

Transmission problems already for being a newer car. The value depreciation rate is terrible. I, wouldn't recommend these cars. Too many issues, and the ride quality is terrible. I'm already trying to trade it in, and I'm just getting low ball offers because these cars have a bad reputation.

Not much, just trying to keep my cool. I'm Just mat at myself for buying this stupid kia forte gt. This thing has been a headache since I bought it. Dealing with condensation issues in my head lights, tail lights etc. Transmission having strange hard shifts. Engine having low idle problems. Yeah, you should of never bought this car. Look homie, there's plenty of chop shops. Plus you don't even need a key to start it.

Hey man, what's up.. Just checking out this weird looking car. Bro, this car is junk what are you thinking? Lol I'm so high right now I don't even know what I'm thinking. Dam dude, well let me tell you something about this car. It sucks, and who came up with the idea of putting turn signal lights on the back end of the bumper. Ohh shizneck, man that does look weird as hell. Yeah, and these cvt transmissions are garbage. Well, bro let's go find something else, this car sucks.

Great car quick for what it is with the 7speed and 1.6turbo  the GT was do believe it should have power windows besides that has tons of tech and safety features I’ve done a 10 hour road trip seats are comfortable plus it’s a great price for heated and cooled seats beat other brands for the price
How dare kia be so cheap as to make newer models after 2021 without a push start. You're enabling thieves and adding to the problem. Shame on you

Auto insurance is insane on these cars because they are number 1 stolen cars along with hyundai. Not what I expected from a small compact sedan. It was an okay car to drive around in at the time. Cost just got to expensive for my budget. These cars have a terrible transmission cvt. Not very good gas mileage. Uncomfortable seats after awhile of driving. Resale value reputation is bad.

Just a bad resale value reputation vehicle. They have poor quality looks. Reliability is not that good. I'm glad I just traded in this car. It was a bad idea buying it in the first place. The interior is full of plastic, and the stereo sits on top of the dashboard that has a tablet design look. I, wouldn't recommend this car for the price tag there asking.
Do not recommend this car. Had to replace the engine twice and it had a bunch of other mechanical issues.

I bought this car brand new in 2018 and have had nothing but problems since. Only at 91,000 miles and the car no longer works. Over the last 2 years i've put over 2k into replacing everything.  Constant recalls and engine problems. I do not recommend this car at all. The music cuts off randomly at times, screen will go black just paid it off and now have to get a new car. Put your money into a better brand

I've had the car about 3months and really enjoy it yes I got it used but still drives like a new car love the gas mileage also the spacious room it has. And for a four banger it has great power and makes me happy

The air conditioning stopped to work and I had to replace the AC Compressor for my KIA Forte 2018 at less than 30k miles of use, which is a very low mileage for such a problem to have. In fact I never experienced an AC failure happening to any of my previously owned cars, either foreign or domestic and some of them I used for 80-90k miles. 
The average cost of replacing the AC Compressor is around $1500 depending of the service facility and it is not covered by manufacturer’s extended warranty (after 12,000 miles or 1 year, whichever first).

I have had a lot of vehicles in my life but my 2018 Kia Forte might be the best. And at a great price with an amazing warranty. Great handling. Great price for brakes and tires and parts are readily available. My sales person was great and I am so glad I bought this vehicle.

A couple bells, no whistles. It’s a great basic car. Good gas mileage, general maintenance only.  Heat and air conditioning are more than adequate even on extreme days. Have had no issues. It went in once and they performed recall maintenance at the same time. I can’t recall what the problem was but it was under warranty. Bluetooth phone with controls on steering wheel. Paint has held up well even with it parked outside in the California sun. Things I wish it had: cruise control and navigation. Thinking of upgrading for more road trips.

Yes, the car is at high risk of being stolen. There are a lot of recalls. Things seem to break down too quickly. The car feels cheap. 

I used to have a Chevy Cruze and I had been deciding between that and this one when we bought the Kia Forte. Boy do I regret my decision. The Cruze was just way better quality. 

Given the easiness with which people can steal the Kia, I feel like I put a bunch of money into something that's worthless. I despise this company.

Clean Car, very well taken care of, drove to work and home, all maintenance, oil changes, done on time. Has both cool and heated seats, heated steering wheel, folding mirrors, Bluetooth, X-M Radio, AM/FM, Black on Black, letter interior.

To be a new car still with only 18500 miles on it. It was just average. It had several issues in the first 2 years that I didn't think should have been OK and there was no recall. The transmission would have trouble shifting in Smart Mode because the computer couldn't make up its mind what to do. So it might try to throw you backwards or forwards depending on its choice at lower speeds.

Just purchased one, nice and smooth and has the amenities of a luxury vehicle. Only thing is that the kia rotors started to wear out at 5k, returned for svc and replaced at no cost. It's a fun car to drive especially in sport mode.

Comfortable, GT Model very sporty and handles great, economy drive, normal and custom for your need for speed days. Paddle shifters, Bose Sound.
Love It!
Great car&&sssss&ssssdgggggggggvcccvhhjjhygvvvbbbvccffgggbhhhygvvbbbbbbhhugvvvbhhjiuutrghjuijkjjhhhhhhh
I am not a car person, I normally drive trucks. But I purchased this car to save on gas because I drive 75+ miles a day. This has been an excellent purchase!

The K5 GT Line AWD is great. I have gotten more compliments on this car mostly by older men that appreciate a nice looking car!! Of course it is black, blacked windows, black interior and the panoramic roof. Premium wheels are great. Only thing it does not have for its class is the premium sound, but the Harmon System isn’t bad! It will fly when I need it too and has ECO for when I don’t and want to save on gas! It’s a fun car to drive. My biggest irritation is that I can’t put my license plate on the front center because of all the sensors for the various warnings. It also will drive hands free as
Long as the lines are clear
In the road. It makes
Me uncomfortable so
 I don’t use it much, I don’t like how the cruise slows down via sensor on the highway, I was told it could be turned off but not sure about that and I don’t drive enough in interstates to have checked  into it much. I do like the change lanes alert and the back up camera not only beeps at me but slams on my brakes if I am backing out and something is coming behind me. That took some getting use too but I don’t mind it now. The app on the phone is great especially for winters, I can always track it if the kids take it, It is comfortable, no mechanical issues it is 1 year old as of 3 week ago! It’s been on 2 trips each 1400 miles one way. So that has knocked my mileage up. But with everything the way it is I am still $3,000 below trade in which is Unheard of for a new car. I was always a truck/SUV person this is my 3rd Kia Optima/K5 and the first brand new one and I love it. In a few years may look at their electric vehicles.
One thing if you get a new one get the paint protectant plan the older Kias I have had tended to get  chips in paint easily. So far after that treatment this one has been great!

Almost been a year since I bought it. I opted for the GT-Line since at the time the GT was impossible to come by and still wanted that sporty look. Great tech, great features, and premium feeling ride. I love the exterior of this car and constantly get compliments and people asking what model it is.
So many bells n whistles I’m still figuring it out a year later! Comfy-gets up and GOES when needed. Love love love everything about this car.

Drove the A7, E350 and the LS 500. I can buy what I want, badging means nothing. A car is a tool. I require three things from a car. Those are comfort, reliability and low maintenance.
This car checks all the boxes. What a value....

This car is fantastic! I paid half the price as its equivalent in BMW, Mercedes and Audi. This car has every thing in it you could wish for. KIA had this great new luxury vehicle that didn’t sell so discontinued it. Less than 400 in the whole country I believe so you never see another one anywhere. Interior is gorgeous and ride extremely smooth. I plan on never selling the K900 as i consider it a collectors car.

Great low end touque.  Its my second K900.  Miss the V8 a little, but have to say the throttle response is much better now.  Interior very nice, not S class but nice.  If your ego can get past the lack of a badge it is a no brainer.  I have owned them all BWM 7 series, Porche, and Mercedes.  This car is not quite there, but close enough for the vast majority including myself.  In other words if I blind fold  you and you didnt see the badge, it would be hard for most anyone to tell the difference.  Also, have less worry that if something tears up that it will cost a fortune.

This is a follow up to my previous review last year.  As I approach 15,000 miles I continue to be impressed.  This car delivers comfort and performance.  My highway mpg exceeds 25 on all highway trips.  I usually get 27 to 28 mpg while maintaining 70+ mph.  So, I don't understand the 25 MPG EPA rating.

My passengers notice the quality detail inside and out including the detail in the trunk to backseat controls and the awesome 17 speaker sound system.

Lastly, as I pulled into a restaurant this summer one of the patrons asked me if I was driving a Lexus... not bad company for a KIA.

I have owned 2 dozen cars in the past 10 years and usually don't buy new because of depreciation. However, my mind has changed with this purchase! This is an incredible value and a very, very good car. It easily drives as well as top of the line BMW, Mercedes and Audis and looks like a cross between a Lexus and a German Sedan. Kia really nailed it! It is even more gorgeous inside, with real wood paneling (ala Bentley), high quality leather and a ton of features that even some of the Germans don't offer. Lastly, the 3.3L Twin Turbo Engine has tons of power and the car drives with excellent precision and handling.

So why don't they sell and why the rebates? My guess is that the Stinger (an amazing car in it's own right)  is too close a competitor and their sister company Genesis is taking all of the other potential buyers with their own excellent G80 and G90. Also,  No one wants to pay $60k+ for a Kia! There is no Brand Cache and no one thinks you have money or power if you drive a Kia. Kia is a brand for those who are 'striving' to make it.. not for those who have 'made' it, the way that people perceive the German and Japanese luxury brands. Lastly, the Luxury sedan is a dying segment and the target for this market has moved into Luxury SUVs that are easier to get in an out of and provide a 'aura' of safety due to their high driving position.

However if you can get past that silly mindset, compared to the $90k you would have to spend to get a Lexus or Mercedes of equivalent value, the K900 is a downright bargain. Now take the $10-$20k rebates Kia is offering and you are getting a Steal! Now for the cherry on top.. the car has a 100k mile warranty and runs on 87 pump gas. 

In conclusion, If you are in the market for a luxury Sedan and haven't considered the KIA, you need to give it a look.

I've had two Genesis G80s before, and this car makes them look mediocre.
While they were great cars, the K900 fit, finish, and ride outshines them.
All details have been attended to with tactile finish and quality materials.  The ride and seating are outstanding.  I am more than pleased with this vehicle.

Leased a brand new 2019 Kia K900, got a great deal for end of year,  This car is   classy, powerful and a comfortable cruiser, all options, quality of materials are top  notch, definealty be buying this at lease end.

I researched vehicles for several months with the criteria of comfort, power and AWD.  I kept coming back to the K900 since it met all the criteria and presented a great value.  Once I test drove the car I was sold.  I was able to take advantage of a rebate and a discounted price under $50k.  After 5 weeks of ownership I continue to be impressed.  The ride, power, quality, features and an absolutely awesome sound system is impressive to all who have rode with me, including my skeptical wife.

Love the 23 Niro HEV. Getting 50-51 MPG. Nice vehicle for seniors as easy to get in and out plus all the safety features (Lots). 
Would definitely purchase again

We love our new Niro EX.  The interior is roomy and offers plenty of head space for tall passenger.  I find the seats (front and rear) to be very comfortable.  With the smaller tires on the EX (as compared to the EX touring), we have been getting 52 mpg in the winter, in Maine.  The car seems plenty peppy to me even when the sport mode driving is not engaged.  While all the features take a little time to learn, I'm impressed with all of the technology this car offers, and the comfort of the ride.

This car is like a video game and the high score is to see how good you can get your gas mileage. Supposedly the EPA rating is 45 highway and 53 City. But if you don’t know the tricks, you are rarely going to get these numbers (probably 40 highway, 48 City) and if you do know the tricks, you should be able to get much better, especially in the city (46-49 highway, 55-65 City). The trick is to learn to use the levers for breaking. This is great for regenerative breaking recharges. The other major tricks are to: slow down when the car goes into EV mode. This will extend the distances your car stays in EV mode; Don’t maintain high RPMs for long periods; Drive faster when going up hill then down hill(this habit will keep your battery charging really high); use short bursts of sport mode for several seconds to reach a good speed and then cruise back in eco mode. This is why this car is so fun! Try different things and you will see that this is car is the video game of all cars. Very fun and when you really get in the game and see what works, you’ll find it  hilarious that everyone else around you is getting 15-20 mpg while you’re getting 60-80mpg easily!

We bought our 2023 Kia Niro EX Touring in December 2022. After a year of driving it regularly, here are the pros, cons:

Pros: 
1. When you fill up, it only holds 10 gallons. Unbelievably this is enough to go for weeks. The gas mileage is so good, you are almost driving for free. Even if you are heavy footed like my wife, stomping on gas and brakes, you get the same great MPGs. We are averaging 47MPG since buying the car. If we had the smaller wheels, we'd get in the mid 50s. 
2. It looks really nice. Inside and out, the styling is really good. It just blends in nicely in any situations. You can park in a lot with expensive luxury cars and fit right in. At the same time, you can park in a bad neighborhood and not be a target. 
3. Seamless power. You will hear the motor switch on and off but you don't feel any effect and learn to disregard that. The power from pedal to wheels is seamless and the transmission shifts nicely every time to the right gears (not a CVT, which is nice in my opinion). 
4. Interior is really nice and seems to be good quality. I especially like the display screen. 
5. Safety features like rear cross traffic warning and side mirror car detection lights are a must, especially in a car this small. 

CONS:
1. We got the pearl white. Usually, a white car always looks clean even when dirty. Not this one. It is a magnet for dirt and it is visible. It sticks to it like metal shreds to a magnet. When you wash your car, there is a massive amount of dirt in the door jams and places you wouldn't expect it. 
2. Display controls. I've almost crashed a bunch of times trying to do something simple like adjust the temperature. It uses almost all touch display and you know how that is when trying to drive. Also, the radio and climate share a touch pad, and you are supposed to alternate between the two by touching a spot on the screen. Super awkward.
3. Climate has a mind of its own. I like to have the recycled air on all the time, otherwise I smell the exhaust of the car in front of me. I understand this turns off when using defrost, that is normal. But this car changes my settings constantly for no reason, even though I turn off "auto" climate, it comes back on. Every time I turn on recycled air, a few minutes later, it's off. For me, this is the worst part of the car. 
4. Rear brake noises. We notice after a month the rear brakes at times would make a frightening noise like a train stopping, and the whole car would vibrate. I took it in for this they said they couldn't replicate the issue. After my own trial and error, I realized it is likely the Auto Hold feature getting confused when going at low speeds like through a parking lot or backing out of the driveway.
5. The back hatch closes way too easy, so until you get used to it, you will slam the heck out of it. My daughter closed it once and the rear license plate fell off. 

Wishlist: I have the EX Touring which I believe included the moonroof and bigger wheels and some safety features. 
-I don't know all the trim levels and features, but I wish our model included the seat memory buttons. When you have a car that gets MGP like this everyone in the house will be driving it. It is a big hassle adjusting the driver seat and mirrors every day. 
-I wouldn't get the bigger wheels next time, I would rather have the extra MPGs
-I wouldn't get the moonroof. There is no feature that closes it automatically if you leave it open. So it just takes 1 time forgetting to close it, followed by rain, and your interior is ruined. I hardly use the moonroof and my wife never uses it, but I worry about it all the time. 
I think some of these things are bundled in certain trim models, like the seat memory button and bigger wheels, so it may not be possible. For Kia, you should make the features all available options in every model.  

Overall, for all the annoyances, all is forgiven when you go to fill it up and it's only $40 and everyone around you is moaning and groaning.
Previous Toyota, Mazda owner and Kia Niro has been an excellent car in savings gas, very solid car, good for 5 people and still space for luggage

I have a 2018 Ex Touring currently inoperable the power steering went had to have it towed. I had it 5 years with 86,000 miles being told not covered under warranty. I did my research and found several models in Kia line up has this issue but never a recall issue.  
 It got great gas mileage. I averaged 50s to low 70s mpgs. But still filled up every 10 days 3 times a month. Financially speaking really didn’t see the savings $150 a month in gas. 
 In summary the Niro is hit or miss either it’s fine or you have problems with it. What I learned from other owners. I wouldn’t have bought one. No one buys a car hoping it only lasts for 5 years and have to buy another car and still owe a lot to roll into another car.
Just turned 60k miles, runs great, and average a solid 50 mpg, nothing to complain about at this point

I leased the Kia Niro PHEV as a step stone toward an EV vehicle. I have used it primarily for work and for errand shopping. The 26 mile electric range is adequate for it, but more range would had been nice. MPG is typically in the 110 range and higher, thought it drops into the 60's during the winter season. I have refilled the tank 4 times since I bought it and that's when the gas tank is at half.

The safety features work as intended. Forward and side sensors warn you if the car ahead of you is moving and when a car is coming into your blind spot during a lane change. The parking reverse feature shows you the projected path of your turn and that makes it easier.

The sports mode allows for extra pep when you are on the highway. 

The  issues I've encountered are 1) when someone hit me from behind.  2) The fuel tank lid was sticking and I had to go back to the dealer to see what the problem is. It ran rough one morning in winter and I attribute it to water condensing in the fuel tank during the winter.  3) I got ghost warnings like it showed a non working turn signal a few times before it stopped.

Drove this car for over 3 years driving about 4,000 per year and I am quite impressed! First of all, compared to my 2014 Subaru Crosstrek hybrid, the drive between electric and gas is dramatically better and smooth as any hybrid can can perform. In addition to the high mpg, the SPORT mode surprisingly has great power for those times when you need extra power.

I bought my Niro for rideshare use and have accumulated 170k on it in just under 3 years. Not a single thing has broken on it, and I've completed minimal maintenance. I change the oil and rotate the tires every 10k miles, change the air filter every 50k miles. I've never taken the car to the dealership or mechanic and it still drives almost as good as new. The original brake pads still have around 70% life and all fluids are original. Over the life of the car it's averaging 50 mpg, however, I'm currently getting about 48 mpg as it seems to drop by 2 mpg every 50k miles. When new I constantly saw 58 mpg and even broke 60 mpg a few times. It's very practical as a wagon and use it to haul large loads of luggage almost daily. It's not fast or flashy, so if you prioritize that look elsewhere. If you want something practical, ergonomical, and reliable, the Niro might be for you.

Good mileage, Better look than the Prius, Ample Cargo Space, Plenty of safety features, Great Warranty, an upscale interior, an easy-to-use dashboard, decently powered to pass cars on highways, low maintenance, and AFFORDABLE if you go for the Hybrid EX version (Best bang for the buck IMO). 

I bought the car brand new and accumulated about 35,000 miles over 1.5 years. I don't do a lot of daily commutes but I do a lot of travel with different terrains, snow, rain, sand, mountain, etc. The car has great cargo space for someone single like me. However, I met my girlfriend and it became very too small for us to travel and car camping in the car. The gas mileage is decently at 52 MPG if you just use it as a hybrid and don't have a place to charge like me. The car only has 139 Horse Power but you can switch to Sport Mode to boost the car for uphill or passing on the highway. It's kinda cool because it makes you a bit more engaged while driving but also saves fuel when you don't use it most of the time. I also only do regular maintenance, oil change, fluid change, filter replacements, and tire rotations during my ownership. The 12-V battery for the car is NOTORIOUS small and failed to start the car after 1 year. Fortunately, I brought it to the dealership and they replaced a new one for free with a 3-year warranty. 

I recommend this car for single or a young couple who use it for daily commutes and occasional travel. There won't be enough power or space if you have a bigger family.

save money with low milaeg, i pay about 80 a month and drive an houre a day
but not fun to drive, bad pickup, big trunk, overall good car not great

I have had the car about 2 years and almost 45,000 miles.  Been in the shop for a brake fluid change and two recalls.  Don't leave a door open.  The computer runs on 12 volts and if that goes ...  I think that is common from what I have read with most electric cars.

I bought the base model 2020 Kia Niro BEV new in March 2021 and have been very happy with my purchase. I had a Level 2 charger installed in my garage, which makes charging the car extremely easy. I plug in the vehicle at 10 pm and 8-9 hours later it's fully charged. The car's perfect for city driving, but I don't recommend it for long distances since it takes 1 1/2 hours to fully charge the car at a public station; it's not a fast-charging car. Expect 200-220 miles range combined city/highway driving with a full charge. Strictly stop-and-go city driving should achieve 250 miles or higher in range. The base model comes with everything, so I don't recommend the top trim. It handles well except over bumps and potholes. The front driver's and passenger's seats, however, are very uncomfortable, and I am not impressed with the KIA Connect/Access app. My car has 30,000 miles on it and without any infotainment or mechanical issues. The car is definitely not worth $42,000, but it is worth considering if all the federal and state incentives apply.

This is a perfect electric car for first time EV buyers.  It has great power, solid range for a full charger, and decent charge speeds.  It took the Kia Niro from Atlanta to D.C. and back and had no problems.  I've had my car for a little over a year and haven't regretted it even once.  The infotainment isn't great, but I use Carplay, and it does Carplay well.  The seats are comfortable, the ride is quiet, and the adaptive cruise control is something I won't do without for any future cars I buy.  I can't recommend this car enough.

Love my 2022 Kia Niro Hybrid gets great mileage more than enough pep. Got a cargo cover to hide what is in back. My 3rd. Kia not a problem on all 3. Storage batteries are warranty is 10 year 100k to original owner. Used to trade every other year but now retired. So will be keeping this on to about 90k, currently saving for next car.
Try a Kia you will like it ! Eric from Lombard, IL

We bought this car about a year ago and it's been a pleasure - until we went into the dealership for a service call at 7,500 miles. Then we learned the tech package "Ultimate" we had for the first year had been disconnected. No more remote start, no more remote door locks, unless we signed up for an annual contract that runs from $150 - 200 per year. After spending $40,000+ for this car we thought we were entitled to keep the features we bought.

This was my first electric car.  Consumer Reports rated this car at 88 so I decided that the car was worth the cost.  It drives very smooth and has mostly intuitive dashboard although it was an adjustment, coming from driving a 2011 car with no fancy computer screen.  
It drives better than the Tesla (my opinion) due to a more forgiving ride.  Tesla’s are notoriously stiff and choppy.  The price was much lower than the Tesla as well, but more than Chevy Bolt or the Nissan version.  
I only plan to drive city, not much highway, so I believe this car will be a wonderful addition to our family.  So far I have driven the car for 2-1/2 weeks and haven’t had to charge it yet.

We have driven the range beast for over 21,800 miles mix of city/highway (69%/31%) our avg is 4.71miles/KWH = 301 miles real world range, it's rated 239 miles.  It's a solid EV, after 10.5 months no issues yet, tires still good they will probably last50k miles.  This has been a GREAT EV no issues to date, not a one charges solid at EA can get up to 93 KWH, avg is about 60 to 74 KWH.  We have level 2 charging  at home it's all you need.  We charge the battery to 100% almost every night the battery has gotten better no degradation after 10.5 months and 21.9k miles Great Car!!
Great overall package,  tons of standard equipment. Unfortunately this model will no longer qualify for the federal tax credit.

Love the 23 Niro HEV. Getting 50-51 MPG. Nice vehicle for seniors as easy to get in and out plus all the safety features (Lots). 
Would definitely purchase again

We love our new Niro EX.  The interior is roomy and offers plenty of head space for tall passenger.  I find the seats (front and rear) to be very comfortable.  With the smaller tires on the EX (as compared to the EX touring), we have been getting 52 mpg in the winter, in Maine. Overall, for all the annoyances, all is forgiven when you go to fill it up and it's only $40 and everyone around you is moaning and groaning.
Previous Toyota, Mazda owner and Kia Niro has been an excellent car in savings gas, very solid car, good for 5 people and still space for luggage

I have a 2018 Ex Touring currently inoperable the power steering went had to have it towed. I had it 5 years with 86,000 miles being told not covered under warranty. I did my research and found several models in Kia line up has this issue but never a recall issue.  
 It got great gas mileage. I averaged 50s to low 70s mpgs. But still filled up every 10 days 3 times a month. Financially speaking really didn’t see the savings $150 a month in gas. 
 In summary the Niro is hit or miss either it’s fine or you have problems with it. What I learned from other owners. I wouldn’t have bought one. No one buys a car hoping it only lasts for 5 years and have to buy another car and still owe a lot to roll into another car.
Just turned 60k miles, runs great, and average a solid 50 mpg, nothing to complain about at this point

I leased the Kia Niro PHEV as a step stone toward an EV vehicle. I have used it primarily for work and for errand shopping. The 26 mile electric range is adequate for it, but more range would had been nice. MPG is typically in the 110 range and higher, thought it drops into the 60's during the winter season. I have refilled the tank 4 times since I bought it and that's when the gas tank is at half.

The safety features work as intended. Forward and side sensors warn you if the car ahead of you is moving and when a car is coming into your blind spot during a lane change. The parking reverse feature shows you the projected path of your turn and that makes it easier.

The sports mode allows for extra pep when you are on the highway. 

The  issues I've encountered are 1) when someone hit me from behind.  2) The fuel tank lid was sticking and I had to go back to the dealer to see what the problem is. It ran rough one morning in winter and I attribute it to water condensing in the fuel tank during the winter.  3) I got ghost warnings like it showed a non working turn signal a few times before it stopped.

Drove this car for over 3 years driving about 4,000 per year and I am quite impressed! First of all, compared to my 2014 Subaru Crosstrek hybrid, the drive between electric and gas is dramatically better and smooth as any hybrid can can perform. In addition to the high mpg, the SPORT mode surprisingly has great power for those times when you need extra power.

I bought my Niro for rideshare use and have accumulated 170k on it in just under 3 years. Not a single thing has broken on it, and I've completed minimal maintenance. I change the oil and rotate the tires every 10k miles, change the air filter every 50k miles. I've never taken the car to the dealership or mechanic and it still drives almost as good as new. The original brake pads still have around 70% life and all fluids are original. Over the life of the car it's averaging 50 mpg, however, I'm currently getting about 48 mpg as it seems to drop by 2 mpg every 50k miles. When new I constantly saw 58 mpg and even broke 60 mpg a few times. It's very practical as a wagon and use it to haul large loads of luggage almost daily. It's not fast or flashy, so if you prioritize that look elsewhere. If you want something practical, ergonomical, and reliable, the Niro might be for you.

Good mileage, Better look than the Prius, Ample Cargo Space, Plenty of safety features, Great Warranty, an upscale interior, an easy-to-use dashboard, decently powered to pass cars on highways, low maintenance, and AFFORDABLE if you go for the Hybrid EX version (Best bang for the buck IMO). 

I bought the car brand new and accumulated about 35,000 miles over 1.5 years. I don't do a lot of daily commutes but I do a lot of travel with different terrains, snow, rain, sand, mountain, etc. The car has great cargo space for someone single like me. However, I met my girlfriend and it became very too small for us to travel and car camping in the car. The gas mileage is decently at 52 MPG if you just use it as a hybrid and don't have a place to charge like me. The car only has 139 Horse Power but you can switch to Sport Mode to boost the car for uphill or passing on the highway. It's kinda cool because it makes you a bit more engaged while driving but also saves fuel when you don't use it most of the time. I also only do regular maintenance, oil change, fluid change, filter replacements, and tire rotations during my ownership. The 12-V battery for the car is NOTORIOUS small and failed to start the car after 1 year. Fortunately, I brought it to the dealership and they replaced a new one for free with a 3-year warranty. 

I recommend this car for single or a young couple who use it for daily commutes and occasional travel. There won't be enough power or space if you have a bigger family.

save money with low milaeg, i pay about 80 a month and drive an houre a day
but not fun to drive, bad pickup, big trunk, overall good car not great

I bought this new Never ANY problems with it, Very comfortable even driving long distances. Get better gas milage than they quote. (got up to 43 mpg driving cross country. Usually ~32 around town. Just do regular oil changes. One of the best cars I've ever owned.

Love my 2020 LX.  Don't listen to the bad words on the engines.  Kia will fix them.  Call down all you negative karens!!!  Lol.     Only thing that bums me out, tge cars don't hold there value.    I still owe 15,000.  And trade in value is 12,000.   Ugh!!!!

I do not recommend kia optima. I have 2018 optima and engine is burning oil like crazy. I did some research and their GDI engine has oil burning issue. Kia has been sued in Canada for this reason.  I have to put a quart every week. I talked to the dealer and basically brushed me aside as I am second owner of the car. Engine is basic component and if they don't know how to build engine I don't trust this brand. Buy a Toyota or Honda
My  Kia has been the best car that I have ever owned. It got great gas mileage, had lots of interior room, and never gave me any problems the six years that I owned it.

I purchased my Optima LX pre-owned with 36,000 miles on it when I was 17 years old -- my first ever car! It's a very comfortable car with generous cargo space, smooth steering, decent acceleration, impressive handling in "Sport" mode, and a great sound system. Because I only have the LX, the car lacks a lot of features that I believe were already standard in 2016 base models of other makes: no Carplay / Android Auto, blind spot sensors, proximity sensors, or crash prevention technology. If I had owned a more "modern" car prior to my Optima, this lack of features would probably have docked a point from my review, but it does just as well for my purposes. 
This car is surprisingly capable in all sorts of terrains, including the dreaded New England snow and sleet, mud patches, and uneven grassy turf. Snowy roads can be a bit slippery, but I suspect that has more to do with my tires of choice than the actual car; with that being said, the traction and stability control of the Optima is a force to be reckoned with and one that has yet to fail me (knock on wood). 
The Kia Optima has a special place in my heart and I hope to keep her around for at least five more years before upgrading to the K5. I would buy another Optima in a heartbeat if they hadn't "evolved" it into the K5! So far, I've been without any major mechanical problems (although the VCM motor failed about 10,000 miles ago, which would have been an $800 repair if not for the extended insurance package I had purchased with the car). I'd recommend the Optima to anybody looking for an affordable and reliable vehicle.

This kid has not only been the smoothest ride but also the easiest for maintenance, and very little for any kind of repair. It's mileage is wonderful it's great on the highway and does a real nice job of a smooth drive. However the most important factor is safety. This Kia was sitting at a stoplight and I was driving, but a truck behind us decide to be on their phone and rammed into us at 25 miles an hour it bounced twice and the back of the car while dented and broke underneath never lose it's form.. have we been in any other car it would not have been good.

And for these crazy grass prices excellent on gas in the city and on the road!

Had this car stolen and repaired 3 times already. I'm so done with this. Depreciating value at an alarming rate. The market is saturated and nobody buying them because no insurance company will insure them. Dying breed.  Can't give this car away.
very comfortable easy to drive commuter car that turns heads and is easily mistaken for a higher end luxury sedan

I love this car and would recommend it to anyone looking to buy a 2018 Optima Hybrid EX without the tech package.  I have a pearly white car with the white "leather" interior and its absolutely beautiful!  I'm a big interior guy; the interior better be comfortable, dependable, and functional since that is where my behind will be.  I feel the interior is beautiful and wonderful to sit inside of with the color scheme I chose.  There are many soft-touch materials and everything is well laid out.  Of all the vehicle's I've owned, this is the best car I've ever had...EVER.  Everything works great in this vehicle.  I live in Arizona and the A/C blows hard and cold each and every time I drive the car (I LOVE THIS btw!!!!).  The Android Auto has worked flawlessly and the car has never given me one problem EVER!  I obtain an average of 45 MPG on the highway and I drive about 20K miles a year in some of the most extreme climates.  I use only full-synthetic oil and change my air filters regularly (by my own doing, not by the stealership's high cost).  I have not had a single warranty repair to my car yet.  Despite my love for this vehicle, there are three improvements I can suggest.  First, the driving position could be more comfortable.  I'm 6'00" tall and find that I cannot position the steering wheel and my seating position in a way where I can drive the car with only one hand.  The sculpting on the door is either too deep, or the steering wheel has limited adjustment which prevents me from being able to comfortably rest my elbow on a soft surface while holding onto the steering wheel with one hand.  I have fixed this by planting my left foot on the ground, thereby flexing my left knee at a 90 degree position where I can rest my arm on my leg and hold the wheel comfortably.  Overall, it's not a huge problem but it can get annoying for long drives.  Second, I wish there was more sound-proofing added to the vehicle.  It's a hybrid car and not a sports car or luxury sedan.  Instead of trying to land in the middle of the two, I wish KIA would flex more toward a luxury vehicle with the sound dampening material.  I do have the upgraded Harmon-Kardon sound-system and it's GREAT!  However, I wish the road noise was less pronounced.  My third, and last complaint, has to do with the headlights.  KIA, PLEASE MAKE HID OR LED HEADLIGHTS STANDARD to your vehicles.  I drive about 53 miles round trip each day.  26 of those miles are done at night, on baron desert roads with with wildlife crossing the road at random points.  Standard HID or LED lights alone would make this vehicle the perfect car.  Fuel economy is pretty spectacular in my opinion; I average 45 MPG combined hwy/city driving.  My worst fuel economy numbers are at extreme temperatures which is below 35 degrees or above 105 degrees (highest so far was 120 degrees at 38 mpg).  Overall, I'd recommend this car to any one of my friends or family who want a semi-luxury vehicle with great fuel economy at a solid price point. Good Job Kia!

This car is excellent in every way. In 2019, I averaged 81.54 MPG over the course of the year. Every use case is different, but for my purposes in East Central Indiana it has been exemplary. The winter months see this vehicle a bit less efficient than in the summer months when electric A/C does all the work of maintaining cabin temperatures. I regularly see 32 miles on EV mode from a full charge before the car switches to hybrid mode.

after being left stranded for another time, while still being completely under warranty, I figured I would actual say something. My newest example started when my car suddenly shuttered in the middle of the freeway, at cruising speeds. By the time I got off the road, it was shaking very noticeably even when idled. Unfortunately, I broke down a whole 40 miles from my local KIA dealer, so KIA gave me the choice of using their closest dealer or baying around $400 to get it to my local dealer. They then proceeded to tell me that, while my local dealership may be able to get to my vehicle by the next day, they wouldn't be able to until the next week and, better still, they also wouldn't be providing me with a vehicle in the meantime, because they have inspect my vehicle first. So, while I continue to pay the monthly payments on my KIA, I also get to pay to rent its replacement as well. I'm sure I have many more stranded days ahead of me; I can't wait until it happens a few hundred miles from home, you know, when I'm using it to travel, that thing the great fuel economy is supposed to be good for. I can't wait to have to pay to have my new car towed hundreds of miles while KIA - it's the true KIA experience. I'm not even mentioning the fiasco that you have to get involved in just to get your vehicle towed, but you're welcome to find out.

After enjoying 3 Honda Accords, I finally switched to a Plug-In Hybrid Kia Optima EX Premium 2020. In the first month, I managed 2,8 litres/100 km in fuel economy. In fact, in my day-to-day commuting (20 km), I only use the EV mode. The gas engine comes on idling as a generator only when the heater/AC or the defrosting is demanding, (or after about 40 km of EV driving) and then it's also silky-smooth with its 6-speed automatic transmission (gladly not a CVT!). Otherwise, I REALLY enjoy the complete silence and the torquey accelerations of the electric motor on green lights. I plug it every night and I wake up to a fresh new battery every morning. I always have about 900 km extra autonomy on gas, but I mainly drive it in electric mode. The ride is extremely smooth and quiet. The interior is very roomy and comfortable. The chassis feels very solid and high-quality. Steering is precise. The equipment is complete, from the panoramic moonroof, heated leather steering wheel, heated and cooled leather seats with 10 electric adjustments, to all the programmable driving aids like intelligent Cruise-Control, Lane-Maintaining Assist, 360⁰ cameras, 2-zone AC, 10-speakers Harman-Kardon sound system, Apple CarPlay, automatic rain-detecting wipers, self-dimming road lights, LED lighting all around including new foglights, etc. The addition of a big battery behind the backseat spreads the weight over the long wheelbase, so they beefed-up the rear suspension and the ride feels very well balanced and composed. It's not a sports car but, thanks to the newly-revised dampers and links, it rides like an expensive european sedan on any type of pavement. The only fault is the size of the trunk, which will not allow many big suitcases like regular sedans do. Built in South Korea, the Plug-In Hybrid Kia shows perfect fit and finish. I'm really impressed!

This is a fantastic automobile with a range of 40 - 45 MPG.  If you're looking for all the bells and whistles with wonderful mileage, the Kia Optima Hybrid is where to go.  I'm only considering giving it up because I want a sports car.  Sure wish Kia made one in a hybrid.

car is ok the electric is fun to drive.  
wish it charged faster also you loose a lot of gas mileage when you use the heat. it is relatively comfortable to drive the heated seats are great but trunk is very small and you can't drop the back seat because of the battery is there I have been getting over 1000 miles on a tank of gas because I  make a lot of trip less than 50 miles. does not do well in snow.
