car is ok the electric is fun to drive.  
wish it charged faster also you loose a lot of gas mileage when you use the heat. it is relatively comfortable to drive the heated seats are great but trunk is very small and you can't drop the back seat because of the battery is there I have been getting over 1000 miles on a tank of gas because I  make a lot of trip less than 50 miles. does not do well in snow.

In 1993 if you bought a subcompact you bought a Ford Festiva or a Geo Metro and you were miserable. 30 years ago a "sub-comp" meant you enjoyed being punished on your drive into work every day.
Fast forward to 2023 and while the Mazda 2 is gone (lord those were fun cars) the Kia Rio is the best small car on the market today. 
120 hp in a 2700lb sedan is ALOT more fun than you think it would be, and when you are returning 40+ mpg while cruising down the interstate w/ the A/C on, it all just goes to show how fantastic this little car is.
I generally hate CVT transmissions from being plopped in nissan rental cars, but the Rios transmission is a pure joy. The only downside is no manual offering here.
Fit and finish is way nicer than youd expect from a $17k new vehicle. The same goes for the infotainment system, and overall driving characteristics of the car.
The 2018-23 Rio's have also not been plagued by Kia's general awfulness and you dont have to worry about your motor locking up in these bad boys.
If you can find one at the Kia dealer, and you are looking for a cheap new car, these are the one to get..

Worse resale value vehicles. These cars are completely junk. They have many issues with them. Engine, transmission, resale value. It's not reliable, and the cost for repairs are to high for what it is. Trust yourself, walk away!!!
I like everything about this little car. I would've given it a 5 star but it didn't come wirh a cruise control.
Transmission had to be replaced 6 months after buying it brand new. Throwing transmission errors and stalls between gears.

I don't know what kind of 2019 Kia Rio others have driven, but, I drove hwy miles from KY to NC and I have a photo of the mpg I was getting...I couldn't believe it so I snapped a shot! 69mpg! That's not normal I guess, but this car is great with gas mileage. It's easy to drive, and is dependable and just an all around great car!

Drove 12000 miles, already noises from the back of the car. The rear brakes knock when braking at a low speed. The rear left shoe has been adjusted once by the original dealership and then it started knocking again. Because I moved to another city, I had to find another official dealership. Never seen mechanics so reluctant to check it out and of course they found nothing.

Infotainment system is prone to overheating.

Never buying a brand-new car ever again, especially Kia.
It's a good car everything's new dependable and reliable got four brand new tires and has oil change every 4,000 MI and excellent condition

Model Rio are no longer made I believe. However with costs today. 40 mpg is not hard to take. My little hatch back holds a lot in the back when necessary. Excellent in upstate NY weather. Love my little car

DO NOT buy a 2016 Kia Sedona.  In fact, stay away from Kia and Hyundai all together.  This van was 50,000 new. It's the SXL with every bell and whistle imaginable.  I got it used in 2020 during the pandemic for a STEAL.  I LOVED it.  Until I was driving down a major highway and the car lost all acceleration and went into limp mode.  Thankfully it was early in the morning and there weren't many cars on the road, or it could have been much worse.  I was going 60 and suddenly it almost stopped and went down to 35mph.  I took it to my mechanic and the oil was BONE DRY.  I get my oil changed every 3-5000 miles and check it regularly in between.  There were zero warning lights that the oil was low and no changes in performance.  It just died.  And no evidence of an oil leak either.  If you look up 2016 Kia Sedona anywhere you will find hundreds of owners who have the EXACT same issue.  Right around 100K, conveniently just after the warranty expires, the engines fail and start burning oil at warp speed.  Kia doesn't care because it's "out of warranty" so I am stuck with car that I can't drive and still am making payments on. Kia has been making faulty cars and not standing behind their products.  Avoid this car at all costs!!
Comfortable seats, smooth ride, quite and good gas mileage. Plenty of storage.  Heated seats. I love my Sedona.

Too many owners of Kia's lives are being ruined due to these vehicles being stolen, damaged if not totalled. Owners are still having to make payments on vehicle even they don't have vehicle. They are being damaged and if found they are held for evidence. When released there is an extremely long wait for repair parts. Who is being responsible for so many lives being affected by this?

At first I was Leary of owning a mini van, I started with a KIA 2012 the regular size, but I got use to driving everywhere. I used the vehicle for most anything,  due that it had a smooth ride and my siblings enjoyed me taking them on trips.
   Now I own the KIA 2016 Sedona which is the extended version ( EX ). I soon realized that I had to adjust for my right turns. Afterwards, I am still driving my siblings on  trips with more room to stretch, Most of the seats are capable reclining back at different positions particularly for long trips.
   It has pretty much every thing that one may need. I added small round disk mirrors  to the exterior mirrors for backing up and good for parking inside the white line, for considerations for other people's vehicles and protecting my KIA

The vehicle's MSRP was $37,690.00 and 55 months later most dealers are offering $24,000
for it. New car prices are sky rocketing from Feb. 2021 to date. Used car prices are up 35% over last year. I've been watching your blue book value for a year, and they don't reflect that 35%. 35% of $24,000 is $8,400, making the vehicles value $32,400. I'm sure the dealers would want to offer me $24K, the they will mark it up 35%. Here's the real problem, the dealer are finding it harder and harder to get NEW vehicles. I think I'll keep my vehicle another 5 years, who knows, when customers get rid of their EV vehicles, because they won't work in harsh weather environments.
Can't wait to see these vehicle on used car lots, with no warranty. Can't fix stupid

Bought brand new, in August 2016. Needed a vehicle for 7-passengers, looked into buying an suv. That were priced at $50,000 to $80,000 thousand. Found this gem for starting at only $25,000. Has run great no problems, gets good gas mileage. Has 100,000 miles and going for a other 100,000. That you KIA.

Love this car. light color inside. heated seat, electric seat. comfortable in front for adults. Back seats to low for adults to place legs, esp if bad knees. Like that the doors auto lock, as I drive off.  So far - so good.

Bought this new in Oct., 2016, based on reviews and personal comparisons with Toyota and Honda vans.  Learned that KIA has greatly improved their quality and styling, the Sedona was an easy choice.  Price was slightly less than both Toyota and Honda similarly-equipped models.  Vehicle has been a terrific performer for our needs.  No, we're not a family with kids, nor do we regularly transport a car-load of people but, we're sr. adults and wanted room for family for short road-trips or sightseeing around town (lived in FL).  Lifetime gas mileage - 19.2 mpg.  There have been 2-3 minor maintenance repairs (in warranty, of course), but nothing of major concern.  Overall, this is a great minivan and we're seriously considering trading up to the new 2022 model!!

Perfect commuter vehicle. I got it  just for that: not long road trips. I’m old, so for long trips I prefer a more serene, smooth ride. I’m not in it more than an hour or so at a time. Have had for 3 plus years. Average 30-31 mpg over all. It’s the sx turbo because I wanted all the bells and whistles on the top model.  This baby has everything.
I am grateful for the Kelley Blue Book website. I had no problems understanding how to complete the form. The site provided everything I needed to make a decision about my car.
Great Car Great Tech. People say it is slow but it is quicker than many cars on the road I would call it Peppy

SUV muy espaciosa.  Asientos acoginados.  Mayor rendimiento en gasolina para el modelo LX.
Tecnología en el tablero y radio, puedes coectar con car play o apple play.  Muy buen precio en el mercado.  100% recomendada.
You might as well be driving a semi truck when you are going up a hill when driving a 2021 Seltos because the car does not go over 40 miles an hour going up a hill.

I have been so happy with this car and have had several people try to buy it from me. Its the gold color, which is very popular and hard to find. My only issue is that I did not get the automatic opening for the trunk area. The gas mileage is great and I never lose it in a parking lot.
Great gas mileage, easy ride and compact with a big trunk. Back seat is a little tight but overall a great car.

Bought a 2022 seltos sx a year ago today. It has had multiple issues with the forward collision, sensor issues, and electrical issues. The cruise control stopped working 6 months into owning this brand new off the lot car. The Kia dealerships say "even if someone tapped your front it causes the sensors to not work, could have even been in a parking garage." Anyways, there are no issues physically with damage that would indicate this happened, and they won't fix it. Additionally, I paid extra for the paint protection wax stuff and I already have chips on the top hood of my car. My car is kept in a garage at work and home. The gas tank is tiny, I'm filling up every two days. The gas mileage is about 26-27, not what I was told it would get. The trunk space is very small and the back seat is very small in comparison to other crossover models. The front driver seat does not allow for tall drivers to extend the seat upward enough (I'm only 5'7" and still feel I'm cramped there.) The wipers are brand new too and these leave smudges on the window, don't properly clear rain during a rain storm and don't move quick at all. The app for auto start never works, even when the car is in my driveway. The heat never turns on when I do get it to work, I Brought it in for service on this and their response, "yeah your car doesn't heat up as fast as it should, it's still cold after 20 minutes of auto start." But had NO IDEA how to fix it. Overall, I am having way too many issues with this vehicle and I would not recommend it at all.

Bad resale value reputation. Engine, transmission is all junk. Gasoline vehicles are also taking a noise dive. It's best to walk away, before purchasing this lemon. This is a true review. These are not a good vehicle choice.

The headlights, dash board, computer screen, power, everything turned off while I was driving in the dark at rush hour. I had owned the car for less than 48 hours before heading to the dealership to unwind the deal and return the car. After some research after the fact, I found alot of people have experienced this as well.

I've had this vehicle for almost a year now. I was hesitant to buy a Kia based on a number of anecdotal horror stories, but I needed a 3-row hybrid on short notice for a school carpool--I just couldn't bear burning gas while sitting in a carline--and this was about the only one I could find so here we are.

Overall, I've been pleasantly surprised. It feels solid the way older Kias decidedly do not, it drives very smoothly, and now that I've figured out how to work with the electric/gas engine transition points I can get well over 40mpg in the city, which is 75% of my driving. Mileage does dip a bit in the winter when the gas engine is required to heat the cabin, but even then I've not had a tank below 37.

A couple things I do not love:

--The beige faux-leather upholstery is comfy in all weather, but it's not wearing particularly well. It already looks worn and a bit faded.
--The fact that Apple CarPlay only works when the phone is physically attached via USB is maddening. My last car was a 2017 and CarPlay worked flawlessly via bluetooth. Kia service says there will be an update for this "in a few months," but that was 11 months ago and still nothing...and it will probably come with a hefty price tag.
--There is an unnatural delay every time you touch any "button" on the touchscreen, be it the permanent options to the left and right of the screen or live code-driven buttons, before there is any response. I've gotten used to it, but for the first few weeks it was pretty annoying, especially when driving. Now, when I want to, say, change from radio to navigation I'll just touch "nav", look back at the road, and then it'll be there when I look back. Seems like this is something they can fix in future models, and perhaps even with a firmware update.
--I live in a mountainous region, and sometimes the transition from electric to gas at slow speeds going uphill can be very herky-jerky. You basically stop going forward for a beat and then lurch onward when the gas kicks in. It's not a big deal and overall the transitions are VERY smooth, but this does happen regularly in that one particular situation. If you don't have occasion to drive very slowly up steep hills, this will never come up.

All in all, it's a better car than I thought I was getting and I feel like the $41K sticker is reasonable (it's the EX trimline with all the cool stuff). I had to pay a little bit above that because this was the only EX hybrid available this side of the Mississippi when I needed to buy it, but I imagine those days are over as it looks like there is plenty of inventory today.

If you want the LX trim due to its affordability stop and choose a better trim or car. The third row seats are 75% lower than the other seats. Also the rear seats ther is no air conditioning. The big classic Kia’s 2010-2020 bulky seats allow no air to get to the back row when the windows are open. The time for the first row only heated seats to power up is when I arrive at my 18 minute destination. The dash is badly designed even for the pre-big dashboards in 2021. Kia’s older version of its “high-quality” Syn-Tex stitches come off easily. And the stitching of the world’s hardest leather on the sides of the dash also comes off easily. Do not buy this car for a luxury pre-owned vehicle on the LX seat package. I have no idea about the other trim levels but from pics I have seen online the dash is similar and it costs a lot more to get the navigation package. The only reason I got this car was to have it for my kids and nanny (that is why it is the second lowest trim). And I know apple car play was not as popular but the only reason I got this because it was the lowest trim with apple car play. It took me 40 minutes in the settings to turn the annoying beep noise off for when I touched on the dashboard. My friends 1999 Oldsmobile silhouette had nicer features (but obviously lower tech). Get the 2018 soul with the middle trim level for a nice deal or just get a higher trim level if this still seams like the car for you.
Not a long-term buy, CPO has no value denied warranty.  No more KIA, back to Toyota or Honda, not KIA, shame I really liked my Sorento.

At first when I got My Kia I wasn;t sure about it,I thought I was going to have lots of problems with the motor or trasmission wise.
I have this car for over 2 years and I love how fast its when I need to go fast,I love the gas mileage that gives me. I have a large family and I always look for extra room just in case,Kia Serento gives you pleany of space for your family.
Over all I'm very happy with this car !
Don’t buy. Kia don’t stand by there warranty. Blown head gasket after 2 years. Burn excessive oil. Buying me a Toyota or Honda.
This is my third Kia.  Love the car and the warranty is great.  The service has been really good.  Kia is an excellent car

It sucks that there is not theft technology installed on a 2020 car…. Therefor mine was stolen and wrecked. They burned the tread off my front tires completely. Now insurance wants to fix it because it’s a 25k car. I get it but who wants a car back that was stolen, abused and trashed inside and out. Do better KIA/HYUNDAI.
Otherwise it's a fantastic vehicle. For a 4 cyl. It has great get up and go power. The only issue with the Sorento are the side mirrors, they create serious blind spots.

Let’s begin with it’s not a Ferrari, it’s great transportation for $20,000. That in mind, great warranty, decent acceleration, loads of room, good ride, easy in and out and actually fun to drive. My son has a 2021, zero issues. I bought a 2023 for an around town car to keep mileage off my BMW and Bronco. All said, you can’t buy a better car for $20,000.

The first thing you should do is drive a kia Soul. It holds the road. The electric power steering steers like a micrometer! Brakes in the dime, rides like a much larger car,sits high so you don't feel like you are lying down. Ac and heater has the power to cool and heat rapidly. Enough room for 4 people comfortably, Great gas mileage  with good acceleration! I have owned many different cars in my life and this is the best made one I have owned. I am 79 years old!
Roomy subcompact. Fun to drive and great on gas. I've drove one for the past 6 years my favorite car!
Good car everything works brand new low miles ac work clean interior single owner  2020 kia soul great car

I purchased a 2020 Kia soul with 12 miles - brand new! And I absolutely love love it! It is so spacious and meets my every need. The gas milage is about 28miles per gallon... and I have had zero issues! zero! It's my favorite car to date and will be trading it in for a new Kia Soul this summer! More than exceeds my expectations! Have not disappointed!

This is a solid although not highly polished vehicle that does well for a variety of purposes and is especially valuable for those interested in having access to good cargo space for dollar value. Has a good alternate manual transmission ("slap shift") type option for those who want to improve its performance and can go back and forth with the automatic, though clutch purists will not be satisfied with it but it helps. The seating is a tad firm and the ride is bumpy but this can be ameliorated by adding ballast in the rear too. Excellent headroom, solid stereo system, good rear camera, dashboard controls fairly simple. Rear seating is solid legroom. It is pretty well designed for the price. I tend to think the cargo space is the best value-for-dollar aspect of this although you should get the rear-floor-insert-accessory if available. Acceleration is not bad. Braking seems fine. Mine gets up to 37 mpg. I have a little trouble finding the right A/C setting and blower angles for consistent comfort. Lighting is OK, no more than average. It's been worth it although I wish Kia would do more to smooth out the ride.

I've owned a lot of cars over the past 50 years, most of which were more high end than this, but this is better and more fun than any of them (except maybe the Honda Prelude).  Part of the reason for that is cars have generally gotten better over the years (safer, more features, more reliable), but this one is an incredible value and has everything I need.  Absolutely love it.  Oh, and I drive it in Minnesota winters with no problem although I would be very hesitant to take it out in 4  inches of new unplowed snow.
The problems started when my oil was running consistently low before the specified time to change it. It wasn't leaking, it was burning the oil. About a year later, my car is totally dead.

Purchased new. Wasn't really looking to buy a Soul, but had rented one and was surprised at the cargo space and peppy engine. Test drive sold me. The 1.6l turbo is very quick. Handling is okay but has the expected body roll when cornering hard, and rear end is so light it is not pleasant riding in the rear seats. Transmission shifts fine though I have noticed lag upon pulling away from a stop. Things that I have come to dislike are: no spare tire, soft crackling noise that pulses through the speakers (can't figure out why), rear seats don't fold flat to make a level cargo floor, only one seatback pocket (passenger seat), and probably the most annoying thing is the built-in tech. Really don't need it, but all cars come equipped with it now. Hate touchscreens, just give me good old fashioned knobs for climate control. (Why two buttons to control fan speed? Ridiculous.) Anyway, it has been a good vehicle for the 40,000 miles we've put on it but I don't think I'll buy another.

I didn't think I could have strong feelings about a car but turns out I can. The kia soul has tons of issues from being so easy to steal you only need a usb charging cable to the bad mileage 25mpg is the highest I've gotten going 20mph under the speed limit. I had to replace the engine in the first year due to it leaking oil and not telling me I was low on oil or even out of oil, the battery has already been replace since it kept failing randomly. The seats dont go low enough so I cant see the stop lights, the headrest only has a few settings which dont fit me, the AC changes my settings/speeds all the time even w/ auto off, if the air outside is 72 and I have it set to 70 it'll blow cold air but if outside is 67 it'll blow hot even with A/C turned on. Bass kind of sucks on the car even after you adjust the settings, I could keep going but honestly what's not to hate about this car?

If you live in a city or WILL be stolen or broke into.  KIA refuses to fix theft problem for free even though they have a solution.  Also, these engines are failing at 100,000 miles because excessive oil burning gums up the works.  There is a class action lawsuit related to this issue.  Insurance companies are refusing to cover this car.  Stay away.  Anybody reviewing this car that doesn't mention these issues lacks ethics.

Purchased this Soul at 6,000 miles. Put 150,000 on it. Around 120,000 it started to burn oil to the tune of 1/2+ quart a week. It is my daily driver and I put about 65 miles a day on it. Had Kia do their standard oil test and it measured a quart low at 1000 miles. This is acceptable by Kia’s standards. 

Between 120,000 and 157,000 miles, I’ve had to replace 3 O2 sensors, the catalytic converter (went bad), front breaks, AC compressor, spark plugs and it is still consuming oil. (There are no leaks, multiple mechanics have checked)

Today, my mechanic let me know the PCM is bad and my 3rd coil is fried. This is a repair to the tune of 1400.00. Even if I pull a used one from the junkyard, it must be programmed by Kia to the VIN. I own a 1996 Honda Civic that I’m currently driving while I decide what to do about this Kia. I just don’t think this car is worth 1400.00, when it is 1000 dollaring me per year. 


They just don’t make cars like they use to. Wonderful safety features, amazing ability to turn on a dime, and 64 square feet of storage space.  Good little car till around the 100,000 mile mark. After that, time to consider it a trade in.

Had my second engine blow today with only 50k miles on it.  First one blew at 103k miles.  No help from Kia motors.  They have done a recall for the same engine on prior years, but didn’t cover this year.  Steer clear!
Bought a Kia 10 months ago.  Engine went.  Fix time is over a month from a huge lot filled with Kia's that don't work. This car is junk.  I think the reviews are scammed.  It's a terrible car.

Looking to a perfect sale . Inside is like new. I need a great sell. I am 
out of driving. I have seller but I need how to get my sell
Save on gas by not having to by any! I live the panoramic sun roof, the led lights are amazing! Has a lot of get up and go for an electric car

I leased my 2018 KIA SOUL + in 2018, over 4 years ago.  It started out with 119 miles range on a full charge and today, 34,000 miles later it has 130 mile range on a full charge.  The only time I took it to the dealership was two months ago for new wiper blades and a cabin filter.  I've never had a single problem with it!  Ultra low operating costs average 4 miles KWh and around town I get upwards of 9 miles KWh!  At .30 cents per KW that's 7.5 cents per mile average and around town it only costs 3 cents per mile to drive.  We put in a 220V charger in the garage and it takes only about 4 hours to fully charge.  I do my best to charge during Edison's "super off peak" times.

Couldn't have been happier with this car. Better handling and off-line acceleration than my gas Kia Soul; great fit and finish; upscale interior for the price. This is a fun, dependable car: wonderful driver experience and 110 mile + range, which is fine for 99% of my days; though having another car in the household would be optimal for occasional long trips.
Seats are very comfortable, power is great, features are great..  Range is so so, unless you baby it and keep it under 55 MPH..

Initially thought I would give this car to my daughter for going back and forth to school but decided to use it as a commuter car for a while to save on gas. This car is the perfect commuter car for commutes of 50 miles a day or less. It's no race car but it's quick and keeps pace with traffic well. Handles and soaks up bumps well for it's size and comfortably carries 4 people. No plush but gives you all the options you need in the base model. Apple Car Play, heated seats, tilt telescoping wheel, auto air and push button start. With all the discounts and rebates I got mine cost $17,500. Can't beat it for a new anything plus Kia's 60/100K warranty. Best purchase I ever made.
In the first year using this car I had to replace the main board PC and the battery ranges changes from 100 miles to 80 miles

I love this car, my first Kia. I've always had Nissan and Infiniti's prior..   Easy to charge, park, decent ride, nice fit/finish, great stereo, love the heated and vented seats, heated steering wheel..
Oregon DOT placed many CHadMo sites-- make this CA originating car very well placed

My two year old K5 gets 36 on a trip and 25 in everyday use. My hybrid on a trip to Niagara Fall ON from Pittsburgh 32mpg everyday use 31. K5 very smooth drive, minimal wind noise,very quiet. Sportage road noise, I believe its the tires Goodyear Assurance,these would not be my choiceK5 separate controls for radio and ventilati. on, hybrid you must use one knob to change between the two systems. K5 auto trunk Sportage manual lift gate.K5 headlights are superior in all aspects. K5 much better sound to radio, Sportage minimal base. Sportage sterring assist very sensitive. K5 adaptive cruise, not on the Sportage EX. And the list goes on.

As a SUV the Sportage is really good and I like it very well. It outshines its competition but falls short of its heritage. In my opinion the hybrid is not worth the money. Put the K5 motor into the Sportage and wow would that be super!

Price of my K5 was $27,000 Sportage $33,000 I cannot see anything extra except its an SUV. On par with my 2021 Rogue that I traded. The Rogue got 32 on a trip easy and 25 everyday.

I really like my K5 so figured the Sportage is a Kia so lets try it. Like I said its great compared to other SUVs of that size, but does not deserve the name KIA. I also owned a Kia Forte EX and loved it! My grand daughter has a Kia Soul and thinks its a great little car. In hindsite I expected too much from a hybrid.

Would I buy again? yes but not the Hybrid and maybe move up to the next level. Just not what I expected from Kia based on past experiences.

2024 Sportage SX FWD 4cyl Wolf Gray. Owned 5 months and 3,500 miles

There is some things to like about the new Sportage, but there is one thing that I absolutely hate about it, and had the dealership been upfront about it, I'd of never bought the vehicle. And that is the 'smart' cruise control (SCC). We've had Kia's in the past with this 'upgrade', but never before have we had it and NOT been able to completely disable it, and it is the most annoying feature I have personally ever dealt with in a new car. So much so, that we will be trading it off asap. The SCC feature is SO 'smart' that it isn't smart enough to shut itself off...lol, and when using cruise control, even with it set at its lowest distance, it will STILL start hitting the brakes and slowing the car down a good 150-200 feet behind a vehicle that is in front of you. And in our world today, with our very busy highways and interstates, that just doesn't work. It is seriously the most annoying thing I have dealt with in a new car, and makes taking a long trip a very irritating experience at times. I'll drive my own car, thank you.
Our lame dealership didn't disclose this new info when we asked before buying the car, and I was dumb enough to assume that they were being upfront about it all. We tried to take it back that day...but nope, we were stuck with it. Lesson learned....the hard way.

The rest of the car is decent, but has A LOT of cheap plastic on the inside, and out. It's also nearly impossible to turn the heat or radio up (same 1/4 tall knob), without accidentally touching the 'Auto Climate' button, which then loses all your current settings, and makes you set it all back back to where you had it and liked it. Great idea. NOT. Whoever designed that jewel is less than a genius for sure. **rolls eyes** 
The ride is decent, road noise is good, u-turn radius is wayyy too big, engine response is super laggy, and you'll find yourself putting the go pedal almost to the floor at times before the car will actually GO (and then it will try and spin the tires) which can be a huge safety issue. The rear storage is plentiful, and gas mileage is pretty good (37 mpg highway, 27 mpg all around). Would I buy it again? No. Too many forced options for those of us that actually pay attention when we drive, and too many poor design issues for me.

Got the EX Hybrid w/premium package in Vesta Blue. Exterior is very cool, color is perfect for the car. Interior is comfortable, modern, well thought out, and loaded with tech. Also very spacious, hard to believe it's classified as a CUV. It rides smoothly and the pickup is perky. Quiet too. Biggest pleasant surprise is the audio quality on the factory sound system. It's better than the premium system we had on our outgoing Accord! One minor disappointment though. The outside mirrors do not fold. Our driveway is narrow and we have to do a dance each time we enter or exit the vehicle. With all the tech, some of it over the top, you would think Kia would have taken care of this basic shortcoming. Otherwise, a perfect car at this point.

Terrible vehicle! Check engine light keeps coming on. Stranded us by the side of the road when battery died and didn't kick over to hybrid. They don't have all the kinks worked out in their plug in hybrids yet. We've had it in the shop 8 times in 6 months. Last time they had it for TWO WEEKS. KIA has been rude to deal with. Buy a Honda or Toyota. Buying this car was the WORST CAR BUYING MISTAKE I've made in my life!!!!!
It’s Good for small kids not needing a large trunk space. It has great gas mileage and easy to care for.

I would recommend to a small family
Perfect size
Not good going up and down mountains regarding gas. Should have more features added base on price

Windshield washer is defective.  Sprays roof & entire side doors and windows.  Told it can't be fixed.  No one admits it is a problem.  All just say it works as designed.  No one wants to be upfront and address the problem.

I bought the 2022 Kia Sportage SX Turbo package, and I’m really liking it right now. I’ve bought more cars than you can shake a stick at, and at least half the time I’ll be feeling that buyer’s remorse or totally disinterested after the new wears off. I can honestly say, it’s not like that with this vehicle. I wasn’t a fan of Kia, and I went on a whim. I checked out a car first that was nice but i like to feel like I’m sitting down inside of a vehicle and the car just felt too high seated. Seen the Sportage and I was feeling it. It was around $10,000 more, but I decided I wanted to test drive it. With all the bells and whistles that come with this particular package, I was sold fairly easily. My 11 year old daughter likes it also. I came from a Jeep Wrangler with a 15 gln tank, so the gas mileage was great compared to what I’m accustomed. It’ll get up and go when you need it to. I looked down and had to pump the breaks because I was coming up on 100mph. It comes with 3 drive settings. Eco is what I keep it in, and I’m currently getting around 26/28 miles a gallon. Other two are Smart and Sport.
Great shape. comfortable, smooth, lots of storage. Power seats. great radio, blue tooth, WiFi, storage in all doors. Cup holders. Carpet floor marts.

I bought the car new and got all the bells and whistles.   Super comfortable and great for long trips.   My wife has a Mercedes C 300 and she usually drives the Kia.   Much better ride and just as fast.  It is a great car.

I have 75k miles on it. I live in a hot Az. This car is very much comparable to $50,000 cars in 2024 based on options, engine power and interior space. My cost so far were as following:
 Tires, one time brake pads, battery and regular oil and filters. If you want to save yourself at least  +$25k in a new comparable cars just buy a preowned   sportage sx and be assured it will last you for a long time. I have to add that i always changed oil at 5k miles and i did change brake fluid and Coolant at 60k miles prior to any warnings. Preventive maintenance is better than cure both for car health as well as your own health.

I will never purchase another KIA. I would not recommend it to nobody. Less than a year of having it, my back passenger door stopped working, my middle back seat seatbelt is stuck under the seat which has been that since it left the factory because you would have to take the back seat out to get it, my heater stopped working, my driver side window stopped working both sun vizors in the front clamps came off had to glue them back on, it has a oil leak. I take very good care of my vehicles I keep up on my maintenance. The worst part of it all is I had to purchase the vehicle at the end of the Covid outbreak when there was a shortage on vehicles, so Im paying way to much for it, and unfortunately, there weren’t too many vehicles to choose from. Now I’m stuck with a piece of junk. 😭 do not buy a Kia Sportage.

I purchased a 2020 Kia Sorento after my Subaru Crosstrek was totaled. Went for 3rd row seating over all the extras..
Well 12/21 I traded it in for a brand new 2022 Kia Sportage EX, panoramic roof, leather seats and a few more extras for a few dollars more a month. 
At 20,000 miles 21 months later, sadly I miss my basic Sorento. 
Michelin tires worn out, as well as automatic start, temp control and lock on the Kia app only free for the first year..? 
Now if I want to start my Sportage EX, I have to pay a fee of $150-$200 yearly!! No thank you.
Automatic Start can be installed in many cars for under 200$ and it’s the lifetime of the vehicle.
Oh and the gas mileage in the older Sorento was better than the Sportage, both in Eco mode..?
Why I didn’t research, well I was excited about new car, new features and knew availability was a problem in 2019-2022+
Please make sure you ask for any and all details, warranties and extra cost before jumping in, trusting I wouldn’t be misled by a lifetime family friend.

I've replaced the motor in the driver's window once. Replaced passenger window motor twice. Back window seat motors I haven't spent the $500 each on. I will never buy another Kia. Motor burns oil and these are known issues..no recall no factory repairs...

I bought this vehicle 16 months ago. I currently have 14k miles on it and it has provided all of features and benefits that Kia advertised it to have. I truly enjoy this vehicle and if you are considering a Sportage, I would recommend the older style (like mine) 2022. It is worth mentioning that other than the trailer hitch wiring, there has been ZERO recalls! This is not a top-end vehicle, such as an Audi or a Lexus, but for an "everyday" driver I feel it is a great value and my AWD model does really well in the Michigan winter!

My vehicle is cursed. Something is always
wrong. Fix one thing and three more things
go bad. Engine (not covered under warranty), vacuum pump, ecu, waste gate actuator, a/c compressor, fuel injectors, high pressure fuel pump; all out of pocket in the past 12 months alone. I'd like to drive this thing right back down to where it came from. Stay far away from Kia in general. It is impossible to get good service. The company in general is crooked. They find loop holes to get out of honoring warranty work when it comes to their flawed engine designs. A known cause of engine failure is from the rod bearings. Mine broke and I had to pay 8k for them to replace it with the same engine with the same flawed design. They put band aids on. Yes, the inside is fancy but that's how they get you. Everything is great until it isn't and ! can 100% guarantee you that one day you will end up with a case number and a good for nothing case worker from Kia America. A lemon of lemons. Can't even afford to get rid of it.

My two year old K5 gets 36 on a trip and 25 in everyday use. My hybrid on a trip to Niagara Fall ON from Pittsburgh 32mpg everyday use 31. K5 very smooth drive, minimal wind noise,very quiet. Sportage road noise, I believe its the tires Goodyear Assurance,these would not be my choiceK5 separate controls for radio and ventilati. on, hybrid you must use one knob to change between the two systems. K5 auto trunk Sportage manual lift gate.K5 headlights are superior in all aspects. K5 much better sound to radio, Sportage minimal base. Sportage sterring assist very sensitive. K5 adaptive cruise, not on the Sportage EX. And the list goes on.

As a SUV the Sportage is really good and I like it very well. It outshines its competition but falls short of its heritage. In my opinion the hybrid is not worth the money. Put the K5 motor into the Sportage and wow would that be super!

Price of my K5 was $27,000 Sportage $33,000 I cannot see anything extra except its an SUV. On par with my 2021 Rogue that I traded. The Rogue got 32 on a trip easy and 25 everyday.

I really like my K5 so figured the Sportage is a Kia so lets try it. Like I said its great compared to other SUVs of that size, but does not deserve the name KIA. I also owned a Kia Forte EX and loved it! My grand daughter has a Kia Soul and thinks its a great little car. In hindsite I expected too much from a hybrid.

Would I buy again? yes but not the Hybrid and maybe move up to the next level. Just not what I expected from Kia based on past experiences.

2024 Sportage SX FWD 4cyl Wolf Gray. Owned 5 months and 3,500 miles

There is some things to like about the new Sportage, but there is one thing that I absolutely hate about it, and had the dealership been upfront about it, I'd of never bought the vehicle. And that is the 'smart' cruise control (SCC). We've had Kia's in the past with this 'upgrade', but never before have we had it and NOT been able to completely disable it, and it is the most annoying feature I have personally ever dealt with in a new car. So much so, that we will be trading it off asap. The SCC feature is SO 'smart' that it isn't smart enough to shut itself off...lol, and when using cruise control, even with it set at its lowest distance, it will STILL start hitting the brakes and slowing the car down a good 150-200 feet behind a vehicle that is in front of you. And in our world today, with our very busy highways and interstates, that just doesn't work. It is seriously the most annoying thing I have dealt with in a new car, and makes taking a long trip a very irritating experience at times. I'll drive my own car, thank you.
Our lame dealership didn't disclose this new info when we asked before buying the car, and I was dumb enough to assume that they were being upfront about it all. We tried to take it back that day...but nope, we were stuck with it. Lesson learned....the hard way.

The rest of the car is decent, but has A LOT of cheap plastic on the inside, and out. It's also nearly impossible to turn the heat or radio up (same 1/4 tall knob), without accidentally touching the 'Auto Climate' button, which then loses all your current settings, and makes you set it all back back to where you had it and liked it. Great idea. NOT. Whoever designed that jewel is less than a genius for sure. **rolls eyes** 
The ride is decent, road noise is good, u-turn radius is wayyy too big, engine response is super laggy, and you'll find yourself putting the go pedal almost to the floor at times before the car will actually GO (and then it will try and spin the tires) which can be a huge safety issue. The rear storage is plentiful, and gas mileage is pretty good (37 mpg highway, 27 mpg all around). Would I buy it again? No. Too many forced options for those of us that actually pay attention when we drive, and too many poor design issues for me.

Got the EX Hybrid w/premium package in Vesta Blue. Exterior is very cool, color is perfect for the car. Interior is comfortable, modern, well thought out, and loaded with tech. Also very spacious, hard to believe it's classified as a CUV. It rides smoothly and the pickup is perky. Quiet too. Biggest pleasant surprise is the audio quality on the factory sound system. It's better than the premium system we had on our outgoing Accord! One minor disappointment though. The outside mirrors do not fold. Our driveway is narrow and we have to do a dance each time we enter or exit the vehicle. With all the tech, some of it over the top, you would think Kia would have taken care of this basic shortcoming. Otherwise, a perfect car at this point.

Terrible vehicle! Check engine light keeps coming on. Stranded us by the side of the road when battery died and didn't kick over to hybrid. They don't have all the kinks worked out in their plug in hybrids yet. We've had it in the shop 8 times in 6 months. Last time they had it for TWO WEEKS. KIA has been rude to deal with. Buy a Honda or Toyota. Buying this car was the WORST CAR BUYING MISTAKE I've made in my life!!!!!
It’s Good for small kids not needing a large trunk space. It has great gas mileage and easy to care for.

I would recommend to a small family
Perfect size
Not good going up and down mountains regarding gas. Should have more features added base on price

The Stinger is everything it claims to be and more. I have the chromium red gt2  and I love it! I drive from Tn to Oh with no issues to date. 1000 miles round trip. Gas mileage is as described but what do you expect? This thing is fast, quick, handles just fine for me. I don’t plan on racing at any tracks lol! Plenty of interior room. Nice leather seats. I love the black interior. I have never been stopped by more people to ask me what it is and tell me how much they love it!
I love the car. To be a family car have the speed you want and the comfort that it provides is awesome.

I own the AWD/GT2 Model in the battleship gray color, and I absolutely love this vehicle. I have owned quite a few vehicles from BMW's to Audi's and I have never had so many compliments on this vehicle.  People will come up and ask we what kind of car I have and how much they love the looks.  As for the overall vehicle itself, I think for the money, $50K, this is the best car I have owned.  It is quick, handles great, and has every option I can think of and overall, just a great car to drive. Also, I live in Colorado, and have driven this car in all kinds of snow and bad weather at it does awesome!  I truly believe this is such an under rated vehicle.    
Pros:  Looks, and engine!  
Cons:  Small gas tank.  And can't stand the Auto-off.
Amazing Car no complaints at all, very safe and powerful, economic in gas, beautiful line and aerodynamic design
Best car I've ever owned.  I say this having been a previous owner of: BMW M5, BMW M3, Audi S6, Mercedes E55 AMG.

I was introduced to the KIA line by a friend who'd researched and decided on the Niro EV;  she asked me to come and help negotiate.  My first moment in that car wowed me;  I had no idea how much fun, how powerful, how quiet, how easy it was to drive an EV.  My wife took a look on the way home and liked the looks.  
  We had both a Lexus and an Infiniti at home (which my brother gave us over the years) and enjoyed both, so put no thought into getting new, but the Niro got us going.  My wife immediately bought the up-grade EV and we both absolutely love it, especially with gas in California approaching $7!
  Then my daughter leased the Niro Hybrid;  she's got no access to electricity in her driveway.  It's not nearly so powerful, but she loves it and gets a lot of miles out of a tank.
  In the process I saw the Stinger and loved the styling and performance.  I got a call from nearby dealer he had the '22 GT1 with AWF in Ascot Green ready to go.  We saw it, drove it, and leased it immediately.  The dealer doubles the basic warranty to 200K miles, but I'm not figuring I'll reach that milestone.  I did drive my '66 Porsche to almost 325K in the last century.
  So, getting to this car.  It's great.  Great eye-catching styling, great performance.
  Let me first mention a few minor quibbles:
  -The tuning and volume knobs on the radio are small and very delicate.  Bu, I can change volume and preset stations on the steering wheel.
  -The size of the font type on the display when using Sirius is way to small to read.  My wife's Niro has much larger type for some reason.
  -I would not have chosen AWD or low-profile tires, but that was the only model available when I bought March '21.  Were I still skiing in the Sierra Nevada's I'd feel differently.
  -The steering wheel should have power adjustment for this price.
  -It's hard to pull the door closed with the handle when seated.
  -The side column is very wide and blocks vision when you actually turn your head to look to the left and back.
  -If the prior driver was smaller, you have to reach in and adjust the steering wheel manually before trying to get in and sit down.
  -However, these are not deal-killers.
  The power ratio is so good I have to warn friends that they'll get a temporary face-life when I hit the gas to merge onto the freeway.
  The overall fuel economy is 21 mpg and I do somewhat more highway than local driving.
  It's been totally reliable.  Expected service visits not too expensive.
  The color and styling are beautiful;  I stand and admire it in my garage each time I come and go.       The Ascot green is unlike any other hue.  Very classy.  The back tires are spread a little more than the front, so the flare looks really good and powerful.
  The standard radio is fine, but does battle road noise at higher speeds.
  The amount of cargo space is impressive.
  The back-seat is ample, though would be a problem to sit behind a tall person.
  The driver's seat is fully adjustable;  the passenger's manual.  The seats themselves are comfortable and form-fitting.  The angle of the headrest suits me, but not so much in the NIRO.
  I don't push my car to the limits, but I feel good ground contact and stability.  365 horses for a car about 3,600 pounds is a great ratio.  I recently test drove a Cayenne S which has 385 horses, but weighs over 5,000 pounds.
  The only other car I had considered once I researched KIA was the Genesis.  The 70 is built on the same platform with same engine as the Stinger, but is slight shorter and lighter, so performs a little more impressively, but I wanted to go for the sporty look.
  So, all in all, I'm fullly delighted that I bought the Stinger '22, especially if we have brown-outs during fire season.  I'm fully delighted that we have an EV, given the price of gas.
  All in all, can't recommend KIA enough.

Seen a few on the road and first was like a Kia , no way. So during COVID’s first few months seen no one was buying cars and there were great prices out there. Test drove Audi, BMW and then Kia. Turbo kicked in right away no lag. 0 to 60 not many cars will keep up. You want a nice car that turns head get it. It’s a fun car
Super bonne voiture excellente performance beaucoup de style et superbe option. Bonne accélération même sur la neige
I don’t have an answer… Only had it a few weeks. so far…. I LOVE it!  So comfortable and roomy … and it’s beautiful. Blue with light gray interior ♥️

I loved my 2021EX fwd Telluride. Put over 64000 miles on it. No issues. None.  Almost felt bad trading it...Traded without being in a hole for the 2024 EX awd xline. 
Love the little upgrades heated steering wheel, mirrors, etc.
Same great vehicle but better.  Quiet inside, great navigation system. Love the safety features.

I love that I can use my phone as my digital key to lock, unlock and start my car, or use the app to start my car and turn on the heater and seats. It drives great and has a ton of safety features. I love the blind spot cam that comes up when you turn the blinker on. Everywhere I go people want to check it out and are very impressed by it. And, to boot, it was very affordable. I'm looking forward to driving it for many years.

I bought a 2024 telluride from Kia Richmond,CA and within weeks it started having an engine problems. It’s in the shop as we speak. I filed a claim with Kia consumer affairs which has not been helpful. I would not recommend the telluride.

***CAUTION***
Look inside drivers door at the VIN tag that is attached to the door jamb.  If there is a maple leaf Canadian symbol this vehicle is meant (built) for Canada (all Telluride vehicles made in West Point, GA).  There is no U.S. warranty with this vehicle and most U.S. (if not all) dealers WILL NOT work on these vehicles.  They say they can't connect to them, read codes, recognize VIN... whether they can't or won't doesn't matter, you can't get this vehicle serviced.

If you were to ask me 10 years ago if I would spend 40k on a Kia I would look at you sideways. Fast forward to now and I’d take this bargain truck any day.. I feel sophisticated driving it and love the comfort/Styling! Kia did their thing on this model for sure, forget other luxury brands that cost double and look no further

Overall an excellent vehicle.  Minor annoyances are the fact that a garage door opener is only standard on the highest trim.

Digital Instrument display is a little cheap looking and not very user friendly or informative.

Other than that, it's a comfortable ride with a bunch of room.  Has built in sunshades in the rear doors which is nice to have.  USB ports everywhere even in the 3rd row.

I chose the Telluride over many other SUVs for the spacious 3rd row. I’m 6-2, and I comfortably fit in the 3rd row. The cargo area has plenty of room with the seats up or down for storage. The seats and console have a great, high-end feel. The bells and whistles, from heated and cooled seats to backup camera, built-in window shades, charging ports, customizable A/C for first and second row passengers, and sun roof make the vehicle luxurious. The Telluride was ranked highest safety rating in the mid-size SUVs, and I notice it in the collision sensor, lane assist, and minimal blind spots. If you’re looking for a smooth drive, good braking system, and nice acceleration for an SUV, then this is the vehicle for you. I bought this for camping trips with 5 friends, and it has served me well every time. I average 25mpg combining city and interstate driving.
Comfortable, great gas mileage, runs amazing and great price— best car ever!! It’s a luxury car that is not considered a luxury car. Awesome!

We upgraded from a Mitsubishi Outlander Sport and an upgrade is exactly what we got. Beautiful vehicle. Clean, uncluttered and comfortable interior.  We get excellent gas mileage. Right now Mitsy averages 33.4mpg. About a 60/40 mix highway/city. The S-AWD is amazing and standard on 2023 models. Dont listen to the haters. Our Outlander has the generic AWD system and it works great. This vehicle has an excellent warranty as well. Save yourself thousands. Buy a Mitsubishi Eclipse or Outlander Sport. We love and swear by ours.

It's a good small cross over with some nice styling. Gas mileage is ok but not the best in it's class. Horsepower is a joke  , I really wish they made it a 2.0 and gave it a little bit of a bigger turbo. Mitsubishi's AWD for the eclipse is not really it's signature AWD from the evo or others in the past which is disappointing.  The eclipse name is kinda trashed on by this SUV. Overall I like how Mitsubishi is doing with the styling . I think they really need to focus on the I interior and engine.

Previously I had a Honda CR-V that was 10 years old. I bought a 2022 Mitsubishi Eclipse Cross and was pleasantly surprised that it's gas mileage is a lot better than the CR-V. I've got as high as 34.4 mpg. I love it!
Great vehicle and very reliable. I've had the SUV for over a year and it's great to drive and travel in

I am an Audi owner.  I’ve been driving the cross for a few years.  Just sold it had to buy a Q5..wrong move.   The audi is great…but should be for twice the cost.  I’m 6’3 240.  Plenty of comfort.  Not all the bells and whistles tech wise…that’s a positive for me. Reverse camera is poor. Good to excellent mileage.  Plenty of power for suburban travel.   Took it for a 2000 mile trip last summer …it was fine…two people two dogs…someone commented about the eye sight internally…it’s not great seeing speedometer etc…but a nice vehicle…I will miss it

I bought brand new in July 2021. I have traded it in for a Chevy already. 
I am short so my seat is up very high. I can’t see the displays behind the steering wheel. The middle console is so high I felt I was in a box. 
They knew the options I wanted but they weren’t delivered. 
No auto hatch opener, big down fall. 
They did not tell me, my remote start which is in an app, will not work everywhere. It did not work at my place. 
They did not resolve this issue.  I live in the mountains where we have a lot of snow and freezing temps. 
I would never suggest this car to anybody
I’ve traded it in for an equinox.

I love my SUV great performance and excellent warranty.  Love how stylish the new design looks. Lots of the same high-end quality features as a luxury vehicle at a lesser sticker price. Some of the features come standard unless you want more with the SE or SEL Trim. Either way the new redesign Model is a beauty.

Very loud ride overall and not very roomy but gets decent mileage. Definitely a $$$ pit though. We had the car for about 6 months and the Air bag light came on, sensor needed to be replaced for a cost of $1500. We've now had it for about 16 months and A/C compressor went out. Cost to replace that is another $2060 at our local shop. Not sure that the slight savings in gas is worth the $3,560 in repair costs for less than 2 years with only 116,000 miles on it. Would not recommend this car to any one :(

I previously owned a 2015 Mirage that was reliable and great value. After 82,000 miles, it was time for an upgrade. Bought it 1/27/24. The 5 year, 60,000 mile bumber to bumber warranty and 2 year 30,000 maintenance free was a no brainer. Android Auto and backup camera a great addition. I fully expect to have this little cutie another 10 years.

I purchased a used 2017 Mirage ES with 57K mikes last year and have put 7K miles on it.  I like it so much I wish I’d spent a little more to get a newer one with more modern features like the 7” screen and cruise control.  Yes, it’s not very fast but I got used to that pretty quickly.  It’s surprisingly roomy inside for a small car, is VERY easy to drive in the city and park, and gets fantastic gas mileage.  I’ve had zero mechanical problems and don’t regret getting the CVT vice 5 speed like I thought I might.

This car isn’t for the car enthusiasts who trash it.  It’s for people who are either on a tight budget or, like me, want a second vehicle as a gas-sipping, easy to drive backup for a bigger pickup or SUV.
It was a decent vehicle great for travel when there is no snow. During the winter season it has tendancy to get stuck in large amounts of snow

My last car was a Honda Civic 2020, which got repossessed. Despite this one being a 2021 with lease total miles on it, it’s inferior in a lot of ways. I don’t care about it being “noisy” like a lot of pages are saying is a con, and I don’t notice any “slowness” to it. 

The problems lie in the size of the cup holders, the lack of a mirror for the passenger side, lack of usb plugs, lack of storage, small trunk space, and a complete lack of a light in the back. All things that my Honda Civic had.

Feels very much like a downgrade knowing that. The tick marks for how much gas is left is also digital in a tamagotchi kind of way, which feels outdated to what the Honda Civic had. My girlfriend thinks it’s a car for old people, and I buy the idea.

Bought this car used after I got my license at 21. It has held up well, and is now over 100k miles. I have had to replace the breaks and serpentine belt, as expected, because these need replaced after many miles. Car is easy on the wallet in terms of price, gas, and insurance. I also looked at new civic when I was going to get my first car, and I couldn't justify spending so much money on a Honda. After all, any car in and of itself is a luxury, which many people around the world would die for. I'm just grateful I have one, even if its cheap.

I give it a 5 out 5 as a budget car.  This car is very reliable, easy drive and has great simple features.   Most of all is very easy on the wallet when it comes to spending money on gas.  The car is comfortable.  It has enough pick up and speed for normal driving, even getting on the highway.  I set cruise control at 70mph on the turnpike and it cruises great.  People that say car is slow or cheap are probably comparing it to sports and luxury cars.  This is a budget friendly car that gets the job done.
2022 Mitsubishi Mirage steering very heavy, steering hurt my wrists. That's my first and last Mitsubishi. Other than the steering, great mileage, good little car.

Very nice car affordable and gas cheaper in oil changes. Perfect for a college student. I love the stitching with the red and then the carbon fiber on the inside and out looks really nice and the steering and handling is amazing roomy back seats. The options are really amazing to.

I agree with every owner of this vehicle model that says this car is fantastic.  The reviewers talk about hard ride, tough steering, cheap seats, small engine ,,,blah, blah.  My mirage G4 was purchased in 2017 and it rides GREAT for its class.  I never have had an issue with the car.  I tool around the mountains in NY and even this small engine and "tough" steering gives a rush around the mountain curves. If I wanted a luxury car, I would have purchased one.  The only thing that I have replaced is a set of front brakes and rotors 43,000 miles.  This is a great little car.

Don’t waste your time or money on this car. 0 I mean 0 safety features. Noisy, gutless p.o.s I was at work and they talked my husband into this car. So I’m stuck with it. Please don’t let this happen to you
Nice car. Paint good. Motor clean. Int very good. Good tires. Great gas mileage. Am FM CD player. Blu tooth.

I love this car so far. It's not overly fancy, it's a basic car that can get you from point A to point B. You really pay for what you get. I think this would be a great car for a teens first car or for someone who would prefer something small.
bad car. not much to say. i wrote a review on the hatback mirage and see that for more information.

My 2018 Mitsubishi Mirage G4 is great. It's peppier than I thought it would be after reading reviews prior to purchasing it. Sure, the engine is loud...but who cares. The fuel mileage is fantastic! Reliability is fine. Couldn't ask for more for what it costs. And people say there is "no" trunk space...I beg to differ. For a small car the trunk size is fine.

It has a lot of pep for a small car, super easy to park, easy to see out of, and it has gotten up to 46 mpg mix. I want to go on a trip to see if we can hit 50.
The main draw back is no truck space.

We have Owen’s 9 Mitsubishi vehicles. Always dependable and reliable.  Great warranty great safety. Do your homework. And if you’re not somebody that needs fancy wheels to keep up your image, then buy one of these and save yourself a lot of money. And enjoy a Mitsu. I swear by the 7 passenger ones because of the extra space

It looks good but that's where the positives on this end. This car is full of never ending issues from suspension to steering to air conditioning to informant system. Don't trust that it has a nice warranty because Mitsubishi famous response to these issues are "known issue no known repair..." Cheaply made rebadged Nissan. Cheap and faulty.

I have own 2022 model SE for 18 months now. Very economical on gas for a three  row suv in eco mode. I average 31  miles per gallon in eco mode , gas is 5$ per gallon so its a good buy  to commute to work and back far away. Lots of features for this price and size . Very nice modern design inside and out.

Everything is good.  Heating in winter needs to turned up to keep the car warm.
good acceleration and features

I never gave Mitsubishi a second thought while looking to get into an economical SUV until I ran across one of their ads. I found the new styling to be pretty slick and liked that it was slightly larger than other compact SUVs.

The highlight here is the interior, it's what sold me. It's reminiscent of a luxury brand and its materials and styling. Super happy about this.

Some say the engine is a bit underpowered, but for the average driver it feels very responsive and peppy, but do agree that at higher speeds it's a bit reluctant to get going for passing at freeway speeds.

After buying the car I had to go on the road trip for work and was very happy with the 30.7 miles per gallon I got with cruise control set around 72 miles an hour on mostly flat highway. The adaptive cruise control made my 3-hour drive easy and pleasant.
 
I was not bothered by things people complain about on the CVT transmission, though it can be a bit jerky at times unless you're smooth on the gas pedal.

Third row seat is kind of a joke, but put the seats down and you get more cargo space and that's a win for me.

Overall, I love the car. It handles great, gets decent gas mileage and feels much more luxurious than the price tag, even on my SE model. I'm a very happy first time Mitsubishi owner/driver.
3 rows seating capacity, high mile and outstanding looking gets attractions and asked about your car wherever you go, park
plenty of room has a 3rd row seat , can even fit a baby seat in center row with plenty of space and very stylished

First off I would like to state I have previously owned a few Mitsubishi cars from lancers to eclipse cross including the previous 2019 Mitsubishi Outlander. With that being said, I have a good understanding of what to expect when owning a Mitsubishi in terms of reliability, capability and build quality of their vehicles. This car already started off bad because you had less features to begin with when compared to the previous generation. This 22 was a ES and didn’t have heated seats, heated mirrors, and roof rails where my 2019 ES did. Upon further downership of the vehicle I noticed it got 1 mpg better on the highway but lacked in other areas. The AWD system has changed from the previous generation and is insufferable when actually needing to be used on any other surface but pavement. The new driving modes are there for nothing short of esthetics. 

Nissan had purchased Mitsubishi and is going to kill off their line-up just like they did for their own brand. Everything under hood is now Nissan and that’s why the quality and capability is horrendous. Recalls became a monthly task for multiple different items. 

Let’s talk about interior. The shifter is a joke. Your car can lock you out from shifting from park. Turning the vehicle on and off multiple times usually did the trick to be able to get out of park and drive the car. The infotainment system would freeze and call people at random. Multiple check engine lights for reduced performance with no real tsb to resolve the issue. 

On the exterior. The sporty body kit was put on with Elmer’s glue and side skirts can fall off at highways speeds and the hood rattles so severely it looks like it may be popped but it is not. 

My suggestion is to not buy this Nissan made Outlander and buy the true remaining Mitsubishi’s while you can which include the Outlander sport, Eclipse Cross and Mirage before Nissan destroys them as well.

2014 SE absolutely zero repairs required in 9 years. Only negative thing I can say is that the entertainment system takes 20 seconds to boot up each time you start the car. Rear windshield wiper control is buried in a sub menu that is grayed out if the car is moving.
Solid vehicle. No problems so far. Cut could be adjusted to match the engine. It revs too high before changing gears.

I've replaced brake pads once, tires twice, and of course maintained with oil changes. Thats it, no problems @ over 104k miles. Handles well and is comfortable to drive. When I originally purchased it new, I wasn't 100% convinced it was the right choice, but now after driving it the last 5 yrs I believe it was! Price was the lowest I could find for 4WD, I took a chance, and it's paid off. I'll certainly consider another Outlander for my next car purchase.
55000 miles on this vehicle. So far so good, I would buy a new one confidently. Very good value for your money.

This car is very  spacious.Its  is really great as a 3rd row seater or more  trunk room.
Will be happy with your purchase as I was.

I've owned an outlander SE 2.4 since '14. Other than routine maintenance, and a battery not much has gone wrong. Two complaints are, 1: The Harman kardon touch screen takes 15 seconds to boot up each time you start the car. 2: the black trim that runs along the outside under the door sticks out enough to get your pants dirty if the car is dirty.
I bought this car brand new in 2020 and I’ve driven a lot. She still keeps up and I haven’t had any problems.

I was asked 'why Mitsubishi?' by many of my friends. Online reviews by 'so called experts' were poor, but I gave it a chance.  Initial impulse for buying brand new Outlander was a sticker price, styling and the name is somewhat relevant from 90s.
5 years and 80 K miles later my only regret is not buying a higher trim. 
Pros reliable (never been to shop other than routine maintenance), roomy, 3rd row is perfect for kids (2 families can travel together), good gas mileage, good on snow in 4X4 mode, lots of options for the price, exterior looks, and some interior ergonomics.
Cons seats could have been more comfortable, somewhat underpowered (but with CVT at 3000 rpm acceleration is ok),  CVT (I got used to it), paint quality, steering could use more precision/agility.
But overall for $26500 brand new, reliable, 3 row, 4x4 suv that is going strong was a great deal.

We have Owen’s 9 Mitsubishi vehicles. Always dependable and reliable.  Great warranty great safety. Do your homework. And if you’re not somebody that needs fancy wheels to keep up your image, then buy one of these and save yourself a lot of money. And enjoy a Mitsu. I swear by the 7 passenger ones because of the extra space

It looks good but that's where the positives on this end. This car is full of never ending issues from suspension to steering to air conditioning to informant system. Don't trust that it has a nice warranty because Mitsubishi famous response to these issues are "known issue no known repair..." Cheaply made rebadged Nissan. Cheap and faulty.

I have own 2022 model SE for 18 months now. Very economical on gas for a three  row suv in eco mode. I average 31  miles per gallon in eco mode , gas is 5$ per gallon so its a good buy  to commute to work and back far away. Lots of features for this price and size . Very nice modern design inside and out.

Everything is good.  Heating in winter needs to turned up to keep the car warm.
good acceleration and features

The highlight here is the interior, it's what sold me. It's reminiscent of a luxury brand and its materials and styling. Super happy about this.

Some say the engine is a bit underpowered, but for the average driver it feels very responsive and peppy, but do agree that at higher speeds it's a bit reluctant to get going for passing at freeway speeds.

After buying the car I had to go on the road trip for work and was very happy with the 30.7 miles per gallon I got with cruise control set around 72 miles an hour on mostly flat highway. The adaptive cruise control made my 3-hour drive easy and pleasant.
 
I was not bothered by things people complain about on the CVT transmission, though it can be a bit jerky at times unless you're smooth on the gas pedal.

Third row seat is kind of a joke, but put the seats down and you get more cargo space and that's a win for me.

Overall, I love the car. It handles great, gets decent gas mileage and feels much more luxurious than the price tag, even on my SE model. I'm a very happy first time Mitsubishi owner/driver.
3 rows seating capacity, high mile and outstanding looking gets attractions and asked about your car wherever you go, park
plenty of room has a 3rd row seat , can even fit a baby seat in center row with plenty of space and very stylished

But overall for $26500 brand new, reliable, 3 row, 4x4 suv that is going strong was a great deal.

Made a big mistake I feel, not impressed. The body is light weight, going through a car wash soap gathers in all door jams, took it to the shop and heard excuses! Fill the tires with air and the indicator light comes on again a day or two later, the shop over filled them? No heated seat, no push start, no keyless entry, no front license bracket, the list goes on and for the price Mitsubishi dropped the ball. They won’t even give me my warranty papers?

I have this car and absolutely love it. I had a 2018 version and was in a head on collision. That car saved my life. My only injuries were from seatbelt and air bag. I felt it held up well so I wanted another outlander.

I had the non-pleasure of having this car as a rental while my 2019 Hyundai Tucson was getting accident repair. After driving this piece of plastic for 5 days now, I can say my Hyundai Tucson feels like a Mercedes G-wagon compared to this thing.  Whoever designed this “suv” and whoever thought 23k would be a great starting price has never actually used a vehicle before.

First off the bumper is made with the same plastic and feel as a gallon of milk. No joke, the wind can dent it. Secondly, the engine has the power of my push lawnmower. Good luck trying to get to 25mph especially on a hill without feeling like the engine is going to explode. 

There are literally zero features in this. You have to use a key to start the engine. It’s a 2022 vehicle. The display doesn’t show the speed you are going, like every other vehicle made since 2004. You have to use a knob to use change the volume for the radio. Max volume is barely a 2/10 on my vehicle. It has no other features that come standard in new cars, like CarPlay, lights to see the power window indicators, side view mirror warning indicators or a horn that’s so quiet it wouldn’t even wake up a cat if it was sleeping on the hood.  It handles the road as bad as ice skating for the first time. Literally the only thing this vehicle has is a color night back up camera. It must be a mistake though because there is no reason for this vehicle to have such luxury. 

If this car is was the showpiece prize at the end of The Price Is Right, I would purposely guess a negative dollar amount so I wouldn’t have the burden of having this vehicle. 

I feel bad for anyone who purchased this vehicle willingly, even if it was a free gift.

Overall it looks nice but is very cheap. The back seat rattles whenever you’re driving and now the back left window also rattles while driving both when rolled up and down. Also does not do well at all in the snow, I don’t feel safe driving it. Definitely would look at something else.

My new vehicle with 3,008 miles on it was held at the dealer for around 5 months to have the catalytic converter replaced after it was stolen 7 weeks after I had purchased it. After countless calls to the dealer and Customer relations, Mitsubishi was unable to expedite the part or help in any matter to have my vehicle repaired earlier, and basically said that it was out of theirs hands. If you plan on purchasing a Mitsubishi vehicle, keep in mind, that your vehicle may be at the dealer longer than you more reputable dealer.

Just bought the 2021 outlander, my first SUV in a long time. So far seems like a great car, I like the fact that is a compact SUV that fits great in my small garage. The motor is quiet and rides are fairly smooth, also has great air conditioning and cargo space. Inside is somehow similar to the eclipse cross, not all the way but it has some similarities. The interior seems a little simple in my model, but it has a few extras. Overall is a nice car, perfect for everyday use, errands and other things.
Very great car driving comfort  & power
I recently purchased the outlander sport limited edition ...it has great styling sporty and lots of creature comforts....some i haven't quite figured out yet ....by far the best value in its class

I bought outlander sports 6 cylinder sports 7 passenger. I was looking for more power, I pulled my RPOD trailer 3000 LBS with no problems, also filed a utility trailer and traveled around US and Mexico through the mountains. ( I tried Honda CRV and Toyota rave4 , there is no match with Mitsubishi, I like the fact it has transmission cooler, make it safer for towing a trailer. so far driven 70000 without going to a garage or mechanics. Just regular maintenance and break changes and fluid flush. The most disappointment is for the amount of money I paid I expected navigation system and apple car play or android, this is the most draw back with bad quality sound system, unless you go to GT model and pay a lot more for that little future.
I like my outlander .  But has anyone else noticed it pulls to right especially with breaking ?  Had it aligned and it jerked back .  No one has answered my question as to why.  Any information ,?
Good car.

For a SUV that's 9 years old I have no regrets in purchasing it new.  In those 9 years I've replaced the tires, battery and windshield wipers.  That's it.  When I'm driving around town I get 24 to 25 mpg, when on the interstate I get between 28 and 32mpg,.  I looked at a dozen or more SUV's for comfort and when I got into this one I know it was right.  Very comfortable seats. It may not suit everyone but it suits  me just fine.
Great vehicle to drive around is very stable too.. the car is off roading reliable and great and is perfect for family too

I got this with 15k miles and I'm at 72k now. I have not had issues with it except for some random times my phone does not connect to my radio, but turning the car off and on fixes that, and it's not common anyways.

The road noise going over 65mph is also loud. I'm guessing they did not test it for that speed because it is quite noticeable once I get on the highway and hit the gas hard.

I have the 2.4L engine and I highly recommend getting this option. The 2.0 would be too small for this car. The 2.4 gets the car zipping around no problem.

Have great performance, good price . My only only drwback are the cvs transmision and the poor protection for the catalitic. It is so expose that takes only seconds for taking out by the  outlaw people to access it easily
Car very reliable no issues take me from downtown chicago to suburbs in no time with no car issues .
